name: Beginning Ancient Greek I
desc: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I.

name: Beginning Ancient Greek II
desc: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II.

name: Intermediate Ancient Greek I
desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part I.

name: Intermediate Ancient Greek II
desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature.

name: Reading Ancient Greek: Prose
desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek prose.

name: Reading Ancient Greek: Verse
desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek verse.

name: Greek Prose
desc: Studies in history, philosophy and/or oratory. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 401.

name: Greek Verse
desc: Studies in epic, tragedy and/or comedy. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 402.

name: Studies in Ancient Greek Prose and Verse
desc: Thematic studies using both Greek prose and Greek verse. May be repeated for up to 6 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 403.

name: Made in Italy
desc: Where do Italy's glamour, lifestyle, traditions come from? This course introduces Italy's multifaceted ways of being and the cultural creations of the peninsula in their context.

name: Introduction to Italian Culture I: From the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period
desc: The shift from the Medieval to the Early Modern worldview, explored through some of the major representatives of the verbal and visual arts, from Dante to Machiavelli, from Giotto to Leonardo.

name: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age
desc: The debate around nation vs. empire vs. republic, from the Napoleonic age to our days, as captured in Italy's microcosm, condensing and often anticipating issues that have later become global.

name: Introduction to Italian Cinema
desc: A thematic course surveying major classics of Italian cinema, emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts.

name: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
desc: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.

name: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
desc: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.

name: Cultural Exchange between Modern Italy and China
desc: Key moments and texts about intercultural exchange between Italy and China since the beginning of the twentieth century in their social, historical, and political contexts.

name: Colonial and Postcolonial Italy
desc: Italian colonialism in the twentieth century and postcolonial legacy in recent decades through media, literary, and cinematic texts.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Italian Cinema
desc: Gender and sexuality in Italian cinema within the country's historical, socio-political, and cultural milieus.

name: Italian Food Cultures
desc: Analyses of Italian or Italian-style foodways and the role they play in articulating larger cultural issues.

name: Italian Cinema: Neorealism
desc: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts.

name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy in Translation
desc: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works:

name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages in Translation
desc: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITAL 404.

name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance in Translation
desc: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Precludes credit for ITAL 405.

name: Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 416 or ITAL 406.

name: Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 417 or ITAL 407.

name: Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
desc: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 408.

name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
desc: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.

name: Special Topics in Italian Studies
desc: Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

name: Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
desc: Films with English subtitles. Precludes credit for ITAL 430. Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

name: Research Intensive Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture
desc: Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 495 or ITST 495.

name: Introduction to Law and Society
desc: Ideas, concepts, and frameworks for thinking about the nature of law and legal processes in both Canadian and global contexts.

name: Against the Law
desc: Competing approaches to law and legal authority shaped by conflicts over historical and contemporary inequalities, including the exercise of and challenges to coercive law enforcement and claims made for legal redress.

name: Topics in Law and Society
desc: Interdisciplinary approaches to topics such as the purpose of law, retribution and punishment, restorative justice, ethics, property ownership, human rights, gender equality, legal change, or civil disobedience.

name: Introductory Indonesian I
desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100 or INDO 102.

name: Introductory Indonesian II
desc: Continuation of INDO 100. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 101 or INDO 102.

name: Introductory Indonesian
desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100/101 or INDO 102.

name: Intermediate Indonesian
desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201/202 or INDO 200.

name: Intermediate Indonesian I
desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201 or INDO 200.

name: Intermediate Indonesian II
desc: Continuation of INDO 201. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 202 or INDO 200.

name: Foundations of Chemistry
desc: Atomic and molecular properties, chemical reactions, bonding, nomenclature, kinetics, equilibrium processes, acids and bases, oxidation and reduction.  Intended for students who do not receive a satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test, and need to establish a foundation of chemistry skills before proceeding to other first year chemistry courses.
prer: Not open to students with credit for Chemistry 12.  Permission of the department head.

name: Structure, Bonding and Equilibrium in Chemistry (Lecture)
desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society.
prer: Not open to students with credit for Chemistry 12. A satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test.

name: Structure, Bonding, and Equilibrium in Chemistry
desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-1]
prer: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12. A satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test.

name: Introductory Chemical Laboratory I
desc: An introduction to the principles and techniques of the chemistry laboratory. [0-3-0]

name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry (Lecture)
desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society.

name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry
desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories and structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

name: Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry
desc: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

name: Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry (Lecture)
desc: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121.

name: Introductory Chemical Laboratory II
desc: An introduction to the principles and techniques of the chemistry laboratory. [0-3-0]

name: Chemistry for Engineering
desc: Chemical bonding, properties of matter. Chemical thermodynamics with applications to phase equilibria, aqueous equilibria and electrochemistry. Processes at surfaces. [3-3*-0]

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
desc: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223, CHEM 225 or CHEM 233, 235. [3-3-0]
prer: Either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 130, CHEM 135 or (c) SCIE 001.

name: Physical Chemistry
desc: Chemical kinetics and thermodynamics and spectroscopy useful in biological, medical, agricultural, earth, and related sciences. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of CHEM 130, CHEM 123, CHEM 154.

name: Coordination Chemistry
desc: Fundamental concepts and principles governing bonding and reactivity of coordination complexes: ligand field theory; symmetry and point groups; frontier molecular orbital theory.

name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis (Lecture)
desc: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis
desc: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography.
prer: Either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 130, CHEM 135 or (c) SCIE 001.

name: Organic Chemistry
desc: Spectroscopy of organic compounds.  Mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-carbon bond formation; functional group interconversion.  Preference will be given to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 233.

name: Introductory Analytical Chemical Laboratory
desc: An introduction to the principles and techniques in the analytical chemistry laboratory. [0-3-0]
prer: CHEM 210 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 135.

name: Fundamentals of Reactivity in Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Chemical reactivity of inorganic systems: oxidation/reduction chemistry; multiply-bonded systems; main group chemistry.

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry (Lecture)
desc: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. Students should consult the Credit Exclusion List for credit exclusions relating to second-year organic chemistry courses. [3-0-0]

name: Introductory Synthetic Chemical Laboratory
desc: An introduction to the principles and techniques in the synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry laboratory. [0-3-0]

name: Organic Chemistry for the Biological Sciences
desc: Reactions and properties of carbonyl compounds, carbohydrates, amino acids, nucleic acids. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 233 or CHEM 203 or CHEM 223. [3-0-0]

name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
desc: Techniques of organic chemistry. To be taken in conjunction with, or in the term following, CHEM 233. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 235 or CHEM 203. [0-3-0]

name: Intermediate Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory
desc: Techniques in synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) all of CHEM 223, CHEM 225 or (c) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 235.

name: Inorganic Chemistry for Engineers
desc: Chemistry of selected groups of inorganic compounds, considered in relation to industrial processes. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

name: Physical Chemistry for Engineers
desc: States of matter, properties of gases, phase diagrams. Elementary chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Reaction equilibria. [3-0-1]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

name: Organic Chemistry for Engineers
desc: A description of the properties and reactions of organic compounds. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

name: Communicating Chemistry
desc: Effective argumentation and communication skills in chemistry. Only open to students in a Chemistry specialization.

name: Aqueous Environmental Chemistry
desc: Properties of natural waters, including gas and solid equilibria, pH, redox, complexation analysis, corrosion treatment, ion exchange, colloids and microbial transformations. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 220 and Third year standing.

name: Atmospheric Environmental Chemistry
desc: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHBE 220 and Third year standing.

name: Fundamentals of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
desc: Principles of chemical thermodynamics; introduction to statistical mechanics; phase equilibria; electrochemistry. [3-0-1]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Biophysical Chemistry
desc: Diffusion and transport phenomena; interaction of radiation and matter. Methods for determining molecular weight, size, and shape of molecules in solution. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and either (a) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 205 or (b) CHEM 304 or (c) PHYS 203.

name: Instrumental Analytical Chemistry
desc: Theory, design, and application of instrumental methods of chemical analysis including spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electroanalysis, and chemical separations.. [3-0-1]

name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
desc: Principles of quantum mechanics; atomic wavefunctions; angular momentum; spin; atomic term symbols. [3-0-1]
prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
desc: Chemistry of organic substances having particular relevance to the life sciences. [3-0-0]

name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory I
desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]
prer: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 208, CHEM 211, CHEM 215, CHEM 225, CHEM 235.

name: Principles of Catalysis
desc: Fundamental aspects of chemical catalysis: kinetic models; catalytic processes in biochemistry and industry; emerging topics in catalysis.

name: Practical Skills for Chemical Research
desc: The nature of scientific research; practical skills for chemical research; communicating science.  Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory I
desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry specializations. [0-8-0]
prer: One of CHEM 211, CHEM 215 and all of CHEM 208, CHEM 213, CHEM 245.

name: Introduction to Materials Chemistry
desc: Basic principles of materials chemistry: classification; nomenclature; synthetic methods; characterization.
prer: One of CHEM 208, CHEM 250 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

name: Research Ethics and Data Analysis Skills
desc: Research ethics; data analysis skills for chemical research. Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
desc: Application of carbonyl group chemistry, cyclization reactions, conformational analysis and rearrangement reactions in organic synthesis. [3-0-0]

name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory II
desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]

name: Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
desc: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory II
desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.   Open only to students in Chemistry Major or Honours specializations. [0-8-0]

name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory
desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry for students in Combined Major in Science or a Minor in Chemistry integrating experiments from organic, inorganic, physical and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Principles of Spectroscopy
desc: Rotational, vibrational, electronic and magnetic resonance spectroscopy and associated techniques; group theory. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

name: Diffraction Methods
desc: Crystal structures; point and space groups; X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction, electron diffraction of gases and surfaces. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 402 or CHEM 514. [3-0-0]

name: Surface Chemistry and Surface Analysis
desc: Surfaces and phenomena occurring at surfaces and interfaces: adsorption, thermodynamic treatments, technological applications. Methods for characterization and modification of surfaces. Dynamic electrochemistry and its application to understanding fuel cells. [3-0-0]
prer: CHEM 304 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Computational Chemistry
desc: Application of numerical techniques to study chemical systems; molecular simulation. Prior computer programming experience is not required.
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and Third-year standing.

name: Biophysical Chemistry
desc: Interactions of macromolecules in solution: ligand, antibody and ion binding to macromolecules; thermodynamics of polymer solutions; excluded volume effects; phase separation; partition in two phase polymer solutions. [3-0-0]

name: Polymer Chemistry
desc: Structure and availability of monomers; Propagation mechanisms; synthesis of polymers with predetermined properties; measurement and interpretation of physical properties of polymers. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 213, CHEM 260 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 304, CHBE 220.

name: Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
desc: Introductory concepts of statistical mechanics and statistical thermodynamics. Applications to chemistry with emphasis on understanding chemical reactivity. Credit will be granted  for only one of CHEM 503/CHEM 407 or PHYS 455. [3-0-0]

name: Chemical Dynamics
desc: Macroscopic and microscopic kinetics; photochemistry; theory of reaction rates; reaction cross sections, energy distributions, experimental methods. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 408 or CHEM 508. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

name: Properties of Materials
desc: Electromagnetic, optical, thermal and mechanical properties, and chemical reactivity of solids; electrons in periodic systems: bands, zones; excitations: excitons, phonons, plasmons, polaritons; crystalline order and disorder; ionic conductivity. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 410 or CHEM 502. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

name: Synthesis and Chemistry of Natural Products
desc: Methods and tactics for the synthesis of biologically active natural products and analogs, particularly alkaloids, polyketides, steroids and terpenes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 411 or CHEM 566. [3-0-0]

name: Electronic Structure of Atoms and Molecules
desc: Introduction to variational methods; many-electron systems; semi-empirical methods; perturbation theory; computational methods. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 312, PHYS 304 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Bioorganic Chemistry
desc: Enzyme catalysis; mechanistic enzymology; chemistry of cofactors; biosynthetic transformations; natural product biosynthesis; topics in chemical biology. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 413, CHEM 569, or BIOC 403. [3-0-0]

name: Coordination Chemistry of the Transition Elements
desc: Molecular and electronic structures and reactivities of coordination compounds of the transition elements. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 414 or CHEM 525. [3-0-0]

name: Physical and Theoretical Organic Chemistry
desc: Energetics and catalysis in organic reactions. Pericyclic reactions. Substituent effects. Linear free energy relationships. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 416 or CHEM 563. [3-0-0]

name: Nuclear Chemistry and Radiochemistry
desc: Basic treatment of the nucleus, with analogy to concepts in chemistry. Nuclear stabilities and associated radioactive decay processes. Nuclear structure. Applications of radioisotopes in chemistry. The interaction of radiation with matter. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130 and Third year standing. CHEM 312 is recommended.

name: Organometallic Chemistry
desc: The chemistry of compounds containing organic groups directly bonded to metals and metalloids. Emphasis will be placed on the structure and bonding of the compounds and their use in synthetic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 418 or CHEM 524. [3-0-0]

name: Establishing a Career in Chemical Research
desc: Current research and career perspectives in chemistry.  Restricted to Honours students with fourth year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory fourth year standing.

name: Applications of Materials Chemistry
desc: Contemporary materials chemistry, including design and synthesis of materials for energy, electronics, and health applications. [3-0-0]

name: Developments in Contemporary Chemistry
desc: A review of modern developments in general chemistry for teachers of Secondary School chemistry (Not for credit in the Faculty of Science). Course is offered periodically in extra-sessional sessions.

name: Principles of Chemical Separation
desc: Unified theory of separation science; liquid and gas chromatography; capillary electrophoresis; electrochemical and spectroscopic detection; separation methods coupled with mass spectrometry and tandem mass spectrometry; biochemical applications. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 434 or CHEM 534. [3-0-0]

name: Bio-Inorganic Chemistry
desc: A discussion of the involvement of inorganic chemistry in biological systems. Chemistry of cations, metalloenzymes, and simpler model systems. Reactions of coordinated ligands, chemistry of sulfur and phosphorus. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 435 or CHEM 526. [3-0-0]

name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry
desc: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting. [0-8-0]
prer: One of CHEM 345, CHEM 335. Students satisfying the prerequisite requirement using CHEM 335 must have fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.

name: Directed Studies in Chemistry
desc: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

name: Seminar and Thesis
desc: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Weekly seminar. Required of all Honours students. Open to Majors students with a satisfactory standing and permission of the department head.

name: Organic Synthesis: A Mechanistic Approach
desc: Presentation, mechanistic discussion and analysis of modern synthetic methods using principles of physical organic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 460 or CHEM 560. [3-0-0]

name: Synthetic Chemical Biology
desc: Synthetic, mechanistic, and biochemical approaches to chemical biology, including the design of drugs, probes, and catalysts. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 461 or CHEM 561.

name: Structure Determination and Reaction Analysis
desc: Application of mass spectrometry and modern spectroscopic techniques, including multidimensional NMR spectroscopy, to reaction analysis and detailed characterization of complex organic and organometallic molecular structures. [3-0-0]
prer: CHEM 245 and one of CHEM 313, CHEM 318, CHEM 330.

name: Topics in Chemistry
desc: Selected topics in a specific area of Chemistry. May be taken more than once for credit with permission of the Department. [3-0-0]
prer: Third-year standing in a Chemistry specialization and permission of the Department.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the fall term of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
desc: An overview of the culture and society of Latin America from ancient to contemporary times and from Argentina to Mexico.

name: Popular Culture in Latin America
desc: The culture of everyday life, both rural and urban: issues of identity, popular memory, resistance, negotiation, as expressed through ritual, crafts, the body, social movements, films, music, and literature.

name: Issues of Development in Modern Latin America
desc: Theory of development in the Latin American context: current problems and development alternatives.

name: Human and Civil Rights in Latin America
desc: Focuses on human rights movements; state violence and impunity; reform of criminal justice systems; rights of indigenous peoples, women, and minorities; international protection of human rights; the UN and inter-American systems.

name: Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
desc: Ethnohistory and contemporary cultures of the indigenous peoples of Mexico, Middle America, and South America. Different cultural areas or regions may be selected to illustrate the course's principal themes.

name: Introduction to Instrument Design
desc: Practice in engineering design and instrument development including mechanical and electrical design, and communications with sensors, actuators. Micro-controller implementation and system integration. Engineering design review process and presentations. Engineering communication in design and product release. [3-6-0]

name: Heat and Thermodynamics
desc: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter; heat transfer by conduction; convection and radiation; kinetic theory of gases and gas laws; heat engines; refrigeration; change of state; first and second laws of thermodynamics. [1-3-1]
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 254, MATH 255;  and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

name: Experimental Techniques
desc: Basic experimental techniques in acquisition, analysis, and presentation and communication of data and technical results. [2-3-0]
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150 and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

name: Mechanics II
desc: Dynamics: systems of particles, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies (plane motion), energy and momentum, rotating coordinates. [2-0-1]

name: Laboratory Techniques in Physics
desc: Some of the experiments will be based on the lecture material for PHYS 301. Other techniques and subjects will also be covered. [0-3-0]

name: Engineering Physics Project I
desc: Engineering project planning, execution and reporting. The course involves carrying out an open-ended Engineering project to meet specific performance metrics on an industry relevant topic selected by instructors. Reporting on progress is both oral and written.

name: Engineering Physics Project II
desc: Project planning, management and reporting. This course involves writing a project proposal, carrying out an open-ended Engineering project, and reporting the results both orally and in writing.

name: Engineering Physics Project III
desc: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry.

name: Engineering Physics Project IV
desc: An optional course for those students wishing to continue their project work beyond the development in ENPH 479.

name: Entrepreneurial Projects I
desc: A project course for students pursuing entrepreneurial training within Engineering Physics, and wishing to further develop projects resulting from ENPH 459.

name: Directed Studies
desc: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS.

name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. It is expected that the course will generally be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. This course will be of a specialized nature and at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

name: Marine Invertebrate Zoology
desc: A survey of the marine phyla, with emphasis on the benthic fauna in the vicinity of the Marine Station. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

name: Comparative Invertebrate Embryology
desc: A comprehensive study of development of marine invertebrates available at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre, including all major phyla and most of the minor phyla.

name: Biology of Fishes
desc: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast.
prer: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy.

name: Structure and Function in Marine Animals
desc: Principles of classification, evolution, morphology, biomechanics, physiology and biochemistry will be illustrated in representatives from a variety of animal phyla. [3-3-0]
prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

name: Marine Phycology
desc: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms in the vicinity of the Marine Centre. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

name: Ecological Adaptations of Seaweeds
desc: Morphological, physiological, genetic and reproductive adaptations of seaweeds to their environments. [3-3-0]
prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

name: Marine Ecology
desc: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities are provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas, and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Marine Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.

name: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
desc: An introduction to the biology of oceans, with supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on plankton biology, community structure and life histories, and influencing environmental factors. Collections will be made from sheltered inlets, through Barkely Sound to offshore waters. The course will involve both field and laboratory.

name: Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
desc: Emphasis on interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physiochemical environment, and on biological diversity. [3-3-0]
prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

name: Biology of Marine Birds
desc: Study of interrelationship of birds and the marine environment. Census techniques and observation of birds in the field will be emphasized.
prer: Completion of a course in vertebrate zoology or permission of the instructor.

name: Biology of Marine Mammals
desc: Survey course covering systematics and distribution of marine mammals, their sensory capabilities and physiology, with special emphasis on the Cetacea. The course will involve an independent field study.

name: Seminars and Papers in Marine Science
desc: Instruction in the critical analysis of published research papers and of oral seminars. [2-2-0]
prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

name: Introduction to Politics
desc: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

name: The Government of Canada
desc: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

name: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
desc: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
desc: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

name: Currents of Political Thought
desc: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

name: Introduction to Global Politics
desc: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.
prer: Recommended for prospective students of POLI 360-373.

name: Canadian Political Parties
desc: The organization and operation of party politics and the systems of party competition in Canada. The focus is on national-level politics.

name: Public Administration
desc: The structure and organization of the administrative branch of government in theory and practice. Administrative powers and policy-making in the modern state. Examples of the administrative processes are drawn from Canada and other countries.

name: Federalism in Canada
desc: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

name: British Columbia Government and Politics
desc: An examination of the party system, and other institutions and processes of the British Columbia political system.

name: Canadian Political Ideas
desc: Political theories and ideologies in Canada.

name: Local Government and Politics in Canada
desc: Local and regional political institutions and processes in Canada, with particular attention to those of Vancouver and other British Columbia localities.

name: Quebec Government and Politics
desc: The nature of politics and the conduct of government in contemporary Quebec. The course is open to students from fields other than political science.

name: Issues in Canadian Politics
desc: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
desc: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Parliament and Party: The Strategy of Politics
desc: Parliamentary and party politics, showing how politicians in Canada and other countries strike bargains with allies, outmanoeuvre opponents in debates, and manipulate institutional rules.

name: Global Indigenous Politics
desc: The political dynamics of Indigenous peoples' politics on the global level; the legal and practical realities of colonization as a global Indigenous experience; current global Indigenous political issues and avenues of Indigenous resistance.

name: Government and Politics of the United States of America
desc: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

name: Chinese Politics and Development
desc: The course will explore various aspects of Chinese politics and the dynamics of China's development since 1949.  Topics include: the Cultural Revolution, political reform and protest, and economic reform policies and their consequences.

name: Japanese Government and Politics
desc: A general introduction to modern Japanese politics from various theoretical and comparative perspectives.

name: South Asian Government and Politics
desc: Comparative analysis of politics and government in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. Imperial legacies and nationalist movements; political institution-building amidst socio-cultural diversity; parties and interest groups; elections and leadership crises; military intervention; ethnic and class conflicts; foreign policy.

name: Southeast Asian Government and Politics
desc: The political systems of contemporary Southeast Asia.

name: Communist and Post-Communist Politics
desc: An examination of the origins, development, and demise of Communist political systems, as well as the nature of post-Communist politics, with special emphasis on the Soviet Union and its successor states.

name: European Politics: Selected Cases
desc: The politics and government of one or more European countries: political development, institutional structure, party politics, and policy-making. The specific country or countries will vary by section.

name: European Integration
desc: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

name: Topics in Comparative Politics
desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Gender and Politics
desc: Relations between gender and political processes and institutions, including the impact of globalization and economic development.

name: Japanese Political Economy
desc: Issues in contemporary Japanese political economy, including industrial policy, the Keiretsu groupings, the main-bank system, trends toward deregulation, and business-labour relations.

name: Korean Government and Politics
desc: An introduction to the politics of Korea. The evolution of Korean politics from authoritarian rule to democratic transition, focusing on present and future political, economic and social issues.

name: Politics and Government of Latin America
desc: A comparative examination of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America: populism, corporatism, bureaucratic authoritarianism, transitions from authoritarianism, and contemporary debates on the quality and diversity of democratic institutions.

name: Issues in Comparative Politics
desc: An examination of a major issue in comparative politics (e.g., the media, gender, nationalism, ethnic conflict). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Comparative Democratization
desc: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization.

name: Comparative Federalism
desc: An empirical and normative analysis of federalism as a way of structuring political life in industrialized democracies, investigating explanations for the design, persistence and operation of federal systems.

name: Associations and the State in Comparative Perspective
desc: How organised groups (civil society organizations, NGOs, interest groups) interact with governments in a variety of countries.

name: The U.S. Presidency in Comparative Perspective
desc: Executive leadership of the U.S. presidency in comparison to the leadership of other Anglo-American systems, including the U.K., Canada, and Australia.

name: Politics and Development
desc: The relationship between political institutions and economic growth. How governments shape economic policy and development aid.

name: History of Political Ideas
desc: An introduction to the political ideas of leading political philosophers from Ancient Greece to the 19th century.

name: Contemporary Political Theory
desc: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

name: Modern Political Theory: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
desc: A detailed examination of an acknowledged masterpiece of modern political theory. The text and attendant literature vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Theories of State and Society
desc: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Toqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources.

name: Social and Political Thought
desc: An examination of some of the major concepts in political philosophy such as justice, equality, rights, obligation, liberty in the context of both classical and contemporary political thought.

name: Gender and Politics: Political Thought and Practice
desc: The role of gender in Western political theory and the implications for the practice of politics.

name: Democratic Theory
desc: An examination of both classical and contemporary theories of democracy. Representative democratic theory, participatory democratic theory, and their relationship to twentieth century concepts of democracy.

name: Law and Political Theory
desc: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

name: Political Theory and Public Policy
desc: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum.

name: Public Policy
desc: An introduction to public policy: rationales for government intervention, the influence of interest groups and political institutions on policy outcomes, and the various stages in the policy process.

name: Environmental Politics and Policy
desc: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

name: Comparative Politics of Public Policy
desc: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

name: Security Studies
desc: The contemporary international security context: reorientation of the study of security, patterns of inter- and intrastate conflict and communal violence, dilemmas of international response and conflict management.

name: International Violence and Its Control
desc: A study of the nature of international violence from guerrilla to nuclear war; a survey of theories of the causes of interstate war; recent research findings on the causes of war and conditions for peace; a comparative analysis of strategies for controlling violence through disarmament and the promotion of alternative means of conflict resolution.

name: The Great Powers and International Politics
desc: An examination of the changing nature of Great Power relations, including procedures and institutions for managing their conflicts, in the pre-Cold War, Cold War, and post-Cold War international systems.

name: Canadian Foreign Policy
desc: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

name: International Organizations
desc: Analysis of the activities and influence of modern international organizations in international security, economic, and social issue areas. The course will focus on organizations associated with the United Nations, but other world and regional bodies will be analysed as well.

name: Asian International Relations
desc: Analysis of the foreign policies of one or more of the states of East, Southeast, and South Asia; their relations with other states in the region as well as with major outside powers.

name: International Political Economy
desc: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

name: International Relations Theory and the International System
desc: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.

name: Japan's Foreign Relations
desc: Japan's security policy, aid policy, relations with the United States and with neighbouring Asian nations, role in the United Nations and other international institutions.

name: Issues in International Security
desc: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Issues in International Conflict Management
desc: Problems of managing conflict in the international system (e.g., intervention, mediation, sanctions). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Humanitarian Engineering: Politics and Practice
desc: An interdisciplinary study of best practice, politics, and ethics associated with technical solutions to humanitarian assistance within Canada and abroad; examines policies used in aid and development contexts with emphasis on the application of engineering.
prer: Restricted to students with a Major, Combined Major, Honours, Honours with, or Minor specialization in Political Science or International Relations, or at least 3rd year standing in any BASc program.

name: Multinational Corporations and Globalization
desc: Multinational corporations and the state in the contemporary international system, including the impact of multinationals and foreign direct investment on governments, societies, and industry.
prer: Third year standing. Previous completion of an introductory course in international relations (e.g. POLI 260 or its equivalent) is very strongly recommended.

name: Ethics in World Politics
desc: When is it right to wage war?  Who should pay for global warming?  Should the wealthy provide foreign aid- how much?  Analysis of traditions of moral thought to reach reasoned judgments about such dilemmas in global politics.

name: International Peacekeeping
desc: The development of peacekeeping within and outside the United Nations system and as an instrument of conflict management.

name: Global Environmental Politics
desc: Ecological consequences of the global political economy.

name: International Law
desc: The nature, sources, and sanctions of international law; the notion of nationhood with particular reference to the status of the British Dominions; territorial and extra-territorial jurisdiction; diplomatic and sovereign immunities; international delinquency; treaties; settlement of disputes; international organizations. This course  may not be taken for credit in both Arts and Law.

name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
desc: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
prer: Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program

name: The Politics of Terrorism
desc: Exploration of contemporary terrorism as a contested area of understanding and as a social construct.  Includes origins and motives, evolution of terrorist groups, strategies and tactics, and anti-terrorism and counter-terrorism responses.

name: China in World Politics
desc: Impact and implications of the rise of China in historical and contemporary perspective.
prer: Third year standing. Previous coursework on international relations or POLI 321 are recommended.

name: Quantitative Methods in Political Science
desc: An introduction to quantitative methods as utilized in the study of Political Science. Not available for credit in the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Topics in Quantitative Analysis
desc: Application of quantitative techniques to selected topics in Political Science. Topics vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Public Opinion and Elections
desc: Psychological and social foundations of public opinion; quality of democratic decision-making; how voters make up their minds; impact of electoral systems; social bases of party systems; campaigns and the mass media. The Canadian experience in comparative context.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

name: Canadian Provincial and Regional Politics
desc: Seminar examines political parties, processes, and institutions in the provincial political systems and regional arrangements between provinces.
prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution
desc: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: The Political Economy of Canada
desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the interplay of economic and social factors in the shaping of Canadian politics: the major issues and strains in the functioning of the Canadian polity.
prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Public Policy and Its Administration
desc: Political and administrative aspects of public policy, particularly in Canada.
prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308, POLI 350, POLI 351, POLI 352.

name: Topics in Canadian Politics
desc: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Politics
desc: Seminar in political structures, activities, and demands of aboriginal peoples; policies of federal, provincial, and territorial governments; relations between these governments and aboriginal peoples; role of the courts and the Constitution.
prer: POLI 101 and at least 3 credits from POLI 301–308.

name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics
desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics: Non-Western
desc: A seminar devoted to comparative analysis of politics in non-western states. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics
desc: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Issues in Comparative Politics
desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of constitutionalism, authoritarianism, democracy, etc. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Ethics in Democratic Politics
desc: Ethics in politics, including citizenship and public service, and practices demanded by the institutions of democracy.

name: Seminar on Comparative Parties and Party Systems
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Issues in Chinese Politics and Development
desc: Seminar examines one issue in Chinese politics (e.g., environmental politics, local government, state-society relations) from a broadly comparative perspective.

name: Comparative Public Management
desc: Major changes in the structures and processes of government in advanced democracies, including the welfare state, citizenship, ethics, accountability, and institutional reform.
prer: Restricted to Major/Honour POLI or Combined Major with POLI.

name: Seminar in Issues in Gender and Politics
prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 345, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Politics and Economic Growth
desc: The relationship between politics, economics, and development. The role of the state, political institutions, economic policy, and foreign aid in development strategies.

name: Contemporary Political Theory
desc: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

name: Interpretation and Criticism in Political Theory
desc: Approaches to political criticism: Critical Theory, Foucauldian genealogy, critical realism, and feminism, including forms of domination, which shape people's beliefs and self-conceptions.

name: Contemporary Political Theorists: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
desc: This seminar examines in detail the political ideas of an important political philosopher of the twentieth century. The theorist studied varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Modern Western Political Thought
desc: Seminar: Texts in the history of modern Western political thought, such as works by Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Karl Marx, Alexis de Tocqueville, John Stuart Mill, Friedrich Nietzsche, Max Weber, and Sigmund Freud.

name: Critical Theory: Policitical Theory and the Problems of Race
desc: Traditions of critical social theory, broadly construed, to examine the modern politics of 'race,' racism, and racialized identities.

name: Multiculturalism and Identity Politics
desc: Seminar will examines how "identity" is theorized in contemporary political thought, beginning with the role that identity plays in the "western" canon and proceeding to examine feminist, multicultural, queer, and post-colonial theories of citizenship along with their critics.

name: Democratic Theory
desc: Overview of traditional democratic theory with close readings of several contemporary theories, such as those of Habermas, Rawls, and Arendt. Readings are drawn from complete original texts, and assessment is based on a research essay.

name: Policy Analysis
desc: Practical skills for generating written and oral analysis for a client or supervisor.
prer: Either (a) POLI 101 and one of POLI 302, POLI 306, POLI 350;  or (b) all of POLI 350, POLI 352.

name: Foreign Policy Analysis
desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

name: Peace and Conflict Studies
desc: A seminar on a selected topic concerning the causes of war and strategies for the promotion of peace. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

name: International Relations Theory
desc: This seminar examines some of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

name: International Interdependence
desc: This seminar analyses issues relating to the politics of international economic relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the brochure issued by the Department.
prer: One of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370, POLI 375. 6 credits of ECON are recommended.

name: Problems in International Relations
desc: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: The Politics of International Law
desc: Seminar on the origins and politics of international law, and its impact on international affairs; the laws of war, human rights, environment, law of the sea, and international criminal law.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

name: Introduction to Canada
desc: Approaches to the study of Canada from an interdisciplinary perspective, including cultural, political, historical, and economic dimensions.

name: Canadian Studies
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

name: Senior Seminar in Canadian Studies
desc: The Canadian experience from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Offered by the McLean Chair in Canadian Studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

name: Soil and the Global Environment
desc: Soil as the base of the Earth's ecosystem pyramid. The interconnection between soil, climate change and human activity, the carbon cycle, water resources, food security, food safety, and biofuel production. Strategies for sustaining soil resources.

name: Introduction to Soil Science
desc: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised. [3-2]

name: Vascular Plants
desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology. [3-3]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 7 credits of first-year biology.

name: Introduction to Horticulture
desc: The cultivation of key temperate fruits, vegetables, greenhouse, ornamental and nursery crops in BC, integrated with scientific and practical aspects of their sustainable production and marketing.

name: Biotechnology in Agricultural Food Production
desc: Genetics, genomics, and biotechnology concepts with applications to agricultural food production and food safety. [3-3]

name: Atmospheric Environments
desc: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates from the scale of plants and animals to the globe. Daily weather systems and climate change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 200, GEOB 204 or APBI 244.

name: Agroecology I: Introduction to principles and techniques
desc: Biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems.

name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
desc: Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Students who already present credit for APBI 260 are not permitted to receive credit for APBI 265. [1-3-0]

name: Introductory Topics in Applied Biology
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates.
prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. And 3rd year standing.

name: Reproductive and Digestive Physiology
desc: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
prer: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 260. 3rd year standing.

name: Animals and Society
desc: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

name: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
desc: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, or AANB 515. [1-0-3]
prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

name: Equine Biology, Health and Welfare
desc: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour. [3-0]

name: Welfare and Ethics of using Animals in Science
desc: Historical and current debate, ethical perspectives, governance, and scientific understanding of experiences of animals in research.

name: Applied Plant Breeding
desc: Small-scale classical (i.e., non-biotechnological) plant breeding. Hands-on, application-oriented approach to techniques and procedures for managing seed inventories, designing and implementing a simple plant breeding program, and evaluating the impact of selection on breeding populations and desired outcomes.

name: Aquaculture and the Environment
desc: Interactions between aquaculture and the environment. Current issues, comparison of systems, species, production methods, environments, and socioeconomics.
prer: One of BIOL 230, APBI 260, APBI 265, CONS 330, ENVR 200, ENVR 300 and third year standing. Or permission of the instructor.

name: Horticultural Techniques
desc: Horticulture theory and methodology in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, canopy management, cultivation media, horticultural systems examined in the context of integrated crop management.

name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

name: Introductory Plant Pathology
desc: Study of the ecology of plant pathogenic organisms; principles of disease development and control. [3-1-0]

name: Introduction to Entomology
desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations. [2-3-0]

name: Weed Science
desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventive, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

name: Soil Biology
desc: The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

name: Plant Physiology
desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. [3-3-0]
prer: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. CHEM 233 is recommended.

name: Agroecology II: Application and analysis
desc: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems.

name: Key Indicators of Agroecosystem Sustainability
desc: A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems. [1-0-3]

name: Summer Practicum in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
desc: Based at the UBC Farm. Application required. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
prer: One of APBI 260, APBI 265 and third-year standing.

name: Research Methods in Applied Biology
desc: Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
prer: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program or permission of the instructor.

name: Soil Processes
desc: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes. [3-0-0]

name: Sustainable Soil Management
desc: Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. [1-0-3]

name: Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
desc: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. [1-3-0]

name: Applied Animal Health and Physiology
desc: Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

name: Reproductive Physiology and Technology
desc: A comparative overview of reproductive physiology and reproductive technologies in domesticated and laboratory animals. [3-2-0]
prer: BIOL 201. Third year standing or higher.

name: Belowground Ecosystems
desc: Concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 512 or APBI 412. [3-0-0]
prer: Fourth year standing in a Bachelor of Science Program. Permission is required for registration.

name: Stress and Coping in Animals
desc: Understanding, assessing, and managing stress in farm, companion, captive wildlife, and research animals: sources of stress; behavioural, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses; effects on growth, reproduction, health.
prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and courses in animal physiology and animal behavior recommended.

name: Animals and Global Issues
desc: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals. [3-0-0]

name: Applied Animal Behaviour
desc: Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict. [3-0-0]

name: Compassionate Conservation
desc: Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 330 recommended.

name: Production and Postharvest Physiology of Vegetable Crops
desc: Morphology, growth and development, production, compostition, quality, and postharvest physiology of vegetable crops. [3-2-0]

name: Intensive Fish Production
desc: Management of fin fish throughout the life cycle; broodstock, egg, larvae, and juvenile. Control of environmental factors, including pathogens, for maximum productivity at all life stages. [3-2-0]
prer: Third-year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 recommended.

name: Fish Health
desc: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
prer: Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and  APBI 418 strongly recommended.

name: Ecological Restoration
desc: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
prer: APBI 200 and one of FRST 201, APBI 260, BIOL 230.

name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

name: Insect Ecology
desc: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of BIOL 327, APBI 327.

name: Integrated Pest Management
desc: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops. [3-2]

name: Plant Genomics
desc: Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology. [3-0-0]

name: Wine Grape and Berry Biology
desc: Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442, APBI 443, or PLNT 542.
prer: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, APBI 210, BIOL 210.

name: Field Study of Wine Grape Production
desc: Lectures, field trips, laboratory sessions focused on major issues related to grape and wine production. Origin of grape varieties and rootstocks, morphological features of the grapevine, training systems, canopy management strategies, berry composition, the impact of terroir on wine quality. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 542, APBI 442 OR APBI 443.
prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 121. And one 200-level BIOL course.

name: Agroforestry
desc: An introduction to the application of knowledge and principles of agroecology and forest ecology to global agroforestry systems. The course includes a one-weekend field trip that requires a supplemental fee. [1-0-3]
prer: An undergraduate course in ecology or equivalent.

name: Agroecology III: Synthesis and evaluation
desc: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability in food producing agroecosystems; emphasis on ecological similarities between natural ecosystems and managed  agroecosystems.

name: Applied Agroecology
desc: Analysis and solution of problems in agricultural production systems through the integration and application of agroecological knowledge and principles. [1-0-3]

name: Conservation Agriculture and Biodiversity Monitoring
desc: Biodiversity indicators and basic monitoring methods. Sources of agroecosystem biodiversity, including plants, insects, soil invertebrates, and vertebrates. Proficiency in using techniques to measure key abiotic factors in the field.
prer: One of BIOL 300, GEOG 374, FRST 231, LFS  252. APBI 260 recommended

name: Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
desc: Integrates classroom and applied learning at the UBC Farm with design project. [1-3-0]

name: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

name: Human Wildlife Conflict
desc: Evaluation of the impacts of human wildlife conflicts on wildlife populations; application of innovative methods to reduce human wildlife conflicts. [2-0-1]
prer: Third-year standing or higher. BIOL 230 or FRST 395 and APBI 315 or APBI 416 recommended.

name: Applied Animal Biology Practicum
desc: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

name: Undergraduate Essay
desc: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program advisor is required.

name: Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
prer: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

name: Family Context of Human Development
desc: The influence of family dynamics and social conditions on human development.

name: Family Resource Management
desc: Conceptual models of resource management as related to families.

name: Parent-child Relationships
desc: Parent-child interaction over the life span.

name: Relationship Development
desc: The study of the development, course, and decline of personal relationships.
prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

name: Human Sexuality
desc: An examination of human sexual development and behaviour.
prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

name: Social Context of Child Development
desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

name: Special Oral Care in the Community
desc: Provision of special oral health services in community settings.
prer: All of DHYG 405, DHYG 435. Prerequisites may be waived for non-program dental hygienists and others.

name: Dentistry I: Foundations of Clinical Dentistry
desc: Fundamentals of human biology, body systems, diseases, and supporting basic oral health sciences. Learning in small groups, classroom, laboratory, and clinical settings utilizing technology.  Professionalism, ethics, interprofessional education and the social contract, communication skills, and critical evaluation of the literature. Begin to apply foundation knowledge and skills to patient assessment and care.

name: Dentistry II: Basic Clinical Dentistry
desc: Continued exposure to body systems and the supporting biomedical sciences with applications in dental clinical sciences, integrated into small group learning, classroom, laboratory, and community settings utilizing technology; continued engagement in professionalism, ethics and communication skills.

name: Dentistry III: Intermediate Clinical Dentistry
desc: A multi-disciplinary course integrating didactic, simulation, clinical, and community service learning. Students function as team members in clinical group practices with individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships.

name: Dentistry IV: Complex Clinical Dentistry
desc: A continuing integrated, multi-disciplinary course with ongoing participation in clinical group practices and individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships and community service learning.
