name: Exploring Our Food
desc: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future. [3-0-0]
prer: At least second year standing required.

name: Nutrition Concepts and Controversies
desc: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
prer: Either (a) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (b) all of KIN  131, KIN  132. At least second-year standing required.

name: Introductory Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition, and health. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Food Engineering
desc: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement. [3-0-1]

name: Food Chemistry
desc: Chemical and physical properties and reactions of food constituents, including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals and vitamins. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

name: Food Analysis
desc: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

name: Food Product Development
desc: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
prer: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200. FNH 301 recommended.

name: Food Processing
desc: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions. [3-0-1]

name: Food Microbiology
desc: Roles of microorganisms in food production, preservation, spoilage, and foodborne disease; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in foods; methods for identifying, enumerating, and eliminating microorganisms in food-production environments. [3-0-0]

name: Food Science Laboratory I
desc: Laboratory techniques used in food chemistry, microbiology and processing; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]

name: Food Science Laboratory II
desc: Laboratory techniques used in food analysis, food processing, sensory science and product development; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]

name: Introduction to Wine Science 1
desc: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation. [2-1-0]

name: Introduction to Wine Science II
desc: Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis. [3-1-0]
prer: FNH  330 and third-year standing or higher.

name: Food Theory and Applications
desc: Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food, and experimental and practical applications to food preparation.
prer: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

name: Food Theory Applications
desc: Experimental and practical application of scientific principles and theories to problems of food preparation. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe I certificate.

name: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
desc: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces. [3-0-0]
prer: At least third year standing required.

name: Counselling Skills in Dietetics
desc: Counselling in dietetics: communication theory and foundational counselling skills.

name: Fundamentals of Nutrition
desc: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism. [3-0-0]
prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

name: Vitamins, Minerals, and Health
desc: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health. [3-0-0]
prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

name: International Nutrition
desc: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world. [3-0-0]

name: Nutrition Assessment
desc: The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations. [3-0-0]

name: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
desc: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span. 3-0-0

name: Nutrition Care I
desc: Etiology, pathophysiology, and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include metabolism, obesity, eating disorders, diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. Restricted to students in year 3 of the dietetics major.
prer: All of FNH  350, FNH  370 and one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155.

name: Professional Dietetic Practice I
desc: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
prer: Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

name: Dietetics Practice Education Placement I
desc: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
prer: All of FNH  375, FNH  380. Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

name: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
desc: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.
prer: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

name: Functional Foods
desc: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods.

name: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
desc: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance.
prer: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300 or equivalent background in statistics.

name: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
desc: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
prer: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203. Third-year standing.

name: Food Safety
desc: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.
prer: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, CHEM 233, FNH  313.

name: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
desc: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
prer: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

name: Interfacial Phenomena
desc: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519.

name: Food Science Laboratory III
desc: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry. [0-3-1]

name: Enology and Wine Biotechnology
desc: Yeasts and bacteria involved in wine making, metabolic pathways leading to the production of flavour and spoilage compounds, genetic improvement of wine yeasts, and red and white wine fermentations. Approaches and technologies for the improvement of wine safety. Sensory evaluation of wines.
prer: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325, FNH  313, BIOC 302.

name: Integrated Functional Genomics
desc: Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general.

name: Food Service Systems Management
desc: Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

name: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
desc: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism. [3]
prer: All of FNH  350, BIOC 302 and one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155, CAPS 301.

name: Fish Nutrition
desc: Physiology of digestion and excretion, nutrient requirements, sources of nutrients, diet formulation, feeding management. [3-0-0]

name: Applied International Nutrition
desc: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

name: International Nutrition Field Studies
desc: Theoretical and practical application of international nutrition and food security knowledge and skills.  International field placement for a minimum of 12 weeks with pre-departure sessions.  Restricted to students in International Nutrition Major or by permission of instructor.

name: Nutrition Care II
desc: Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include nutrition support, gastrointestinal conditions, surgery, allergies and intolerances. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.

name: Maternal and Fetal Nutrition
desc: Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply. [3-0-0]

name: Applied Public Health Nutrition
desc: Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health. [3-0-0]

name: Sport Nutrition
desc: Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

name: Nutrition Care III
desc: Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include neurological disorders, dysphagia, critical care, oncology, hepatobiliary conditions, HIV and renal disease. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.

name: Nutrition and Disease Prevention
desc: Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease. [3-0-0]

name: Professional Dietetic Practice II
desc: Skill development and application for practice education placements and dietetic practice settings.  Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

name: Dietetics Practice Education Placement II
desc: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.

name: Dietetics Practice Education Placement III
desc: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.

name: Dietetics Practice Education Placement IV
desc: Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

name: Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health
Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis.
prer: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

name: Introduction to Film Studies
desc: Basic aesthetic, economic, sociological, and technological aspects of film.

name: Introduction to Canadian Cinema
desc: History and aesthetics of Canadian cinema.

name: Early Cinema
desc: Aesthetics, economics, history, and technological characteristics of international early film.

name: Hollywood Cinema 1930-1960
desc: Analysis of the aesthetics, economics, history and technological characteristics of the Classical Hollywood period.

name: Introduction to Asian Cinema
desc: Overview of the cinemas of China, India, Japan, and Korea.

name: Media Industries
desc: Overview of today's film and media industries, and of the concepts governing their practices.

name: Cult Cinema
desc: Overview of world cult cinema.

name: Studies in Film Theory
desc: A seminar introducing the many theoretical approaches to film: formalist, historical, Marxist, psychoanalytic, semiotic, and structuralist.

name: Studies in Genre or Period
desc: A seminar examining one or more genres or periods, such as the Western, Film Noir, Science Fiction, Films of the 1980's. Also includes study of national cinemas.

name: Seminar in Documentary
desc: An analysis of the representational strategies and ethics of the form.

name: Seminar in European Cinema
desc: Topics may include a study of a European national cinema.

name: Asian and Australasian Cinema
desc: Topics may include an analysis of a national cinema, such as that of China, India, or Australia.

name: Media Audiences
desc: Overview of approaches for studying audiences and receptions of film and contemporary media.

name: Studies in Auteurism
desc: A seminar examining the work of one or more directors, such as John Ford, Francois Truffaut, Denys Arcand, Margarethe Von Trotta, or of a screenwriter over many films.

name: Seminar in Motion Picture Forms
desc: Animation, experimental, and/or multimedia.

name: Studies in Film
desc: A seminar devoted to a topic of current interest in film. Topic will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

name: Seminar in American Cinema Since 1960
desc: Topics may include an analysis of a specific period.

name: Seminar in Canadian Cinema
desc: Topics may include an analysis of the Canadian Governmental agencies supporting Film Production.

name: Honours Essay
desc: A course allowing honours students to work with a faculty member on a major research paper.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 250 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 131 or CHIN 101 or CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 131. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 133 or CHIN 103 or CHIN 134.

name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 500 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 134 or CHIN 104 or both CHIN 101, CHIN 103, or both CHIN 131, CHIN 133.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 141 or CHIN 111 or CHIN 144.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 141. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 143 or CHIN 113 or CHIN 144.

name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and in reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 144 or CHIN 114 or both CHIN 111, CHIN 113, or both CHIN 141, CHIN 143.

name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Chinese
desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Mandarin Chinese.

name: Chinese Characters I
desc: 250-300 basic and frequently-used Chinese characters in their simplified form, including character radicals, strokes and stroke-order, meaning, and pronunciation. Introduction to theories of Chinese character formation.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing Mandarin Chinese, active vocabulary of about 750 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 231 or CHIN 105 or CHIN 234.
prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 231. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 233 or CHIN 107, or CHIN 234.

name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 1000 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 234 or CHIN 108 or both CHIN 105, CHIN 107, or both CHIN 231, CHIN 233.
prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 241 or CHIN 115 or CHIN 244.
prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 241. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 243 or CHIN 117 or CHIN 244.

name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 244 or CHIN 118 or both CHIN 115, CHIN 117 or both CHIN 241, CHIN 243.
prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 331 or CHIN 201 or CHIN 334.
prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 331. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 333 or CHIN 203 or CHIN 334.

name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 334 or CHIN 204 or both CHIN 201, CHIN 203 or both CHIN 331, CHIN 333.
prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 335 or CHIN 205 or CHIN 338.
prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 335. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 337 or CHIN 207 or CHIN 338.

name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 338 or CHIN 208 or both CHIN 205, CHIN 207 or both CHIN 335, CHIN 337.
prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 341 or CHIN 211 or CHIN 344.
prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 341. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 343 or CHIN 213 or CHIN 344.

name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Heritage)
desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 344 or CHIN 214 or both CHIN 211, CHIN 213 or both CHIN 341, CHIN 343.
prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Heritage)
desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 345 or CHIN 215 or CHIN 348.
prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 345. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 347 or CHIN 217 or CHIN 348.

name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Heritage)
desc: Communication skills. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 348 or CHIN 218 or both CHIN 215, CHIN 217 or both CHIN 345, CHIN 347.
prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

name: Reading Course in Chinese for Honours Students
Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers I
desc: Strictly for Cantonese speakers from Hong Kong who cannot speak Mandarin but who have advanced Chinese reading and writing skills (2,000 characters). Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 381 or CHIN 221.

name: Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers II
desc: Continuation of CHIN 381. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 383 or CHIN 223.

name: Introduction to Classical Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
desc: The basics of classical Chinese grammar, with short illustrations from texts of the Warring States and early Han Period. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 389 or CHIN 388.
prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234, JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260, KORN 200. Or placement approval.

name: Introduction to Classical Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
desc: Practice and expansion of the grammar skills learned in CLCH 389 or CHIN 388; reading of additional and longer passages from the classical canon. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 399 or CHIN 389.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 405. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 401 or CHIN 301 or CHIN 404.
prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 401. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 407. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 403 or CHIN 303 or CHIN 404.

name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Non-Heritage)
desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 408. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 404 or CHIN 304 or both CHIN 301, CHIN 303 or both CHIN 401, CHIN 403.
prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 401. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 405 or CHIN 305 or CHIN 408.
prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 405. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 403. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 407 or CHIN 307 or CHIN 408.

name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Non-Heritage)
desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 404. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 408 or CHIN 308 or both CHIN 305, CHIN 307 or both CHIN 405, CHIN 407.
prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Media Chinese I (Heritage)
desc: Reading and understanding Chinese as used in newspapers, radio/TV, and the internet news. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 415 or CHIN 309.

name: Twentieth-Century Chinese Literature
desc: Selected short stories, novels, plays, essays, and poems from 1917 to the end of the twentieth century.  For students who have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese.
prer: 12 credits at CHIN 300 level or above is recommended.

name: Business Chinese I (Heritage)
desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to advertising, the stock market and E-commerce. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 435 or CHIN 321.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Business Chinese II (Heritage)
desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to legal and financial documents such as contracts, investments, and insurance. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 437 or CHIN 323.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Heritage)
desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and CHIN 445. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 441 or CHIN 311 or CHIN 444.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 441. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437 and/or CHIN 447. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 443 or CHIN 313 or CHIN 444.

name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Heritage)
desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 448. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 444 or CHIN 314 or both CHIN 311, CHIN 313 or both CHIN 441, CHIN 443.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Heritage)
desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and/or CHIN 441. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 445 or CHIN 315 or CHIN 448.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Heritage)
desc: Continuation of CHIN 445. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437and/or CHIN 443. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 447 or CHIN 317 or CHIN 448.

name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Heritage)
desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 438 and/or CHIN 444. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 448 or CHIN 318 or both CHIN 315, CHIN 317 or both CHIN 445, CHIN 447.
prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Readings in Classical Chinese
desc: Focus on reading longer texts in Classical Chinese, producing careful and polished translation, using appropriate reference works and appreciating nuances of style and genre. Transition from textbook-based study to independent reading and scholarly translation necessary for advanced study and research.

name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature I
desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1900 to 1949, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 451 or CHIN 411.
prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404, CHIN 435, CHIN 441, CHIN 443 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408, CHIN 437, CHIN 445, CHIN 447.

name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature II
desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1949 to the present, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 453 or CHIN 413.

name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Early Periods) (Non-Heritage)
desc: Early fiction, including tales of the supernatural and romance, to the Tang Dynasty. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 455 or CHIN 421 or CHIN 458.
prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Later Periods) (Non-Heritage)
desc: Texts in vernacular Chinese, including drama and fiction, from the Yuan to the Qing Dynasties. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 457 or CHIN 423 or CHIN 458.
prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Intensive) (Non-Heritage)
desc: Covers a range of stories, fiction, and drama to the Qing Dynasty. Only for students who did not have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese before entering university. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 458 or CHIN 424 or both CHIN 421, CHIN 423 or both CHIN 455, CHIN 457.
prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (to Han)
desc: Readings in classical poetry from the pre-Qin to the end of the Han Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 461 or CHIN 464.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Han to Tang)
desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Six Dynasties to early Tang, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 463 or CHIN 464.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
desc: A combination of CHIN 461 and 463. Classical poetry from pre-Qin to the early Tang Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 464 or both CHIN 461, CHIN 463.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Fantasy in Chinese Literature
desc: Themes in Chinese literature from pre-Qin to the present, with a focus on narratives about the supernatural, the marvelous, and the fantastic.
prer: One of CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448. Or placement approval.

name: Chinese Martial Arts Fiction
desc: Chinese martial arts fiction as a form of cultural expression first created in classical Chinese fiction and then evolved into contemporary popular literature.
prer: One of CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448. Or placement approval.

name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Tang)
desc: Readings in classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Tang Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 471 or 474.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (after Tang)
desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Song to the Qing dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 473 or 474.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
desc: A combination of CHIN 471 and 473. Classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Qing Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 474 or both CHIN 471, CHIN 473.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Tutorial in Chinese for Honours Students
desc: Will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Review the course section information or consult the Department for details. May be taken for up to a total of 12 credits. Restricted to students in the Honours Asian Area Studies or Asian Language and Culture programs.

name: Modern Chinese Literature I (Heritage)
desc: Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 481 or CHIN 484.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Supervised Study in the Chinese Language
desc: Focus changes from year to year. Please see Department website (asia.ubc.ca) for further details. Open to undergraduate and graduate students.

name: Modern Chinese Literature II (Heritage)
desc: Historical continuation of CHIN 481. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 483 or CHIN 484.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Intensive Modern Chinese Literature (Heritage)
desc: A combination of CHIN 481 and 483. Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to the present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 484 or both CHIN 481, CHIN 483.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Contemporary Chinese Fiction in Film
desc: Contemporary Chinese films from the 21st century adapted from literary works.
prer: One of CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448. Or placement approval.

name: Classical Chinese I (Heritage)
desc: The development of early Chinese from the classical period through the Six Dynasties (5th century BCE to 6th century CE). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 491 or CHIN 431 or CHIN 494.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Classical Chinese II (Heritage)
desc: Focus in on the Tang and Song dynasties (617 - 1279). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 493 or CHIN 433 or CHIN 494.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Intensive Classical Chinese (Heritage)
desc: A combination of CHIN 491 and 493. Readings on classical philosophy, history, literature, and culture. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 494 or CHIN 434 or both CHIN 431, CHIN 433 or both CHIN 491, CHIN 493.
prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Introduction to Business
desc: Introduction to the Faculty of Management and traditional areas of business including accounting, economics, finance, marketing, organizational behaviour, operations, business policy, information systems and entrepreneurship. Identifies the steps needed to build and manage successful local, national, and international competitive businesses and organizations. Introduces ethical and policy decisions faced by businesses, organizations and governments.

name: Introduction to Management Thought and Social Responsibility
desc: Introduces management thought in business and organizations. Utilizes critical thinking in socially and ethically responsible decisions at a corporate and personal level. Includes managing responsibly through people, mass production, ethical and socially-responsible practices. Covers start-ups, entrepreneurs, family business, non-profit/for-profit organizations and governments in global regions. Credit will be granted for only one of MGMT 110 or MGMT 200.

name: Introduction to Management Thought and Social Responsibility
desc: Introduces management thought in business and organizations. Utilizes critical thinking in socially and ethically responsible decisions at a corporate and personal level. Includes managing responsibly through people, mass production, ethical and socially-responsible practices. Covers start-ups, entrepreneurs, family business, non-profit/for-profit organizations and governments in global regions. Credit will be granted for only one of MGMT 200 or MGMT 110.

name: Ways of Seeing: Introduction to Visual Studies
desc: Drawing on examples from across history and around the world, this course deals with the role of the visual in society, culture, and everyday experience.

name: Crisis and Contradiction in Art and the Built Environment
desc: Concepts and issues critical to the understanding of art and its histories in a global context.

name: Byzantium: Arts of an Empire
desc: Art, architecture, and material culture of the Byzantine Empire situated in the eastern Mediterranean (c. 300-1453); focus on social and cultural contexts of artistic production, including interactions with neighboring cultures.

name: Art, Patrons, and Audiences in the Middle Ages
desc: A thematic study of the relationship between patrons and audiences in painting, sculpture, and architecture through the 15th century.

name: Art, Colonialism, and Indigeneity
desc: Tensions and conflicts resulting from the expansion of trade and encounters among cultures, ethnicities, and religious practices, explored in visual art and architecture from the sixteenth century to the advent of the modern era.

name: What is Modern Art?
desc: Select issues in 20th-century art and the visual and built environment.

name: Art & Feminism(s): Histories, Lineages, Legacies
desc: Feminist art and visual culture, from the political activism of the feminist first wave to its intersections with present-day social justice movements.

name: Asian Arts: From Chinese Warriors to Bollywood Posters
desc: A thematic examination of Asian arts, such as historic, religious, and secular painting and sculpture to contemporary visual culture.

name: Asian Architecture: Sacred and Urban Spaces
desc: Select built forms in Asia, such as temples, tombs, palaces, cities and gardens, and their relations to cultural, social and political systems.

name: Pre-Hispanic Arts of Central and South America
desc: The relevance of various arts to social institutions in ancient societies of Peru and Mesoamerica.

name: Indigenous Arts of North America
desc: A survey of the artistic production by Indigenous peoples of North America from pre-contact times to the present.

name: Art and the Moving Image
desc: Intersections between visual art and the moving image in both a theoretical and historical context.

name: Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History
desc: Theories, problems, and literature in the study of art history. Required of all Major and Honours students in art history.

name: Arts of Africa and the African Diasporas
desc: Comparative exploration of art practices and their relationship to colonial and postcolonial histories.

name: Art and the Religious Transformation of the Roman Empire
desc: Visual culture and religious diversity of the Late Roman Empire (2nd-7th c.); social, political, and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks.

name: Early Medieval Art
desc: From pagan adornment to Christian devotion to service of Christian or Islamic rule (AD 500-1000). Art and architecture of the Early Medieval world's diverse and transforming social, political, cultural contexts.

name: Medieval Art in the Age of Monasticism
desc: Art in Europe between 1000 and 1200; the role of monasteries as leading institutions and patrons of art and large-scale architecture.

name: Art, Church, Society and their Margins in the Later Middle Ages
desc: Diversification of the arts and architecture with the expansion of patronage in late medieval society. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 313 or ARTH 333.

name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

name: Entangled Worlds: Spain and Colonial Latin America (1500-1700)
desc: Role of visual art and culture within Catholic Spain and colonial Latin America is surveyed, with emphasis on transculturation from mudejar to mestizaje.

name: Public and Private Bodies: Italian Renaissance Art and Culture
desc: Visual art and culture within the social, political, and religious contexts of the Papacy and the city-states ca. 1350-1550 (Siena, Florence, Venice, Mantua).

name: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700)
desc: Focus primarily on Rome as the center of artistic, cultural, economic, and religious power in the seventeenth century.

name: Heaven and Earth: Renaissance Art and Culture in Northern Europe
desc: Early Modern painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts from the great devotional triptychs, through the Reformation, to the emergence of a secular art (1400-1600).

name: Urban and Courtly Arts in Early Modern Northern Europe (1600-1700)
desc: The role of visual art in 17th century court cultures, commercial urban centres, and emergent nation states.

name: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharaohs
desc: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire.

name: Greek Art and Architecture
desc: Visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

name: Roman Art and Architecture
desc: Visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

name: Visual Culture in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution (1715-1830)
desc: Art, architecture, and social space in Europe and America: redefining gender, identity and nation in the era of industrialization and political change.

name: 19th-Century Art and Social Space
desc: Ideologies of gender, class, race, ethnicity, and economics in 19th-century European and American visual culture.

name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Triumph and Demise of Modernism
desc: A critical survey of western art and cultural production from the turn of the century to the development of Pop Art.

name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
desc: A critical examination of international visual art and culture from the 1950s to the present;  the role of art in consumerist society and the emergence of postmodernism.

name: Latin American Art: Modern and Contemporary
desc: Analyses of specific works and texts will emphasize visual inventions and meaning in the light of recent theoretical debates

name: Inventing Canada Through Art
desc: The institutions and art movements that constructed a view to the country now known as Canada, from colonial contact, to Confederation, through the mid-1900s. Emphasis on the significance of locality and situated approaches to understanding the land.

name: Contemporary Conversations about Art in Kanata/Canada
desc: Radical shifts in thinking about Canadian art and culture since the mid-20th century. The art movements, debates, and institutions that contribute to the complexity of artistic approaches to representing Canada today.

name: History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
desc: History and theory of photography, from the competitive context of invention in the 1830s to contemporary uses in social media.

name: Architecture in Europe: Building the Fabric of the Modern State (1715-1837)
desc: The role of architecture within the development of the modern state.  A survey of broad cultural dynamics, particular building projects and design careers.

name: Architecture in Europe: Modern Paradigms of Design (1837-present)
desc: An examination of new requirements imposed on architecture by the consolidation of a capitalist economy, industrialization, new technologies and scientific methods.

name: Architecture in North America: Colonial Projects and Disruptions (1605-1867)
desc: The role of architecture in the imposition of European governance within North America;  the modification of received conventions in relation to topographical, ethnic-religious and political factors.

name: Architecture in North America: Independent Design Idioms (1867-present)
desc: The emergence of a distinctive architecture that superseded British and European agendas; the growth of private and public patronage and the establishment of modern design and practice.

name: Grounding the Islamic Image
desc: Contextualizing the complex language of images in the Islamic world.

name: Art and Urban Culture in the Islamic World
desc: A thematic and comparative study of visual arts and architecture in their urban contexts.

name: Historic India:  Images, Temples and the Construction of Indian Art History
desc: North and South Indian art and architecture with an emphasis on Buddhism and Hinduism.

name: Nepal and Tibet:  Art, Ritual and Performance
desc: Art of the Himalayan region situated within social and religious practices, festivals, and performances.

name: Mughal India:  Art, Architecture and the Spectacle of Empire
desc: The complex relationship of Mughal imperial architecture and painting with those of the Hindu Rajput courts.

name: Modern and Contemporary India: Art in Colonial and Independent India
desc: The development of a new Indian art during the colonial period and nationalist movement; the construction of India's contemporary visual culture.

name: Chinese Art and Architecture: Patronage and Collecting
desc: The commission, production, preservation, and transmission of Chinese monuments and artworks focusing on the court and questions of cultural policies.

name: Chinese Art for the Afterlife
desc: Close analyses of Chinese tomb objects and tombs as spatial constructs in their historical, ritual, and social context.

name: Chinese Painting: Word and Image
desc: Analyses visual narratives and relationships between painting, calligraphy, and poetry in court and literati painting.

name: Chinese Modern and Contemporary Art
desc: Chinese art and its global entanglements from Qing Encounters to the 21st century.

name: Art in Japan: Objects and Spaces
desc: Changing relationship between art objects and the built environment in the Japanese archipelago, in its social and historical context.

name: Art in Japan: The Problem with Painting
desc: Key debates in the history of painting and its institutionalization.

name: Art in Japan: Print Media
desc: Historical and theoretical questions concerning the development of print media in Japan, from Edo period woodcuts to the advent of digital technologies.

name: Art in Japan: Modern Visual Culture
desc: Self and community in the art and visual culture of modern Japan.

name: Arts of Mexico's Early Peoples
desc: Pre-Aztec monumental and portable arts of the Olmec, Zapotec, Teotihuacan and Classic Veracruz peoples.

name: Arts of the Aztec period in Mexico
desc: Symbolic meanings and political agendas of Aztec architecture, sculpture and manuscript illustration investigated using Spanish accounts.

name: Maya Public Ritual Arts
desc: Architecture, sculpture, costume, and visual productions associated with Maya public ritual, including the ancient ball game and modern cofradía dances.

name: Maya Arts of Everyday Life
desc: Social context and meaning of the Maya's elaborate architecture, sculpture, mural paintings, jewelry, ceramics, figurines, and textiles, ancient and modern, of residences from humble to palatial.

name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The North
desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Northern Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South
desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Southern  Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

name: Art as Technology
desc: Relationship between artistic practice and media, examined through a history of paradigm shifts in technology.

name: The Artist in the World
desc: Critical approach to the figure of the artist in art, film and texts, from the Early Modern period to the present.

name: Is Art History Queer?
desc: Issues in the history of art through the lens of queer theory.

name: Queer Partnerships in Art & Art-Making
desc: Diverse forms of human contact and creative collaboration, their effects on art and art-making, and their capacity to challenge conventions of artistic genius as dependent on masculinity, singularity, and heteronormativity.
prer: Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students majoring in Visual Art or Art History.

name: Seminar in African Art
desc: Key debates in the art of Africa and the African diaspora

name: Studies in the Art and Archeology of Greece and Rome
Seminar in the Art of the Middle Ages
Seminar in Modern and Contemporary Art
Seminar in Contemporary Latin American Art
Film and the City
desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

name: Seminar in Art in the Islamic World
desc: Key debates in the field of art and architecture in the Islamic World.

name: Seminar in the Art of South Asia
Seminar in North American Indigenous Art
Performance Actions and Approaches
desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

name: Visual and Digital Media Theory
desc: A thematic examination of key arguments in visual and digital media theory, focusing on developments in lens-based and digital media in relationship to twentieth-century and contemporary artistic practice.

name: Art History Internship
prer: ARTH 300 and departmental approval. Interested students may contact the department for details on how to proceed.

name: Geography, Environment and Globalization
desc: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

name: Geography, Modernity and Globalization
desc: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

name: Vancouver and Its Region
desc: An integrated approach to the physical and human geography of the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Field trips.

name: The State of the Earth
desc: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future.

name: Geopolitics
desc: Introduction to the political geographic perspectives on today's interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

name: Cities
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

name: People, Places & Landscapes
desc: Relationships among individuals, social groups, and place, with a focus on everyday spaces. Examines how social identities are intertwined with the places we live.

name: Geography of the Pacific Rim
desc: An introduction to changing geographies (social, economic, and political) of the Pacific Rim, with special emphasis on the relationships between Canada and Japan.

name: Introduction to the Geography of Canada
desc: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

name: Environment and Sustainability
desc: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems.

name: Urban Environments
desc: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies.

name: Climate Change: Science and Society
desc: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems.
prer: One of GEOS 102, GEOB 102, GEOS 200, GEOB 200, GEOS 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. 3rd year standing.

name: Environmental Justice and Social Change
desc: Economic, social, political and cultural structures and institutions that shape contemporary socioecological challenges.

name: Analysing Environmental Problems
desc: Concepts and techniques employed in environmental research; challenges in the areas of climate change, water use, knowledge translation and natural hazards.
prer: Two of GEOG 211, GEOB 102, GEOB 103, GEOS 102, GEOS 103.

name: Human and Environmental Geography Field Course
desc: Engage in primary field-based research in British Columbia on important issues concerning intercultural understanding, engagement with local communities and sustainability. Focus will shift on a bi-annual basis in accordance with location and available community partners. Special fees and liability insurance are required. Third year standing is recommended.

name: Geography of Natural Hazards
desc: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations.
prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOS 102 and one of GEOB 103, GEOS 103.

name: Sustainability in a Changing Environment
desc: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy.

name: Environmental Impact Assessment
desc: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally.

name: Historical Geography of Urbanization: Cities, Space, and Power
desc: From the origins of urbanism to the modern era.

name: Creating Canada
desc: Canada from the beginning of European contact to the mid-19th century, stressing the changing geographical patterns of settlement, economy, and culture.

name: Constructing Canada
desc: The construction of Canadian political space after Confederation, aboriginal-newcomer relations, regional development and conflict, industrialization, urbanization, and war.

name: Political Geography
desc: Review of political geography and geopolitics; relations among space, power and politics; cases from current global affairs.

name: Theory and Practice in Human Geography
desc: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

name: Topics in Geography
desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website or contact the Geography undergraduate advisor for details.

name: Urban Worlds
desc: City systems and theories of urban location; internal spatial structure of the city; commercial and industrial location; social areas; neighbourhood and land use change; urban trends and public policy.

name: Urban Environmental Politics
desc: Effects of urbanization and global environmental change on the geographies of cities across the world. Specific focus on urban environmental justice and inequality.

name: Urbanization in the Global South
desc: Urbanization in the developing countries of Latin America, Africa, and Asia; the role of cities in the development process and the features and problems of rapid urbanization.

name: Geographies of Migration and Settlement
desc: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

name: Society, Culture & Space
desc: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and environments both reflect and shape social life.  Third year standing is recommended.

name: Critical Geographies of the Economy
desc: History and methods of economic geography. Location of resource industries, manufacturing, and service activities with emphasis on British Columbia in its North American and world setting. Recommended for students with no previous exposure to geographies of the economy, before taking other courses in the 36x and 46x series.

name: Geography of Economic Development
desc: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds.

name: Globalization, Cities, and Regions
desc: Forms of economic development; changing location of economic activities and functions; implications for government and politics; local strategies for growth and equity.

name: Research Strategies in Geography
desc: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography.

name: Statistics in Geography
desc: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Field Course in Human Geography
desc: As announced by the department a year in advance.

name: Geography of Asia
desc: A comparative regional analysis stressing the historical development and changing cultural, economic, and political patterns of the area. Special reference to India, Indonesia, China, and Japan.

name: Geography of Selected Regions
desc: A geographical analysis of selected regions not regularly included in the Department's offerings in regional geography (e.g., tropical Africa, Oceania). Students should consult the Department regarding regions to be covered.

name: Modern Europe: Places and Borders
desc: An introduction to the present-day human geography of the regions and places between the Atlantic and the Ural Mountains.

name: Culture, Nature, and Coloniality in Latin America
desc: Socio-ecologies in 1491; Spanish colonialism and biological imperialism; contemporary coloniality and neoliberalism; and social movements.

name: Geography of Africa
desc: A comparative regional analysis of Africa with a focus on contemporary environmental and development issues. Credit will be allowed for only one of GEOG 396 and 496.

name: Environment and Society
desc: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy.

name: Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice
desc: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally.  Focus on social science perspectives.  Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills.

name: Research in Environmental Geography
desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor. GEOG 313 and 314 recommended.

name: Development of Environmental Thought
desc: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society.

name: Feminist Geographies
desc: An introductory survey of contemporary feminist approaches to human geography.

name: Historical Geography of British Columbia, I
desc: Colonialism, resistance, and land use in early British Columbia.

name: Research in Historical Geography
desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.

name: Radical Traditions of Decolonization and Liberation
desc: Decolonial theory and practice through an examination of critical Indigenous and critical race scholarship and activism.
prer: Restricted to students with 3rd year standing or higher. GEOG 121, or equivalent, is strongly recommended for students with 3rd year standing.

name: Student Directed Seminar in Human Geography
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in human geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars."  Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 442 or GEOG 443.

name: Topics in Geography
desc: See the departmental undergraduate advisor for details.

name: Directed Studies: Off Campus Research
desc: Based on project work outside the university, on a topic to be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member and the student.
prer: Open to upper-level students enrolled in the Geography Majors or Honours programs. Permission of the Undergraduate Advisor and supervising faculty member is required.

name: Directed Studies in Geography
desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member and the student.
prer: Open to upper-level students enrolled in the Geography Majors or Honours programs. Permission of the Undergraduate Advisor and supervising faculty member is required.

name: Urban Research
desc: Historical, legal, and quantitative analysis of urban research. Emphasis on spatial, racial, and political dynamics of urban inequality.

name: Political Geographic Analysis
desc: Political organization of space; territorial and spatial patterns of power and identity; contemporary geopolitical struggles.

name: Film and the City
desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

name: Social and Behavioural Geography
desc: Theories of social change in the global city; labour markets; poverty and inequality; social polarization; housing markets; gentrification and housing affordability; immigration and segregation; diversity and multiculturalism; transnationalism; the entrepreneurial state; the convivial city.

name: Political-Economic Geographies
desc: Principal theories and debates in contemporary political-economic geography, with particular emphasis on global and regional transformations.

name: Geography of Japan
desc: A critical analysis of significant human adaptations to changing ecological conditions in the Japanese archipelago.

name: Geography of Southeast Asia
desc: A critical analysis of significant features of political, economic, and cultural development in the region from pre-colonial times to the present.

name: Geography of China
desc: An introduction to the changing cultural, social and economic geography of China.

name: Contemporary Europe: Identity and Geopolitics
desc: Political, economic, and social geographies of post Cold War Europe with a special emphasis on east-central Europe: societal transformations in the formerly socialist states; European Union and NATO enlargement; the external relations of these two organizations.

name: Geographies of Social Movements in the Americas
desc: The politics of North-South solidarity in theory and practice through community service learning models.

name: Geography of Africa
desc: A comparative regional analysis of Africa with a focus on contemporary environmental and development issues. Credit will be allowed for only one of GEOG 396 and 496.

name: The Arctic
desc: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems.

name: Geographies of the Middle East
desc: Critical analysis of economic, social, and political development and processes defining the modern Middle East region.

name: Introduction to Microcomputers
desc: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312, EECE 256, EECE 259 or EECE 355.

name: Computing Systems II
desc: Computer architecture and the hardware- software interface: pipelining; caches; virtual memory; memory management; linking; concurrency; introduction to compilers. [3-2-0]
prer: CPEN 211 and one of CPEN 221, CPEN 223, CPSC 259.

name: Software Construction I
desc: Design, implementation, reasoning about software systems: abstraction and specification of software, testing, verification, abstract data types, object-oriented design, type hierarchies, concurrent software design.

name: Software Design for Engineers
desc: Introduction to robust software design: static typing, procedural specifications, unit testing, black-box & white-box tests, user- defined data types (representations, invariants, abstraction functions), data abstractions, communicating design (e.g., UML).

name: Technical Communication
desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Computer Engineering Design Studio I
desc: Design projects involving hardware (electronic devices and circuits, microcomputers) and software.

name: Digital Systems Design
desc: Advanced combinational and sequential electronic system design. Hardware specification, modelling, and simulation using hardware description languages (HDLs) and CAD tools. Design with programmable logic including FPGA's. Applications include complex state machines, microcontrollers, arithmetic circuits, and interface units.

name: Digital Systems and Microcomputers
desc: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of CPEN 312, CPEN 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading
prer: One of ELEC 201, ELEC 204, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

name: Software Engineering
desc: Engineering practices for the development of non-trivial software-intensive systems including requirements specification, software architecture, implementation, verification, and maintenance. Iterative development. Recognized standards, guidelines, and models. Credit will only be granted for only one of CPSC 310, CPEN321. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Software Construction II
desc: Contemporary concepts and techniques for developing interactive software applications: client-server architectures; session-oriented systems; security and scalability; models of application deployment.

name: Operating Systems
desc: Operating systems, their design and their implementation. Process concurrency, synchronization, communication and scheduling. Device drivers, memory management, virtual memory, file systems, networking and security.

name: System Software Engineering
desc: Use of operating systems abstractions; real-time systems; principles of concurrent and multi-threaded programming; information structures; introduction to object oriented analysis; design, and modelling using UML; software testing.

name: Computer Engineering Design Studio II
desc: Design and implementation of a hardware platform and software design and implementation at the operating system and application layers.  Project management skills. Effective presentations.
prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292 and CPEN 311.

name: Topics in Computer Engineering
desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

name: Computer Architecture
desc: Modern processors, GPUs, and memory hierarchies; quantitative principles and instruction set design; pipelining, superscalar issue, out-of-order execution, branch prediction and speculation; memory hierarchies, caches, virtual addressing, prefetching, coherence, and consistency; multicores, VLIW, on-chip networks, and other advanced architectures. Credit will be granted for only one of CPSC 313, CPEN 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Microcomputer Systems Design
desc: Microprocessor and system buses; advanced I/O methods; priority interrupts; event/exception handling; serial I/O; computer networking; memory system design; interaction of hardware and software, microprocessor comparison, testability issues, safety critical systems.
prer: CPEN 311 and one of CPEN 211, CPEN 312.

name: Software Project Management
desc: Advanced project planning, cost estimation and scheduling. Project management tools. Factors influencing productivity and success. Productivity metrics. Analysis of options and risk. Tools. Case studies.

name: Software Testing and Analysis
desc: Different levels of testing including unit, integration, system, performance and regression levels. Requirements flowdown. Problem tracking. Coverage criteria. Static methods. Tools support. Specialized techniques. Assessment of correctness, reliability, safety.
prer: One of CPEN 221, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310.

name: Software Architecture
desc: Software architecture as a bridge from requirements to implementation. Architectural description and patterns. Iterative development. Use of commercial off-the-shelf products.

name: Design of Distributed Software Applications
desc: Communications, processes, naming, synchronization, consistency and replication, fault tolerance, object-based middleware, and security technologies for distributed applications. [3-2-0]
prer: One of CPEN 331, CPSC 313 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210.

name: Real-time System Design
desc: Multi-tasking; interrupt-driven systems; task scheduling; schedulability analysis; inter-process communication and synchronization; resource management; performance measurement; hardware/software integration; hardware/software tradeoffs; system reliability.

name: Human Computer Interfaces in Engineering Design
desc: Practical issues for interfaces for modern software. Task analysis, user modelling, usability engineering, representations, metaphors, prototyping tools. Applications: interactive multimedia systems, engineering, scientific visualization, engineering design.
prer: One of CPSC 260, CPSC 221 and one of CPEN 221, CPSC 210, CPEN 333.

name: Introduction to Cybersecurity
desc: Security risks, threats, and vulnerabilities from technical perspectives; cryptography; software and web security; access control, assurance, accountability; usable privacy and security; engineering of secure systems; cryptocurrencies.

name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

name: Computer Engineering Capstone Design Project
desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real-world computer engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities. Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

name: Research Experience in Computer Engineering
desc: Directed research experience. Communication of research ideas. Pass/Fail.

name: Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

name: Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern
desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.

name: Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

name: History of the Romance Languages
desc: Development of the Romance language family from its origins in Latin to contemporary varieties. Emphasis on French, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish.
prer: A beginners knowledge (A1) in at least of one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.

name: French Literature from the Middle Ages to the Revolution
desc: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works.

name: French Literature since the Revolution
desc: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works.

name: Masterpieces in Hispanic Literature
desc: Literary texts from Spain and the Hispanic world. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of yesterday and today.

name: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature
Romance Linguistics
desc: The Indo-European background; Classical and Vulgar Latin; the origin, development and spread of the Romance languages; their vocabulary, phonology, morphology, syntax; vernacular Latin texts and Romance texts.
prer: Two years study of each of two Romance languages or two years of one Romance language and one year of Latin.

name: Research Intensive Seminar in Romance Studies
Greek and Latin Roots of English
desc: Greek and Latin roots of English vocabulary and grammar, with an introduction to language history and Greek and Roman culture.

name: Greek and Roman Mythology
desc: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation.

name: Golden Age of Athens
desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of fifth-century Athens.

name: Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome
desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome.

name: Gods, Graves, and Goods: The Archaeology of Ancient Greece and Rome
desc: A survey of the material cultures of the pre-classical and classical civilizations of Greece and Rome, illustrating the principles and techniques used to illuminate the archaeological history of these civilizations.

name: Greek Philosophy I
desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for CLST/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310.

name: Greek Philosophy II
desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310 and PHIL 311.

name: Ancient Greece
desc: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE).

name: Ancient Rome
desc: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine.

name: Gladiators, Games, and Spectacle in the Greek and Roman World
desc: History, development, and social function of various forms of spectacle in ancient Greece and Rome, from the Olympic games to the Roman arena.

name: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
desc: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences.

name: Ancient Technology: Greece and Rome
desc: The origins, achievements, and social impacts of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to Late Antiquity (c. 1500 BCE - 400 CE), with special attention to archaeological evidence.

name: Greek Law
desc: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored.

name: Roman Law
desc: The development of Roman private law during the classical period with special attention to family law, contract and delict.

name: Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
