desc: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records.

name: Women in the Roman World of Republican and Imperial Times
desc: Women  in the Roman world in the culture of the Republic and the Empire. Literary, artistic, and mythological sources are compared and contrasted to historical, legal, and archaeological records.

name: Greek Epic
desc: Homer's

name: Latin Epic
desc: The development of the epic genre in Latin, with detailed study of Vergil's

name: Classical Tragedy
desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation.

name: Classical Comedy
desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation.

name: The Roman Army
desc: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers.

name: Slavery in the Ancient Greek and Roman World
desc: The study and history of slavery in the Greek and Roman worlds as a political, legal, economic, social, and cultural phenomenon.

name: Ancient Greek Warfare
desc: Ancient Greek methods and tactics of war plus underlying social, religious and philosophical concepts relating to warfare, through sources in translation.

name: Greek Art and Architecture
desc: The visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

name: Roman Art and Architecture
desc: The visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

name: Greek Religion
desc: A survey of both traditional and exoteric religious practices from the Archaic to the Hellenistic period.  Some knowledge of ancient Greece is recommended.

name: Roman Religion
desc: Roman religions between the ninth century BCE and the fourth century CE, including mystery religions, magic, emperor worship, and early Christianity, with particular attention devoted to the primary sources. Some knowledge of ancient Rome is recommended.

name: The Roman Republic
desc: Rome from the foundation to the Augustan settlement. Constitutional development; the workings and failure of the Republican political system; acquisition and growth of Empire; the political, social, and economic consequences of imperialism.

name: The Early Roman Empire
desc: Roman imperial history during the Julio-Claudian and Flavian periods (30 BC-96 AD).

name: The Athenians and their Empire
desc: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew.

name: Alexander the Great and his Empire
desc: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East.

name: Life and Society in Classical Antiquity
desc: Topics in Greek and Roman life and society.

name: Seminar in Classical History
desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman history, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Seminar in Classical Literature
desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman literature, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Seminar in Classical Art and Archaeology
desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman art and archaeology, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Seminar in the Reception of the Classical World
desc: Selected topics in the reception of the classicial world in its own time and in later eras, with an emphasis on research. Prerequisite: at least one 3-credit upper-level course of content appropriate for the topic of the seminar (to be established by individual instructors). Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Introduction to Russian and Slavic Culture
desc: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present.

name: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe
desc: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

name: Introduction to Cognitive Systems
desc: Interdisciplinary examination of human mental processes and how these are mediated by the brain. Will draw on cognitive psychology, linguistics, cognitive neuroscience, philosophy, artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]
prer: second-year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Science.

name: Understanding and Designing Cognitive Systems
desc: Theory and methods for integrating diverse disciplinary content in cognitive systems. [3-2-0]

name: Research Methods in Cognitive Systems
desc: Examination and comparison of the research methodologies of different disciplines relevant to cognitive systems. [3-0-0]

name: Seminar in Cognitive Systems
desc: Interdisciplinary seminar integrating theory, methods, and current research topics. [1-0-4]

name: Research in Cognitive Systems
desc: Supervised research project in a Cognitive Systems-related laboratory. [0-9-0]

name: Indigenous Views of Landscapes
desc: Introduction to Indigenous people's interpretation of landscape and worldview. Learning from knowledge keepers, the course covers culturally significant places, place names, ceremonies, berry picking, medicines, fishing, and hunting.

name: Introduction to Natural Resources Stewardship
desc: Introduction to the principles of 'caring for the land' and integrating this ethos into natural resources management, including topics on caretaking for the land, animals, and future generations; sacred places; and the principle of interconnectivity of all living things.

name: Community Engagement: Principles, Practices and Protocols
desc: Introduction to working and professionalism in cross-cultural contexts, with a focus on Indigenous governments and the importance of organizational values, cultural practices and protocols, consensus-based decision-making, principles of engagement, conflict resolution and political dynamics.

name: Decolonization and Natural Resources
desc: Introduction to Indigenous People's history, cultures and experiences, and the effect on control over natural resources, drawing from local to international perspectives, with a focus on how decolonization, as an analytical lens, can transform institutions and Indigenous People's everyday lives.

name: Introduction to Governance
desc: Foundations of governance, with a focus on Indigenous governance in Canada. Topics include traditional governance, self-governance and natural resources governance.

name: Ways of Knowing
desc: Introduction to Indigenous Knowledge, with a focus on Indigenous and Western Knowledge for managing ecosystems and integrating knowledge.

name: Holistic Resource Stewardship
desc: Introduction to holistic resource stewardship and the interconnectivity of all living things. A holistic resource stewardship approach is taught, and students learn to operationalize a holistic stewardship plan.

name: Community: Capacity Development
desc: Foundations for understanding community organization and collective action in communities. Introduction to techniques for building capacity among members/citizens.

name: Plant Identification and Dendrology
desc: Introduction to structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, drawing from Indigenous and western knowledge systems.

name: Field Measurements
desc: Introduction to different techniques commonly used in field surveys, including assessments of landforms, soils, vegetation patterns and cultural features.

name: Ecology 1 - Foundations
desc: Foundations of ecology, the interaction of organisms and the environment, drawing from Indigenous and western perspectives. Topics include organismal, population, community and ecosystem theories.

name: GIS and Mapping
desc: Introduction to digital mapping and spatial analysis using a geographic information system (GIS) for analyzing geographic problems and creating maps.

name: Communications Tools
desc: Foundations of communications and communications tools. Topics include written, verbal, phone, email and social media communications, with special focus on mobilizing knowledge through social media to a general audience.

name: Ecology 2 - Disturbance and Climate Adaptation
desc: Foundations of disturbance from Indigenous and western perspectives. Topics includes natural (fire, wind, flood, climate) and anthropogenic (logging, dams, mining, climate) disturbances in both intact and altered landscapes.

name: Analytics for Land Stewardship
desc: Introduction to analytics for land stewardship. Topics includes basic probability and statistics skills, the limitations and strengths of analysis tools used to analyze data, and interconnections between analytical tools, data and landscape level decision-making.

name: Interventions on the Land
desc: Interventions on the land, drawing from Indigenous and western perspectives.  Topics covered include problem diagnostics and the design and implementation of holistic interventions.

name: Indigenous Law
desc: Indigenous legal orders, Canada's constitutional framework, treaties and self-governance. Topics also cover the international context, and the implications of the evolving legal context for land management.

name: Forest and Land Use Planning on Indigenous Lands
desc: Forest and land use planning on traditional territory. Topics include Aboriginal rights and title, clan and family jurisdiction, traditional use studies and mapping and provincial regulations.

name: Forest Modelling and Inventories
desc: Forest management strategies, including statistical inventory tools and growth and yield models, for producing estimates of forest stand characteristics over specified times. Forest growth models are linked to economic models and forest valuation.

name: Wildlife Ecology, Conservation and Management
desc: Wildlife conservation and management principles from Indigenous and western perspectives. Topics include the nexus between wildlife populations and healthy environments and wildlife habitat and other landscape needs.

name: Business Management
desc: Business management in a First Nations context. Topics include strategy, leadership and management, culture, accounting, human resources, regulation and law, natural resources and marketing.

name: Business Models
desc: First Nations business models, including community business enterprises (CBEs), joint ventures and limited partnerships, entrepreneurship and economic development among First Nations.

name: Business Tools
desc: Business management tools to sustain business competitiveness in a First Nations context. The course covers strategic planning, customer and stakeholder management, management information systems, benchmarking and supply chain management.

name: Indigenous Research Methods
desc: Research terminology, ethics and practice. Drawing from Indigenous and western science approaches, the course covers Indigenous, quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods approaches.

name: Policy Building and Processes
desc: Policy theory and practice in the Indigenous land stewardship context. Topics include developing and influencing policy and the drivers of policy change.

name: Community Conflict Management
desc: Conflict management focusing on power, rights and interests in Indigenous communities. Topics consensus-based and collaborative approaches.

name: Stewarding in Practice
desc: Stewarding land and forests in practice, drawing from Indigenous and western perspectives.
prer: All of ILS  100, ILS  200, ILS  300 or admission by permission of the instructor.

name: Land Stewardship Plan
desc: Capstone field course to produce a land stewardship plan integrating a diverse range of objectives and goals for a community or industry partner.

name: Circuit Analysis I
desc: The fundamentals of analysis of lumped linear time-invariant circuits; network theorems; operational amplifiers; first order circuits; DC analysis of diodes, BJT, and FET circuits.
prer: MATH 101 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158.

name: Circuit Analysis II
desc: Phasor analysis and AC three phase systems power; transfer functions; Bode plots; filters and resonance; Laplace transforms; transformers and mutual inductance; two-port networks. First and second order circuits.
prer: All of PHYS 158, MATH 101 and one of ELEC 201, ELEC 203 and one of MATH 255, MATH 256.

name: Basic Circuit Analysis
desc: Ideal passive elements and sources; Kirchhoff's Laws; DC circuits; natural and complete response of first order circuits; operational amplifiers; impedance; phasors; complex power. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

name: Linear Circuits
desc: Basic concepts and analysis techniques in the context of electric and electronic circuits including Bode plots and the Laplace transform. Treatment of RLC circuits, phasors, op-amps. Introduction to nonlinear circuit elements, diodes, BJT, FET circuits.
prer: MATH 152 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158, PHYS 153.

name: Electronics Laboratory
desc: Experiments involving electronic devices and circuits.

name: Engineering Electromagnetics
desc: Electrostatics, electric currents, dielectrics, capacitance, electrostatic potential, magnetostatics.
prer: One of MATH 263, MATH 253 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

name: Signals and Systems
desc: Complex numbers, LTI systems, convolution sum, discrete-time Fourier series and transforms, z-transform, sampling, introduction to filtering and modulation, feedback systems, stability.

name: Selected Topics in Biomedical Engineering
desc: Effective communication in a multi-disciplinary environment, introduction to emerging areas of biomedical engineering and biotechnology, ethics, and responsibility. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering program in Electrical Engineering.

name: Technical Communication
desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, BMEG 201 or APSC 201.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio I
desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, and microcomputers.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design Studio
desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, microcomputers with applications in biomedical engineering. Final group project requiring oral presentation of student-prepared slides.

name: Electronic Circuits
desc: Analysis and design of electronic circuits; biasing of and small-signal models for transistors; frequency response of amplifiers; feedback and stability aspects of amplifier design; OP-AMPs; active filters; oscillators; IC specification and selection. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 356, ELEC 301, and EECE 374.
prer: Either (a) one of ELEC 201, ELEC 203 and ELEC 202;  or (b) ELEC 204.

name: Electronic Circuits for Electromechanical Design
desc: Semiconductor fundamentals; modelling of electronic devices including diodes and transistors; design of power supplies, waveform generators and logic circuits; signals in time and frequency domains; operational amplifiers; active filters; oscillators; device specification and selection.

name: Electromagnetic Fields and Waves
desc: Waves and propagation; Maxwell's equations; applications including transmission lines; impedance matching and Smith charts; reflection and refraction; waveguides and antennas.
prer: ELEC 211 and either (a) all of MATH 101, MATH 263, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 264, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (c) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256, MATH 264.

name: Electronic Materials and Devices
desc: Fundamental aspects of electronic materials such as: semiconductors, metals, dielectrics, piezoelectrics, magnetic materials, and their applications in devices such as diodes, transistors, and transducers.

name: Stochastic Signals and Systems
desc: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems; discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modelling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making.
prer: One of ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Electrical and Computer Engineering Student Services.

name: Computer Communications
desc: Analysis, design and implementation of computer networks and their protocols. Application layer protocols, transmission control protocol (TCP), Internet protocol (IP), routing algorithms, reliable data transfer, multiple access, Ethernet.

name: Systems and Control
desc: Continuous time system analysis by Laplace transforms; system modelling by transfer function and state space methods; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control design; frequency domain analysis.

name: Electro-Mechanical Energy Conversion and Transmission
desc: Three phase power; transformers and harmonics; magnetic materials and circuits, electromechanical energy conversion; DC machines; rotating magnetic field, AC induction and synchronous machines; variable frequency operation, brushless DC machines; stepper and single-phase motors.

name: Electromechanics
desc: Electromechanical energy conversion; linear actuators; torque/speed of rotating devices; reluctance, stepper, permanent- magnet, induction, brushless-DC motors and DC motors; actuator/motor drive circuits/controllers. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 344, ELEC 342, ELEC 343.

name: Applied Electronics and Electromechanics
desc: Characteristics of semiconductor devices; analog circuits; force and torque production; motor principles and torque-speed characteristics; principles of power electronics. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

name: Electric Energy Systems
desc: Overview of three-phase energy systems. High-voltage transmission, low-voltage distribution. Performance of renewable electricity generation. Grid integration of renewable energy systems.

name: Molecules to Mechanisms
desc: Forces, scaling, thermal, fluidic, and mechanical properties relevant to the design of emerging devices and systems whose basic structures are at micrometer and nanometer scales.

name: Biomedical Engineering Instrumentation
desc: Theory and experiments involving instruments for general, orthopedic, cardiac and minimally invasive surgery as well as sensors for respiratory, cardiac, bioelectric, biochemical and nervous system measurement. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering option in Electrical Engineering and the Biomedical Engineering program. This course is cross-listed with BMEG 321. Credit will only be given for one of ELEC 371 or BMEG 321.
prer: Either (a) all of MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) MATH 256;  and either (a) all of ELEC 202, ELEC 292 or (b) all of BMEG 220, BMEG 257.

name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio II
desc: Introduction to project management.  Problem definition.  Design principles and practices.  Implementation techniques including circuit design, software design, solid modelling, PCBs, assembling, and packaging.  Testing and evaluation.  Effective presentations.
prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292 and two of ELEC 315, ELEC 301, ELEC 341, ELEC 311, ELEC 342.

name: Topics in Electrical Engineering
desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

name: Analog CMOS Integrated Circuit Design
desc: Design and analysis of analog integrated circuits, with emphasis on CMOS design techniques. Gain stages, opamp design, frequency compensation, oscillators, A/D, D/A converters, PLL, DLL.

name: Introduction to VLSI Systems
desc: Static CMOS combinational logic circuits. Standard cells design and layout. Memory element (flip-flop and latch) design. Dynamic logic families. Synchronous logic and timing analysis. Power, scaling, and industry trends. Verification. VHDL/Verilog design, layout and synthesis project using CAD tools.

name: Advanced Digital VLSI Systems
desc: Logical effort. Noise in digital systems. Low power techniques. Power distribution. SRAM and DRAM design. Non-volatile memory technologies. High speed adder, multiplier and divider design. Clock Trees. Synchronization and FIFO. Scaling, and industry trends. High-speed circuit design and layout project.

name: RF Integrated Circuits
desc: Introduction to radio-frequency (RF) communication systems; matching networks, transceiver architectures, low noise amplifiers, mixers, oscillators, etc.

name: Antennas and Propagation
desc: Basic antenna concepts; antennas for low, medium and high frequencies; terrestrial and satellite propagation links; environmental effects on electromagnetic radiation.

name: Optical Waveguides and Photonics
desc: Planar dielectric waveguides; single mode optical fibers; integrated optics waveguides and devices; resonators; transfer matrix methods; optical communications links.

name: Semiconductor Lasers
desc: An introduction to lasers and applications. Theory, modelling, fabrication and performance of semiconductor lasers. Optical communications links.

name: Semiconductor Devices: Physics, Design and Analysis
desc: Physics of operation, and design and analysis of semiconductor devices of topical interest, e.g., solar cells, LEDs, high-speed MOSFETs, high-frequency HBTs, low-noise HEMTs.

name: Quantum Dots and Device Applications
desc: Theory and modelling techniques of 0-dimensional structures. Electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of quantum dots. Current and future applications of quantum dots including: single electron transistors, quantum dot lasers, optical detectors.

name: Digital Signal and Image Processing
desc: DSP fundamentals; image processing; signal representation; digital filtering; statistical estimation; DSP applications.

name: Biosignals and Systems
desc: Data acquisition, time and frequency domain analysis, analog and discrete filter design, sampling theory, time-dependent processing, linear prediction, random signals, biomedical system modelling, and stability analysis; introduction to nonlinear systems.
prer: All of ELEC 371, ELEC 341, ELEC 221 and one of CPSC 260, CPSC 259 and one of STAT 251, MATH 318, MATH 302, STAT 302.

name: Communication Systems I
desc: Review of probability theory, signals and noise; digital communication over Gaussian noise channels, optimal receiver design, modulation techniques and error performance calculations; measure of information, source coding, symbol and stream codes; channel coding, capacity, simple linear block codes; practical applications.
prer: ELEC 221 and one of ELEC 321, MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 251, STAT 302, STAT 357.

name: Communication Systems II
desc: Communication over bandlimited additive white Gaussian noise channels; power spectra of digitally modulated signals; intersymbol interference; cyclic, convolutional, low-density parity check and turbo codes; trellis coded modulation; spread spectrum techniques; security; wireless communication systems and standards; practical applications.

name: Error Control Coding for Communications and Computers
desc: Design techniques, including Hamming, BCH, Reed-Solomon, LDPC and convolutional codes, ARQ techniques, and LFSR implementation of encoding-decoding algorithms.

name: Introduction to Optical Networks
desc: Wavelength division multiplexing, framing techniques, traffic grooming, virtual topology design, routing and wavelength assignment, protection and restoration, optical packet switching.

name: Control Systems
desc: Relationships between system parameters and system responses for linear control systems. Design specifications for dynamic and steady-state performance and realization by use of feedback control. Robust design of PID controllers and multivariable controllers.

name: Introduction to Robotics
desc: Common manipulator configurations, actuator and sensor technology. Efficient representations and computational methods for real-time microprocessor-based implementation of robot control algorithms. Robot control methods, network equivalents, impedance control. Introduction to teleoperation implementation aspects.

name: Power Electronics
desc: Power diodes, thyristors, transistors and FETs; analysis of idealized circuits with generalized loads; AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC converters, modulation techniques, gating circuits; practical design and applications.

name: Industrial Drives
desc: Typical mechanical loads; dynamic and static characteristics and analysis of DC and AC drives; microprocessor-based controllers; commercial choices of drives for various applications.

name: Power System Analysis
desc: Transmission and distribution; phasors, complex power; balanced/unbalanced three-phase operation; symmetrical components, sequence networks; voltage regulation; short circuit capacity; circuit breakers; transmission lines, series/shunt impedance; short, medium, and long line models.

name: Power System Analysis II
desc: Power system monitoring/control; large networks; automatic generation control; optimum power flow calculations; traveling wave transmission lines; EMTP and MATLAB programs for transients, short-circuit, and transient stability analysis.

name: Power Systems Protection
desc: Analysis of disturbances, security of power systems, cascading and blackouts; role and impact of protection; transducers and measuring elements; protection of transmission and distribution systems; protection of generators, substation equipment, special protection systems and relays.

name: Decision Support Methods in Power Systems Operation
desc: Principles; acceptable regions of operation; energy management systems; load flow methods; static and dynamic security; contingency analysis; transient and voltage stability; online stability assessment.

name: Optimization of Power System Operation
desc: Application of linear and nonlinear optimization methods in power systems; constrained optimization; optimal power flow; economic dispatch; electricity market; local prices for active and reactive power; security-constrained OPF; state estimation, reliability analysis.

name: Nanotechnology in Electronics
desc: Topics of special importance to understanding and designing electronic devices in which quantum effects and the discrete nature of matter become important.
prer: One of CHEM 312, ELEC 315, PHYS 250, PHYS 304.

name: Sensors and Actuators in Microsystems
desc: The mechanisms, design, fabrication, and testing of microsensors, actuators, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

name: Micro/Nanofabrication and Instrumentation Laboratory
desc: Microfabrication methods and nanofabrication techniques. Imaging and characterization of micro and nanostructures

name: Nanotechnology and Nature
desc: Examples of nature's fabrication methods, sensors, actuators, energy harvesting, signaling and information processing, and comparisons with artificial methods.

name: Microsystems Design
desc: Structured modelling and design practices; multiphysics at microscales; physical limitations in MEMS; interface with electronics; behavioural modelling languages for mixed analog-digital system design. Credit will only be given for one of ELEC 465, or EECE 581.

name: Medical Imaging
desc: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics, and interventions.
prer: All of ELEC 371, ELEC 341, ELEC 311, ELEC 221.

name: Biomechatronics
desc: Design of mechatronic systems to measure and manipulate biological materials and processes; compliant structures; bioelectronic circuits; biomedical embedded systems and BioMEMS.  Example applications from clinical medicine and biomedical research.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 423 or EECE 472.
prer: All of ELEC 201, ELEC 202, CPEN 211, ELEC 341.

name: Biological Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems
desc: Principles of sensors, actuators, microfluidics, biotechnology and nanotechnology, with applications in probing, detection, assaying and drug delivery.

name: Biophotonics
desc: Lens theory, light sources and detectors, image resolution and contrast, tissue absorption and scattering, fluorescence, microscopy, spectroscopy, optical imaging systems, and their applications to life sciences and medicine.

name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

name: Electrical Engineering Capstone Design Project
desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real-world electrical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

name: Biomedical Engineering Capstone Design Project
desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world biomedical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

name: Research Experience in Electrical Engineering
desc: Directed research experience. Communication of research ideas. Pass/Fail.

name: Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

name: First-Year Portuguese I
desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

name: First-Year Portuguese II
desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

name: Elementary Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 101 and 102 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 110, PORT 101, or PORT 102.

name: Second-Year Portuguese I
desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

name: Second-Year Portuguese II
desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit may be granted for only one of PORT 202 or PORT 210.

name: Intermediate Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 201 and 202 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 210, PORT 201, or PORT 202.
prer: PORT 110. Heritage speakers who feel ready to enter PORT 210 directly should consult the undergraduate advisor in Portuguese.

name: Introduction to the Analysis of Portuguese and Brazilian Cultures
desc: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. This course is taught in English.

name: Advanced Portuguese
desc: Advanced work in composition for students who have reached the Language-Requirement level of Portuguese.

name: Portuguese for Business (in Portuguese)
desc: Communicative Portuguese for students studying Commerce or otherwise preparing for a career in business.

name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature (in English)
desc: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information.

name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture (In English)
desc: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information.

name: Introduction to Modern Biology
desc: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.  Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB). [3-0-0]

name: Biology of the Cell
desc: The principles of cellular and molecular biology using bacterial and eukaryotic examples. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

name: Genetics, Evolution and Ecology
desc: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. [3-0-0]

name: Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
desc: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions. [1-2-0]

name: Human Biology: Anatomy and Physiology
desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). Laboratories include selected experiments on organ physiology and general anatomy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prer: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

name: Human Biology: Physiology and Introductory Anatomy
desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology).  (physiology and introductory anatomy). Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]
prer: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

name: Fundamentals of Cell Biology
desc: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130;  or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223.

name: Introduction to Biochemistry
desc: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, or BIOC 203. [3-0-1]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.

name: Eukaryotic Microbiology
desc: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution. [3-3-0]
prer: BIOL 140 and one of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. BIOL 200 recommended.

name: Vertebrate Structure and Function
desc: Introduction to the vertebrate phyla and their evolution; a comparative study of vertebrate structure and function, with dissection of representative forms. [3-3-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

name: Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
desc: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates. [3-3-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

name: Biodiversity of Algae, Fungi and Bryophytes
desc: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae. [3-3-0]
prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

name: Vascular Plants
desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology. [3-3-0]
prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 or  8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

name: Fundamentals of Ecology
desc: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

name: Genetics for Life
desc: How genetic differences determine individual characteristics, and how they are inherited, analyzed, and modified. Emphasis on genetic diversity, human ancestry, personal genomics, and cancer genetics. [3-0-2]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001; or (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

name: Fundamentals of Genetics
desc: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001; or (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

name: Fundamentals of Physiology
desc: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.

name: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
desc: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

name: Biomathematics
desc: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

name: Advanced Ecology
desc: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

name: Introduction to Animal Behaviour
desc: Animal behavior from an ecological and evolutionary perspective; the methods used to study behaviour and test its adaptive significance. [3-0-2]

name: Elements of Biodiversity
desc: The units of biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems, how they are structured in space, and their importance to human well-being and ecosystem health. [3-0-0]
prer: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207.

name: Weed Science
desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventative, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

name: Survey of Algae
desc: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology. [3-3-0]

name: Morphology and Evolution of Bryophytes
desc: A study of evolution, taxonomy and morphology of mosses, liverworts and hornworts with emphasis on living plants in their environment. [2-4-0]

name: Structure and Evolution of Ferns and Fern-allies
desc: Anatomy, morphology and relationships of the ferns and fern-allies, with assessment of both fossil and extant taxa. [2-4-0]

name: Structure and Reproduction of Fungi
desc: The evolutionary diversity of the fungi as shown by their morphology and reproductive biology. [2-3-0]

name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

name: Introduction to Animal Mechanics and Locomotion
desc: Comparative aspects of the functional design of skeletal systems and the mechanics of swimming, flying and terrestrial locomotion, with particular reference to the vertebrates. [3-0-0]

name: Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
desc: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field.  Marine emphasis. [1-4-0]

name: Introduction to Entomology
desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations.

name: Introductory Parasitology
desc: Classification, morphology and life histories of animal parasites affecting humans and other animals. [2-3-0]

name: Developmental Biology (Lecture)
desc: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

name: Developmental Biology
desc: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-3-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

name: Protistology
desc: Cell biology, ecology, and evolution of protists; origins of multicellularity; the role of protists in micropaleontology, parasitology, and oceanography. [3-3-0]

name: Molecular Genetics
desc: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics. [3-0-2]
prer: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.

name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
desc: Natural selection; population genetics, quantitative genetics and systematics; classical and molecular approaches to the study of evolution. [3-0-2]

name: Introductory Genetics Laboratory
desc: A laboratory course demonstrating the fundamental principles of inheritance: Mendel's Laws, sex-linkage, mapping, mutagenesis, chromosome structure, developmental biology, biochemical and population genetics. [1-4-0]

name: Introduction to Genomics
desc: An introduction to genome biology and applications of genomics. [3-0-1.5]

name: Introductory Cell Biology Laboratory
desc: Experiments using unicellular eukaryotes or prokaryotes with emphasis on techniques in microscopy and cell biology. [1-3-0]
prer: All of BIOL 140, BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.

name: Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
desc: Use of recombinant DNA techniques. [1*-4-0]
prer: BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.

name: Integrative Biology Laboratory
desc: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms. [1-3-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology; and third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science.

name: Plants and Peoples
desc: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students. [2-2-1]

name: Human Heredity and Evolution
desc: Relates genetic and evolutionary concepts to humans. Primarily for upper-level students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. Not open to students in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

name: Human Ecology
desc: Basics of ecology are introduced, focussing on observations of the natural world. Assignments, including a group project, consider connections between research, awareness and practical uses of ecology. Not for credit in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

name: Microbes and Society
desc: An elementary course in molecular biology primarily for Arts students. The historical development of recent discoveries in molecular biology with emphasis on bacteria and viruses and their interaction with humans. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Not for credit in Life Sciences. [3-0-0]

name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
desc: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449. [2-3-0]

name: Plant Physiology I
desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology. [3-3-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130;  or (b) SCIE 001. CHEM 233 is recommended.

name: Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
desc: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches. [2-3-1]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302. CHEM 233 is recommended.

name: Neural and Muscular Physiology
desc: Excitable membranes, neural signaling and transmission; transduction and coding of sensory information; muscle contraction. [3-0-0]

name: Cellular Physiology
desc: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Combined Honours Biophysics. [2-0-1]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of APBI 312, APBI 351, BIOL 260, BIOL 351, BIOL 352, BIOL 361, FRST 311.

name: Laboratory in Animal Physiology
desc: Experimental studies in animal physiology. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology, Nutritional Sciences and Combined Honours Biophysics. [1-3-1]

name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Combined Honours Biophysics. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

name: Principles of Muscle Physiology and Energetics
desc: Introduction to the structure and function of the muscular system, metabolism and energetics from a comparative perspective across vertebrates and invertebrates. [3-0-0]

name: Principles of Neurobiology I
desc: Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system, excitable membranes, and synaptic signaling using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species. [3-0-0]

name: Principles of Neurobiology II
desc: Examination of the neural systems underlying sensation, action, and complex behaviours using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species. [3-0-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Work experience in an industrial setting, taken during Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Theory of Evolutionary Dynamics
desc: Evolution as a dynamical system based on ecological interactions. Adaptive dynamics and evolutionary game theory. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 401 or BIOL 560.
prer: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

name: Aquatic Ecology
desc: Theoretical and applied limnology; ecology of inland water organisms in relation to physical, chemical and biological factors. One weekend field trip required. [2-4-0]
prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

name: Microbial Ecology
desc: Theoretical and applied ecology of microbes. Focus on microbial symbionts of animals, plants and seaweeds.  Research project development through critical analysis of microbial ecological literature and computational analysis of ecological data.
prer: BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200. Fourth-year standing.

name: Ecological Methodology
desc: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data. [2-4-0]
prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

name: Plant Ecology I
desc: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data. [3-3-0]

name: Principles of Applied Ecology
desc: Principles of animal and community ecology applicable to the management of animal resources; application of statistical and computer techniques for measuring, analyzing, modelling, and simulating resource systems; problems of multiple resource use. [2-2-0]

name: Field Course in Ecology
desc: A two-week intensive course in field methods used in ecology. Fieldwork for this course is normally in the summer. A fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration required.
prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. BIOL 306 is recommended.

name: Current Topics in Animal Behaviour
desc: Lectures and seminar discussions on selected topics in animal behaviour. [2-0-2]
prer: BIOL 310. Permission of the head of Zoology is also acceptable.

name: Insect Ecology
desc: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0-0]

name: Phytogeography
desc: Description and interpretation of present and past floristic vegetational patterns; integration of evolutionary, ecological, and phytogeographical concepts. Terrestrial and aquatic plants are considered. Restricted to students of third and fourth years. [3-0-0]

name: Zoogeography
desc: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year. [3-0-0]

name: Evolutionary Processes in Plants
desc: Experimental and comparative analysis of evolutionary processes, speciation, and phylogenetic patterns in plants. [2-0-0]

name: Principles of Conservation Biology
desc: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-0-2]

name: Phylogenetic Biology
desc: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology. [2-0-2]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. BIOL 336 is recommended

name: Evolutionary Ecology
desc: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations. [2-2-0]

name: Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
desc: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.

name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-0-2]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

name: Plant Stress Ecophysiology
desc: Molecular mechanisms of plant responses to extreme environments. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

name: Tropical Ecology and Conservation
desc: Ecology, function, history and conservation of tropical systems. Focus on ecological and evolutionary principles using tropical landscapes as a geographic template. Assessment of factors that make tropical systems vulnerable to degradation. Research project development using analysis of tropical ecology literature. [2-0-2]
prer: BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOS 207, GEOB 207.

name: Biomechanics
desc: An analytical approach to the study of skeletal mechanics and animal locomotion. Selected topics in the structure and properties of biological materials, the functional design of skeletons for locomotion, and the fluid mechanics of swimming and flight. [2-3-0]

name: Mammalogy
desc: Natural history, behavioral ecology and conservation of terrestrial mammals. The laboratory includes classification, life histories, and ecology, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

name: Ornithology and Herpetology
desc: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles.  Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

name: Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
desc: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective.  Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages. [3-0-0]

name: Genome Evolution
desc: Integration of molecular genetics and genomics with evolutionary biology. Emphasis on the evolutionary dynamics of genomes and the evolutionary implications of recent discoveries in molecular genetics and genomics. [3-0-0]

name: Evolutionary Cell Biology
desc: Ultrastructure, biogenesis, and evolution of eukaryotic cells and cell organelles, including their macromolecular basis. [3-0-0]

name: Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
desc: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. And fourth-year standing.

name: Plant Genetics
desc: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering. [3-0-2]

name: Population Genetics
desc: Theoretical and experimental aspects of population and quantitative genetics. [3-0-2]
prer: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302.

name: Integrated Functional Genomics
desc: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests. [3-0-0]

name: Laboratory in Animal Cell Molecular Biology
desc: The use of recombinant DNA techniques to explore problems in animal developmental biology. [2-4-0]
prer: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.

name: Zoological Physics
desc: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0]
prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended.

name: Plant Genomics
desc: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants. [3-0-0]

name: Cell Biology of Intracellular Trafficking
desc: Analysis of cellular organelles and the intracellular traffic between them, concentrating on mammalian cell systems. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362.

name: Techniques in Plant Molecular Biology
desc: Purification and analysis of nucleic acids, electrophoresis and immunodetection of proteins. Restricted to Honours students with permission of the Head of Botany and the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory. [0-7-0]

name: Darwin's Fishes
desc: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public. [2-0-2]
prer: Third-year standing in Science is required.

name: History and Philosophy of Biology
desc: The nature of science, this history of evolutionary and molecular biology, philosophical questions about scientific methods and fundamental conclusions of biology. [3-0-0]
prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program is required.

name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
desc: Seminars, debates, workshops and tutorials designed to produce competence in specific areas of Biology. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. [2-3-0]

name: Directed Studies in Biology
desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

name: Directed Biological Research
desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required.

name: Molecular Adaptation of Animals to the Environment
desc: Physiological, biochemical, and molecular strategies of adaptation of animals to environmental challenges.  The evolution of genetic and biochemical systems, and their impact on animal structure and function. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 457 is recommended.

name: Comparative Animal Physiology
desc: Selected topics in physiology emphasizing comparisons between diverse phylogenetic groups of animals. [3-0-0]

name: Comparative Neurobiology
desc: Current approaches in neurobiology, from the cellular to the behavioural level, are examined using representatives of vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems. [3-0-2*]
prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.

name: Comparative and Molecular Endocrinology
desc: A comparative study of vertebrate and invertebrate endocrinology. [3-0-0]

name: Comparative Environmental Physiology
desc: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments. [3-0-0]

name: Developmental Neurobiology
desc: Cellular, molecular and physiological aspects of nervous system development with applications to understanding adult nervous system function and neurological disorders. [3-0-0]

name: Neurobiology of Sensory and Motor Systems
desc: Analysis of the mechanisms of sensory processing and motor orchestration using vertebrate and invertebrate model systems.  Neural circuit structure, specialization, information coding, integration, and behaviour. [3-0-0]

name: Neurobiology of Vision
desc: Advanced investigation of animal vision; critical analysis of recent literature and research project development in visual neurobiology. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 372, CAPS 301, PSYC 304, PSYC 367, PSYC 370.

name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
prer: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201. BIOL 209 or BIOL 210 is recommended.

name: Gene Regulation in Development
desc: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 331 is recommended.

name: Animal Developmental Genetics
desc: Role of genes in embryonic development.  Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types. [3-0-0]

name: Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
desc: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity. [2-3-0]

name: Applied Biology of Fishes
desc: Physiological ecology and exploitation biology of teleost fishes; computer-based analysis and modeling of fish populations.

name: Student Directed Seminars
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Normally not suitable as a specific BIOL program elective. [3-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Introductory Psychology
desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, biopsychology, learning, perception, memory, cognition, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology.  Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 or PSYC 101 and 102.

name: Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
desc: Introduction to Methods and Statistics, Biopsychology, Learning, Perception, Memory, and Cognition. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 101.

name: Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.

name: Contemporary Issues in Psychology
desc: Topics include addiction, culture and evolution in social behaviour, personal relationships, pro- and anti-social behaviour, judgment and decision-making, prejudice and discrimination. Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

name: Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology
desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.

name: Contemporary Topics in Social, Developmental, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in social, developmental, personality, and clinical psychology.

name: Questioning Psychological Science in the Media
desc: Use basic principles of quantitative psychological research methods to critique psychological claims presented in the media and to translate psychological science to everyday life. Intended for non-psychology majors to prepare for upper level courses. Majors should take PSYC 217 instead.

name: Research Methods
desc: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department). Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 217 or PSYC 277.
crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

name: Analysis of Behavioural Data
desc: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. PSYC 218 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 218 or PSYC 278.
prer: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 277. And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.
crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

name: Experimental Psychology and Laboratory
desc: Detailed introduction to experimental and theoretical aspects of motivation, sensation, perception and learning. Course no longer offered. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 260 or PSYC 270.
prer: Completion of first-year Science program and permission of the department head is also required.
crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

name: Contemporary Issues in Behavioural Neuroscience
desc: Contemporary issues in behavioural neuroscience. Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Behavioural Neuroscience
desc: Foundational topics in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 260 or PSYC 270.
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140;  or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.

name: Introduction to Behavioural Neuroscience (Lecture)
desc: Foundational topics in behavioural neuroscience.
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 130. And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.

name: Introduction to Behavioural Neuroscience (Laboratory)
desc: Guided laboratory investigations in behavioural neuroscience.

name: Behavioural and Neuroscientific Research Methods (Lecture)
desc: Research methods used in behavioural neuroscience.
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 130. And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.

name: Behavioural and Neuroscientific Research Methods (Laboratory)
desc: Guided applications of research methods used in behavioural neuroscience.

name: Analysis of Behavioural and Neuroscientific Data (Lecture)
desc: Statistical methods for use in behavioural neuroscience.

name: Behavioural and Neuroscientific Research Methods
desc: Research methods used in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 217 or PSYC 277.
prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140;  or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.

name: Analysis of Behavioural and Neuroscientific Data
desc: Statistical methods for use in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 218 or PSYC 278.

name: Abnormal Psychology
desc: The definition, history, and scope of abnormal behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 227.

name: Brain Dysfunction and Recovery
desc: Cognitive and behavioral impairments resulting from brain dysfunction. Focus on the efficacy of various intervention approaches.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Infancy
desc: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Tests and Measurements
desc: Theory and practice of psychological measurement, statistical models for items and tests, assessment of test reliability and validity, factor analysis, scoring.

name: Brain and Behaviour
desc: The neurobiological bases of behaviour; brain processes involved in perception, motivation, emotion, psychopathology, learning and memory. Open to all Arts and Science majors except those in the B.Sc. Psychology program. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 304 or PSYC 360.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and one of PSYC 216, or either PSYC 217 or 277, or either PSYC 260 or 270.

name: Personality Psychology
desc: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277

name: Principles of Animal Behaviour
desc: Behavioural neuroscience; behavioural genetics; social systems; mating and parental strategies; instinct and learning; evolution of human behaviour. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 310 or PSYC 306.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Cultural Psychology
desc: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Social Psychology
desc: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Cognitive Processes
desc: Contribution of cognitive processes to perception, attention, and memory; cognitive development, language, thinking, and creativity.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Psychology of Sport
desc: Psychological theory, research, and skills training related to sport performance, exercise motivation, and adherence. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 311 and KIN 150 and 231.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: History of Psychology
desc: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Health Psychology
desc: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277

name: Childhood and Adolescence
desc: Human development from the preschool period through adolescence.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Applied Developmental Psychology
desc: Applications of theories and research in developmental psychology to contemporary social issues; topics may include daycare, child abuse, divorce and remarriage, substance abuse, sexuality.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Psychology of Sex Differences
desc: Theory and research on gender development and the influence of sex and/or gender on cognition, emotion, motivation, social behaviour, and health.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Environmental Psychology
desc: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.

name: Adulthood and Aging
desc: Issues, theories, and psychological research regarding adulthood and the aging process.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Socialization: Media Content and Effects
desc: Examines human development in the context of the socializing role of media.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Forensic Psychology
desc: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
desc: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277. Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 420 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.

name: Memory II
desc: Organic amnesia; remembering childhood events; the self and memory; and the problem of distinguishing genuine from simulated forgetting.

name: Gambling and Decision Making
desc: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: The Psychology of Language I
desc: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.

name: The Psychology of Language II
desc: Language and thought; deriving psychological principles from language universals; the psychology of literacy, dyslexia, multilingualism, and natural language processing.
prer: PSYC 336 or permission of the instructor.

name: Directed Studies in Psychology
desc: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience
desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102;  and all of PSYC 217,  218. Restricted to students in Honours.

name: Psychological Aspects of Human Sexuality
desc: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Evolutionary Psychology
desc: Theory and research on the evolution of the human mind, with emphasis on implications for cognition and behaviour in contemporary environments.
prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.

name: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
desc: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
prer: Either (a) one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278;  or (b) PSYC 366.

name: Biopsychology
desc: The relationship between the nervous system and behaviour; the physiological basis of perception, motivation, learning, and memory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. Course no longer offered.

name: Neuroscience of Motivation
