desc: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, contour integration, Laurent series, residues, integrals of multi-valued functions, Fourier transforms. See Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.
crer: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

name: Applied Linear Algebra
desc: Applications of linear algebra to problems in science and engineering; use of computer algebra systems for solving problems in linear algebra. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.

name: Euclidean Geometry
desc: Classical plane geometry, solid geometry, spherical trigonometry, polyhedra, linear and affine transformations. Linear algebra proofs are used. It is suggested that MATH 307 be taken concurrently. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121;  or (b) MATH 223.

name: Topics in Geometry
desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These may include conic sections, projective configuration, convexity, non-Euclidean geometries, fractal geometry, combinatorial problems of points in the plane. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121;  or (b) MATH 223.

name: Abstract Linear Algebra
desc: Linear spaces, duality, linear mappings, matrices, determinant and trace, spectral theory, Euclidean structure. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

name: Introduction to Number Theory
desc: Euclidean algorithm, congruences, Fermat's theorem, applications. Some diophantine equations. Distribution of the prime numbers. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226, CPSC 121 and 9 additional credits of mathematics courses.

name: Topics in Number Theory
desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These might include: division algorithms, group theory, continued fractions, primality testing, factoring.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

name: Elementary Differential Equations II
desc: Power series methods (ordinary and regular singular points, Bessel's equation); boundary value problems and separation of variables (Fourier series and other orthogonal series), applications to the vibrating string, heat flow, potentials. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

name: Calculus IV
desc: Parametrizations, inverse and implicit functions, integrals with respect to length and area; grad, div, and curl, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253. One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 is recommended.

name: Probability with Physical Applications
desc: Random variables, discrete and continuous distributions. Random walk, Markov chains, Monte Carlo methods. Characteristic functions, limit laws. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.
crer: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

name: Introduction to Real Analysis
desc: Ideas and methods of real analysis and their application. Countability and topology of the reals; convergence, continuity and differentiability of functions; metric spaces. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 220 or (b) a score of 55% or higher in one of MATH 223, MATH 226.

name: Real Variables I
desc: The real number system; real Euclidean n-space; open, closed, compact, and connected sets; Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem; sequences and series. Continuity and uniform continuity. Differentiability and mean-value theorems. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

name: Real Variables II
desc: The Riemann or Riemann-Stieltjes integrals. Sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence. Approximation of continuous functions by polynomials. Fourier series. Functions from R

name: Introduction to Group Theory
desc: Groups, cosets, homomorphisms, group actions, p-groups, Sylow theorems, composition series, finitely generated Abelian groups. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 223, MATH 310 or (b) one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

name: Introduction to Rings and Modules
desc: Rings, ideals, unique factorization, Euclidean rings, fields, polynomial rings, modules; structure theory of modules over a principal ideal domain. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Mathematics
desc: Intensive course with required tutorial. Combinatorics, probability, geometry and elementary number theory. Not for credit in the Faculty of Science. Students who obtain credit at UBC for any other mathematics course cannot in the same or later years obtain credit for MATH 335. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

name: Introduction to Linear Programming
desc: Linear programming problems, dual problems, the simplex algorithm, solution of primal and dual problems, sensitivity analysis. Additional topics chosen from: Karmarkar's algorithm, non-linear programming, game theory, applications. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics
desc: Introduction to ideas and methods of discrete mathematics and their application. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

name: Algebra and Coding Theory
desc: Error-correcting codes via abstract and linear algebra.  Emphasis on proofs and computation.  Finite fields, Hamming distance and error-correction, upper and lower bounds on the size of a code, linear codes, groups and cosets, encoding and decoding schemes. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121;  or (b) MATH 223.

name: Mathematical Game Theory
desc: Introduction to mathematical game theory and its applications. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121;  or (b) MATH 223.

name: Applied Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
desc: Phase plane methods, bifurcation and stability theory, limit-cycle behavior and chaos for nonlinear differential equations with applications to the sciences.  Assignments involve the use of computers. [3-1-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

name: Engineering Analysis
desc: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra;  discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing applications emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 or MATH 358. [3-2*-0]

name: Mathematical Modelling in Science
desc: Principles of model selection and basic modelling techniques in biology, earth science, chemistry and physics. Optimization, dynamical systems and stochastic processes. Preference will be given to Combined Major in Science students, or to students in Year 3 or higher. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Biology
desc: Mathematical modelling of basic biological processes in ecology, physiology, neuroscience and genetics. Dynamic behavior of difference equations, differential equations, and partial differential equations, explained with reference to concrete biological examples. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 301, MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

name: Applied Partial Differential Equations
desc: Separation of variables, first order equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transform methods. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

name: Green's Functions and Variational Methods
desc: Green's functions for partial differential equations. Calculus of variations. Eigenfunction expansions. Rayleigh-Ritz and finite element methods.  See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312 or (b) MATH 400.

name: Calculus of Variations
desc: Classical variational problems; necessary conditions of Euler, Weierstrass, Legendre, and Jacobi; Erdmann corner conditions, transversality, convex Lagrangians, fields of extremals, sufficient conditions for optimality, numerical methods; applications to classical mechanics, engineering and economics. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320.

name: Stabilization and Optimal Control of Dynamical Systems
desc: Dynamical systems; stability by Liapunov's direct method; controllability and eigenvalue assignment for autonomous linear systems; linear-quadratic regulator, time optimal control, Pontryagin maximum principle, dynamic programming; applications in engineering, economics and resource management. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320. MATH 402 is recommended.

name: Harmonic Analysis I
desc: Harmonic analysis on Euclidean spaces, with applications to number theory, partial differential equations and geometric measure theory. [3-0-0]
prer: MATH 300 and a score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

name: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
desc: Interpolation, numerical integration, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. Practical computational methods emphasized and basic theory developed through simple models. See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

name: Variational and Approximate Methods in Applied Mathematics
desc: Variational and Green's function methods for ordinary and partial differential equations, introduction to finite difference, finite element and boundary element methods.  See Faculty of Science Credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 307, CPSC 302 and either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312 or (b) MATH 400.

name: Advanced Linear Algebra
desc: Topics include decompositions of linear operators, multi linear algebra, bilinear forms, metric spaces. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of MATH 320, MATH 322.

name: Mathematical Demonstrations
desc: Students will prepare material illustrating ideas and applications of mathematics and present it to audiences outside the University. Intended for third or fourth year Mathematics students and Math/Science Education students. [2-0-0; 1-0-0] or [3-0-0]

name: Probability
desc: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectation, conditional probabilities, convergence of random variables, generating and characteristic functions, weak and strong laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

name: Stochastic Processes
desc: Random walks, Markov chains, branching processes, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion. [3-0-0]

name: Real Analysis I
desc: Sigma-algebras, Lebesgue measure, Borel measures, measurable functions, integration, convergence theorems, L
prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

name: Real Analysis II
desc: Banach spaces, linear operators, bounded and compact operators, strong, weak, and weak* topology.  Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems.  Hilbert spaces, symmetric and self-adjoint operators, spectral theory for bounded operators. [3-0-0]

name: Fields and Galois Theory
desc: Field extensions, the Galois correspondence, finite fields, insolvability in radicals, ruler and compass constructions, additional topics chosen by instructor. [3-0-0]

name: Commutative Algebra
desc: Commutative algebra; homological algebra or representation theory of finite groups. [3-0-0]
prer: MATH 323 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 412, MATH 422.

name: Classical Differential Geometry
desc: The differential geometry of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space. Mean curvature and Gaussian curvature. Geodesics. Gauss's Theorema Egregium. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 223 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 152, MATH 221;  and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 227 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 217, MATH 254, MATH 264, MATH 317.

name: Introduction to Modern Differential Geometry
desc: Riemannian manifolds, tensors and differential forms, curvature and geodesics. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Topology
desc: General topology, combinatorial topology, fundamental group and covering spaces, topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of MATH 321, MATH 322.

name: Topics in Topology
desc: Homology theory, homotopy theory, manifolds, and other topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0]

name: Mathematical Classical Mechanics I
desc: Newton's equation, conservation laws, the Euler-Lagrange equation; Hamilton's principle of least action, Hamilton's equations, Lagrangian mechanics on manifolds. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of PHYS 216, PHYS 306, ENPH 270.

name: Special Topics in Analysis
desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

name: Special Topics in Algebra
desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

name: Number Theory
desc: Divisibility, congruences, Diophantine equations, arithmetic functions, quadratic reciprocity, advanced topics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

name: Complex Analysis
desc: The residue theorem, the argument principle, conformal mapping, the maximum modulus principle, harmonic functions, representation of functions by integrals, series, and products. Other topics at the discretion of the instructor. [3-0-0]
prer: MATH 300 and a score of 68% or higher in MATH 320.

name: Mathematical Modelling: Discrete Optimization Problems
desc: Formulation of real-world optimization problems using techniques such as linear programming, network flows, integer programming, dynamic programming. Solution by appropriate software. [3-0-0]

name: Graphs and Networks
desc: Graph theory, emphasizing trees, tree growing algorithms, and proof techniques. Other topics chosen from shortest paths, maximum flows, minimum cost flows, matchings, and graph colouring. [3-0-0]
prer: 3rd year standing and one of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226 or CPSC 221.

name: Graph Theory
desc: Introductory course in mostly non-algorithmic topics including: planarity and Kuratowski's theorem, graph colouring, graph minors, random graphs, cycles in graphs, Ramsey theory, extremal graph theory. Proofs emphasized. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]
prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226, CPSC 121. And 6 credits of MATH numbered 300 or above.

name: Mathematical Research and Writing
desc: Current research topics in pure and applied mathematics are explored at the undergraduate level.  Technical communication and research skills are developed. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 226 and 6 credits of MATH courses numbered 300 or higher.

name: Topics in the History of Mathematics I
desc: Historical development of concepts and techniques in areas chosen from Geometry, Number Theory, Algebra, Calculus, Probability, Analysis. The focus is on historically significant writings of important contributors and on famous problems of Mathematics. [3-0-0]

name: Directed Studies in Mathematics
desc: Introduction to the methods of mathematical research through an exploration of a mathematical topic under the supervision of a faculty member.  Written report required. [3-0-0]
prer: Third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department Head.

name: Honours Reading
desc: Independent reading by Honours students in Mathematics under the direction of a faculty member. Written report required.

name: Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods
desc: Asymptotic expansions. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals; WKBJ methods. Regular and singular expansions. Boundary layer theory; matched asymptotic expansions. Multiple scale techniques. [3-0-0]

name: Projects in Mathematical Biology
desc: Development and analysis of mathematical models for complex systems in ecology, evolution, cell biology, neurophysiology, and other biological and medical disciplines. [3-0-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

name: Counselling for Maternity Care Providers
desc: Theory, knowledge, strategies, and skills of person-centered counselling including family systems, trauma theory, theory, grief counselling, motivational interviewing skills, self-awareness and mindfulness, interprofessional communication, and cultural competency in continuity of care.

name: Birth and its Meaning
desc: An interdisciplinary study of pregnancy and childbirth drawing on and integrating the disciplines of psychology, sociology, philosophy of science, anthropology, women's studies, and cultural studies.

name: Applied Health Services for Maternity Providers
desc: Introduction to diagnostics related to cellular and humoral immune responses in pregnant women and newborns, the properties of viruses, epidemiology, the principles of bacterial pathogenesis, and related physiologic responses.

name: Lactation Consultation for Maternity Care Providers
desc: Breastfeeding physiology, pathophysiology, and strategies for support of the dyad based on best-practice principles.  Discussion of major Canadian and international initiatives for the support and protection of breastfeeding.

name: Reproductive Anatomy and Physiology
desc: Physiology of conception, pregnancy, lactation, fetal growth, labour, birth, transition to extra-uterine life, postpartum. A series of lectures and lab sessions.

name: Physical Assessment
desc: Principles of physical assessment, physical and psychological assessment of the mother and neonate. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.

name: Foundations for Midwifery Practice
desc: Scope of practice of a midwife, regulatory framework, skills for basic midwifery practice. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.

name: Research Methods for Midwives
desc: Research designs used in midwifery research, types of studies reported in the midwifery and health care literature, research methodology and basic principles of epidemiology, biostatistics and social research.

name: Midwifery and Social Justice
desc: Social justice frameworks and issues as they pertain to individuals' engagement with health care systems. Draws on various disciplines, including sociology, anthropology, gender studies, and cultural studies.

name: Pharmacology for Maternity Care Providers
desc: An overview of basic concepts in pharmacology, pharmacy, and therapeutics relevant to the practice of midwifery in Canada.

name: Introduction to Midwifery Clinical Care
desc: Clinical care of women experiencing normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium.  Clinical education experiences in preventative and therapeutic midwifery care with emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  Clinical practice education opportunities within the province.  Pass/Fail.

name: Clinical Skills for Midwifery Practice
desc: Online situation-based learning tutorials occurring simultaneously with MIDW 200 clinical placement.

name: Evidence-Informed Midwifery
desc: Principles of evidence-informed midwifery, what counts as evidence? Making sense of the evidence, applying the evidence in practice.

name: Ethics in Maternity Care
desc: Ethics using ethical theory in health care and midwifery.

name: Midwifery Theory for Primary Care
desc: Care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an empahsis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  Inludes a four-week intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and simulation and skills lab practice.

name: Core Midwifery Clinical Care
desc: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an emphasis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  A clinical practicum in locations around the provice.  Pass/Fail.

name: Midwifery Theory for Variations in Primary Care
desc: Theoretical principles of care for pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside of normal.  Consists of a one-week intensive time in Vancouver, during which emergency skills certification is acquired, and weekly web-based tutorials. [3-4-3]

name: Senior Research Project
desc: An original piece of scholarship that builds on knowledge and skills acquired from coursework and in consultation with faculty mentors. This self-directed course can be taken in year 1, 2, or 3 of the Program.
prer: Exemption from or completion of MIDW 115.

name: Variations in Midwifery Clinical Care
desc: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside normal.  A 12-week practicum in locations around the province.  Pass/Fail.

name: Midwifery Primary Care
desc: Clinical course focusing on consolidation of skills and knowledge of all aspects of midwifery care.

name: Professional Issues in Midwifery
desc: Professional issues in midwifery including responsibilities and conduct, self-care, peer review, interprofessional relations and communication, legal and business concepts, and continuous quality assurance and improvement in practice.  A series of lectures and workshops delivered in an intensive format over two weeks. [3-0-0]

name: Interprofessional Placement
desc: Opportunities to explore health professions that partner with midwives to care for the childbearing family within the province.  Pass/Fail.

name: Global Maternal Infant Health
desc: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  Theoretical course in preparation for global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

name: Global Clinical Placement
desc: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  A global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

name: Midwifery in Special Contexts
desc: Clinical course providing opportunity to study midwifery in contexts beyond those usually offered on the program. Students select context and provide rationale for how the context will enhance their learning.

name: Advanced Topics in Midwifery Theory and Practice
desc: Theoretical principles for midwifery care of pregnancy, labour, birth, newborns, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on assessment and management skills for abnormal situations.  Includes a five-day intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and lab practice. [1-2-3]

name: Advanced Midwifery Clinical Care
desc: Clinical education for midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an empahsis on abnormal situations in pregnancy, labour and birth, and in newborns.  Clinical practicum around the province.  Pass/Fail.

name: Comprehensive Midwifery Theory and Practice
desc: Theoretical principles and evidence basis for comprehensive midwifery care. Tutorials are carried out in an online live classroom setting.

name: Clinical Clerkship
desc: Students assume a primary care role in clinical placements in midwifery practices across the provinces.  Demonstration of independent decision making and application of the full range of their academic knowledge to professional practice.  A practicum under the supervision of a registered midwife.  Pass/Fail.

name: Midwifery Self-Directed Course
desc: Unique self-directed elective learning opportunities.

name: Introduction to Near Eastern and Egyptian Archaeology
desc: An overview of the past two centuries of archaeological investigations of the civilizations of the ancient Near East and Egypt.

name: Early Empires of the Ancient Middle East
desc: A history from 3100-333 BC with emphasis on Mesopotamia.

name: History of Ancient Egypt
desc: History and culture of Ancient Egyptian civilization from political, intellectual, social and environmental perspectives

name: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharaohs
desc: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire.

name: History of Women in Early to Late Medieval Muslim Societies
desc: Realities of Muslim Women's lives are reconstructed through a critical examination of a variety of literary and material sources.

name: Prehistoric Egypt
desc: A survey of the development and evolution of prehistoric humans and their material culture in Egypt from the Lower Paleolithic to the Chalcolithic.

name: Religion in Ancient Egypt
desc: A survey of the religious beliefs, cults, and religious institutions in Pharaonic Egypt.

name: Introduction to Middle Egyptian
desc: Language of Ancient Egypt and the main literary texts composed during the Middle Kingdom.

name: Introduction to Akkadian
desc: The basic grammar and introduction to the cuneiform writing system of the Akkadian language of the Ancient Near East.

name: Introduction to Coptic
desc: An introduction to Coptic, the language of Christian Egypt from 100 AD.

name: Egyptomania
desc: The adaptation and appropriation of ancient Egypt in ancient and modern art, architecture, film, and music; the development of Egyptology since the 19th century.

name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

name: Materials and Technologies of the Ancient Near East and Egypt
desc: The natural resources and production technologies of the ancient Near East and Egypt.

name: Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
desc: The main genres and texts of Egyptian and Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern Interpretation. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 401 or 505.

name: The Archaeology of the City in the Ancient Near East
desc: The material manifestations of urbanism in the ancient Near East, from the 4th millennium BC up to the 1st millennium BC. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 402 or 506.

name: Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
desc: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

name: Human Anatomy for Physical Therapy Students
desc: Microscopic systems anatomy and regional anatomy of the nervous system. [3-0-0]
prer: Registration in Rehabilitation Sciences (RSPT) is required.

name: Human Anatomy
desc: A correlated course of study for medical and dental students of the structure of the human body including gross and radiological anatomy and embryology. Clinics are held in cooperation with the Departments of Medicine, Orthopaedics, Surgery and Family Practice. Both terms.

name: Microscopic Human Anatomy
desc: A survey course for medical and dental students of the microscopic structure of the human body as studied by light and electron microscopy. Lectures and laboratory sessions. Both terms.

name: Elements of Neuroanatomy
desc: An introduction to the structure of the human nervous system. Given only in conjunction with PHYL 425.  (Open to Medical and Dental students only.)

name: Directed Studies in Anatomy
desc: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

name: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar I
desc: Current topics in the Pharmaceutical Sciences and basic skills for a short presentation on a biological science topic.

name: Biochemical Pharmacology
desc: Biochemical pharmacology including fundamental aspects of enzymology, biochemistry, enzyme kinetics, drug metabolism and pharmacokinetics.

name: Drug Delivery Technologies and Personalized Medicine Theory and Laboratory
desc: Theoretical and practical knowledge of biopharmaceuticals, pharmaceutics, formulations, nanomedicine, and precision medicine as they apply to pharmaceutical sciences.

name: Pharmaceutical Research
desc: Types of research scientists in Academia and Industry undertake across the broad range of Pharmaceutical Science Disciplines.

name: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes I
desc: Population-level study designs and critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice.

name: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar II
desc: Current topics in the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industry and intermediate level skills for a short presentation.

name: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenomics
desc: Basic pharmacokinetic concepts: metabolism, clearance, volume of distribution, half-life, and hepatic clearance. Basic pharmacogenomics concepts of genetic polymorphism.

name: Nanomedicine
desc: Advanced nanomedicine concepts for drug packaging, delivery and efficacy.

name: Biopharmaceutics Theory and Laboratory
desc: Theoretical and practical knowledge of the areas of formulation, drug delivery and biological drugs commonly used in Academic Research as well as the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industries.
prer: All of CHEM 211, CHEM 233, CHEM 235, PHAR 204.

name: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes II
desc: Population-level study designs and their critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice and the practical application of population-level data analysis and interpretation.

name: Medicinal Chemistry of High-Impact Pharmaceuticals in Major Diseases
desc: Structure and mechanism of action of drugs used in the treatment of major chronic diseases: heart disease, cancer, lung disease, and diabetes.

name: Analytical Sciences Theory and Laboratory
desc: Theoretical and practical knowledge of the analytical sciences commonly used in Academic Research as well as the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Industries.
prer: All of CHEM 211, CHEM 233, CHEM 235, PHAR 204.

name: Systematic Pharmacology
desc: General principles of pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics: drug action on nervous, cardiovascular, GI and endocrine systems; beneficial and detrimental effects of drug action.

name: Pharmaceutical Cases I
desc: Application and problem solving in the pharmaceutical sciences. Integration of knowledge and skills from multiple courses to problem solve authentic cases and problems of increasing complexity. Development of self-directed learning skills.

name: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar III
desc: Preliminary skills and concepts for planning, delivering and critiquing a scientific presentation using selected topics in the pharmaceutical sciences.

name: Living Language: Science and Society
desc: Multidisciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prer: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Drug Safety
desc: Pharmacist knowledge and skills in relation to current issues in drug safety.

name: Pharmaceutical Research: From Bench to Bedside and Beyond
desc: Basic, translational, clinical, and community-based research.

name: Topics in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
desc: A study of selected topics in the field of pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics. Registration restricted. Permission of instructor required.

name: Precision Medicine
desc: Skills and concepts in pharmacogenomics as applied to medical practice and dosing.

name: Pharmacoeconomics
desc: Evidence evaluation skills and understanding the role of, and the methods and principles used in, health economics and economic evaluation in healthcare, with a focus on health technology assessment studies.

name: Pharmaceutical Outcomes Research
desc: Principles of qualitative research design. Practical skills in ethics, recruitment, data collection and analysis. Application of epidemiologic and statistical knowledge to a research product in the area of health services outcomes.

name: Financing and Therapeutics in the Canadian Health Care System
desc: Foundation in Canadian health care delivery systems and policies, with a focus on pharmaceutical policy and on comparison with other types of health care systems.

name: Biologics
desc: Biologics as a therapeutic; how biologics are developed as drugs; synthesis and unique properties of biologics as drugs.

name: Advanced Anesthetics and Analgesics
desc: Advanced concepts in anesthetic and analgesic drugs, their uses and abuses.

name: Drug Structures in Medicinal Chemistry
desc: Therapeutically important privileged scaffolds and functional groups, and selectivity achieved through different chemical modifications.

name: Clinical Chemistry
desc: Principles, practices and procedures of medical laboratory clinical chemistry.

name: Adverse Drug Reactions
desc: Molecular and physiological basis of common adverse drug reactions (ADRs). ADRs in the context of current understanding of drug metabolism and pharmacogenetics. New approaches to prediction, detection and treatment.

name: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry
desc: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate enzyme activity.

name: Toxicology
desc: Biochemical, cellular, and molecular processes that govern toxicity elicited by drugs and environmental toxins at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ system levels. Adverse drug reactions and precision medicine approaches to mitigate drug toxicity.

name: Advanced Pharmacokinetics
desc: Polyexponential pharmacokinetics, pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic modeling, pharmacokinetic predictions, physiologically-based pharmacokinetic modeling and population-based pharmacokinetic modeling.

name: Essential Medicinal Chemistry Concepts for Pharmacists
desc: Applying selected chemical concepts to understand drug structure and properties, using frequently encountered drugs as examples. Examining how drugs are used to inhibit enzyme activity.

name: Pharmaceutical Cases II
desc: Advanced application and problem solving in the pharmaceutical sciences. Integration of knowledge and skills from multiple courses to problem solve authentic cases and problems of increasing complexity. Further development and practice of self-directed learning skills.

name: Pharmaceutical Topics and Communication Seminar IV
desc: Senior level skills and concepts for planning, delivering and critiquing a scientific seminar using extended topics in the pharmaceutical sciences and beyond.

name: Research Project
desc: Provides research experience equivalent to one full-time term of work on a defined research project in an area of pharmaceutical research.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Research project and production of a thesis document in an area of pharmaceutical research according to national/international standards.

name: Practicum
desc: Provides practicum experience equivalent to one full-time term of work in a professional area of pharmaceutical research.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmaceutical Sciences
desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation in an area of pharmaceutical research.

name: Elementary Danish I
desc: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Danish courses (DANI 100 and DANI 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (DANI 200 and DANI 210).

name: Elementary Danish II
desc: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Danish courses (DANI 100 and DANI 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (DANI 200 and DANI 210).

name: New Media and Society
desc: Development of new media technologies, their applications, and their cultural, political, and social impacts.

name: Feminist Postcolonial Critique and Journalism in a Digital Age
desc: Feminist postcolonial critique of journalism, and an examination of underlying democratic ideals in a rapidly evolving media landscape.

name: Decoding Social Media
desc: Examines the challenges, opportunities and foundational research related to the emergence of social media platforms, services and tools as part of an evolving media ecosystem. Political, social, ethical and legal implications for media organizations, journalists and citizens.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 12-credits of 300-level courses related to media, technology and/or communications recommended.

name: Introduction to Medieval Studies
desc: A survey of the study of the medieval period in Western Europe (400-1550), integrating history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies Advisor.

name: European Literature from the 5th to the 14th Century
desc: Selected works from the 5th to the 14th centuries in their cultural and social contexts.
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.

name: European Literature from the 14th to the 16th Century
desc: Selected works of the Late Middle Ages and Renaissance in their cultural and social contexts.
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.

name: Topics in Medieval Studies
desc: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

name: Research Seminar in Medieval Studies
desc: An intensive research seminar in a specific period, area, or issue integrating topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

name: Social Issues in Education
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Social and Ethical Considerations in Education
Education, School, and Social Institutions
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Education, Knowledge, and Curriculum
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Ethics and Teaching
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Educational Anthropology
desc: Selected concepts from educational anthropology for teachers. Comparative study of school and classroom culture, school teaching, and multicultural education. Pass/Fail.

name: History of Education
desc: An examination of selected topics in the history of Canadian and British Columbian education and of the relationships between historical development and current educational policy.

name: Philosophy of Education
desc: An introductory course in which consideration is given to the philosophical foundations of education and to the practical bearing of theory upon curriculum content and classroom practice in our schools.

name: The Social Foundations of Education
desc: An application of the social sciences to the study of education. Pass/Fail.

name: Educational Sociology
desc: Selected theories of society and schooling applied to Canadian education.

name: Issues and Frameworks in Environmental Education
desc: Competing conceptions of environmental education; the social construction of nature and of science; addressing class, race, culture, and gender in developing sound teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

name: Gender and Education
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Moral Education in Elementary and Secondary Schooling
desc: Approaches to moral education; developing educationally and morally justifiable teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

name: Critical Thinking: Frameworks, Methods, and Challenges
desc: Competing conceptions of critical thinking, including feminist and post-colonial; teaching and evaluation strategies. Pass/Fail.

name: History of  Childhood and Youth
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Introduction to the Study of Higher Education
desc: An overview of the field of study of higher education in Canada and other countries emphasizing current issues such as accessibility, enrolment, diversity of offerings, and internationalization. [3-0-0]

name: Introductory Workshop
desc: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101. Pass/Fail.

name: Measured Architectural Drawing
desc: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing techniques. Open to all UBC students regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 110 or DES 110.

name: Design Culture and Ecology
desc: Survey of the visual, cultural, ecological and spatial literacies in architectural and urban design.

name: Design Thinking
desc: Design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture and urban design and through hands-on design projects. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will granted for only one of ENDS 231 or DES 200.

name: Design Studio I - Context and Site
desc: Design within the context of various analytical lenses including ecological, climatic, social, political, cultural and historical influences.

name: Design Studio II - Form
desc: Essential processes and methods for thinking in three-dimensional spatial terms.
prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  201.

name: Design Media I
desc: Techniques in architectural drawing, two-dimensional representation, three-dimensional representation and general visual literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 320, ARCH 515 or DES 211.

name: Design Media II
desc: Advanced techniques in architectural representation and discourse in digital representation and digital making. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212.

name: Architecture and Urbanism in Context: Vancouver and its Region
desc: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region. Open enrolment course.  Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 220 or DES 220.

name: Sustainability by Design
desc: Interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 221 or DES 230.

name: Site Analysis and Planning
desc: Analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Credit will be given for only one of DES 231, LARC 440, or LARC 540.

name: Material Culture
desc: An investigation of building materials and associated design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 232 or ARCH 411.

name: Design Studio III - Building Scale Synthesis
desc: Design at the architectural scale through the medium of program and site.
prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  202.

name: Design Studio IV - Vancouver
desc: Vancouver as a laboratory for design at the architectural and urban scale with a focused view into how design is implicated in the social, political, and environmental transformation of the city.
prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  301.

name: Architectural History I
desc: A global history of architecture pre-20th century. Credit will be granted for only one of  DES 321, ARCH 404 or ARCH 505.

name: Architectural History II
desc: A global history of architecture, 20th and 21st century. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 322, ARCH 405, or ARCH 505.

name: Histories in Landscape Architecture
desc: Landscapes from medieval times to the present studied synchronically across design elements as well as chronologically with the development of several key historical concepts.

name: Structural Systems and Supports
desc: Basic structural systems in the built world including wood, steel, concrete, composite systems and essential structural logics of soil retention systems and drainage.

name: Co-operative Education I
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Experiential Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Design Build
desc: Direct hands-on confrontation with the realities of design and construction, engaging in both conventional and unconventional building processes.

name: Design Studio V - Urban Systems Scale Synthesis
desc: Relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure and ecological systems.

name: Design Studio VI - Away
desc: A design project engaged with an international context and site. Emphasis placed on mapping, interpretation of the international context as well as methods of construction, notions of program, and policies, regulations and codes that relate to the site.
prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  401.

name: Senior Design Project
desc: Final design project in the Honours Option with an independently conceived methodology allowing a student the opportunity to pursue his/her own set of interests and concerns.
prer: A score of 80% or higher in DES  401.

name: Design Theory
desc: Introduction to a broad range of theories in architecture and design as they relate to the built environment.

name: Urbanism by Design
desc: A history of the planning, landscape architecture and urban design of cities, and of how ideas have influenced the design of the city.

name: Environment, Urban Form, and Infrastructure
desc: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and infrastructure of livability of cities.

name: Co-operative Education II
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Career Development Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education III
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education IV
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Entrepreneurship and Ethics in Design
desc: Core business skills, building on students' design capabilities to pursue ethical and sustainable design-based business goals.

name: Introduction to Human Occupation
desc: Explores human occupation, conceptualized as all activities people do based on need, obligation, or preference. As the core construct of the discipline of occupational science and practice of occupational therapy, human occupation is examined for its relation to personal and social determinants of health. [3-0-0]

name: Stress and Strategies to Promote Well Being
desc: Introduction to foundational knowledge related to stress, stressors, resilience, social support, and strategies to foster physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual health. Open to all students interested in learning about managing and navigating the stressors of student life.

name: Human Sexual Health
desc: Beliefs, behaviours, and expressions of human sexuality and the link to health for students from any program. How sexuality is discussed and practiced from various perspectives, and strategies to promote healthy sexual expression and sexual health.

name: Health Impacts of Climate Change
desc: Human health impacts of the current and projected environmental crisis; study of key concepts and ideas to prepare for the future to promote wellbeing of individuals, communities and populations.

name: Theoretical and Professional Foundations for Nursing Practice
desc: Introduction to knowledge fundamental to the discipline and practice of nursing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Primary Health Care
desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice in the context of primary health care.
prer: Five of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
desc: Theory informing a life course perspective on nursing practice with people living with mental health challenges and their families is introduced.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Basic Principles of Pharmacology for Nursing Practice
desc: Basic principles of pharmacology and the basic structure and function of each body system will be explored to demonstrate how drug interactions occur within systems.

name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice I
desc: Skills and competencies for clinical practice using a variety of modalities and learning activities.
crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice II
desc: Clinical practice through a variety of modalities and learning activities in the laboratory environment.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: Either (a) all of NURS 345, NURS 365 or (b) all of NURS 346, NURS 366 or (c) all of NURS 303, NURS 363 or (d) all of NURS 301, NURS 362.

name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice III
desc: Skills and competencies for clinical practice across the lifespan and health care continuum through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Adults/Older Adults and their Families
desc: Fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to nursing practice with adults/older adults and their families.
crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and Their Families
desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to acute care nursing practice with adults/older adults and their families.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Critical Inquiry and Leadership Synthesis
desc: Evidence is examined and synthesized to understand and identify theoretical insights to address a leadership challenge in professional practice.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Childbearing Individuals and their Families
desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with childbearing individuals and families during the transition to parenthood in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: One of NURS 322, NURS 401 and NURS 365.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Infants, Children, Youth and their Families
desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with infants, children, youth and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: One of NURS 322, NURS 401 and NURS 366.

name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Health Care Practice
desc: The significance of critical inquiry and research in nursing and health care, and the fundamental concepts and processes pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based practice, and research utilization in nursing. Students who take NURS 350 cannot earn credit for NURS 305, NURS 339 or NURS 342. This course is eligible for Cr/F for 19W2 only.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Leadership, Policy, and Informatics
desc: The enactment of nursing leadership and policy within different health sectors and jurisdictions and the relevance and application of informatics competencies to the delivery of nursing care.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Relational and Ethical Nursing Practice
desc: Relational theoretical underpinnings of nursing practice and healthcare ethics are critically examined.
crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

name: Promoting the Health of Indigenous People
desc: Foundations to contribute to supporting and providing high quality, ethical, respectful and culturally safe health care in partnership with Indigenous people in Canada and around the globe.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Complexities in Seniors Care
desc: Research and clinical practice innovations in the care of Seniors and their families (e.g., philosophies of care; age-friendly initiatives) and provide strategies for improving their health through the purposeful integration of such practices in clinical settings.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Nursing Practice with Adults/Older Adults and their Families
desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of adults/older adults with stable or expected health care challenges and their families.
crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352.

name: Nursing Practice with Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and their Families
desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of adults/older adults experiencing acute health challenges and their families.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.

name: Nursing Practice in Primary Health Care Contexts
desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the context of primary health care.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: NURS 301 and one of NURS 322, NURS 401.

name: Nursing Practice with People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
desc: Students will apply theory and concepts from a life course perspective in the provision of nursing care to persons living with mental health challenges and their families.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: NURS 303 and one of NURS 322, NURS 401.

name: Nursing Practice with Childbearing Individuals and Families
desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of childbearing individuals, infants, and their families.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: One of NURS 322, NURS 401 and NURS 345.

name: Nursing Practice with Infants, Children, Youth and their Families: Practicum
desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of infants, children, youth and their families.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352.
crer: NURS 346 and one of NURS 322, NURS 401.

name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice IV
desc: Students are prepared with the skills and competencies for clinical practice in simulated acute and community settings through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 352, NURS 360.
crer: Either (a) all of NURS 345, NURS 365 and all of NURS 346, NURS 366;  or (b) all of NURS 303, NURS 363 and all of NURS 301, NURS 362.

name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice V
desc: Students are guided to consolidate skills and competencies for clinical practice through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 353, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

name: Supplemental Guided Study
desc: Supplemental guided study to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies. For Bachelor of Science Nursing students only. Pass/Fail.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Special Topics in Complex and Urgent Health Challenges across Settings/Populations
desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to nursing practice across the life-span and care context.
prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 301, NURS 303, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 330, NURS 331, NURS 345, NURS 346, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 353, NURS 354, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

name: Introduction to Environmental Science
desc: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies. [3-0-0]
prer: Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.

name: Introduction to Research in Environmental Science
desc: Environmental research.  Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields. [3-0-0]
prer: Open to all students with third-year, or higher, standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Community Project in Environmental Science
desc: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449. [3-0-0;3-0-0]

name: Energy, Environment, and Society
desc: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use.  Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use.  Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives. [3-0-0]
prer: Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.

name: Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
desc: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources. [3-0-0]

name: Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability
desc: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions. [3-0-0]
prer: One of ENVR 300, BIOL 230. Or fourth year standing in the BSCN program or other demonstrated ecology background.

name: Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science
desc: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data. [2-2-0]
prer: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211. Third-year standing.

name: Directed Studies in Environmental Science
desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of an ENSC advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required prior to registration.
prer: Third year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Environmental Science HonoursThesis
prer: ENVR 300 and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.

name: Student Directed Seminars in Environmental Sciences
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in environmental sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars.

name: Introduction to Wood Products and Global Trade
desc: Introduction to forestry, wood products industry, processes, products, markets and global trade policy issues affecting the wood industry. Not available for credit to students in the B.S.F. degree. [2-3]

name: Communications Strategies
desc: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing.  Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills.

name: Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
desc: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems. [3-2-0]
prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

name: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
desc: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0]

name: Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products
desc: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics.

name: Wood Products Chemistry I
desc: Chemistry relating to wood and wood products: chemistry of lignin, cellulose, hemicelluloses, extractives, and biological degradation of lignocellulosics; wood pressure impregnation procedures. [3-3-0]
prer: WOOD 280 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123.

name: Mechanics of Wood Products
desc: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products. [3-2-0]
prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 117, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

name: Wood Anatomy and Identification
desc: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality. [3-2-0]

name: Wood Physics and Mechanics
desc: Wood-moisture relationships, transport phenomena, acoustical and electrical properties of wood. Effects of wood attributes at macro- and micro-levels on the strength properties of solid wood. [3-2-0]

name: Secondary Wood Products Manufacturing
desc: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment. [2-3-0]

name: Two-Dimensional and Solid Computer-Aided Graphics
desc: Computer-aided graphics software used in the wood products sector.  Visualization of product designs and specifications in two and three dimensions.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing who have completed the co-op orientation workshops.

name: Wood Machining Skills
desc: Safe working procedures for wood processing machinery, explanation of various manufacturing equipment, product documentation, product development and manufacturing processes.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Industrial Engineering
desc: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning. [3-2-0]

name: Quality Improvement
desc: Modern techniques for improving quality in the workplace with particular emphasis on the forest products industry. Topics include quality control management, control charting, continuous improvement and analysis of variance techniques. [2-2-0]

name: Mill Site Visits
desc: One week of on-site study of forest products manufacturing plants immediately following Spring examinations of second or third year. Representative sawmills, plywood mills, remanufacturing plants, particleboard manufacturers, pulp mills, laminated timber plants and wood preservation facilities in the Interior are studied. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

name: Machine Components
desc: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs.

name: Wood Industry Business Management
desc: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design. [3-0-2]

name: Wood Adhesives and Coatings
desc: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives. [2-3-0]

name: Wood Sawmilling and Drying
desc: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods. [3-2]

name: Applied Mechanics of Materials
desc: Beam analysis, shaft analysis, columns, stress/strain transformations, thin-walled pressure vessels, material strength failure, criteria, fatigue, design and sizing, ISO standards. [2-2-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime.  Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Co-operative Work Placement V
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

name: Plant Layout and Design
desc: Techniques for developing a plan,setting goals, and evaluating the impact of changes in the design, layout and operation of the factory with an emphasis on computer simulation.

name: Engineering Economics
desc: Use of engineering economics to evaluate investment proposals of an engineering nature, including decision making processes, time value of money, cash flow analysis, comparison methods, depreciation, replacement analysis, taxes, inflation and sensitivity analysis. [3-1]

name: Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing
desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

name: Globalization and Sustainability
desc: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects. [3-1]

name: Wood Finishing and Protection
desc: Introduction to polymeric coatings and finishes used in the wood products industry; surface preparation, application equipment and properties of various coatings; wood deterioration and its protection for external applications. [1-3-2]

name: Wood Properties, Identification and Uses
desc: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students. [3-2]

name: Design of Timber Structures
desc: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

name: Building Science
desc: Building enclosure design considering heat and moisture transmission, air flow and ventilation, condensation, acoustics; roofing systems; diagnostic evaluations; fire protection. [3-0-0]

name: CAD/CAM
desc: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing.

name: Furniture Construction
desc: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets. [3-1]

name: Wood Composites
desc: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products. [2-3-0]

name: Wood Products Design and Development I
desc: Introduction to wood products design, from the product idea to the production-ready design.

name: Wood Products Design and Development II
desc: Design and fabrication of wood products.
prer: WOOD 488 and a portfolio demonstrating competence in the operation of woodworking machinery.

name: Environmental Facilities Design
desc: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation. [3-2]

name: Modelling for Decision Support
desc: Applications of mathematical modelling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support. [3-3]

name: Project in Program Major
desc: A report (approved by a faculty supervisor and the Program Director) based on either a technical description of a study, an extension of the senior co-op report, a detailed literature review, a research-based project, or a guided independent study developed by the student.

name: Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling
desc: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning. [2-3-0]

name: Wood Products Capstone
desc: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company.  Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses.
prer: All of WOOD 365, WOOD 440 and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.

name: Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts
desc: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.

name: Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature
desc: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors.

name: Cities
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization.  Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

name: Seminar in Urban Studies
desc: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines.

name: Urban Research
desc: Historical, legal, and quantitative analysis of urban research. Emphasis on spatial, racial, and political dynamics of urban inequality.

name: Basic Korean I
desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100 or KORN 102.

name: Basic Korean II
desc: Continuation of KORN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 101 or KORN 102.

name: Basic Korean
desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100/101 or KORN 102.

name: Basic Korean Grammar
desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing, and reading. For heritage learners and students with prior background in spoken Korean.

name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning
desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Korean.

name: Intermediate Korean
desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200.

name: Intermediate Korean I
desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201 or KORN 200.

name: Intermediate Korean II
desc: Continuation of KORN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 202 or KORN 200.

name: Readings in Korean Topics
desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

name: Readings in Korean Topics I
desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

name: Readings in Korean Topics II
desc: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

name: Introduction to Sino-Korean Readings
desc: Chinese characters in their Korean pronunciations and shapes. Students learn approximately 600 characters, related vocabulary, and do structured readings in mixed scripts on aspects of Korean culture and contemporary life.

name: Modern Korean Short Fiction
desc: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.
prer: Either (a) KORN 300 or (b) all of KORN 301, KORN 302.

name: Advanced Readings in Korean Non-Fiction
desc: Guided readings on contemporary affairs from the Korean press and/or selected readings in Korean academic prose.

name: Korean-to-English Translation
desc: Translation into English of Korean writing in various literary genres, including short story, poetry, personal essay, and academic essay. Supplementary readings in translation studies and translation theory.

name: Korean Conversation and Composition
desc: Structured conversation practice and weekly composition assignments based on viewing one designated Korean television program per week.

name: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean
desc: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries.
prer: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.

name: Supervised Study in the Korean Language
desc: Seminar in Korean-to-English literary translation.  Primarily for, but not limited to,  students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

name: Beginning Biblical Hebrew I
desc: Biblical Hebrew, with an introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of simple biblical texts in the original.

name: Beginning Biblical Hebrew II
