desc: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original.

name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I
desc: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to enrich vocabulary and grammar and enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts.

name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II
desc: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to further enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts.

name: Asian Canadians in Popular Culture
desc: Popular culture's role in the production of Asian Canadian and diasporic communities, with emphasis on race, gender, sexuality, and other identity categories.

name: Dis/Orienting Asian Canada
desc: The histories, cultures, social dynamics, and life experiences of Asian communities in Canada in the context of global migrations. Restricted to students with second year status or higher.

name: Selected Topics in ACAM Studies
desc: Selected Asian Canadian Asian Migration topics. Consult acam.arts.ubc.ca for this year's offerings.
prer: Restricted to students with at least Second year standing; a previous course in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies is recommended.

name: Asian Canadian Community-Based Media
desc: Digital media production in the context of community engagement. Includes critical media literacy, community-based research ethics, project design, training in media forms such audio, video, photography, and web publishing.

name: Asian Migrations in a Global Context
desc: Transpacific, migratory and socio-cultural connections of Asian migrations in a global context.
prer: Minimum 2nd year standing, 3rd year standing recommended.

name: Directed Studies in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration
desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking within the scope of Asian Canadian and Asian Migration.
prer: Permission of the Chair of the ACAM program.

name: Sustainable Forests
desc: An overview of forests and forestry.  Survey of the disciplines, areas of study, and values that frame sustainable management of forests in BC and the world.  Assignments focus on critical thinking and written communication skills. [3-0-0]

name: Principles of Microeconomics for Forestry and Land and Food Systems
desc: Principles of microeconomics and their applications in forestry and land and food systems. The basic concept of the economy to focus on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101 or ECON 101. [3-0-1]

name: Land One: First-year Integrative Seminar
desc: Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both First Nations and Western perspectives.

name: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Forestry
desc: Communicating concepts of forestry and links to human and environmental activities through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience.

name: Forest Plant Biology I
desc: The structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, with emphasis on the angiosperms. [3-2-0]

name: Forest Ecology
desc: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience. [3-2-0]

name: Forest Ecology
desc: The Ecosystem concept; energy biomass and nutrient cycling; the physical environment; population and community ecology; succession, Biogeoclimatic classification and some coastal ecosystems. Available only through Distance Education. [3-2]

name: Silvics of Forest Trees of Western Canada
desc: Ecological and silvical characteristics of forest trees; assessment of ecological site quality and biogeoclimatic classification; application of silvics in silviculture. A plant herbarium of at least 50 species is required. Only available through Distance Education. [3-2]

name: Forest Plant Biology II
desc: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms. [3-2-0]

name: Forest Classification and Silvics
desc: Forest classification and the application of silvics in forest management, including world forest classification systems, the Biogeoclimactic Ecosystem Classification system, and ecosystem diagnosis in the field. [3-2-0]

name: Introduction to Biometrics
desc: Basic theories of probability and statistics. Sampling distribution, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing; goodness of fit and tests for independence; analysis of variance, regression and correlation. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190.

name: Computer Applications in Forestry
desc: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools. [3-2]

name: Tree and Stand Level Measurements
desc: An introduction to measurement of individual trees and stands; use of aerial photographs, maps, and various measurement instruments. [3-2-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Orientation workshops required. Final work term report required.

name: Forest Genetics
desc: Population genetics and conservation of genetic resources; principles of genetics and their application to forestry. [2-2]

name: Principles of Forest Science
desc: Introduction to growth of trees and forests with emphasis on evolutionary, ecological and environmental aspects. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

name: The Science of Forests and Conservation
desc: Global perspectives on natural and planted forests, focused on the science of conservation and social roles on forest management. Designed for students without strong science backgrounds and not available for credit to Faculty of Forestry students. [3-0-0]

name: Silviculture
desc: Silviculture concepts and principles; stand dynamics; artificial and natural regeneration; cultural techniques for forest stand establishment and stand tending; silvicultural systems; decision making and development of prescriptions; connections to forest planning. [3-4*]
prer: FRST 201 and one of FRST 350, FRST 351, UFOR 400.

name: Biotic Disturbances
desc: Concepts of disturbance ecology with special reference to insects and diseases in the forests of British Columbia; forest health problems in the biogeoclamatic zones of BC; present management strategies and future potentials in a scenario of climate change. [3-3-0]

name: Forest Entomology
desc: An introduction to insects that cause damage to forests and forest products; how insects live; life cycles and attack symptoms of representatives of major groups of insects; principles for control and management. Available only through Distance Education.

name: Forest Pathology
desc: Biology and management of forest tree diseases. Available only through Distance Education.

name: Soil Biology
desc: The diversity and interactions of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

name: Plant Physiology I
desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. CHEM 203, CHEM 213, or CHEM 233 and CHEM 235  is recommended. [3-3-0]

name: Forest and Conservation Economics
desc: Practical problem solving of economic issues related to forestry and conservation, touching on investment analysis, capital budgeting, non-timber economics, ecosystem services, and forest certification. Completion of FRST 232 or intermediate knowledge of MS Excel essential. [2-3-0]

name: Principles of Forestry Economics
desc: Introduction to the economics of production, distribution and consumption of goods and services produced by, and dependent on, the forest resource. Available only through Distance Education.

name: Abiotic Disturbances: Fire and Climate
desc: Ecological effects of fire and climatic (wind, temperature, and snow) disturbances; fire danger rating, principles of fire management and prescribed fire use; windthrow risk modelling and management. [3-2-0]

name: Forest Level Measurement and Productivity
desc: Obtaining and forecasting information for stands and forests. [3-2-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Facutly of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Foundational Field School
desc: Field study concentrating on outdoor skills, forest measurements, site diagnosis, and an integrated overview of the ecological, social and economic basis for forest management. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 350 or 351.

name: Interior Field School
desc: Field study at an interior BC location concentrating on land use, management and silviculture. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses. Students with FRST 351 and FRST 350 can only count 2 credits toward their program requirements.

name: Community Forests and Community Forestry
desc: Community forests and community forestry throughout the world, with special attention to participation by aboriginal peoples; emphasis is on forms of governance, public participation, and adaptive learning. [3-0-0]

name: Watershed Hydrology
desc: Measurement and analysis of hydrological processes in response to forest management activities. [3-2-0]

name: Aquatic Ecosystems and Fish in Forested Watersheds
desc: Effects of forest management activities on fish and aquatic ecosystems. [3-2-0]
prer: Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science or Applied Science.

name: Forest Wildlife Ecology and Management
desc: Biology of important bird and mammal species resident in forested regions, with particular emphasis on the influences of silvicultural and logging practices. [3-2-0]

name: Introduction to Research Methods
desc: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and the scientific method, with special emphasis on field research. [2-1]

name: Living Language: Science and Society
desc: Multi-disciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prer: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: The Sustainability of Production in Managed Forest Ecosystems
desc: Study of the functional and dynamic characteristics of forest ecosystems and their response to forest management using ecosystem-level microcomputer simulation models. [3-2-0]

name: Advances in Silviculture
desc: Fundamental silvicultural problems; the application of research findings to the practice of silviculture. [4-0]

name: Advanced Forest Pathology
desc: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases. Given in alternate years. [2-2]

name: Advanced Forest Insect Ecology
desc: Role of climate and climate change in the population dynamics, outbreak potentials and resultant impacts to forest ecosystems associated with herbivorous forest insects. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Landscape Ecology and Management
desc: Current concepts, methods, and applications of landscape ecology with emphasis on spatial patterning, spatial heterogeneity, and dynamics; problem-solving approaches to natural resource issues through the application of landscape ecological principles and tools.

name: Complex Adaptive Systems, Global Change Science, and Ecology Sustainability
desc: Concepts of complex adaptive systems (CAS); exploration of how CAS can be used to manage natural and social environments for multiple goals under changing climatic and socio-economic conditions. [3-0-0]

name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210;  or (b) all of FRST 200, FRST 210.

name: Sustainable Forest Policy
desc: The development, implementation, and analysis of forest policy. [3-0-0]

name: Quantitative Forest Management
desc: Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

name: Mathematical Modelling in Forest Resource Analysis
desc: Modelling techniques used in strategic and tactical forest resources analyses. [2-0-3]

name: Forest Management Planning
desc: Forest management designs to identify and integrate economic, social, and environmental objectives across a forested landscape both strategically and tactically. [4-2-2]

name: Advanced Biometrics
desc: Analysis of variance, multiple regression and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments. [3-2]
prer: One of FRST 231, BIOL 300, STAT 200. And FRST 399 or equivalent. Restricted to students with 4th year standing or by permission of instructor.

name: Ecological Genomics
desc: The genomic basis of adaptation to environments. Topics progress through community structure, life history patterns, stress responses, and variation and adaptation. [3-0-0]

name: Growth and Yield
desc: Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth. [2-2-0]

name: International Forestry
desc: The socio-economic, biological and technological aspects of forestry within the international frame, in both the developed and developing world. Regional studies and the role of national and international agencies. [2-2-0]

name: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management
desc: Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. [2-2-0]

name: Agroforestry
desc: Integration of farms and forests, including tropical agroforestry systems, non-timber forest products, forest farming, woodlot management, silvopastoralism, riparian buffers, windbreaks, soil fertility improvement and nutrient cycling. [3-2-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry
desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Coastal Field School
desc: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
prer: Third or fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program.

name: The Role of Natural and Planted Forests in the Global Bioeconomy
desc: (Go Global Seminar Series) An intensive one-month field school in Chile focused on fast-growing industrial forest plantations, innovative wood products, land use strategies for natural and planted forests, and their impact on society.

name: Forests and Society
desc: Social aspects of forestry and forest communities. [3-0-1]

name: Forest Watershed Management
desc: Effects of land management on quality, quantity and timing of water flow. [3-2-0]

name: Visual Resource Management and Planning for Aesthetics
desc: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning & management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management & community engagement.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. [2-2]

name: Visualization and Forest Design
desc: GIS-based spatial planning and 3D landscape visualization for forest management. [3-0-1]

name: Environmental Perception
desc: How individuals perceive their environment.  Emphasis will be given visual perception in the context of natural resource issues and the effects of those perceptions on individuals including issues of human wellbeing. [3-0-0]

name: Biological Diversity and Forest Management
desc: Principles, problems, and practices of managing  forests and nature reserves for biological diversity; integration of forestry and wildlife with particular emphasis on diversity of all life forms. [2-2-0]

name: Communications and Professionalism
desc: Preparing professional reports and presentations; professionalism and professional ethics. [2-0-2]

name: B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. Available only to students in the BSFS Honours specialization.

name: B.S.F. Thesis
desc: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

name: Introduction to Tibetan I
desc: Concepts, grammar, syntax of spoken and written Tibetan for beginners. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

name: Introduction to Tibetan II
desc: Focus on grammar, syntax, and structures to improve comprehension and communication skills. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

name: Classical Tibetan I
desc: The basics of classical Tibetan grammar and vocabulary, with readings from a selection of daily prayer verses.
prer: Completion of TIBT 100 or TIBT 390 with a minimum grade of 60%.

name: Classical Tibetan II
desc: Continuation of introductory classical Tibetan grammar and vocabulary, with selected readings to strengthen one's foundation in classical Tibetan.
prer: Completion of TIBT 300 with a minimum grade of 60%.

name: Tibetan Language in a Community Context
desc: Beginner to conversational level Tibetan combined with experiential learning and cultural activities at local Tibetan community sites. Interactive practice with everyday phrases, grammar structure, and vocabulary with Tibetan community members.

name: Introductory Sanskrit
desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

name: Introductory Sanskrit I
desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

name: Introductory Sanskrit II
desc: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit
desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit I
desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit II
desc: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400.

name: Further Readings in Sanskrit
desc: Study of selected texts belonging to a particular period (e.g., Vedic) or representing a specific branch of kavya (poetic literature) or sastra (technical-philosophical literature).
prer: One of SANS 200, SANS 202, SANS 400, SANS 402.

name: Administration of the School Library Resource Centre
desc: The role, philosophy, and management of school library resource centres in elementary and secondary schools. [3-0-0]

name: Special Topics in Teacher Librarianship
desc: In-depth study of selected topics in library education. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Music Education
desc: Role of music education in schools and society, including historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Includes guided class observations and practice music teaching in elementary and secondary schools. Criminal Record Check required.

name: First-Year Russian
desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

name: Basic Russian I
desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian. Oral practice, grammar, reading, and writing.

name: Basic Russian II
desc: Continuation of RUSS 101.

name: Russian for Singers
desc: Study of Russian language and culture for opera students.

name: Second-Year Russian
desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 200 or both of RUSS 201 and RUSS 202.

name: Second-Year Russian I
desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 201 or RUSS 200.

name: Second-Year Russian II
desc: A continuation of RUSS 201. Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 202 or RUSS 200.

name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
desc: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

name: Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
desc: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

name: Russian Practice
desc: Emphasis on oral practice and reading. It is recommended that this course be taken concurrently with one of the following: RUSS 200, RUSS 201, RUSS 202.

name: Third-Year Russian
desc: Intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition.

name: Third-Year Russian I
desc: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 301 or 300.

name: Third -Year Russian II
desc: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 302 or RUSS 300.

name: Topics in Russian Culture (in English)
desc: Features of Russian culture with an emphasis on historical and social contexts. Specific course content will vary. Consult CENES for this year's offerings at https://cenes.ubc.ca/undergraduate/slavic-studies/russian-minor/

name: Readings in Russian Literary Texts
desc: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21st-century sources.

name: Russian Literature in Translation
desc: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

name: Advanced Russian Practice
desc: Continuation of RUSS 215. May be taken concurrently with RUSS 300.

name: Russian through Film (in Russian)
desc: Conversation and composition using Russian film.

name: Imagining Location in Russian Literature (in English)
desc: Russian literature and film, focused around a particular geographical and cultural location.

name: Fantastic Worlds in Russian Fiction (in English)
desc: Russian genre fiction and film (science fiction, fantasy and gothic).

name: Fourth-Year Russian
desc: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

name: Russian for Reading Knowledge
desc: Russian for Reading Knowledge This course provides a reading knowledge of Russian, sufficient to enable students to understand scientific and scholarly material. Basic grammar and practice in the translation into English of texts in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities. Intended primarily for upper-year and graduate students.

name: Studies in Russian Poetry
desc: For further details see Department.

name: Studies in Russian Prose Before 1917
desc: See Department for further details.

name: Contemporary Russian Literature after 1917
desc: See Department for further details.

name: Women in Russian Literature and Culture
desc: Analysis of translated texts by and concerning women from folklore to contemporary society.

name: Our Changing Environment: Climate and Ecosystems
desc: Energy and water in the Earth-Atmosphere system, global climates and climate change, ecosystem properties and processes, human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

name: Our Changing Environment: Water and Landscapes
desc: Physical processes acting at the Earth's surface; water cycle; landforms; human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

name: Atmospheric Environments
desc: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates from the scale of plants and animals to the globe. Daily weather systems and climate change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOS (or GEOB) 200, GEOS (or GEOB) 204, or APBI 244. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of GEOS 102, GEOB 102 or second-year standing in science.

name: Introduction to Biometeorology
desc: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOS (or GEOB) 200, GEOS (or GEOB) 204, or APBI 244. [3-2-0]

name: Geomorphic Processes and Hazards
desc: Earth surface processes shaping the landscape; identification of hazards and hazardous areas associated with these processes; introduction to techniques for measurement and analysis at various spatial and time scales; field trips are required. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of GEOB 103, GEOS 103, EOSC 110, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

name: Introduction to Biogeography
desc: Geographical ecology emphasizing contemporary species distributions at local to global spatial scales, population and community dynamics, and human impacts. Labs emphasize collecting data (sometimes outdoors) and interpreting results. [3-2*-0]

name: Geographic Information Science
desc: Computer-based graphical methods of data input and analysis. Emphasis on data visualization techniques such as cartographic modelling and exploratory data analysis. [2-2-0]

name: Microscale Weather and Climate
desc: Meteorology and climatology at the micro-, local, and meso-scales. Interactions between land surfaces and atmosphere. Basics of atmospheric turbulence and transfer processes. Microclimates on scales of a leaf to those of a large valley. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 204, GEOS 204, ATSC 201.

name: Paleoecology: Lessons for the Anthropocene
desc: Paleoecology of terrestrial ecosystems, particularly during the Quaternary, application of historical context to inform contemporary Anthropocene policy and management dilemmas, and including a foundation in relevant ecosystem and ecological concepts. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) one of GEOB 102, GEOS 102, GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 204, GEOS 204, GEOB 207, GEOS 207, GEOG 211, BIOL 230 or (b) EOSC 340.

name: Tropical Ecosystems in a Changing World
desc: Biogeography and ecology of tropical systems, including patterns of species diversity, forest dynamics, plant-animal interactions, carbon and nutrient cycling. Impacts of global environmental change and conservation strategies for tropical ecosystems. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 207, GEOS 207, BIOL 230, FRST 201.

name: Synoptic Meteorology and Climatology
desc: Analysis of meteorological fields, diagnostic analysis of synoptic weather systems, applications of synoptic meteorology. Requires participation in weekly weather map discussion. [2-2-0]

name: Introduction to Hydrology
desc: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and larger regional scales. Introduction to techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 204, GEOS 204, APBI 244, ATSC 201. And one of PHYS 100-level or CHEM 123.

name: Biogeography and Global Change
desc: Biogeographic concepts in understanding responses in ecosystems to environmental change at global, regional, and local scales. Conservation issues such as the loss of biodiversity and endangered species. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of BIOL 230, GEOB 207, GEOS 207, FRST 201.

name: Quaternary and Applied Geomorphology
desc: Quaternary landscape development emphasizing the history of glaciation with special reference to western North America; applications of geomorphology in resource development and land management; interpretation of Quaternary materials. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of EOSC 320, EOSC 330, GEOB 206, GEOS 206.

name: Geographical Sciences Field Course
desc: Field sampling, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, and data analysis; mandatory multi-day field camp in May or June. Special fees and liability insurance are required.
prer: One of BIOL 230, GEOB 207, GEOS 207 and one of GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 204, GEOS 204.

name: Advanced Geographic Information Science
desc: Theoretical and practical aspects of Geographic Information Systems, including cartographic modelling, digital terrain models, management issues, and spatial interpolation. [2-2-0]
prer: One of GEOB 270, GEOS 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOS (or GEOB) specializations, with some introductory knowledge of GIS.

name: Cartography
desc: Cartographic methods: development of cartography; projections; data ordering, compilation and symbolization; cartographic design, map reproduction. [2-2-0]
prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOS 102, GEOB 103, GEOS 103.

name: Introductory Remote Sensing
desc: Aerial photography; measurement from aerial photographs; photo-interpretation in geographic analysis; remote sensing of the earth's surface and atmosphere. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of GEOB 270, GEOS 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOS (or GEOB) specializations.

name: Global Change Science
desc: Processes controlling the planetary cycles of elements like carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus, the human perturbation of these biogeochemical cycles, and the consequences for the atmosphere, terrestrial ecosystems, and aquatic ecosystems. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 110;  or (b) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 121, CHEM 120;  or (c) SCIE 001. Fourth year standing is also required.

name: Urban Meteorology
desc: The impact of urbanization upon atmospheric processes and climates. The energy and water balances of cities. Meteorological effects (urban heat island, precipitation modification, etc.) and their significance. Models of the urban atmosphere. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 204, GEOS 204, GEOB 300, GEOS 300, AGRO 244, APBI 244.

name: Air Pollution Meteorology
desc: The nature of atmospheric pollutants. The ability of the atmosphere to disperse, transform, and remove pollutants. Air pollution dispersion models. Air quality monitoring, criteria, and standards. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 300, GEOS 300.

name: Catchment Hydrology
desc: Hydrometeorology; runoff processes; streamwater chemistry in relation to runoff processes; effects of climate variations and land cover change on streamflow regimes; models of catchment hydrology. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOS 200, GEOB 204, GEOS 204 and one of GEOB 305, GEOS 305, FRST 385 and one of STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300.

name: Fluvial Geomorphology
desc: Introduction to open channel flow and sediment transport. River morphology and channel types. Palaeohydrology. The development of channel networks. [2-3-0]
prer: One of EOSC 320, EOSC 330, GEOB 206, GEOS 206.

name: Watershed Geomorphology
desc: Hillslope and stream channel processes and their rates of operation. Analysis and modelling geomorphic processes and associated hazards at the watershed scale. Applications in geoscience and engineering. [2-2-0]

name: Vegetation Dynamics: Disturbance, Climate and Human Impacts
desc: Investigation of vegetation dynamics integrating theory and research to address contemporary issues of global environmental change. Students will conduct fieldwork and learn to analyze data and interpret results. [2-3-0]
prer: One of BIOL 230, GEOB 207, GEOS 207, FRST 201.

name: The Changing Cryosphere
desc: Formation of ice masses and their evolution including snowpacks, glaciers, and ice sheets. Relationships between ice and climate including records of climate change, glacier dynamics and ice-related hazards. [3-0-0]
prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of GEOB 206, GEOS 206, GEOB 305, GEOS 305, GEOB 308, GEOS 308.

name: Advanced Field Studies in Geographical Sciences
desc: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed field-based research. [2-2-0]
prer: One of GEOB 309, GEOS 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Sciences, Environmental Sciences or Major in Geography (Environmental and Sustainability).

name: River Restoration: Science and Society
desc: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry. [3-0-0]
prer: One of GEOB 206, GEOS 206, GEOB 305, GEOS 305, GEOB 405, GEOS 405, GEOB 406, GEOS 406, EOSC 329, EOSC 330.

name: Directed Studies in Geographical Sciences
desc: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 448, GEOS 448 or GEOG 448.

name: Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Original research on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a faculty member. Open to 4th year students in Geographical Sciences with appropriate background courses related to the research topic, and permission of the directing faculty member. The 3-credit option is only available to students who complete GEOS 449 in tandem with GEOS 409.

name: Research in Cartography
desc: Use of cartography in primary research applications. Discussion of contemporary topics in cognitive, social, and technical cartography and data visualization. [3-2*-0]
prer: One of GEOB 270, GEOS 270, GEOB 372, GEOS 372.

name: Research in Geographic Information Science
desc: Students use GIS in primary research applications in conservation biology, crime analysis, and health geography; theoretical and practical aspects considered in a hands-on environment. [2-2-0]

name: Student Directed Seminar in Geographical Sciences
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in physical geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars." This course carries science credit. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 490, GEOS 490 and GEOG 442.

name: Designing for Global Community Development
desc: Design methodologies for exploring global community development processes relating to achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Introduction to Social Welfare
desc: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

name: Introduction to Social Work Practice
desc: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

name: Topics in Social Work Practice I
desc: Examinations of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying various topics in generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program

name: Interviewing Skills
desc: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

name: Practicum I
desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

name: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
desc: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

name: Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis
desc: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

name: Topics in Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
desc: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.

name: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
desc: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

name: Canadian Social Policy
desc: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

name: Social Work Practice II
desc: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

name: Practicum II
desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
desc: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

name: Introduction to Social Work Research
desc: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320.

name: Special Studies in Social Work
desc: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work
desc: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

name: Social Context of Child Development
desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

name: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
desc: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
prer: SOWK 441 or another course in child development.

name: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
desc: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness.

name: Health Care Team Development
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400.

name: HIV Prevention and Care
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402.

name: Disability and Justice
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

name: Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.

name: Palliative Care
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.

name: Special Topics in Collaborative Healthcare
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares students to practice patient-centred interprofessional collaboration in a specific area of healthcare. Offered as IHHS 480 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 456 or IHHS 480.

name: Foundations of Pharmacy
desc: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

name: Medication Management I
desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology.

name: Study Design and Interpretation I
desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice I
desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice.

name: Technology in Healthcare
desc: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care.

name: Community Service Learning I
desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail. Not offered in 2021/22.

name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient I
desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Pass/Fail.

name: Medication Management II
desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders.

name: Medication Management III
desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology.

name: Nutrition for Pharmacists
desc: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice.

name: Study Design and Interpretation II
desc: Principles of screening and diagnostic tests, clinical prediction rules, clinical practice guidelines, conflicts of interest, economic evaluation of therapeutics and medical technologies, harm-benefit analysis, and how to incorporate the best available evidence into practice.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice II
desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice.

name: Institutional Practice Skills
desc: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations.

name: Indigenous Health and Cultural Safety
desc: Overview of Indigenous health in Canada and the role a pharmacist can have in collaborating with Indigenous communities in providing culturally safe care and healing

name: Community Service Learning II
desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient II
desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient
desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world inpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

name: Selected Topics
desc: Thesis or essay.

name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy
desc: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of problems involved in the development of pharmaceutical dosage forms.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Education
desc: Individual assignments involving library and scholarly inquiry related to pharmacy education.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacology
desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of certain aspects of drug action.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice
desc: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice.

name: Directed Studies in Epidemiology and Health Outcomes
desc: Individual assignments involving scholarly inquiry related to epidemiology or health outcomes.

name: Medication Management IV
desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry; gastroenterology disorders; and oncology and palliative care.

name: Medication Management V
desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on reproductive health, sexual health, and genitourinary disorders; special infectious diseases; and toxicology.

name: Travel Health
desc: Providing a consultative service to patients based on patient medical and travel history. Recommending and administering vaccinations according to guidelines. Making recommendations regarding oral medications needed for safe travel.

name: Peer Teaching in Pharmacy Skills
desc: Development and delivery of patient counselling role-playing activities.

name: Pharmaceutical Care in Indigenous Health
desc: Indigenous health in Canada and the role pharmacists' cultural humility and safety can play when collaborating with other health professionals and Indigenous communities to provide care and healing.

name: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
desc: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice.

name: Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
desc: Case-based approach to the pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class.

name: Toxicology and Precision Medicine
desc: Basic principles of toxicology; toxicity of pharmaceuticals, and precision medicine approaches to mitigate toxicity.

name: Pharmacology of Drugs of Misuse and Abuse
desc: Biological, pharmacological, and psychological aspects of drugs of misuse and abuse.

name: Leadership Experience Applied to Pharmacy (LEAP)
desc: Leadership skills in preparation for the practice of pharmacy in direct or non-direct patient care settings and contexts.

name: Pharmacy Practice in Acute and Critically Ill Patients
desc: Pharmaceutical care concepts for managing acute and critically ill patients.
prer: Third-year standing and a combined grade average of 70% in PHRM 211 and PHRM 212.

name: Practical Applications of Pharmacoepidemiology & Health Economics
desc: Principles and methods of collecting epidemiological and economic evidence used to assess the value of pharmaceuticals and services provided by pharmacists.

name: Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
desc: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment.

name: Pain Research and Therapy
desc: Basic mechanisms and the clinical management of acute and chronic pain.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice III
desc: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams.

name: Practice Management and Leadership
desc: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations.

name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
desc: Training for authorization to administer injections.

name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient III
desc: Direct patient care activities in an outpatient setting. Building on existing pharmaceutical knowledge and problem solving ability. Increased involvement in diverse patient care situations. Pass/Fail.

name: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice
desc: Pharmacists in practice, emerging pharmacy practice issues and pharmacists as preceptors. Pass/Fail.

name: PharmD Seminar
desc: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail.

name: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail.

name: Patient Assessment Skills
desc: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail.

name: Applied Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenomics
desc: Pharmacokinetic monitoring of drug therapy in common clinical situations with foundations for application to other drugs.  Pharmacogenomics and personalized medicine principles and applications to practice. Pass/Fail.

name: Practice Management
desc: Values, concepts, issues and responsibilities of individuals exercising leadership and management roles in pharmacy practice and health care settings. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 1
desc: Therapeutic foundations. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 2
desc: Respirology, dermatology, and ears, eyes, nose, and throat. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 3
desc: Cardiovascular disorders. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 4
desc: Infectious diseases. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 5
desc: Neurology and psychiatry. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 6
desc: Gastroenterology and musculoskeletal disorders. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 7
desc: Genitourinary disorders, reproductive health, endocrinology, and nephrology. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 8
desc: Oncology, hematology, and toxicology. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 9
desc: Acute and critical care of nephrology, neurology, cardiovascular disorders, gastroenterology, infectious diseases, and respirology. Pass/Fail.

name: Outpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

name: Inpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in inpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

name: Selected Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
desc: Diverse options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/preceptor availability. Pass/Fail.

name: Healthcare Quality Improvement
desc: Builds on the foundation of patient care and management learning with knowledge about healthcare system improvement. Focuses on principles of quality measurement and quality improvement in health. Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of outpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Specialized Outpatient
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of specialized outpatient settings.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Ambulatory/Primary Care
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of ambulatory or primary care settings. Pass/Fail.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Selected Direct Patient Care
desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient or inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Selected Direct Patient Care or Non-Direct Patient Care
desc: Options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/practice educator availability. Pass/Fail.
prer: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Comprehensive Examination
desc: Assessment of skills in the clinical problem-solving process. Pass/Fail.
prer: Successful completion of all other coursework.

name: Introduction to Business
desc: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only.

name: Business Fundamentals
desc: The different disciplines of business and their combination in management planning and decision-making.

name: Business Immersion
desc: A broad introduction to the field of business and how the different disciplines within business interact and combine in business decision-making. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Data: Description, Display, and Inference
desc: Introduction to the use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 126 or COEC 126.

name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

name: Career Fundamentals
desc: Fundamentals of career management including effective resume and cover letter writing, performing well in interviews and learning about the recruiting cycles, networking and resources available at the Hari B. Varshney Business Career Centre.

name: Managing the Employment Relationship
desc: The role of employment relations in enterprise performance. Managing employees under statutory law, collective bargaining, and progressive human resource management. Key issues in forming, developing, and maintaining a work force. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 203 or COMM 392.
prer: COMM 292 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100.

name: Logistics and Operations Management
desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 204 or COMM 399.

name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 205 or COMM 391.

name: Business Communications
desc: An experiential course covering a broad range of business writing and communications. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Introduction to Capital Markets
desc: Roles of capital market institutions and participants. Skill development for basic financial principles in the quantitative and qualitative evaluation of bond and stock investments.

name: Entrepreneurship
desc: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business.

name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Making
desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.
crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: Application of Statistics in Business
desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

name: Management and Organizational Behaviour
desc: Behaviour in organizations as it affects people as individuals, their relationships with others, their performance in groups and their effectiveness at work.

name: Financial Accounting
desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 293 or COEC 293.

name: Managerial Accounting
desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 294 or COEC 294.

name: Managerial Economics
desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, organization of the firm, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, ECON 301, ECON 304, FRE 295 or COMM 295.
prer: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102.

name: Introduction to Marketing
desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.
crer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

name: Introduction to Finance
desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 298 or COEC 298. [3-0-0]
crer: All of COMM 290, COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

name: Study Abroad, Commerce
desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

name: Study Abroad, Commerce
desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

name: Urban Land Economics
desc: Examines economic factors affecting the urban land market, with an emphasis on determinants of urban land values, the housing market, urban transportation, and land use policies.

name: Real Estate Investment
desc: Evaluation of investment in real estate assets; proforma analysis, property and asset management, equity securitization, appraisal, and international real estate investment.
prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298.

name: Simulation Models in Business Decision-Making
desc: Computer simulation, simulation languages. Typical business applications in financial planning, waiting line problems and other operating problems.

name: Research Theory for Commerce Scholars
desc: Social science research: theory, research design, methods, and criticism. For students in the Commerce Scholars Program only.

name: Business Ethics Leadership
desc: Skill Development for leading organizations while better managing for values. Recognizing organizational values, and developing concrete plans for better delivering on these values.

name: Strategies for Responsible Business
desc: Tools to apply sustainable and responsible decision making through individual, organizational, and structural lenses. Topics include diversity and group think, the circular economy, and climate change adaptation.

name: Foundations in Accounting I
desc: Preparation of financial statements and use of financial information contained in financial statements to make better decisions. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Organizational Behaviour
desc: Effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. Application of relevant frameworks from the social sciences to particular organizational situations. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them. Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership (for non-Commerce students only).

name: Information Systems Technology and Development
desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use. Design, implementation and application of Information Systems.

name: Introduction to Digital Business
desc: Business fundamentals in the digital economy: leveraging digitization and automation; data and analytics; platforms; crowdsourcing; understanding the impact of digital technologies on firms, markets, economies as well as individuals and society.

name: Business Programming and Analytics
desc: Introduction to object-oriented computer programming; computational thinking; program design; scripting; documentation techniques; file handling; database access; and web crawling techniques. Students will apply data structures and programming constructs to the development of business analytics and other related applications. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 337 and CPSC 103.

name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management I - Study Abroad
Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management II - Study Abroad
Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management III - Study Abroad
Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management IV - Study Abroad
Logistics Services Management
desc: Overview of the characteristics and commercial environment of logistics and transportation services; service operations planning and design, costing, pricing and quality management.
crer: One of COMM 204, COMM 296, COMM 396, COMM 399.

name: Financial Accounting: Intermediate I
desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.
crer: Either (a) all of COMM 297, COMM 397 or (b) COMM 298.

name: Cost Accounting
desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance. The utilization of statistical analysis and linear models is included.
prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291, COMM 293, COMM 294.

name: Income Taxation
desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and of business enterprise.

name: Consumer Behaviour
desc: The use of consumer research and theory in marketing and policy decisions. Psychological, sociological and economic theory and research relevant to consumer behaviour are considered.

name: Marketing Analysis
desc: Analytical methods applicable to marketing management decision making; attention to strategic considerations linking analysis of consumer data, corporate data, environmental factors, and competitive response. The course makes extensive use of micro computers.

name: Market Research
desc: The process of marketing research including topics such as problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291 and either (a) COMM 296 or (b) COMM 396;  and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

name: Corporate Finance
desc: Examination of corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice, and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

name: Investment Theory
desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 371 or COEC 371.

name: Applied Financial Markets
desc: Introduction to methodologies and evidence concerning the structure and operation of security markets and the valuation of financial securities including stocks, bonds, options and futures contracts; portfolio management, corporate finance and investment decisions.

name: Financial Institutions I
desc: The financial systems in Canada; the practices of the major financial institutions; and theories of financial processes.

name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 456, COMM 377, or COEC 377.

name: Introduction to Pensions and Insurance
desc: Financial dimensions and institutional structure of the pension and insurance industry; calculation of annuities and other aspects of actuarial science based on probability distributions and asset returns. Suitable for students in mathematics who have taken basic finance and for commerce students in finance, accounting and related areas.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce. Option-specific prerequisites apply.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

name: Economics of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
desc: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms.

name: Innovation Leadership
desc: Social science frameworks useful for understanding organizational innovation processes and application of these frameworks to innovation. Diagnosing and solving a broad range of organizational innovation challenges from the perspective of an innovation leader.

name: Entrepreneurial Finance
desc: Financial issues encountered by those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors.

name: Design Methods for Business Innovation
desc: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment.

name: Creativity in Business
desc: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions.

name: Business Writing
desc: An activity-focused course providing the opportunity to study and practice forms of writing needed in business.
prer: One of ENGL 112, ASTU 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 100, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. ENGL 1st, Arts One, a minimum of 18 cr. of Coordinated Arts Program.

name: Commercial Law
desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property; principles of agency, partnerships and company law.

name: Environment, Society, and Government
desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy, with an emphasis on their interactions with the environmental and indigenous communities. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

name: Business Communications
desc: Understanding non-written communications in day-to-day business.

name: Introduction to Business Processes and Operations
desc: The design and management of systems that efficiently and effectively supply products and services to the end-user. The concepts apply to a variety of settings such as manufacturing, logistics, healthcare, and others (For non-Commerce students only).

name: Real Estate Finance
desc: The role of mortgage markets, mathematical analysis of return and valuation issue and methods of dealing with lender and borrower risk exposure.

name: Real Estate Economics
desc: The economics of real estate markets. Topics include real estate cycles and bubbles, search models and vacancy, the relationship between real estate and the economy, housing demand, and models of housing supply.

name: Real Estate Development
desc: The development process from theories of development, market analysis, site selection, project design, land use regulation and financial analysis.
prer: One of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

name: Intermediate Business Statistics
desc: Statistical techniques useful in business environments. Includes regression analysis, analysis of variance, forecasting, and logit and probit analysis. Credit may be obtained for only one of STAT 300, 306, and COMM 411.

name: Negotiation
desc: Negotiation simulations to provide experience and confidence in the negotiation process and to develop effective skills for achieving objectives.

name: Data Visualization and Business Analytics
desc: Descriptive analytics including data analysis and visualization. Predictive analytics including forecasting and various statistical techniques. Predictive analytics including optimization, Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees, and discrete event simulation.

name: Quantitative Policy Analysis
desc: Quantitative evaluation of public policies using statistical evaluation methods, cost benefit, and effectiveness analyses. Public policies affecting service provision and infrastructure investment in air, rail, marine, public transit, and pipelines evaluated on pricing, operating costs, productivity, safety, security, and the environment.

name: Marketing
desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. Analytical frameworks and techniques that are used to guide marketing strategy decisions. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Introductory Finance
desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

name: Research Methods for Human Resource Management
desc: Techniques for collection and analysis of data in organizations to support adoption and administration of human resource management.

name: Selected Topics in Human Resource Management
Law of Business Organizations and Corporate Governance
desc: Statutory provisions and case law that regulate the creation and governance of sole proprietorships, partnerships, corporations, joint ventures, and franchises in British Columbia. Fiduciary duties of partners, directors and officers are also examined.

name: Land Law
desc: Legal principles and concepts relating to real estate and land development.

name: CIO Strategies
desc: Common issues faced by Chief Information Officers (CIO): Cost and value of information technology (IT), IT priorities, IT and the Board of Directors, Business-IT alignment, IT governance, IT talent management, standardization vs. innovation, project and vendor management/partnering, and managing security and risks.

name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
desc: The process of information systems development; modern techniques and tools for systems analysis and design.

name: Database Technology
desc: Theory and technology of database management from an applications perspective; database design; database administration. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 437, COEC 437, or CPSC 304.

name: Management of Information Systems
desc: Managerial issues in the administration of computerized information systems.

name: Business Telecommunications
desc: Basic data communications concepts and technology; local area, wide area, and enterprise networks; the Internet; wireless networking; network development life cycle; network security and management. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM439 and CPSC 317.

name: Advanced Business Logistics
desc: Analysis of logistics systems within firms and across supply chains. The formulation of corporate logistics strategies.

name: Service Operations
desc: This primarily case-based course will cover service operations in general (50%), health care operations (25%), and revenue management (25%). Applications of queuing models will be included in both services in general and healthcare.

name: Air Transportation
desc: An integrative treatment of air transport management including: demand analysis, sales and marketing, globalization trends, aircraft selection and fleet planning; airport economics and management.

name: Maritime and International Transportation
desc: The characteristics of shipping services and the role of shipping services in the design and management of international logistics systems.

name: Transportation Economics
desc: Economic characteristics of passenger and freight transportation services; market structure of the transportation industry; economic impact of public regulation and promotion and the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy. Credit may be obtained for only one of COMM 446, ECON 480.
prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301, ECON 206.

name: Applied Project Management
desc: Project management methodology based on the practices defined by the Project Management Institute, including planning, execution, monitoring, control, and completion.

name: Business Logistics and Logistics Services Management
desc: General services management including warehousing, transportation, intermodal, order-fulfillment, dispatching, and more.

name: Supply-Chain Management
desc: Integrated management of production and logistics systems; management of inter-organizational  relationships in the supply chain, including vendor selection, bidding and negotiation processes, partnering and performance measurement.

name: Financial Accounting - Intermediate II
desc: Intermediate II. Continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

name: Taxes and Decision Making
desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

name: Financial Accounting-Advanced
desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting.

name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

name: Principles of Auditing
desc: Principles of internal control, audit evidence, sampling and testing; audit reports; standards; responsibilities of the external auditor.

name: Information Technology Risks, Protection and Audit
desc: Business risks associated with the use of information technology. Controls for integrity, security safety, and privacy of hardware, software, data and communications. Methods for auditing information systems and their controls.

name: Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
