desc: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only).

name: Fundamentals of Managerial Accounting
desc: Use of accounting data in decision making by businesses; financial statement analysis; cash flows; cost behaviour patterns; methods of accounting for costs. (For non-Commerce students only).

name: Financial Statement Analysis
desc: An examination of financial statement information from the perspective of decision makers external to the firm, e.g., investors and financial institutions.
prer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 370, COMM 397.

name: Social and Nonprofit Marketing
desc: Examines the role, use, and application of marketing in government agencies and nonprofit institutions.

name: Business Development
desc: Principles and practice of personal selling and leadership of teams: strategy, tactics, and implementation.

name: Integrated Marketing Communication
desc: Marketing communication campaign strategy, conceptual framework, and practical application for integrated marketing communications, including advertising.

name: Public Relations
desc: Managing an organization's strategic communications and relationships with diverse publics to handle issues, strengthen reputation, fulfill social responsibilities, and build trust. Topics include stakeholder engagement, issues management, crisis communications, and events and sponsorship.

name: Digital Marketing
desc: Investigation of Internet-based marketing, emphasizing customer-focused perspectives, competitive situations and analysis of the effectiveness of business websites using marketing principles and practices.

name: Marketing Management
desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. (For non-Commerce students only).
crer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

name: New Venture Design
desc: Teams comprising students in COMM 466 and APSC 486 propose a new product, produce a viable prototype, and develop a business plan for the marketplace.  Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466, COMM 497, COEC 497, COMR 497, and APSC 486.

name: Brand Management
desc: Issues and challenges commonly faced by brand managers, including: assessing brand meaning, evaluating brand health, assessing a brand's leverage potential, evaluating brand extensions, managing brands through a crisis, and assessing brand value.

name: Marketing Applications
desc: Applied marketing planning with emphasis on a major industrial analysis and the subsequent development of a detailed marketing plan for an operating organization.

name: International Marketing
desc: An analysis of the scope and significance of contemporary international business operations with particular reference to the marketing management problems encountered by firms with multinational branches and subsidiaries.

name: Venture Capital
desc: Theory and evidence concerning venture capital markets. Contracting, fundraising, and financing choice covered in depth, with the aim of catering to students looking to raise money for entrepreneurial ventures or to invest in entrepreneurial ventures.

name: Mergers and Acquisitions
desc: Mergers and acquisitions as a focal point in making important corporate decisions deduced from careful study of relevant business cases.

name: Business Finance
desc: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only).
prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310;  and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: Fixed Income Markets and Management
desc: Fixed income instruments and derivatives. Risk profiles and their use in establishing fixed income investment portfolios. Performance attribution techniques.

name: Investment Policy
desc: The management of security portfolios for individual and institutional investors; relation of investment policy to money markets and business fluctuations.

name: Risk Management and Financial Engineering
desc: Principles of financial engineering and risk management. Use of derivatives in risk management. Valuation and hedging models for contingent claims.

name: Advanced Topics on Corporate Finance
desc: Corporate Finance is the process by which corporations raise money, allocate funds to real assets, and manage the flow of funds back to the investors. Topics will vary according to interests of students, instructors, and developments in the field.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative. Education Program in Commerce.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

name: New Product Development
desc: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

name: Leadership and General Management
desc: Integration and application of business knowledge to make business decisions across disciplines; development of personal leadership ability and style. Case-based with guest speakers.

name: Sustainability Marketing
desc: Role of marketing in creating social value. Integration of marketing fundamentals with core social, environmental, and economic principles of sustainability. Analysis of current sustainability trends. Development of strategic and practical marketing recommendations for for-profit enterprises. Potential and pitfalls of sustainability marketing.

name: Social Entrepreneurship
desc: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods.

name: Environmental Management
desc: Explores corporate environmental strategy by introducing economic principles underlying environmental policy, law, and technologies for pollution prevention and abatement, environmental management systems, ISO-14001, energy systems, eco-marketing, and life-cycle analysis.  Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 487 or COMM 597.

name: Public Sector Management
desc: This course focuses on some of the distinctive aspects of managing in the public sector.

name: Applied Methods in Technology Start-ups at CDL
desc: Students work with the Creative Destruction Lab team to help start-ups that are focused on science and emerging technology.  Students support real companies with market analysis, customer development, financial analysis, and will see how investors make decisions.

name: Directed Studies in Commerce
desc: An investigation and report on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and a senior student.

name: Strategic Management
desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of private sector, single and multi-business unit enterprises are analysed using the case method. Methodologies which draw on economic and organizational theory are integrated to form the foundations for strategic analyses.
prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

name: Management Simulation
desc: Student teams manage hypothetical firms in a complex simulation, coordinating production, finance, marketing and strategic planning in competition with other teams.
prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

name: Strategic Management in Business
desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year).
prer: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.
crer: One of COMM 329, COMR 329 and one of COMM 465, COMR 465 and one of COMM 473, COMR 473.

name: Business and Sustainable Development
desc: An overview of environmental issues, focusing on corporate strategy, government policy and interactions between these two sectors of the economy.

name: New Enterprise Development
desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466, COMM 497, COEC 497, COMR 497, and APSC 486.
prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

name: International Business Management
desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 498 or COEC 498.
prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

name: Background to Medical Laboratory Science
desc: Introductory lectures and laboratory sessions in clinical chemistry, haematology and blood banking, hospital microbiology, preparation and examination of tissue sections. For Medical Laboratory Science students without previous experience in hospital laboratories. [3-4; 0-0]
prer: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 123, CHEM 205, CHEM 233, CHEM 235, MICB 202.

name: Basic and Physical Biochemistry for Medical Laboratory Scientists
desc: An integrated approach to specific areas of the theoretical and practical aspects of those physical and biological sciences relevant to medical laboratory science. Emphasis will be placed upon the application of basic science to those clinical disciplines practised by the medical laboratory scientist, e.g., histochemistry, clinical chemistry, microbiology, haematology, etc.

name: Cytogenetics, Molecular Genetics, Tissue Culture & Cytology
desc: Fundamentals of human genetics and molecular biology as they relate to studying and detecting disease in a population; tissue culture techniques to assess cell viabilities; cytomorphology principles in disease detection.

name: Normal Human Histology
desc: An advanced lecture and laboratory course in the microscopic structure of the human body necessary for a complete understanding of histochemistry and histopathology.

name: Modern Microscopy
desc: Theoretical and practical application of widely used microscopy techniques.

name: Laboratory Safety for Medical Laboratory Scientists
desc: Control processes for workplace hazards of radiological, chemical, and biological origin.

name: Bacteriology, Mycology, Virology and Parasitology
desc: Descriptions of each group of human microbial pathogens according to biological attributes, clinical features, pathogenesis and pathology, epidemiology, immunological reactions, laboratory diagnosis, principles of antimicrobial therapy, preventative measures. For students in the Faculty of Medicine B.M.L.Sc.

name: Introduction to Human Pathology
desc: A lecture-demonstration course designed to acquaint students in the allied health professions with a basic understanding of the causes, natural history, and pathophysiology of common disease processes.
prer: 6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM

name: Medical Laboratory Science: Haematology
desc: A theoretical and practical examination of those modern concepts of haematology which relate to the practice of medical laboratory science.

name: Diagnostic Histochemistry
desc: A lecture and laboratory course that encompasses the theory and the practice of currently available histochemical techniques. This course is to supplement the histopathological technique course taken as a requirement for CSLT (RT).

name: Seminars in Current Topics
desc: Oral and written presentation and critical appraisal of scientific papers.

name: Clinical Chemistry
desc: This course will review and discuss the methodology of clinical chemistry in order to put these analytical methods into the broad perspective of the pathophysiology of human disease and biochemistry.

name: Medical Laboratory Toxicology: Analytical, Clinical
desc: A theoretical and practical examination of analytical and pathophysiological aspects of clinical and forensic toxicology.

name: Research and Career Skills
desc: Overall operation of research laboratories including roles of personnel and funding; communication of scientific research; career skills and pathways; communication, collaboration, presentations and peer-assessment skills.

name: Immunopathology
desc: Immunological events causing tissue injury.

name: Human Bacterial Infections
desc: Students acquire content relating to the virulence factors of the bacteria and the pathophysiology of the host while working through case scenarios on their own and in online groups. Students taking this course must be willing to engage in both self-directed and small-group learning.

name: Basic Principles of Infection Prevention and Control
desc: This course provides the basic principles to prevent the spread of microorganisms pathogenic to humans. It may be taken towards a Certificate in Infection Control.

name: Viral Infections in Humans
desc: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; prompt virological diagnosis; rationale for antiviral chemotherapy and prophylaxis. [3-0-0]

name: Medical Laboratory Science: Directed Studies
desc: Investigation of a specific topic in Medical Laboratory Science. Permission of the department head is required.

name: Directed Studies
desc: An elective in clinical infection control, medical microbiology or molecular biology.

name: Introduction to Laboratory Medicine
desc: An elective course open to first-year medical students who spend at least three consecutive hours each week in one of the affiliated hospitals of the Department of Pathology, Vancouver Hospital, under the joint supervision of a Senior Resident in Pathology and the Professional Staff of the following Divisions: anatomical pathology, clinical biochemistry, haematology, pediatric pathology. Enrolment is limited.

name: Systemic Pathology
desc: A series of Pathology discussions in conjunction with various clinical departments designed to illustrate the role of Pathology in the diagnosis and management of various diseases.

name: Clerkship in Laboratory Medicine and Infection Prevention and Control
desc: May involve attendance at an approved institution and/or a project assigned by the instructor(s). Instructor permission required. Enrolment may be limited.

name: Clerkship in Anatomic Pathology
desc: An elective course open to third-year medical students, designed to familiarize the student with Anatomic Pathology, including Surgical Pathology, Pediatric Pathology, Autopsy Pathology and Cytology. This elective may involve attendance at one or more affiliated hospitals. Registration requires consent of the Department and enrolment may be limited.

name: Clinical Laboratory Haematology
desc: Correlative seminars based on haematology case studies relating clinical features to laboratory investigations.

name: Clinical Laboratory Microbiology
desc: Selected clinical laboratory exercises plus seminars to illustrate the diagnosis and management of patients with microbial infections. Elective course limited to third- and fourth-year medical students.

name: Basic Microbiology for Infection Control
desc: The identification, clinical significance, and transmission of pathogenic organisms are presented. This course is available by correspondence or webCT. It may be taken towards fulfillment of the Certificate in Infection Control.

name: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
desc: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control.

name: Mineralogy for Mining Engineering
desc: Fundamentals of the rock and minerals formation. Exploring main techniques used to understand implications of mineralogy in mining and mineral processing.

name: Introduction to Mining
desc: Leading practices and technologies employed in the design, planning, and operation of mining systems. Life cycle of surface and underground mining systems.

name: Introduction to Mineral Processing
desc: Overview; extracting a mineral or final product from an ore.

name: Seminar
desc: Oral presentations of topics on mine safety by students. Graded on basis of presentations, summaries of guest speaker presentations, mining processes, and final exam. [1-0-0]

name: Underground Mining and Design
desc: Selection, design, and development of underground mining methods based upon physical, geological, economic, and environmental constraints. Underground excavation methods and equipment selection.

name: Rock Mechanics Fundamentals
desc: The study of the mechanical and structural properties of rock materials at the laboratory and field scale, with reference to common mining, geological and civil engineering problems.
prer: CIVL 210 and one of MECH 260, CIVL 230.

name: Rock Fragmentation
desc: Theory and practice of rock fragmentation by drilling and blasting; introduction to explosives and initiation systems; design of surface and underground blasts; machine excavation systems for tunneling and stoping; environmental impacts, safety, and risk assessment.

name: Surface Mining and Design
desc: Surface mining methods, calculation of pit limits, cutoff grades, break-even criteria, stripping ratios, ultimate pit depth and dimensions, and pit sequencing.  Geotechnical inputs to surface mine design.  Loading and hauling equipment, production rates, capacity and systems.

name: Physical Mineral Processes
desc: Mineral processing unit operations and sampling, crushing, grinding, screening, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, electrostatic separation, concentrate dewatering practices.

name: Flotation
desc: Theory and technology of flotation and ancillary processes.

name: Modelling and Simulation
desc: Methods for determining the behaviour of large scale industrial systems and their application to the design and analysis of such systems.

name: Mine Waste Management
desc: Basic geotechnical, hydrological, and water management aspects of mine waste management.

name: Seminar
desc: Oral presentation of topics by instructor and guest lecturers.

name: Mineral Deposit Modelling
desc: Types of mineral deposits. Exploration and sampling methods. Methods for data analysis and computer modelling of mineral deposits and their use in production planning and design.

name: Engineering Economics
desc: Discrete and continuous cash flow models, discounted cash flow analysis, effects of depreciation and taxes, economic analysis of projects, sensitivity and risk analysis, financing and cost of capital.

name: Mine Ventilation and Occupational Health and Safety
desc: Design and analysis for ventilation systems for mining. Topics such as ventilation design, ventilation surveys, thermodynamic aspects, psychrometry of air and air conditioning.

name: Rock Mechanics Design
desc: The design of rock slopes and underground openings with respect to stress, structure and the rock mass. Stabilization and monitoring of rock movement.

name: Strategic Issues in Mining
desc: Strategic issues in an organization; types of organizations; personnel evaluations and job rating systems; impact of manpower planning on decision-making; union negotiations; public relations; dealing with the media; corporate responsibilities to society and employees.
prer: Third- or Fourth-year standing in Mining Engineering.

name: Introduction to Risk Management for Mining and Large Industrial Projects
desc: Risk management and its application to mining and large industrial projects, including risk analysis, treatment, and governance.

name: Mine Project Valuation and Risk Assessment
desc: Mineral economics and finance. Analytical tools and techniques used in the valuation of mining companies and the financial analysis and risk assessment methods. [2-2-0]

name: Applied Geostatistics
desc: Geostatistical analysis and simulation of spatiotemporal phenomena in natural and engineered systems with applications to mining problems.

name: Mineral Process Control
desc: Automatic control theory, PID control, Laplace and z-transforms, loop tuning, frequency response, stability analysis, control strategies in flotation, comminution, dewatering, reagent and bin/sump levels, automated load-haul-dump and drilling equipment, instrumentation and soft sensors.

name: Processing Precious Metal Ores
desc: Process alternatives and mineralogical considerations; physical and chemical recovery technologies; environmental protection; flowsheet studies.

name: Plant and Process Design
desc: Design of unit operations in a mineral processing plant including crushing, grinding, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, flotation, thickening and filtration. Equipment selection and sizing, flowsheet design, circuit analysis and processing options.

name: Industrial Mixing
desc: Fundamentals of mixing technology, and industrial mixing systems and equipment. Selection, design, monitor, and scale-up mixing systems for mining applications.
prer: MATH 255 and one of MECH 280, CIVL 215.

name: Advanced Process Mineralogy
desc: Textural parameters, such as mineral liberation size and mineral associations in connection with the mineral processing techniques for mineral recovery.

name: Mine Water Management
desc: Mine water management covering integrated water resource management, water balances, sources, water use optimization, water quality and treatment and long term stewardship. [2-2-0]

name: Coal Preparation Technology
desc: Thermal and metallurgical coals: objectives of their cleaning; coal washability and flotability fundamentals; coal preparation unit operations; performance characteristics of coal washing equipment; products dewatering; plant flowsheets.

name: Materials Handling
desc: Knowledge and understanding of equipment used in mining operations, including diesel, electro-mechanical, hydraulic and pneumatic equipment as well as conveyors, load-haul-dump trucks and pumps. [2-2-0]

name: Indigenous Peoples and Mining in Canada
desc: Historical context of Indigenous peoples of Canada interactions with the development of mineral resources. Current best practices and systems supporting effective engagement and involvement of Indigenous peoples in the development of mines and mineral resources.

name: Maintenance Engineering
desc: Analytical foundation for maintenance of industrial plant equipment and mobile equipment in various production environments; maintenance planning and management, life cycle analysis, reliability theory, total quality maintenance, condition monitoring.

name: Cave Mining Systems: Design and Planning
desc: Designs, planning, and leading practices are applied to underground mining systems reliant on induced and controlled rock mass caving.

name: Mining and The Environment
desc: Environmental topics of importance to engineers practicing within the mining, metallurgical and related industries including technical practices, regulatory and public issues.

name: Heavy Oil Sand Mining and Processing
desc: Life cycle of the production of Oil Sands resources, including mining, bitumen extraction, and reclamation.

name: Mine and Plant Engineering Design Feasibility Study
desc: Mining Engineering design project from scope definition to final design and project feasibility. Based on a problem from industry and/or research.
prer: All of MINE 302, MINE 303, MINE 304, MINE 310, MINE 331, MINE 333, MINE 350, MINE 396. Fourth-year standing in Mining Engineering is required.

name: Seminar
desc: Oral presentation of a technical nature. Use of closed circuit television for personal evaluation.

name: Directed Studies
desc: Requires approval of the department head.

name: Reading and Writing about Literature
desc: A writing-intensive introduction to the disciplines of literary studies through the exploration of texts in their critical and theoretical contexts. Fulfils the first-year component of the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement. Open only to students in the Faculty of Arts. Recommended for students intending to become English majors. Essays are required.

name: Approaches to Literature
desc: Study of selected examples of poetry, fiction, and drama. Essays are required.

name: Approaches to Non-fictional Prose
desc: Study of a selection of prose texts ranging in length from the essay to the book, with emphasis on writing of the twentieth century. Essays are required.

name: Literature and Criticism
desc: Enriched study of selected works of literature from a number of critical perspectives. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of "A" (86%) in English 12 or "B+" (80%) in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

name: Introduction to Literary Theory
desc: Enriched study of various theories of literature. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of "A" (86%) in English 12 or "B+" (80%) in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

name: Challenging Language Myths
desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note: This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

name: Principles of Literary Studies
desc: A collaboratively-taught exploration and application of key scholarly, theoretical and critical approaches informing the study of literatures in English.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: An Introduction to English Honours
desc: For Honours students accepted by the English Honours Committee on the recommendation of the instructor. Students permitted to take this course must take ENGL 211 concurrently.
prer: Restricted to students in the Honours program.

name: Seminar for English Honours
desc: An introduction to practical criticism; required of and open only to students of ENGL 210. A limited number of texts from a range of genres and periods will be chosen for close critical analysis.

name: Literature in English to the 18th Century
desc: A survey of prose, poetry and drama to the 18th Century.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Literature in Britain: the 18th Century to the Present
desc: A survey of poetry, drama, fiction and non-fiction prose from the 18th century to the present.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Literature in Canada
desc: The major types of Canadian writing: fiction, poetry, non-fictional prose, and drama
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Literature in the United States
desc: The major types of American writing: fiction, poetry, drama and non-fictional prose.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: World Literature in English
desc: English literature produced outside Britain and North America.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Poetry
desc: Principles, methods, and resources for reading poetry.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Drama
desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading drama.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Prose Fiction
desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading the novel and the short story.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Topics in Literary and/or Cultural Studies
desc: Current research interests in English studies.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Topics in the Study of Language and/or Rhetoric
desc: Consult Department's website for current year's offerings.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Introduction to Indigenous Literatures
desc: A study of cultural expression in contemporary indigenous contexts.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Approaches to Media Studies
desc: Approaches to the study of media: philosophical; technological; cultural; theoretical.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Shakespeare Now
desc: Introductory topics in Shakespeare studies that seek to identify relationships between Shakespeare's work and present-day issues and concerns.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Introduction to Children's and Young Adult Literature
desc: History, genres, and scholarly study of writing for children and adolescents.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Speculative Fiction
desc: Genres and sub-genres of speculative fiction, such as science fiction and fantasy, alternate history, dystopian and post-apocalyptic narrative, and slipstream, as well as the intersections among them.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Environment and Literature
desc: Literary, critical, and/or pop-culture texts about environmentalism and ecology.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Comics and Graphic Media
desc: Introduction to the critical study of comics and graphic media.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Literature and Film
desc: Approaches to the study of the relationships between literature and film.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Television Studies
desc: Introduction to methods and practices of television studies, with emphasis on the use of literary approaches to televisual narrative.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Mystery and Detective Fiction
desc: Thematic and generic approaches to mystery, crime, and detective writing in English, primarily short-fiction and novels; may also include comics, radio, film, and television.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Literary Nonfiction
desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading literary non-fiction, including personal essays, memoir, and literary journalism. May also include nature, travel or food writing or graphic memoir.
prer: Second-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) ARTS 001 or (c) ASTU 100 or (d) ASTU 101 or (e) WRDS 150 or (f) WRDS 350. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Technical Writing
desc: Study of the principles of written communication in general business and professional activities, and practice in the preparation of abstracts, proposals, reports, and correspondence. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Theory: Meaning and Interpretation
desc: An investigation and overview of theories of interpretation and meaning-making.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Theory: Signs, Codes, and Representation
desc: Semiotic and sociocultural aspects of the linguistic turn in critical theory; can include such areas as structuralism, poststructuralism and deconstruction, speech act theory and performativity, assemblage theory, or new media semiotics.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of (a) WRDS 150 or 350; (b) ASTU 100 or 101; (c) ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Theory: Anti-/De-/Post-Colonization
desc: Theoretical work concerned with confronting, resisting and overcoming various forms of colonialism and globalization.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of WRDS 150 or 350; ASTU 100 or 101; ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Theory: Space and Displacement
desc: Critical theories of space and movement, place and displacement and how these theories reflect on cultural performances, subjectivity and social environment.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of (a) WRDS 150 or 350; (b) ASTU 100 or 101; (c) ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Theory: Critique, Intervention and Dissent
desc: Examines theories of intervention, dissent and social engagement.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Theory: Bodies
desc: Theories of corporeality and embodied thought.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of (a) WRDS 150 or 350; (b) ASTU 100 or 101; (c) ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Theory: Feminisms
desc: Relationships between feminist theory, literature, and language.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of (a) WRDS 150 or 350; (b) ASTU 100 or 101; (c) ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Life Narratives
desc: Analysis of modes of self-representation through theoretical, critical, historical, and methodological frameworks.
prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third-year standing; and 3 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English or one of WRDS 150 or 350; ASTU 100 or 101; ARTS 001. Recommended: 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English and/or writing courses.

name: Children's Literature
desc: Genres and texts written for and appropriated by young readers. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 392 and/or 468.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Ecocriticism
desc: Ecocriticism and the environmental humanities encompassing more specific methodologies, such as queer ecology, ecofeminism, postcolonial, decolonizing, and transnational environmentalisms, environmental art.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Canadian Environmental Writing
desc: Ecocritical theory and its application to Canadian literature, including Indigenous authors. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 394 and/or 458.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Studies in Poetry
desc: Poetry organized by thematic approach, cultural movements, critical issues, and/or geopolitical regions. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 395 and/or 402.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Studies in Drama
desc: Plays organized by thematic approach, cultural movements, critical issues, and/or geopolitical regions. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 396 and/or 405.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Studies in Prose Fiction
desc: Novels and short stories organized by thematic approach, cultural movements, critical issues, and/or geopolitical regions. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 397 and/or 406.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Community-Facing Applications of Language and Literary Studies
desc: Principles and practice of adapting the disciplinary work of language and/or literary studies to the needs of community partners.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised work experience related to English studies, in an approved company or organization for a minimum of 455 hours. Orientation workshops and final reports.
prer: Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.

desc: Required of all Language Majors.  See department website (http://www.english.ubc.ca/ugrad/majors/compl_lang.htm) for options.

name: Literature Majors Seminar
desc: Required of all Literature Majors. See Department Website (www.english.ubc.ca) for options.

name: Senior Honours Seminar

name: Directed Readings in English Literature
desc: For Honours students only.

name: Studies in an Asian Language (Basic Course)
desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of an Asian language not normally taught in the Department. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details.

name: Studies in an Asian Language (Intermediate Course)
prer: ASLA 300. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.

name: Introduction to a Salish Language I
desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed.

name: Introduction to a Salish Language II
desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

name: Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
desc: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages.

name: Introduction to an Indigenous Language I
desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

name: Intermediate Salish Language I
desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context.

desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

name: Intermediate Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

name: Intermediate Ktunaxa Language II
desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

name: Sounds of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
desc: Development of skills in the perception and transcription of speech sounds in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Indigenous languages. Capacity-building techniques for digital recording, editing, analysis, and archiving; guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

name: Structures of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
desc: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Indigenous languages. Applied techniques in documentation, workflow and multi-media digital annotation, guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

name: Intermediate Indigenous Language I
desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

name: Intermediate Indigenous Language II
desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

name: Advanced Salish Language I
desc: Emphasis on advanced comprehension and production skills. Extended focus on skills in oral traditions, transcription, literacy, and on deepening the understanding of grammatical structures and dialectal variation. Not offered every year.

name: Advanced Salish Language II
desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

name: Technologies for Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
desc: Digital tools for endangered language documentation, conservation, and revitalization. Overview of best practices, introduction to community engagement and capacity-building, protocols and ethics, project design, cultural context, orthographies, use of audio, video and still photography, data management, archiving and web publishing.

name: Biocultural Diversity: Language, Community, and Environment
desc: Critical exploration of the links between linguistic, biological and cultural diversity; including connections with linguistic relativity, linguistic identity, language and place; and strategies for collective, interdisciplinary action to promote and support the protection of languages, cultures, and the environment.

name: Lexicography for Endangered Languages
desc: Foundational concepts in the discipline of compiling, editing, managing and hosting dictionaries, also known as lexicography. Special focus on the technical and ethical considerations for community-based lexicography projects for endangered and BC First Nations languages.

name: Collaborative Heritage Research in First Nations Languages: Practicum & Workshop
desc: Hands-on experience planning and producing a Breath of Life Language Reclamation Workshop for endangered BC First Nations languages, during which community-based researchers access and interpret relevant heritage resources at UBC and other local institutions for the revitalization of their languages.
crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 389.

name: Directed Research in First Nations Languages
desc: Supervised by a faculty member.
prer: Agreement of Supervisor and approval of Chair of FNEL program.

name: Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
desc: Critical study of the historical, social, cultural, political, and economic factors impacting on language loss, retention, and revival. Research on and application of methodologies for collaborative, trans-disciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization of BC's Indigenous linguistic heritage.

name: Heritage Resources in Endangered First Nations Language Revitalization
desc: Examines the complementary and intersecting roles of libraries, archives, and museums in collections acquisition, development, curation, preservation, and access traditions pertaining to First Nations languages, to explore how each can contribute to endangered language and cultural heritage sustainability.
prer: One of FNEL 180, FNEL 281, FNEL 282 or permission of the instructor.

name: Applied Research in Endangered Language Reclamation
desc: Application of research skills and methodologies in the design and implementation of a research project relevant to endangered language conservation and/or revitalization. Project co-constructed in collaboration with a First Nations community, guided by community-based ethical protocols. FNEL 481 recommended.
crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282, FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 482.

name: Indigenous Languages of BC: Diversity and Vitality
desc: Genetic affiliation, areal contact, typological diversity, and initiatives to sustain the vitality and diversity of BC First Nations Languages.

name: Topics in First Nations and Endangered Languages
desc: Selected topics will vary. Multiple versions of this course may be taken, under consultation with the FNEL program advisor, for up to a maximum of 12 credits.

name: Applied Meteorology
desc: Atmospheric-science principles elucidated by case studies applied to snow sports, sailing, surfing, soaring, and flying. [3-0-0]

name: Meteorology of Storms
desc: Characteristics and physical processes of thunderstorms, tornadoes, lightning, hail, hurricanes, blizzards, cyclones and other storms. [3-0-0]

name: Earth and Atmospheric Science Introductory Computing Laboratory
desc: Computing tools, including Unix/Linux, Web page creation, programming languages used for numerical calculation, database programs. [0-2]

name: Atmospheric Radiation and Remote Sensing
desc: Energy transfer at infrared, visible, and microwave wavelengths. Analysis of satellite measurements of the atmosphere and surface. [3-0-0]
prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158 and familiarity with a programming language.

name: Methods in Atmospheric Science
desc: An introduction to instrumentation used in monitoring the state of the atmosphere; a brief survey of methods of analysis of meteorological data. [2-2-0]
prer: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, GEOB 200.

name: Renewable Energy Meteorology
desc: The meteorology of hydro, wind, and solar power. Atmospheric processes affecting renewable energy on global, regional & local weather scales. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, DSCI 100, EOSC 211.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Winter Session (Term 2) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

name: Dynamic Meteorology
desc: Dynamic principles governing atmospheric motions on a rotating planet. Simplified mathematical models of atmospheric flow based on scale analysis. Application to synoptic-scale and general circulation of the troposphere. [3-0-0]
prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316 and one of EOSC 250, MATH 217, MATH 317.

name: Cloud Physics and Chemistry
desc: Cloud thermodynamics, chemistry and microphysics. Computer modelling of droplet growth, convection, and mixing. Application of differential equations to atmospheric problems. [3-0-0]
prer: MATH 215. Familiarity with a programming language is required.

name: Operational Meteorology
desc: Introduction to meteorological prediction, meteorological data analysis, prognosis of weather systems, motion and development, satellite imagery, Doppler radar, numerical weather prediction, synoptic and mesoscale forecasting, applied laboratory exercises. [2-2-0]

name: Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
desc: Web-based introduction to the practical numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations including considerations of stability and accuracy. Credit will be granted for only one of ATSC 409 or ATSC 506/EOSC 511. [0-0-3]
prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265. Familiarity with a programming language is required.

name: Directed Studies
desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of the undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

name: Honours Project
desc: Honours students must submit a graduating report based on a project undertaken with the approval of the Associate Chair of the Atmospheric Science Program.

name: Student Directed Seminars in Atmospheric Science
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in atmospheric science, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.
prer: ATSC 399 and one of ATSC 303, GEOB 304.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

name: Khichri: The South Asian Languages of Vancouver
desc: A systematic introduction to the grammars and scripts of Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi and Sanskrit, primarily through the media of Indo-Canadian popular culture (film, radio, bhangra, etc.)

name: Supervised Study in South Asian Languages
Introductory Medical Biochemistry
desc: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-0]

name: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
desc: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-1]
prer: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223.

name: Biochemistry Laboratory
desc: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied. [0-3-1]

name: General Biochemistry
desc: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-1]
prer: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.

name: Molecular Biochemistry
desc: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences.  Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.

name: Contemporary Biochemical Research
desc: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues. [3-0-0]

name: Internship Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
prer: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.

name: Internship Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Proteins: Structure and Function
desc: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

name: Enzymology
desc: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOC 402. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.

name: Biochemical Methods
desc: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor. [1-0; 2-0]

name: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function
desc: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

name: Advanced Biochemical Techniques
desc: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor. [0-6-0]

name: Recombinant DNA Techniques
desc: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry. [0-6-0]

name: Concepts in Molecular Biology
desc: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Directed Studies in Biochemistry
desc: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
prer: Permission of the Department Head is required.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

name: Membrane Biochemistry
desc: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
desc: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Biochemistry & Society: Current Issues
desc: Biochemical basis of select global challenges. Critical evaluation of primary literature to form evidence-based opinions and communicating biochemistry as it relates to several controversial societal issues. [3-0-1]

name: Student Directed Seminars
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Not given every year. [3-0-0]

name: Internship Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Internship Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Selected Topics in Infant Development and Supported Child Development
desc: Formerly EPSE 380

name: Introduction to Early Childhood Education and Care
Supporting Young Children's Health and Well-Being in Early Childhood Settings
Foundations of Curriculum and Instruction in Early Childhood Education
Early Learning Curriculum in the Pre-School Years
desc: The development of pre-kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, and curriculum trends and practices.

name: Supporting Early Learning in the Pre-School Years
desc: Planning and implementing pre-kindergarten learning experiences; resources, materials, curriculum integration, evaluation, scheduling, and classroom design.

name: Supporting Learning in The Primary Years
desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the primary years (grades 1-3).

name: Kindergarten Curriculum
desc: The development of kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, curriculum trends and practices, and the place of kindergarten in contemporary education.

name: Supporting Learning in the Kindergarten Year
desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the kindergarten year.

name: History of Early Childhood Education
desc: Political and social factors which influenced movements and trends in early childhood education in North America, pre-kindergarten through primary.

name: Supporting Young Children Through Home, School, and Community Relationships
Advanced Studies in Early Childhood Education
Observation and Documentation in Early Childhood Settings
Assessment of Infants and Young Children with Special Needs
desc: (Formerly EPSE 420).

name: Supporting Social and Communication Development in Infants and Young Children with Special Needs
desc: (Formerly EPSE 440).

name: Early Intervention for Infants and Young Children with Sensory Loss and Motor Impairments
desc: (Formerly EPSE 441).

name: Supporting Indigenous Infants and Young Children within the Context of Their Communities
Selected Topics in Early Childhood Education
Early Childhood Education Practicum & Seminar I
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Early Childhood Education Practicum & Seminar II
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: All of ECED 400, ECED 401, ECED 438, ECED 490, EPSE 406.

name: Early Childhood Education Practicum & Seminar III
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: All of ECED 400, ECED 401, ECED 406, ECED 407, ECED 438, ECED 490, ECED 491, EPSE 406.

name: Introduction to Traditional Asia
desc: A survey of the histories and cultures of Asia before 1600 and the coming of the Europeans. Emphasis will be given to parallel themes in the development of the civilizations of South, Southeast and East Asia.

name: Introduction to Modern Asia
desc: A survey of the emergence of modern Asia. Aims at an understanding of how the various peoples of Asia have maintained distinctive cultural identities despite centuries of political, economic, social and cultural change.

name: Introduction to Religions in Asia
desc: A survey of religious traditions of Asia, including communities, professionals, practices and beliefs of small-scale and large-scale societies. Approaches and theories drawn from the field of religious studies.

name: Asian Internets
desc: The cultures of contemporary Asia through an exploration of the uses, form, and content of online media from and about Asia.

name: Cultural Foundations of East Asia
desc: A comparative survey of the beliefs, assumptions and values which have shaped the civilizations of East Asia in both traditional and modern times.

name: Introduction to Asian Religions
desc: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

name: Modern Islam
desc: History and culture, values, and sociopolitical movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

name: Classical Islam
desc: History and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

name: Cultural Foundations of South Asia
desc: A survey of South Asian cultures, including language and literature, art, religion, polity and society, as they developed in the past and have been transformed in the modern period.

name: Cultural Foundations of Southeast Asia
desc: A comparative survey of the different cultures found in the communities of Southeast Asia. Focus will be on language and literature, arts, religion, society and polity, ideologies and belief systems in the past as well as in modern times.

name: Traditions of Yoga
desc: Philosophical, religious, and cultural development of yoga in classical and medieval South Asia and its relation to contemporary globalized practice.

name: Sex, Sexual Ethics, and Asian Religions
desc: Sex and sexual ethics in the scriptures, monastic rules, rituals, and narratives of Asian religions, such as Sikhism, Hinduism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

name: Writing About Japan
desc: Literary, historiographic, religious, and feminist approaches to Japanese myths, legal tracts, religious tales, fiction, and poetry.

name: Myth, Literature, and Film in North India
desc: Indian literary and mythological texts, in genres from epic to lyric, as recast in contemporary Hindi film.

name: Encountering Asia
desc: Introduction to the literary, religious, and philosophical traditions of at least two Asian cultures using foundational texts. Students will learn about these traditions by encountering them historically as well as through the lenses of their own diverse identities and contexts.

name: Writing Asia
desc: This writing-intensive course is to be taken concurrently with ASIA 222. The seminar builds on the materials of ASIA 222. Students must have knowledge of or be enrolled in the study of one of the languages offered in Asian Studies.

name: Introduction to Buddhism
desc: Origins, basic teachings, development of Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantric traditions, historical spread first through Asia and later the world, and Buddhism in contemporary societies.

name: Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Japanese Literature and Film
desc: The integral role that sex, gender, and sexuality play in literary and cinematic works from Japan. Literary works will be read in translation, movies will be subtitled.

name: Religion in South Asia
desc: The major religious traditions of South Asia, including Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, and Buddhism; the significance of religious thought and practice in premodern India, as well as the continuing impact of religion in today's globalized South Asia.

name: China in World History
desc: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

name: Writing and Culture in East Asia
desc: Practical, aesthetic, historical, technological and political issues pertaining to the use of Chinese characters - hanzi (Chinese), kanji (Japanese), or hanccha (Korean) - throughout the region.

name: Buddhism in the Modern Era
desc: Buddhism from the nineteenth century to present day with special emphasis on its history and character in local settings, including specific traditions such as Tibetan Nyingma and Japanese Zen, as well as the development of a modern and global "Buddhism."

name: Theravada Buddhism
desc: History, story, and culture of the major form of Buddhism primarily focused on the regions of Sri Lanka, and mainland Southeast Asia, including southern Vietnam, parts of southern China, spread to Nepal, and modern global diffusion.

name: Mahayana Buddhism
desc: Historical and philosophical development of Mahayana Buddhism.

name: Survey of South and Southeast Asian Performing Arts
desc: An historical perspective of the performing arts of South and Southeast Asia, highlighting the role of music, dance, and the dramatic arts in the lives of actors and audiences.  Option to complete a practicum performance.

name: Asian Horror Cinema: National Nightmares and Specters of Trauma
desc: Engaging with the ideologies, industrial histories, socio-cultural contexts, and aesthetics of horror films - and the genre itself - from various Asian cinemas.

name: Esoteric Buddhism
desc: Overview of Buddhism's rich and complex esoteric traditions in the Himalayan region and South, Southeast, and East Asia, with particular emphasis on texts, commentaries, and practices from a variety of traditions, locales and time periods.

name: Korean Language and Writing in Culture and Society
desc: An examination of Korean language and writing using approaches from sociolinguistics, the sociology of language, and linguistic anthropology.

name: Myth, Ritual and Epic in Ancient India
desc: Myths of creation Gods and goddesses of the Vedic pantheon. Connections with myths in other parts of the world, particularly in the Indo-European tradition. Literary representations of the myths.

name: South Asian Beyond South Asia
desc: A history of South Asian peoples and communities that emigrated overseas, including Indo-Canadians.

name: Studies in the History of a Major Asian Civilization
desc: Study of an Asian culture area different from those covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

name: Tibetan Buddhism
desc: Religious terrain of the Tibetan cultural realm, looking at the history and development of Tibetan Buddhism and key ideas of the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions.

name: Buddhism in Korea
desc: Historical, cultural and philosophical development of Korean Buddhism.

name: Tibetan and Himalayan Culture and Society
desc: History and culture of the Himalayan regions, including India, China, Tibet, Nepal, and Bhutan.

name: Premodern Japan
desc: Japanese history (political, economic, social and cultural) to 1600.

name: Japan from Feudal to Modern State
desc: Japanese history from 1600 to the Meiji Restoration. Political, economic, social and cultural forces which were involved in transforming Japan.

name: Race and Ethnicity in Japanese Literature and Film
desc: Examines relations between majority and minority groups in Japanese society and changing definitions of "Japan" through literature and film from Japan.

name: The Rise of Korean Civilization
desc: The evolution of a distinctive Korean civilization within the East Asian cultural sphere. Primary focus on cultural, social and political development from the earliest times to the sixteenth century.

name: Premodern India
desc: A survey of the history and culture of India from the earliest historic period to 1200 and the coming of Islam, with emphasis on the evolution of classical Hindu civilization.

name: Contemporary Chinese Popular Cultures
desc: Chinese popular cultures of the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries, in relation to social changes, national policies, individual choices, everyday experience, and globalization.

name: History of Early China
desc: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

name: Celebrity Culture in Chinese Societies
desc: Histories, controversies, and implications of celebrity culture in Chinese societies, with a focus on the entanglement of author, audience, and media across different sociopolitical contexts.

name: History of Cantonese Worlds
desc: The history, culture, languages, and identities of the multi-faceted Cantonese worlds, in the context of Chinese history and the Cantonese diaspora.

name: Literature of Hong Kong
desc: A survey of the literature of Hong Kong, from classical times to the present. Important periods in literary history (imperial, colonial, post-colonial), major authors (locals, visitors, and writers elsewhere), and important genres, including poetry, essays, and fiction.

name: Hong Kong Cinema
desc: A survey of the cinema of Hong Kong from the post-war period to the present. The influence of Hong Kong on global cinema, and the forces (artists, studios, audiences, etc.) that have given rise to filmmaking styles and genres perceived as "distinctively Hong Kong."

name: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
desc: A critical introduction to Japanese manga and anime in the 20th and 21st centuries.

name: Korean Popular Music in Context
desc: History, contexts, and the genres of Korean popular music. Students will analyze specific artists and songs using a range of approaches. While an understanding of basic concepts of music will be helpful, no previous exposure to ethnomusicology or music performance is required.

name: Gender in South and Southeast Asia
desc: A critical examination of what it means to be a woman or a man within the social and cultural context of South and Southeast Asia. What "masculinity" and "femininity" signify in these societies; how these concepts are reaffirmed or challenged.

name: Islam in South Asia (1750 - present)
desc: The history of Islam in South Asia from the fragmentation of the Mughal Empire through the rise of Islamic reform movements under colonial rule and the formation of modern Muslim subjecthood.

name: Islam in South Asia (750-1750)
desc: The history of Islam in South Asia beginning with the first Indo-Islamic interactions, the crystallization of Sufi traditions and sultanates, through the rise of European colonialism.

name: Confucianism in China and Beyond: Reinventions of Tradition
desc: Key ideas and trends in Confucian thought and practice from its origins to modern times through primary sources in translation and secondary scholarship.

name: Contemporary South Asian Gender and Sexuality Studies
desc: Main theories and key concepts with a particular focus on the changing status of women, and gender and sexual minorities.

name: Writing Women in Premodern East Asia
