desc: The construction of gender in literary writings by and about women in select areas of premodern East Asia.

name: Cantonese Music
desc: A history of musical genres with Cantonese lyrics from the nineteenth century to the present.  Topics include music and text relationships, major singers, major genres (narrative songs, Cantonese opera, Cantopop).

name: Sufi and Bhakti Devotional Literatures
desc: Sufi and Bhakti thought and tradition in South Asia through literary works in translation.

name: The Korean People in Modern Times (1600 to the present)
desc: The transformation of Korea from a Confucian state into an industrial nation. The rise of nationalism and modern ideologies in Korea. Cultural, social and economic changes Korea has undergone as it has entered the modern world.

name: India in the Age of Revolutions
desc: History of the political shifts and revolutions that transformed India to a British colony.

name: The Construction of South Asian Communities in the Diaspora
desc: An examination of contemporary South Asian communities in the diaspora. Topics of particular importance are family life, religious life, notions of space, communal memory, literary and visual representation.

name: History of Later Imperial China
desc: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation.  Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

name: Classical Chinese Literature in Translation
desc: Poetry, historical and philosophic prose writings and the earliest genres of fiction in classical Chinese (ca. 1100 BC – ca. 750 AD).

name: Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
desc: Readings in drama and fiction, 800 to 1800 AD. The emergence of vernacular genres as distinct from and sometimes opposed to the existing classical genres.

name: Film in South Asia
desc: Social and cultural history of South Asian film.

name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History I: Aristocrats and Warriors
desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the courtly or warrior culture of Japan.

name: Chinese Film Classics
desc: Introduction to and analysis of artistically significant films made in mainland China during the first half century of Chinese film history.

name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History II: The Early Modern Age
desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the culture of early modern Japan.

name: Traditional Korean Literature in Translation
desc: An introduction to Korean literature from ancient times to 1900.

name: Poetic Life in Classical India
desc: Cultural explorations in the poetry, theatre, and ornate prose writings of India in the classical period (c. 300-1300 CE).

name: Asian Literature in Translation: A Comparative Approach
desc: A comparative approach to the literatures of East, South and Southeast Asia focusing on a specific theme.

name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
desc: Reading of selected novels and stories written between 1750 and the present.

name: Topics in Traditional Chinese Vernacular Literature
desc: Traditional Chinese culture as seen through reading and discussion of exemplary literary works in the vernacular language.

name: Introduction to Hindi Film
desc: History, aesthetics, politics, and social roles of Bollywood films. Films will be subtitled.

name: Introduction to Japanese Cinema
desc: Students will be introduced to the work of the major directors (e.g., Ozu, Mizoguchi, Kurosawa, Itami, Oshima, Shinoda). Ideological uses of literary texts and period pieces (e.g., Ugetsu, Life of Oharu, Double Suicide). Impact of depiction of Japanese in American film.

name: History of Chinese Cinema
desc: Introduction to the work of major directors.

name: Korean Cinema
desc: Introduction to the work of the major film makers.

name: Modern Korean Literature in Translation
desc: Selected fiction and poetry written between 1917 and the present.

name: Literature of Medieval India in Translation
desc: Devotional, mystic, and erotic poetry of medieval Hinduism, Islam, and Sikhism.

name: A Specific Asian Literature in Translation
desc: Introduction to the literature of a linguistic area of Asia not covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation II
desc: A thematic survey of modern Chinese fiction and film in translation.

name: Pre-Modern Japanese Fiction (in translation)
desc: The influential genre of early tales and fiction in pre-modern Japan.

name: Fiction and Film from Modern Taiwan
desc: A reading-intensive survey of literary and cinematic culture in Taiwan since the early 20th century: colonialism, the national divide, nativism, trauma, cosmopolitanism, and utopian imaginings.

name: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
desc: An introduction to the literature and cultural history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

name: Punjabi Cinema
desc: Punjabi culture, history, and social values through films. The class includes film viewings and seminar discussions.  Films will be subtitled.

name: Contemporary Korean Culture
desc: An introduction to the literature, drama, music, and art of Korea today. Particular attention will be paid to the continuing influence of traditional themes and forms.

name: Modern Literatures of South Asia in Translation
desc: Fiction, drama, and/or poetry of modern India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and/or Sri Lanka, including works in translation and/or originally written in English.

name: Asian Folklore
desc: A survey of oral and expressive traditions in Asia, including jokes, superstitions, fairy tales, myths, music, and foodways; practical training in collecting and archiving folklore.

name: The Sanskrit Cosmopolis: India and the World, 200-1500 CE
desc: Languages, religions, art forms, and political structures of Asian societies shaped by creative encounters with Sanskrit.

name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
desc: Chinese thought from its beginnings until the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes, among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

name: Development of Traditional Chinese Thought
desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) to Wang Yangming (1472-1529) in its historical and cultural contexts.

name: History of Hong Kong
desc: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

name: Imagining Punjab
desc: The cultural and linguistic region of Punjab as it has been imagined in different times and places, in South Asia and beyond, in literature, scholarship, film, and popular culture.

name: Global Chinese Cinemas
desc: A survey of Chinese cinemas in global perspective, covering films, filmmakers, producers, audiences, markets, industries, and critical discourse since the early twentieth century. Covers both cinematic culture and filmmaking technique.

name: The Sikhs: Formations, Contexts, and Historical Development
desc: Introduction to the historical development of Sikh traditions in India and Diaspora, from the 15th century to the present, with attention to broader historical contexts.

name: History of Korean Thought
desc: An examination of Korean religious, philosophical, and scientific thought from the earliest written records to the present day, with particular focus on the interaction of Shamanism, Buddhism, Confucianism, and, in the present century, Christianity.

name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

name: Modern Arabic Literature from the Middle East and North Africa in Translation
desc: Analysis and critique of 20th and 21st century Modern Arabic prose writing emerging from the Middle East and North Africa in translation.

name: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
desc: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century CE in their cultural, intellectual and social contexts.

name: Buddhism in China
desc: History, thought, and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

name: The
desc: Introduction to a foundational text of East Asian thought. Both the primary text and its reception in traditional and modern contexts will be examined.

name: Chan/Zen Buddhism: Doctrine and Practice
desc: The history, doctrines, and practices of Chan Buddhism, particularly the profound influence of Chan Buddhism on various aspects of East Asian culture.

name: Chinese Grammar and Usage I
desc: Analysis of modern Chinese grammar and its usage in various discourses, situating its form and function in relation to social and cultural contexts.
prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 337, CHIN 208, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 347, CHIN 218, CHIN 348 or a higher level of Chinese language proficiency.

name: Japanese Religions
desc: An introduction to traditional Japanese religions including Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, Confucianism, new religions and folklore, and their roles in Japanese history, culture and society.

name: Buddhist, Brahamanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

name: Life Writings of South Asian Diasporic Women
desc: Auto/biographies and life writings of South Asian women in the Diaspora. Emphasizes theories of representation, subjectivity, agency, difference, and memory.

name: History of the Indian Ocean World
desc: Societies and empires shaped by voyages of exploration, religious pilgrimages, trading diasporas and forced migration in the world of the Indian Ocean.

name: Classical Persian Literature in English Translation
desc: Works of classical Persian literature dating from the tenth to the seventeenth century.

name: History of Iran from the Sasanians to the Safavids
desc: Iranian history from the fall of the Sasanian empire and the Arab conquest of Iran to the rise of Iranian dynasties in the east, the reign of Turkic and Turko-Mongolian rulers, and the formation of a Shi'ite Iran under the Safavids.

name: Post-Revolutionary Iranian Cinema
desc: Gender politics, family relationships, and women's social, economic, and political roles in post-revolutionary Iran as shown through Iranian cinema.

name: Modern Persian Literature
desc: Modern Persian literature, including fiction, drama, and/or poetry, of Iran, Afghanistan, and/or Tajikistan dating from the mid-19th to the 21st century (in English translation).

name: Chinese Grammar and Usage II
desc: Analysis of modern Chinese grammar and its usage in various discourses, situating its form and function in relation to social and cultural contexts. Continuation of ASIA 386.
prer: ASIA 386 or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.

name: The Idea of India
desc: History of cultural ideas that led to India's transformation from a traditional, colonial society tied to the British empire to a postcolonial, pluralistic, development oriented parliamentary democracy.

name: Narrative Literature in Premodern India
desc: Stories of gods, goddesses and religious heroes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas, Avadanas and in classical poetry and drama.

name: Films of the South Asian Diaspora
desc: Contemporary films of the South Asian Diaspora, with a focus on Canada, US, and UK. Emphasizes theories of representation, visual and cultural analysis.

name: Chinese Characters: Script, Languages, and Civilizations
desc: Advanced study of the structure of the Chinese characters in their graphic, phonetic, and semantic aspects.
prer: ASIA 300 and one of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348, JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361, KORN 300, KORN 301, KORN 302.

name: Language, Writing, and Linguistic Thought in the History of the Sinographic Cosmopolis
desc: History of language, writing and linguistic thought in China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam from a comparative perspective and focusing on the dissolution of this translocal cultural formation with the onset of modernity.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. At least 12 credits of any level of CHIN, JAPN, or KORN or placement approval.  A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: The Interaction of Science, Religion, and Philosophy in East Asia
desc: The influence of Confucianism, Buddhism, Daoism, and Christianity on the way peoples of East Asia understood and manipulated the natural world, focussing on the natural sciences.

name: North Korea in Historical Context
desc: Analytical overview of North Korea's politics, society, and economy.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students.  9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Religion, Society, and Secularism in Modern India
desc: The postcolonial nation-state and the challenge of a multi-religious society.  Religious and secular discourse in colonial India, the partition, the modern constitution, secularism, Hindu and Muslim mobilization, and religious radicalism and communal violence.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: International Relations in Premodern East Asia
desc: International relations, particularly between Korea and Japan in the premodern East Asian context, focusing on migration, trade, diplomacy, war, collective memory, mutual perceptions, and the context of the Sinocentric international order.

name: Chinese Political Thought and Institutions
desc: Chinese theories and practices of government and administration from earliest times to 1949.

name: Pre-Modern Chinese Poetry (Pre-Qin to Tang)
desc: Features and evolution of major pre-Chinese poetry from the 11th century B.C.E. to the 10th century C.E.; analytical reading of signature poems by selected poets in English translation in the pre-modern Chinese poetic tradition during this historical period.

name: Pre-Modern Chinese Poetry (Tang to Qing)
desc: The features and evolution of pre-Chinese poetry from the 10th century to the 19th century; analytical reading of signature poems by selected poets in English translation in the pre-modern Chinese poetic tradition during this historical period.

name: Architecture and Urbanism in Islamic South Asia
desc: Historical factors shaping Indian architecture from the 13th to the 19th centuries.

name: Social History of India
desc: Fundamental institutions including family, caste and religious organizations, with emphasis on the early modern and British periods.

name: Topics in Korean Popular Culture (Hallyu)
desc: A survey of one of the primary areas of Korean popular culture, such as television dramas, film, K-Pop music, graphic novels and webtoons, or Hanshik cuisine.
prer: One of ASIA 327, ASIA 347, ASIA 357, ASIA 447, ASIA 452, ASIA 457. Or placement approval. Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Mughal India
desc: History of the politics, economy, society, and culture of South Asia from the Great Mughals to the British conquest.

name: International Relations in Modern East Asia: Korea and Japan
desc: Trade, diplomacy, war, imperialism, militarism, colonialism, collective memory, mutual perceptions Korean-Japanese relations are examined as an exemplary case for exploring the dimensions of international conflict and partnership.

name: Tibetan Literature, Genres, and Book Culture
desc: Tibetan literature, textual genres, and book and printing culture from the seventh century to the present.

name: Representations of Muslims in Hindi/Urdu Films
desc: Depictions of Muslims in relation to the majoritarian community as well as other minorities in South Asian cinema, with a particular focus on the Hindi/Urdu film industry.

name: The Partition of India in Film and Narrative
desc: Analysis and critique of how the partition of India is depicted in fictional literary works and feature films.

name: Cultural History of Imperial China
desc: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 440 or HIST 479.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Masterworks of Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation
desc: Reading of a classic novel or play, with attention to intellectual, social, and political subtexts as well as aesthetic dimensions and problems of interpretation.

name: Lives of Chinese Books
desc: Concepts and methods for understanding the lives of books across time, through an examination of both the material forms of a text and its cultural reception. Focus on one major work from pre-modern China.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Topics in Modern Japanese Fiction and Cultural History
desc: Focuses on a limited time period or particular aspect of modern Japanese literature.

name: Japanese Crime Fiction
desc: Examines representations of crime and criminality in modern and contemporary Japanese literature.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Korean Women's Literature
desc: Women's voices and issues in the Korean literary tradition, from earliest times to the new millennium, in translation.
prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable. Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Narrative and Performance in South Asia
desc: Key theoretical issues in the production and enactment of folk narratives in traditional and modern South Asian cultures. Intended for advanced undergraduates in Asian folklore studies. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 448 or ASIA 547.

name: Special Topics in Buddhist Studies
desc: For upcoming offerings, including course descriptions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule at https://courses.students.ubc.ca/cs/main.

name: Modern Chinese Authors in Translation
desc: Study of one influential modern Chinese author, such as Lu Xun, Shen Congwen, Eileen Chang, Yu Hua, Mo Yan, or Wang Anyi.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Literature of the Korean Diaspora
desc: A survey of literature, in translation, from the Korean diaspora, focusing on writing by ethnic Koreans in North America, Europe, and Japan.
prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357, ASIA 447, ASIA 457.

name: Japanese Travel Literature
desc: Japanese travel literature (myths, legends, poetry, tales, diaries, illustrated guides, satiric sermons, haiku, comic fiction, colonial reporting, and ethnography) from the 8th century to present.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Japanese Poetry in Translation
desc: An introduction to Japanese poetry from its origins in song and myth, to its development from a courtly art (waka) to a popular pastime (haiku). Influences on prose, autobiography, and theatre will also be considered.

name: Adaptations of Japanese Classics
desc: Introduction to literary, stage, and film adaptations of Japanese classics and legends and the ways in which these "new" works appropriate the past to comment on the present.

name: History and Culture of Taiwan
desc: The major social, economic, political, and cultural changes in Taiwan since the seventeenth century; the post-World War II process of democratization and Taiwan's place in the contemporary world.

name: The Modern Korean Novel
desc: Survey of major single-volume novels, ranging from Yi Kwang-su's

name: Modern Asian Women in Narrative
desc: Experience of women in the context of a particular Asian culture, as seen through literature, popular culture, film and folklore. Narrative as a medium for the representation and constitution of gender.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Iranian Narratives
desc: Literary, cinematic, folk, and/or popular culture texts from modern Iran. Emphasis on constructions and contestations of masculinities and femininities, as they intersect with sexuality, race, ethnicity, ability, and/or religion.

name: Japanese Documentary Media
desc: Historical survey of Japanese documentary film and media, including press, photography, reality TV shows, and social media.
prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

name: Japanese Women's Self-Writing
desc: Selected aspects of the more than 1000 years of self-writing (diary, autobiography, personal fiction). Theory and criticism about the use of writing as a medium of self-expression.

name: Japanese Horror
desc: The genre of Japanese visual horror explored through formal visual literacy, genre theory, and textual analysis.

name: The History of Christianity in Asia
desc: A survey of Christian proselytizing drives in South, Southeast, and East Asia, focusing on the period since 1500 and the reasons for successes (the Phillipines and Korea, for example) and failures (Japan). Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 466 or 566.

name: Approaches to the Study of Asian Religions
desc: The Western genealogy and problematics of religion, issues in its application to non-Western cultures and traditions, and the practical study of Asian religions, in Asia and its diasporas.
prer: One of ASIA 376, ASIA 381, ASIA 382, ASIA 383, ASIA 387. Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
desc: Ways in which the "self" has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzsche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

name: From the Chronicle to the Archive: Cultures of History in South Asia
desc: Examines how South Asian pasts have been memorialized in writing, from medieval chronicles to the development of history as a modern academic discipline in the nineteenth century. Credit cannot be granted for both ASIA 474 and ASIA 574.

name: Documenting Punjabi Canada
desc: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection.

name: Topics in South Asian Studies
desc: Seminar class designed to explore current scholarly debates in South Asian and Sikh Studies. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 476 or ASIA 576.
prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

name: New Religious Movements of East Asia
desc: Examines the rise of new religious movements in China, Japan, and Korea over the last two centuries, from the Taiping, Tonghak, and Tenri-kyo to the Unification Church, SGI International, and Falun Gong. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 477 or ASIA 577.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: The Religious Image in Asia
desc: The religious image and related material culture within Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Hinduism, Christianity, and Sikhism with special attention to methodological concerns.  Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 478 or ASIA 578.
prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

name: The History of the Choson Dynasty
desc: Political, social, and cultural history of Korea's Choson Dynasty, focusing on how it lasted from 1392 to 1910 and why it collapsed so quickly at the beginning of the twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 484 or ASIA 587.

name: Inventing Asian Religions in the West/East Encounter
desc: An examination of how western imperial expansion transformed the descriptions and practices of Asian traditions through systems of classification, missionaries, discovery of languages, modernity, and fragmentation.

name: Religion, Society and State in Modern India
desc: History of secular and religious discourse in post-independent India. Partition, state policy of secularism, religious mobilization among Hindus and Muslims, communal violence and religious radicalism.

name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar
desc: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

name: India and the Persianate World
desc: Histories of Muslim Empires, spanning Iran, India and Central Asia, from 1000-1800 CE. Examined through the conceptual lens of the Persianate World with emphasis on Persianate culture and power in South Asia.

name: Folk Cultures in the Asian Diaspora
desc: The mediation of folklore (e.g. slang, songs, games, dance, foodways) in the everyday lives of immigrant and transnational Asian communities. Emphasis on Asian-Canadian folklore in Greater Vancouver through digital documentary media production and archival folklore research.
prer: Restricted to 4th year students.  A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Asia in Museums/the Museum in Asia
desc: Museological representations of Asia and Asian forms of museological representation in colonial and post-colonial contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 498 or ASIA 598.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Restricted to fourth-year students admitted to the Honours Program in Asian Studies.
prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

name: Contrasts and Conflicts: The Cultures of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
desc: An introduction to the cultural history of the peoples of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe as reflected in their literature, art and music.

name: Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
desc: Major works of Central, Eastern and Northern European literature from the eighteenth century to the present in their European context.

name: Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
desc: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

name: Witches: Myth and Reality
desc: Examination of the cultural, social, and historical construction of the witch in central and northern Europe with comparisons to recent history, current events, and popular culture.

name: Comics and Graphic Novels in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe
desc: Political, cultural and social themes in European comics and graphic media.

name: Becoming Multilingual: Experience, Aesthetics, Community
desc: Practice, theory, history, aesthetics, and poetics of the multilingual experience in its diverse contexts in Central, Eastern, and Northern Europe.

name: Gender and Nation: Women's State in Modern Central, Eastern and Northern European Literatures and Cultures
desc: Cultural and social discourses of gender in literary works written in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe roughly between 1850 - 1930.

name: Introduction to Business
desc: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only.

name: Entrepreneurship
desc: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business.

name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them. Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership (for non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 292.

name: Economics of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
desc: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms.

name: Entrepreneurial Finance
desc: Financial issues encountered by those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors.

name: Design Methods for Business Innovation
desc: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment.

name: Creativity in Business
desc: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions.

name: Introduction to Business Processes and Operations
desc: The design and management of systems that efficiently and effectively supply products and services to the end-user. The concepts apply to a variety of settings such as manufacturing, logistics, healthcare, and others (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 204.

name: Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
desc: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 293.

name: Fundamentals of Managerial Accounting
desc: Use of accounting data in decision making by businesses; financial statement analysis; cash flows; cost behaviour patterns; methods of accounting for costs. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 294.

name: Marketing Management
desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 296.
crer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

name: Business Finance
desc: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 298.
prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310;  and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: New Product Development
desc: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

name: Social Entrepreneurship
desc: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods.

name: Special Topics in Business
desc: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

name: Strategic Management in Business
desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year). Not for students with credit for, or exemption from, COMM 491.
prer: One of COMM 293, COMM 457, COMR 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.
crer: One of COMM 329, COMR 329 and one of COMM 465, COMR 465 and one of COMM 473, COMR 473.

name: New Enterprise Development
desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466, COMM 497, COEC 497, COMR 497, and APSC 486.
crer: One of COMM 382, COMR 382 and one of COMM 387, COMR 387.

name: Micro Foundations of Real Estate Economics
desc: Basic principles of microeconomics and application to current economic problems.

name: Capital Markets and Real Estate
desc: Basic principles of macroeconomics and application to current economic problems.

name: British Columbia Real Estate Law and Real Estate Ethics
desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies in British Columbia.

name: Canadian Real Property Law and Real Estate Ethics
desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies across Canada.

name: Foundations of Real Estate Mathematics
desc: Introduction to mathematics of real estate finance and statistical measures and methods and their application to practical real estate concepts.

name: Real Estate Finance in a Canadian Context
desc: History, function and mechanics of Canadian mortgage markets.

name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Analysis
desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.

name: Application of Statistics in Business
desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

name: Introductory Financial Accounting
desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use.

name: Introductory Management Accounting
desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports.

name: Managerial Economics
desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision making.

name: Business Communications
desc: Basic communication theory, communications in organizations.  Includes written and oral practice in lab sessions.

name: Urban and Real Estate Economics
desc: Comprehensive treatment of urban and real estate economics; introduction to study of cities and real estate market; analytical microeconomic principles.

name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them.  Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership.

name: Foundations of Real Estate Appraisal
desc: Introduction to concepts and techniques for appraising the value of real estate.

name: Real Estate Investment Analysis and Advanced Income Appraisal
desc: Valuation techniques for income real estate, including income method of appraisal, tax consequences of real property ownership, and portfolio analysis methodology.

name: Information Systems
desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use: design, implementation, and application of information systems.

name: Statistical and Computer Applications in Valuation
desc: Explores creative, practical uses of statistical and computer applications in determining and analyzing real estate value. Through case studies and hands-on computer work, students will learn the fundamentals of exploratory data analysis and appraisal valuation modelling.

name: Case Studies in Residential Valuation
desc: Examines common issues that affect the practice of residential real estate valuation. Credit will be granted for only one of BUSI 352 or both BUSI 442 and BUSI 452.

name: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

name: Cost Accounting
desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance.

name: Introduction to Income Tax
desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and business enterprise.

name: Business Finance
desc: An introduction to the basic principles of financial valuation and an examination of corporate enterprise decisions including working capital management; capital budgeting; capital structures and dividend policy.

name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization.

name: Introduction to Business Law
desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property, principles of agency, partnership, and company law.

name: Residental Property Guided Case Study
desc: The residential property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.

name: Logistics and Operations Management
desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user.
prer: All of BUSI 290, BUSI 291 or equivalents.

name: Residential Property Analysis
desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in design, construction, and inspection of residential properties.

name: Commercial Property Analysis
desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in the design and construction of commercial properties.

name: Data Visualization and Business Analytics
desc: Descriptive analytics including data analysis and visualization. Predictive analytics including forecasting and various statistical techniques. Predictive analytics including optimization, Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees, and discrete event simulation.

name: Real Estate Business
desc: General business skills for real estate practitioners.

name: Real Estate Management I
desc: Examines the day-to-day issues which affect the practice of property management.

name: Case Studies in Appraisal I
desc: Examines the day-to day issues that affect the practice of real estate appraisal.

name: Assessment Administration
desc: Introduces the practice of real property assessment, including the nature of the techniques used, the required duties of assessors, and how an assessment office is administrated.

name: Computer Aided Mass Property Assessment
desc: This course develops and applies the major techniques for valuing real property.
prer: Recommend all of BUSI 121, BUSI 330, BUSI 443.

name: Real Estate Development I
desc: Real estate development process from the project idea to the cursory feasibility stage.  Steps in development planning, including analysis, design and evaluation.  Evaluating development potential, land acquisition, and site planning.

name: Real Estate Development II
desc: Analysis of real estate development process with an examination of economic feasibility studies, approval processes, project financing, construction, project management, and marketing phases.

name: Applied Project Management
desc: Project management methodology based on the practices defined by the Project Management Institute, including planning, execution, monitoring, control, and completion.

name: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
desc: A continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

name: Real Estate Management II
desc: Continuation of BUSI 441.

name: Case Studies in Appraisal II
desc: Continuation of BUSI 442

name: Advanced Financial Accounting
desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting topics.

name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

name: Principles of Auditing
desc: Principles of internal control; audit evidence; sampling and testing; audit reports; standards and responsibilities of the external audit.

name: Critical Analysis and Forecasting in Real Estate
desc: Delves into two quantitative decision-making methodologies – decision analysis and forecasting – and explores them using a problem-solving framework.
prer: BUSI 121. BUSI 331 and BUSI 444 are also recommended.

name: Marketing Management
desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.

name: Taxes and Decision Making
desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

name: Strategic Management in Business
desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change.
prer: All of BUSI 291, BUSI 293, BUSI 294, BUSI 295, BUSI 335, BUSI 353, BUSI 370, BUSI 393, BUSI 450.

name: Guided Case Study in Agricultural Real Estate
desc: An agriculturally-focused version of BUSI 499.
prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

name: International Business Management
desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems.
prer: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.
crer: Two of BUSI 294, BUSI 329, BUSI 370, BUSI 465.

name: Income Property Guided Case Study
desc: The income property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.
prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

name: Computational Thinking
desc: Meaning and impact of computational thinking. Solving problems using computational thinking, testing, debugging. How computers work. No prior computing experience required. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 107, CPSC 110 or APSC 160. [3-1-0]

name: Connecting with Computer Science
desc: Fundamentals of computer science and their connections with the arts, psychology, and biology.  Historical, cultural, and gender  perspectives of important contributions to the field will be discussed.  No prior computing background required. [3-3-0]

name: Introduction to Systematic Program Design
desc: Computation as a tool for systematic problem solving in non-computer-science disciplines. Introductory programming skills. Not for credit for students who have credit for, or exemption from, or are concurrently taking CPSC 110 or APSC 160. No programming experience expected. [3-0-1]

name: Systematic Program Design
desc: Fundamental computation and program structures. Continuing systematic program design from CPSC 103. [3-2-0]

name: Computation, Programs, and Programming
desc: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modelling, and interacting with the world. [3-3-0]

name: Models of Computation
desc: Physical and mathematical structures of computation.  Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution. [3-2-1]

name: Programming, Problem Solving, and Algorithms
desc: Analysis of increasingly complex algorithmic problems, using a modern programming language and a variety of approaches. Problem decomposition and abstraction guide explorations of topics from applied algorithms, for example Voronoi Diagrams, Markov Chains, Bin Packing, and Graph Search. Not for students with credit for, or currently enrolled in, CPSC 210 or CPEN 221. [3-0-1]
prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210, COMM 337.

name: Software Construction
desc: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing. [3-2-0]

name: Introduction to Computer Systems
desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-3-0]

name: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
desc: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency. [3-2-0]
prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, CPEN 221 and one of CPSC 121, MATH 220.

name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Electrical Engineers
desc: Advanced procedural programming.  Fundamental algorithms for sorting and searching.  Data structures including lists, trees, and hash tables.  Introduction to scripting languages and file input/output. [3-2-0]

name: Basics of Computer Systems
desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-2-1]
prer: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during Winter Session of second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education.

name: Computing in the Life Sciences
desc: Basic concepts, tools, and techniques for working with scientific data at larger scales, higher speeds, and lower costs that would otherwise be impossible. Applications and examples drawn from the life sciences. No prior computing background is required. Not for credit for students who have credit for any of the following: APSC 160, Computer Science AP, IB Computer Science, EOSC 211, or 3 credits of CPSC beyond CPSC 101. [3-2-0]

name: Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Numerical Approximation and Discretization
desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving discretization, and their analysis. Interpolation and approximation, including splines and least squares data fitting; numerical differentiation and integration; introduction to numerical initial value ordinary differential equations. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPEN 221, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Introduction to Relational Databases
desc: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages,data warehouses, special topics. [3-0-1]

name: Introduction to Software Engineering
desc: Specification, design, validation, evolution and construction of modern software systems, within the context of socially and professionally relevant domains such as ethics, intellectual property, and information security. [3-2-0]

name: Definition of Programming Languages
desc: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages. [3-0-1]

name: Functional and Logic Programming
desc: Principles of symbolic computing, using languages based upon first-order logic and the lambda calculus. Algorithms for implementing such languages. Applications to artificial intelligence and knowledge representation. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

name: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems
desc: Instruction sets, pipelining, code optimization, caching, virtual memory management, dynamically linked libraries, exception processing, execution time of programs. [3-0-1]

name: Computer Graphics
desc: Human vision and colour; geometric transformations; algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics; hardware and system architectures; shading and lighting; animation. [3-1-0]
prer: CPSC 221 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Internet Computing
desc: Computer networking, basic communication protocols, network infrastructure and routing.  Common application-level protocols and principles associated with developing distributed applications. [3-0-1]

name: Software Engineering Project
desc: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach. [3-0-2]

name: Intermediate Algorithm Design and Analysis
desc: Systematic study of basic concepts and techniques in the design and analysis of algorithms, illustrated from various problem areas. Topics include: models of computation; choice of data structures; graph-theoretic, algebraic, and text processing algorithms. [3-0-1]
prer: CPSC 221 and at least 3 credits from COMM 291, BIOL 300, MATH or STAT at 200 level or above.

name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
desc: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]

name: Applied Machine Learning
desc: Application of machine learning tools, with an emphasis on solving practical problems. Data cleaning, feature extraction, supervised and unsupervised machine learning, reproducible workflows, and communicating results. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) one of CPSC 203, CPSC 210, CPEN 221 or (b) MATH 210 and one of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.

name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
desc: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence. [3-0-1]
prer: CPSC 221 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and one of STAT 241, STAT 251, ECON 325, ECON 327, MATH 302, STAT 302, MATH 318.

name: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
desc: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods. [2-2-2]
prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

name: Honours Research Seminar
desc: Students will attend a series of research seminars presented by faculty members, produce a thesis proposal, and choose their honours thesis supervisor. Available to Honours students. Majors students with satisfactory standing may also be permitted to enrol. [1-0-0]

name: Databases in Data Science
desc: Overview of relational and non-relational database systems, role and usage of a database when querying data, data modelling, query languages, and query optimization. [3-0-1]

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

name: Numerical Linear Algebra
desc: Investigation of the practical techniques of computational linear algebra. Orthogonal transformations and their application to the solution of linear equations, the eigenproblem, and linear least squares. Complete solution of the symmetric eigenproblem, including bisection and the QR method. Refinements of these techniques for sparse matrices. [3-0-0]

name: Advanced Relational Databases
desc: Physical database design, indexing, relational query processing and optimization, transaction processing, concurrency control, crash recovery, data warehouses, data cubes, views, special topics. [3-0-0]
prer: CPSC 304 and one of CPSC 213, CPSC 261.

name: Computational Optimization
desc: Formulation and analysis of algorithms for continuous and discrete optimization problems; linear, nonlinear, network, dynamic, and integer optimization; large-scale problems; software packages and their implementation; duality theory and sensitivity. [3-0]

name: Advanced Software Engineering
desc: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) one of EECE 310, CPEN 321 and one of EECE 315, CPEN 331.

name: Introduction to Compiler Construction
desc: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language. [3-0-0]

name: Advanced Operating Systems
desc: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies. [3-0-0]

name: Distributed Systems
desc: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CPSC 313, EECE 315, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, EECE 358, ELEC 331.

name: Computer Networking
desc: Network protocols and architecture including internetworking, the Internet, layered communication protocols, routing, flow and congestion control, network performance, wired and wireless data communication. [3-0]
prer: All of CPSC 313, CPSC 317 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

name: Parallel Computation
desc: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation.  Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models.  Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks.  Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs.  Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs. [3-0-0]
prer: One of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, EECE 476, CPEN 411 and one of CPSC 320, EECE 320.

name: Advanced Algorithms Design and Analysis
desc: The study of advanced topics in the design and analysis of algorithms and associated data structures. Topics include algorithms for graph-theoretic; algebraic and geometric problems; algorithms on nonsequential models; complexity issues; approximation algorithms. [3-0-0]

name: Introduction to Theory of Computing
desc: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages. [3-0-0]

name: Intelligent Systems
desc: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology. [3-0-0]

name: Geometric Modelling
desc: Digital representation of curves and surfaces, including splines, subdivision surfaces and meshes. Principles, algorithms and mathematical foundations for  geometry representation in computer graphics, computer vision, fabrication, CAD/CAM, and medical imaging. Algorithms for acquisition, creation, representation, and processing of 3D shapes. [3-0-1]
prer: CPSC 320 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

name: Computer Vision
desc: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images.  Image sensing, sampling, and filtering.  Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition. [3-0-0]

name: Computer Animation
desc: Motion in computer graphics for characters and their environments. Keyframing, inverse kinematics, particle systems, rigid body dynamics, contact and collision, controller-based active motion, motion capture. [3-0-0]

name: Video Game Programming
desc: Video game programming techniques and technologies, including rendering, animation, interaction, game AI, real-time software development for games; start-to-finish simple video-game design and implementation. [3-0-1]
prer: CPSC 221 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Computers and Society
desc: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine. [3-0-0]
prer: 3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.

name: Topics in Computer Science
desc: Selected topics in a specific area within Computer Science. May be taken more than once for credit with permission of the department.
prer: Third-year standing in a Computer Science or Computer Engineering specialization, and permission of the department.

name: Advanced Machine Learning
desc: Advanced machine learning techniques focusing on probabilistic models. Deep learning and differentiable programming, exponential families and Bayesian inference, probabilistic graphical models and other generative models, Monte Carlo and variational inference methods. [3-0-1]

name: Advanced Methods for Human Computer Interaction
desc: Design and evaluation methodologies and theories; formal models of the user including visual, motor, and information processing; advanced evaluation methods including laboratory experiments and field studies; HCI research frontiers. [2-2-2]
prer: CPSC 344 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN  206, KIN  371, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366, SOCI 328.

name: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
desc: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing. [3-0-0]
prer: CPSC 320 and either BMEG 250 or six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.

name: Directed Studies in Computer Science
desc: Open ordinarily to students in Computer Science with at least a 72% average and permission of the department.  The course may consist of supervised reading, participation in a seminar, and one or more programming projects.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Under supervision of a faculty member, students investigate a research topic and prepare a thesis.

name: Applied Industry Practices
desc: Hands-on project, mentored by industry experts, integrating skills relevant to early career in the computing industry: technical skills, communication, teamwork, networking and portfolio building. [2.5-2-0]

name: Student Directed Seminars
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". [3-0-0]

name: Interactive Digital Media Practicum
desc: Design and implementation of interactive digital media systems using modern processes and tools. Projects provided by external clients or vetted entrepreneurial pitches are developed by interdisciplinary teams composed of one CPSC 491 student and multiple Master of Digital Media students.
prer: All of CPSC 221, CPSC 310, CPSC 344 and Third-year standing.

name: Co-operative Work Placement V
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

name: Beginners' German I
desc: Introduction to the language.  Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations.  See also GERM 433.

name: Intensive Beginners' German
desc: Introduction to and formal acquisition of German through integrated and interactive practice in reading, writing, listening and speaking. Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 105 or both GERM 100, GERM 110.

name: Beginners' German II
desc: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events and express ideas and hypotheses in German. See also GERM 433.

name: German for Singers
desc: Study of the German language in combination with the study of German lyric diction and musical culture. The course includes translation, phonetic transcription, and the performance of vocal music.

name: German Fairy Tales and Popular Culture (in English)
desc: Examination of folk and fairy tales from the German-speaking tradition and their adaptations.

name: Intermediate German I
desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies.

name: Exile, Flight and Migration (in English)
desc: Transnational narratives about exile, migration and integration in the German-speaking countries.

name: Intermediate German II
desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies; introduction to German for professional purposes.

name: Intermediate German III
desc: Fluency in many relevant situations; competence in the most important areas of cultural life; familiarity with study resources and study skills. Review and expansion of grammar; fostering of speaking and writing skills.

name: German Literature 1900 - 1945 (in English)
desc: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century Germany with special emphasis on plays and novels dealing with the First World War and Nazism.

name: German Literature after 1945 (in English)
desc: Reading and discussion of selected literary works from West, East, and the United Germany, as well as from Austria and Switzerland.

name: German Literature Before 1900 (in English)
desc: Reading and discussion of translated works from the German-speaking countries from the Middle Ages to 1900.

name: German Cinema (in English)
desc: Screening, discussion, and critical analysis of German cinema from the silent era to the 21st century.

name: The Culture of Nazism (in English)
desc: Literature, film and ideology in the Third Reich.

name: Intermediate German IV
desc: Fostering of the ability to discuss controversial issues, express ideas clearly in writing and write essays on selected topics in German. Ongoing grammar review and expansion.

name: Conversational German II
desc: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Fluency in many situations, communicative competence in important areas of cultural life, ability to participate in discussions of current as well as controversial issues to express ideas clearly in spoken word.

name: Business German
desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business.

name: Introduction to German Linguistics
desc: Basic theories and methodologies of modern German linguistics.

name: German Translation
desc: Theory, methodology, and practice of translation from German into English.

name: Heaven and Earth: Studies in German Culture and Literature before 1700
desc: Masterpieces and major trends of the German literature of the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Baroque against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: Reason and Revolution: Studies in the 18th Century
desc: Masterpieces and major trends of eighteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: Tradition and Change: Studies in the 19th Century
desc: Masterpieces and major trends of ninteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: Progress and Disaster: Studies in the 20th and 21st Centuries
desc: Masterpieces and major trends of 20th and 21st-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: Advanced German I
desc: Near-native competence and thorough understanding of critical contemporary topics in a limited number of areas fostering study skills. All skills will be fostered but the course focuses on accurate writing and conversation in particular.

name: Words and Music in German Literature (in English)
desc: Study of individual works and genres in which words and music together form a whole. Possible topics include the Lutheran Hymn, the Volkslied, the Romantic Lied and Brecht songs, operas by Mozart, Wagner and Strauss, and music and the musician as a subject in literature. No musical training is necessary to take this course.

name: Studies in Modern German Culture (in English)
desc: Topics of special interest, varying from year to year.

name: Religion and German Literature (in English)
desc: Religion and literature in Germanic cultural history.

name: Selected Topics in German Literature
desc: A study in depth of one topic of special interest, varying from year to year depending on interests of faculty and students. Possible topics: literature and film, the image of the outside world in German literature, individualism and conformism.

name: Selected Issues in German Culture
desc: In depth study of one topic from German cultural history, varying from year to year. Possible topics: Germany of the New Europe; Gender and nation in German culture; topics from theory, such as the Frankfurt School.

name: Special Topics in German Cinema (in English)
desc: Themes, traditions and techniques specific to German cinema.

name: Advanced German II
desc: Development of capabilities to deal with a variety of authentic texts from and about Germany, Austria and Switzerland; fostering of communicative skills, cross-cultural analysis and critical thinking; effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written German.

name: Major Controversies in German Culture (in English)
desc: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking countries.

name: German Media Studies (in English)
desc: Major themes and methods in German media studies.

name: Business German
desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business. Formerly GERM 314.

name: Advanced German III
desc: Near-native competence and an advanced and transferable understanding of contemporary issues.

name: German Literary Translation
desc: Theory, methodology and practice of translating literary texts between English and German.

name: German Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in German literature and film.
prer: Third Year Standing or permission of instructor.

name: German for Reading Knowledge I
desc: A multimedia introduction to reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course restricted to beginners or to students with no more than one term of beginner's German (or equivalent).

name: German for Reading Knowledge II (Languages for special purposes)
desc: Multimedia teaching of reading skills in German for special purposes. Students are expected to work largely independently. Focuses on specific topics of the student's choice in the humanities, the natural sciences, economics/business and music and enhances skills in technical reading.
prer: GERM 433 or no more than one year of beginner's German.

name: Science One
desc: An innovative first-year multi-disciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
prer: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12 and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

name: Science One A
desc: Block registration marker for the biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics components of the Science One program.  Restricted to students in the Science One program. [12-6-4]
prer: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12 and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

name: First-Year Seminar in Science
desc: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrolment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

name: Topics in Sustainability Science
desc: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0]
crer: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.

name: Communicating Science
desc: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3]
crer: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.

name: Socio-Ecological Systems Research
desc: Research design and methods for socio-ecological systems research. Students work directly with faculty mentors to conduct research on contemporary topics such as climate resilience, food security, and environmental sustainability. [1.5-0-1]

name: Sustainability for Community and the World
desc: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0]
prer: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW  386, LFS  250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Environmental Engineering Design and Decision Making
desc: Environmental Engineering design and decision-making, analysis tools and techniques, data illustration and other communication techniques, professional development including ethics and equity. Subject themes include water, air and soil.

name: Technical Communications for Environmental Engineering
desc: All aspects of technical communication, including report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation, applied to environmental engineering specific cases and projects.

name: Environmental Engineering Science
desc: Analysis of integrated environmental systems, quantification of fundamental chemical and biological processes, systems design, evaluation of environmental impact, future trends.
prer: All of CHEM 154, CIVL 204, CHBE 241, ENVE 200.

name: Environmental Engineering and Sustainability
desc: Sustainability vocabulary and systems theory relevant to environmental engineering practice,  foundational sustainability topics including those relating to urban ecology, industrial ecology/circular economy, and humanitarian engineering, stakeholder analysis, communication,  and adaptive change leadership skills [3-0-2]

name: Environmental Engineering Intermediate Design Project
desc: Real-time, fully-integrated, conceptual and detailed design experiences that address an ill-structured, socially and technically complex but small-scale, environmental engineering problem for remote, rural and culturally distinct communities.

name: Environmental Engineering Capstone Project
desc: Application of chemical, biological, and environmental science; engineering concepts; sustainable development and health and safety considerations; engineering economics; and life cycle analysis. Conceptual and detailed design for a multi-scale and complex environment health and protection problem.

name: Introduction to the Study of Religion
desc: Study of religion through a comparative, cross-cultural, and interdisciplinary approach to humans' engagement with the sacred. Examines religions as complex systems that share certain fundamental common features.

name: Theory and Method in the Study of Religion
desc: Theories and methods for the critical study of religion as believed and practiced in different times and places. Explores methodologies for studying dimensions of religion such as space, bodily practices, cognition, and material culture.

name: The Science of Religion
desc: Explaining religious belief and practice using approaches and methodologies from evolutionary and cognitive science. Topics include gene-culture coevolution, ritual and supernatural belief, religion in groups, and digital humanities techniques.

name: Advanced Seminar in the Study of Religion
desc: Seminar focused on a special theme in the interdisciplinary study of religion (e.g., religious violence, religion and the secular, religious space). Analysis of the theme's contemporary manifestations and implications, through discussion of recent scholarship, both theoretical and case studies.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Undergraduate thesis on a subject in the study of religion. Restricted to students admitted to the Honours Program in the Study of Religion.

name: Introduction to the History of Film Production
desc: The history of film and film production by decade with a strong emphasis on filmmakers and advances in production technology.

name: Introduction to Screen Acting
desc: Fundamental techniques used to create emotionally engaged and narratively effective performances for film and digital media.

name: Introduction to Film and Media Production
desc: A hands-on introduction to Film and Multi/New Media production, focusing on fundamental techniques for creating effective presentations.

name: Introduction to Motion Picture Directing
desc: The role and methods of the motion picture director.

name: Film and Media Production I
desc: Camera operation, lighting, sounds, and editing for film and media production.

name: Production Planning and Professional Practices
desc: Planning of film productions from concept to completion.

name: Image Concepts for Filmmakers
desc: The theory and practice involved in creating images for film and media.

name: Special Topics in Film Production
desc: A topic of current interest in film production.  Topic will change from year to year.

name: Directed Studies: On-Campus Research
desc: On-campus film production field research. Based on film project work on campus productions. Restricted to Film Production students except with permission. Contact department.

name: Film and Media Production II
desc: Intermediate film and media production. Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program. Students who have not already completed FIPR 337, FIPR 338 must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.

name: Cinematography and Lighting I
desc: Introductory cinematography and lighting techniques and aesthetics for 16mm film and digital media.

name: Motion Picture Sound
desc: An introduction to the technique and aesthetics of creating production and post-production sound for film and media.

name: Post-Production Techniques I
desc: Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program.

name: Directed Studies: Off-Campus Research
desc: Off-campus film production field research. Based on film project work outside the university.

name: Film and Media Production III
desc: Advanced film and media production.

name: Producing for Film and Television
desc: The creative and business aspects of producing for film and television.

name: Alternative Cinema Production
desc: Experimental approaches to content, structure, technology and style in film and media production. Students who have not yet completed FIPR 233, 234, 337, 339, must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.
crer: All of FIPR 233, FIPR 234, FIPR 337, FIPR 339.

name: Documentary Development and Production
desc: Documentary concept development, essential production techniques, and marketing.

name: Cinematography II
desc: Advanced camera operation, lighting, and shot design. Open only to students in the FILM BFA Program.

name: Post-Production Techniques II
desc: Advanced instruction in motion picture and sound editing practice. Open only to students in FILM BFA Production Program.

name: Special Projects
desc: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

name: Introduction to Forensic Science
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7320.
