name: Applied Ethics
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT LIBS 7002.

name: Report Writing and Communication for Forensic Investigation
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT COMM 7200.

name: Introductory Forensic Science I
desc: Block registration for the introduction to forensic science course taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Introductory Forensic Science II
desc: Block registration for the applied ethics and report writing and communication for forensic investigation courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Forensic Biology; DNA Typing Theory
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8150.

name: Quality Assurance for Forensic Science
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8370.

name: Business Management for Forensic Science
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8371.

name: Research Methodology and Measurement Models
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7910.

name: Forensic Biology: Evidence Recovery
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8155.

name: Medico-Legal Aspects of Alcohol
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8230.

name: The Science of Fingerprints - Theory
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8320.

name: Forensic Toxicology
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8240.

name: Intermediate Forensic Science I
desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing theory, quality assurance, and business management for forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Intermediate Forensic Science II
desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: evidence recovery, research methodology, and elective courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Co-op Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.
prer: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry and Forensic Science Honours program is required.

name: Co-op Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.

name: Forensic Biology: DNA Typing Applications
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8160.

name: Law for Forensic Science
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7009.

name: The Expert Witness - Prepared for Court
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7010. [2-0-0]

name: Instrumental Analysis for Forensic Chemistry
desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8156. [3-0-0]

name: Advanced Forensic Science I
desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing applications, law and forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Advanced Forensic Science II
desc: Block registration for the expert witness testimony instrumental analysis for forensic chemistry and forensic toxicology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Co-op Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.

name: Co-op Work Placement IV
desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in either an industrial, public, or academic laboratory or a law enforcement agency for a minimum of 14 weeks. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.

name: Introductory Environmental Microbiology
desc: Prokaryotic diversity and the impact and applications of bacterial and archaeal metabolic, genetic, and growth processes in environmental contexts. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, SCIE 001. For students with BIOL 112, CHEM 121 is recommended.

name: Introductory Medical Microbiology and Immunology
desc: Introduction to cellular and humoral immune responses, the properties of viruses and the principles of bacterial pathogenesis. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, BMEG 245, MICB 201, SCIE 001.

name: Basic Microbiology Laboratory
desc: Procedures and principles associated with isolation, characterization and handling of microorganisms. Intended for students requiring a basic microbiology laboratory course. [1*-3-1*]

name: Microbial Ecophysiology
desc: Dynamics and control of prokaryotic cellular processes in response to the biotic and abiotic environment including metabolic interactions and metabolic cooperation between microorganisms. [3-0-1]
prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 201, MICB 201 or (b) BIOT 380.

name: Immunology
desc: Mechanisms of innate and adaptive immune responses.  Hematopoiesis, development of T and B lymphocytes, leukocyte migration, antigen processing/presentation and the major histocompatibility complex, immune responses against pathogens, and diseases associated with aberrant immune responses. [3-0-1]

name: Molecular Virology
desc: Introduction to virus structure and replication. Detailed examination of selected viruses including polio, HIV and cancer-causing retroviruses. Development of vaccines and anti-viral drugs, the use of virus vectors to cure genetic diseases. [3-0-1]

name: Paradigms in Bacterial Pathogenesis
desc: Mechanisms of bacterial pathogenesis including adherence, invasion, intracellular survival, toxins, host defenses and microbial evasion strategies, antibiotics, and vaccines.  Introduction to experimental approaches used to study bacterial pathogens. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) MICB 202 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203;  or (b) BIOT 380.

name: Molecular Microbiology Laboratory
desc: Aseptic handling and characterization of microbes, growth properties, enzyme assays, protein analysis and plasmid isolation. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations. [2-4-0]
prer: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, MICB 201, MICB 202.

name: Molecular Immunology and Virology Laboratory
desc: Genetic manipulations of bacteria, introductory immunological and virological procedures, tissue culture. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations. [2-4-0]

name: Analysis of Microbial Genes and Genomes
desc: Genetic, molecular biological and bioinformatic approaches for the analysis of microbial genomes, gene structure-function and gene expression with emphasis on bacteria. [3-0-0]
prer: One of MICB 201, BIOL 234 and third-year standing or higher.

name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
desc: Procedures and principles associated with isolation, enumeration, characterization and handling of microorganisms. Restricted to students registered in the Food Science program. [1-2-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

name: Environmental Microbiology Laboratory
desc: Microbiological analysis of environmental samples using culture-dependent and culture-independent methods. [2-4-0]

name: Advanced Immunology
desc: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the credit exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the calendar. [3-0-1]
prer: One of MICB 302, BIOT 380. If MICB 302 is used as the prerequisite for MICB 402, students are required to take one of the following as a corequisite: BIOL 234, BIOL 335, MICB 325.

name: Topics in Molecular Bacterial Pathogenesis
desc: A lecture/discussion/library research course. Topics such as antibiotic resistance, pathogen genomics; host-pathogen interactions; evolution of pathogens; host responses to infection, invasive mechanisms, resistance mechanisms. [1-0-4]
prer: MICB 302 and one of MICB 308, MICB 408.

name: Bioinformatics
desc: Computational methods to analyze genome and protein sequences to derive structural and functional information. Related topics in functional genomics. [3-0-1]
prer: One of MICB 301, MICB 325, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 335, BIOT 380.

name: Topics in Molecular Virology
desc: Presentations, library research, paper reviews, class discussions about current research in virology. Topics such as molecular targets in viral therapy; chronic viral infection; virus-host cell interaction. [1-0-4]

name: Viral Infections in Humans
desc: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; persistence and viral oncogenesis; virological diagnosis and treatment. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

name: Advanced Bacterial Pathogenesis
desc: Current and emerging themes in bacterial pathogenesis including cellular microbiology, bacterial cell biology processes and their role in virulence including secretion systems to deliver virulence factors and immune evasion strategies employed by pathogens.  Development of antibiotics and resistance to antibiotics. [3-0-0]
prer: MICB 308. MICB 302 and MICB 325 are recommended.

name: Topics in Immunological Research
desc: Presentations, library research, paper reviews and class discussion on selected areas of advanced molecular and cellular immunological research. [1-0-4]
prer: MICB 302 and one of MICB 402, MEDG 410.

name: Topics in Microbiome Research
desc: Critical examination and discussion of contemporary research literature concerning the impact of host-associated microbiomes on host development, health and disease with a focus on humans.  Priority given to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations. [3-0-0]
prer: Either (a) MICB 302 and one of MICB 308, MICB 325, BIOL 335;  or (b) BIOT 380. And fourth-year standing in Science.

name: Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology
desc: Exploitation of microbial and animal cells for the industrial production of chemicals ranging from alcohol to therapeutic proteins. Genetic manipulation of cellular characteristics, fermentation methods, patenting and governmental approval processes. [3-0-0]

name: Experimental Microbiology
desc: Research in microbial physiology and molecular genetics.  Guided and independent laboratory projects are developed. [2-4-0]

name: Microbial Ecological Genomics
desc: Intrinsic and extrinsic forces driving prokaryotic genome evolution.  Gene transfer; microbial species concepts; community genome structure, function and dynamics; ecological impacts of microbial genome diversity.  Emphasis on problem solving and experimental design. [3-3-0]
prer: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325, BIOT 380. One of MICB 201 or MICB 301 is recommended.

name: Seminar in Microbiological Literature
desc: Student seminars on selected papers from the microbiological literature. Compulsory for Honours students. Major students may enrol with permission of the department head.

name: Experimental Molecular Biology
desc: A laboratory course with a choice of independent, supervised research projects. Students develop protocols to carry out investigation of selected molecular biology problems. [2-4-0]
prer: Either (a) BIOT 380 or (b) MICB 323 or (c) all of MICB 322, MICB 398.

name: Directed Research
desc: A library (3 credits) or laboratory (3 or 6 credits) project. Requires permission of the Undergraduate Advisor. The results are presented in a written report to be reviewed by oral examination.
prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

name: Research Problem
desc: A laboratory investigation in the final year of the Honours program. The results are presented in a written report, to be reviewed by oral examination.
prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 1) of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

name: Writing and Research in the Disciplines
desc: Writing and reading in disciplines across the academy, focusing on practices that research disciplines share and those that differentiate them.

name: Knowledge-Making in the Disciplines
desc: An advanced scholarly research and writing course that allows students to build on their existing knowledge of academic research and writing practices by studying specific features of scholarly writing relevant to their own interests and disciplines.
prer: Restricted to  students with at least 3rd-year standing.

name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

name: Working in International Health
desc: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

name: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
desc: Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 302 or IHHS 302.

name: Selected Topics
desc: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Statistics for Health Research
desc: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited. [3-0]
prer: Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.

name: Indigenous Health: Historical Impacts and Contemporary Approaches
desc: This course covers an epistemological approach that considers the social determinants of health and Indigenous spiritual-environmental and cultural perspectives and approaches to health and wellness.

name: Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers issues associated with aging in our society. For students registered in health and human services programs only. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 406 or IHHS 406.

name: Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
desc: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective. Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 408 or IHHS 408.

name: International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course is an online, interprofessional, comparative inquiry of indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines such as public health, history, sociology and public policy. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 409 or IHHS 409.

name: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course promotes collaborating interprofessionally. Each student team will identify and research a critical public health issue, and develop a detailed practical and effective intervention. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 410 or IHHS 410.

name: Violence Across the Lifespan
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers violence in families across the lifespan. Particular emphasis on intersections of race, class, and gender; the long-term impact of childhood exposure to violence; and prevention-focused initiatives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 411 or IHHS 411.

name: Special Topics in Population and Public Health
desc: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.

name: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
desc: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

name: Languages of the World
desc: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

name: Challenging Language Myths
desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

name: Introduction to How to Learn a Language
desc: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.

name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
desc: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis II
desc: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

name: Language Acquisition
desc: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.

name: Computational Tools for Linguistic Analysis
desc: Practical skills for analyzing language using the Python programming language and relevant packages.
prer: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170, LING 200, LING 201, ENGL 330, ENGL 331. Recommended: LING 201 and CPSC 103 or CPSC 110 (or other programming experience).

name: Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition
desc: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages.
prer: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.

name: Studies in Grammar
desc: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

name: The Languages of Africa
desc: Linguistic survey of the languages of Africa, including typological and historical connections between languages, individual and comparative surveys of sound systems, word structures, sentence structures, semantics, and sociolinguistic properties of a representative selection of languages.

name: Studies in Phonology
desc: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

name: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science
desc: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech.
prer: LING 200. Recommended: All of LING 100,  PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.

name: Instrumental Phonetics
desc: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination.
prer: LING 313. Recommended: All of LING 100, PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.

name: Historical Linguistics
desc: How and why languages change over time, and how languages can be grouped into families based on historical relationships. Methods of comparative and internal reconstruction of phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic change. Social factors in language change. Not offered every year.

name: Introduction to Semantics
desc: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics.

name: Research Methods for Linguistics
desc: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection.

name: Computational Models of Language
desc: A re-examination of major areas of linguistics from a computational perspective, including popular formalisms and algorithms associated with morphology, syntax, semantics, and discourse.
prer: One of LING 201, ENGL 331 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 251, STAT 302, MATH 302, PSYC 218.

name: Pragmatics
desc: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context.

name: Morphology
desc: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year.
prer: All of LING 300, LING 311. Recommended: LING 327

name: Advanced Phonology
desc: Current issues in phonological theory.

name: Language Across Time, Geography, and Society
desc: A cross-linguistic exploration of language change, discussing theories, data, and methods. Topics can include change across historical time periods, lifespan; change across regions, within areas; change due to language contact and other social and cultural factors.
prer: One of LING 319, LING 445, ENGL 318, ENGL 319, ENGL 324 and two of LING 300, LING 311, LING 313, LING 327.

name: Introduction to Linguistics
desc: General background to linguistic studies; the different approaches to the analysis of languages; synchronic and diachronic linguistics; phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours program in Linguistics.

name: Advanced Syntax
desc: Current issues in syntactic theory.

name: Advanced Semantics
desc: Current issues in semantic theory.
prer: LING 327 or PHIL 220. A basic introduction to syntax is recommended (e.g., LING 100, LING 201, or ENGL 331).

name: Honours Seminar in Linguistics
desc: Research papers on general linguistic topics to be read and discussed.

name: Field Methods I
desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

name: Field Methods II
desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied.  Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

name: Native Languages of the Americas
desc: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.

name: Community-based Language Research
desc: Research methods and partnerships, ethical paradigms, the social, cultural and historical context of language research, and the relation of language research to pedagogy, policy and planning.

name: Language as a Social Instrument
desc: Language as a tool that shapes and is shaped by technology, media, politics and power relations in society. Considers multiple levels of linguistic structure from a cross-linguistic perspective.

name: Sociolinguistics
desc: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon.

name: Topics in Linguistics
desc: A capstone course for Linguistics and Speech Sciences majors, normally taken after three years of study.  Individual sections will differ substantially; see online Course List for detailed descriptions and prerequisites. May be repeated for credit when content is different.

name: Directed Studies
desc: Supervisor and topic chosen by mutual agreement between student and Linguistics faculty member. Department Advisor approval is required.

name: Acquisition of Phonology
desc: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech.

name: Acquisition of Syntax
desc: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions).

name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

name: Themes in Architecture and Design
desc: Introduction to a broad range of themes in architecture and design. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

name: Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900)
desc: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Topics in Architectural History II (1900-Present)
desc: History of architecture in the post-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes which have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Research Methods
desc: Motivations and techniques which underpin environmental design research.

name: Design Methods
desc: Techniques for environmental design, including architecture.

name: Materials and Methods of Construction
desc: An investigation of building materials and systems considering design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. The major building systems of light wood frame, steel, and concrete and the technical and expressive opportunities inherent in each. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 411 or DES 232. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

name: Geometric Modelling
desc: Advanced modelling, rendering and image processing applications; the construction of geometric models, their viewing transformations, light and material attributes; mapping and rendering are introduced. Credit will be granted for one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

name: Special Topics in Indigenous Land-based Studies
desc: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information, email inlb.arts@ubc.ca.

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Introduction to Theoretical Perspectives
desc: Cultural, political, and economic context that informs the experiences of Indigenous people and communities. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Introduction to Methods and Application
desc: Applied cultural, political, and economic land-based practices that inform and advance Indigenous self-determination. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Indigenous Knowledge, Science, and Environmental Justice
desc: Indigenous ecological knowledge, its intersections with western scientific knowledge, and approaches to environmental justice. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Introduction to Indigenous Health, Wellness, and Self-determination
desc: Introduction to the social, political, cultural, and gendered determinants of Indigenous Peoples' health and wellness. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Introduction to Gender Justice and Indigenous Communities
desc: Introduction to the politics of gender and sexuality from Indigenous perspectives, with a focus on intersectionality. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Advanced Theoretical Perspectives
desc: Theorizing land and self-determination from Indigenous cultural, political, and economic perspectives. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Advanced Methods and Application
desc: Advanced cultural, political, and economic land-based practices that guide decolonization and Indigenous self-determination. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Advanced Special Topics in Indigenous Land-Based Studies
desc: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Advanced experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information please consult the departmental website.

name: Decolonizing Science and the Politics of Sustainability
desc: Decolonizing ecological knowledge, environmental justice, and the discourse of sustainability. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Decolonizing Indigenous Health and Wellness
desc: The colonial determinants of Indigenous Peoples' health and wellness. The governance of land in relation to health. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Gender Justice and Indigenous Resurgence
desc: The theory and politics of gender and sexuality from Indigenous perspectives. Emphasis on decolonial and intersectional Indigenous feminisms and queer/two-spirit theory. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Students are eligible for Pass/Fail or percentage grading.

name: Technical Communication
desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Manufacturing Engineering Program.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Manufacturing Engineering Laboratory
desc: Theory, operational constraints, and problem solving in traditional manufacturing processes. Casting, heat treatment, bulk deformation (i.e. rolling, extrusion, drawing), machining, joining, and shaping of composites. Experiments in process and product characterization.

name: Thermodynamics
desc: Thermodynamic system and properties, thermodynamic processes; work and heat interactions. Conservation of energy and First Law, internal energy and enthalpy, the Second Law and entropy, application to manufacturing processes.

name: Machine Dynamics
desc: Classifications of mechanisms, velocity, acceleration and force analysis, graphical and computer-oriented vector and matrix methods, balancing, flywheels, gears, gear trains, cams.
prer: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

name: Production Systems Management I
desc: Impact of operations in increasing productivity and reducing waste.

name: Manufacturing Engineering Project I
desc: Project-based, multi-step manufacturing engineering design and problem solving.

name: Production Systems Management II
desc: Functional area of production and operations management. Decision-making, capacity planning, aggregate planning, inventory management, distribution planning, materials requirements planning and quality control.

name: Engineering Materials II
desc: Materials selection for different design criteria; importance of shape and processing variables; computer software in selection. Credit will be granted for only one of MTRL 280 or MANU 378.

name: Manufacturing Processes I
desc: Correlation between material properties and processibility for practical engineering manufacturing routes.  Calculations and design. Application of heat/mass/fluid transport, mechanics and thermodynamics to manufacturing processes.
prer: All of APSC 278, APSC 279, MTRL 264, MECH 260 and one of MANU 261, MTRL 250 and one of MECH 280, MTRL 263.

name: Industrial Automation
desc: Principle components of manufacturing automation, modelling of sensors-actuators and control systems, robotic programming, programmable logical control (PLC) systems and development of PLC ladder diagrams.

name: Manufacturing Design Capstone Project
desc: Project-based, multi-step, multi-part Capstone design project involving manufacturing engineering design methods, problem solving.

name: Factory Planning
desc: Resources planning, layout and logistics. Modular production and cyber-physical manufacturing systems in laboratory scale, virtual manufacturing and factory automation.

name: AI and Machine Learning Applications in Manufacturing
desc: Artificial intelligence, machine learning techniques, Deep learning, Python libraries for machine learning, Basic signal processing techniques, Data Acquisition, Applications in Manufacturing, Use of sound to evaluate operation of CNC machinery, Use of AE sensor to evaluate metal 3D printing

name: Manufacturing Processes II
desc: Numerical modelling of manufacturing processes, linkage between material, process, properties and product geometry, heat/mass transport, thermodynamics and design principles applied to practical engineering processes.

name: Manufacturing Processes III
desc: Integrating concepts of primary (casting), secondary (deformation), and tertiary (machining and surface treatment) processes and economic and environmental assessment.

name: Metal Cutting and Machine Tool Vibrations
desc: Metal cutting and grinding mechanics; prediction of force-torque-power in turning, drilling, milling and grinding operations. Machine tool vibrations, forced and self-excited vibrations in machining, experimental modal testing of machine tools, chatter, and stability. Credit will be granted for only one of MANU 485 or MECH 592.

name: Machine and Part Metrology
desc: Laser interferometer measurement of volumetric accuracy; error mapping, modelling and compensation of errors, rotation metrology, spindle accuracy. Part dimension and surface metrology. Metrology instruments: Coordinate measurement machine, surface profile meter, laser interferometer and ball bar.

name: Career Education for Teachers
desc: Introduction to career education practices and standards program content, and principles for the design of career education programs. [3-0]

name: Communication Skills in Global Contexts
desc: A diversity of communication skills are essential when working in international contexts. The focus of this course is on developing specific skill sets for expanding effective communication competence in a diversity of contexts.

name: Basic Interviewing Skills
desc: Development of basic interviewing skills for counselling and guidance. [3-3]

name: Career Counselling
desc: Critical survey of career counselling theory and practice. [3-0]

name: Family Education and Consultation
desc: Examination of current theories and practices in family education and consultation. [3-0]

name: Introduction to Theories of Counselling
desc: An overview of selected theories of counselling. [3-0]

name: The Role of the Teacher in Guidance
desc: This course is designed to assist the teacher in understanding and using guidance techniques for day-to-day use in the classroom. The emphasis will be on techniques for working with people towards better self-understanding and better perspectives of alternatives. [2-1]

name: Guidance: Planning and Decision-making
desc: The work of the beginning counsellor and guidance worker in assisting students with educational, vocational, and personal planning and decision-making. [3-0]

name: The Personal and Social Development of the Adult
desc: Personal and social adjustment issues for professional counsellors; basic skills necessary for effective group counselling. [3-3]

name: Catalan Language and Culture
desc: Introduction to the Catalan language and important aspects of the culture of Catalonia. Languages of instruction: English and Catalan.

name: The Art of Storytelling for Stage and Screen
desc: Fundamental elements of the art of storytelling as approached within each of the core areas taught in the Department of Theatre and Film: Acting/Directing, Design and Production, and Film Production.
prer: Restricted to students in one of the following BFA programs: Major in Acting; Major in Film Production; Major in Theatre Design and Production

name: Indigenous Settler Legal Relations
desc: Critical examination of the history and legacy of colonial legal orders in Canada. This course is compulsory for students who commence their Juris Doctor degree in September 2020 or later.

name: Canadian Constitutional Law
desc: Principles of Canadian constitutional law, including Canadian federalism, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada.

name: Contracts
desc: Historical development; formation and enforceability of contracts; parties; contractual terms; changes of circumstances; remedies for breach.

name: Criminal Law and Procedure
desc: Bases of criminal responsibility; principles and objectives of the criminal law and procedure; pre-trial procedure.

name: Property Law
desc: The legal concept of ownership and its changing nature and application, including equitable principles, the acquisition and transfer of interests, the regulation of use, Aboriginal title, and statute-based systems for registering interests in land.

name: Torts
desc: A study of the bases of civil liability for intentionally and accidentally caused harms.

name: Public Law
desc: An overview of the constitutional and statutory law governing the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government in Canada, including an introduction to statutory construction and analysis and the administration of law in Canada.

name: Transnational Law
desc: Introduction to principles of public and private international law and research methods for international legal materials.

name: Introduction to Public Law and the Charter
desc: Introduction to the structure, powers, duties of and relationships among the various institutions and actors that comprise the Canadian state, and an introduction to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

name: Legal Research and Writing
desc: Introduction to legal research and writing skills and the use of legal databases.

name: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
desc: An overview of the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada.

name: Jurisprudence and Critical Perspectives
desc: Introduction to the basic principles of legal theory and critical perspectives on law. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 290 or LAW 300.

name: Philosophy of Law
desc: An examination of the principal schools of legal theory, such as legal positivism, legal realism, sociological jurisprudence, and contemporary rights theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Fundamental Concepts of Law
desc: A study of some of the fundamental principles and ideas that cut across many areas of the substantive law, including such concepts as fault, intent, legal personality, possession, ownership, justice, and causation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Legal Traditions and Ideas of Law
desc: Historical and comparative study of the evolution of legal systems from custom and proto law emphasizing influences and sharing ideas among traditions of the Ancient Near East, Athens, Roman Empire, Western Europe and China. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Law, Society and State
desc: Theories of the relationship between the legal system, social relations and the state. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Corporate Social Responsibility and the Law
Women, Law and Social Change
desc: A survey of feminist approaches to law, with reference to selected substantive areas of the law.

name: Feminist Legal Theory
desc: Recent developments in feminist legal theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Feminist Legal Studies
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Economic Analysis of Law
desc: Economic analysis used to explore, describe, evaluate and offer prescriptive suggestions for legal decision-making. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Property Law and Theory
desc: The idea of property, its origins, its justifications, its uses, its effects, and the rules that surround and create it.

name: Topics in Philosophy of Law and Theoretical Perspectives
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Legal History
desc: The relationship between law, society and historical change, normally emphasizing 19th and 20th century issues. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Legal History
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: International Law
desc: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Students who have taken POLI 465 cannot take this course.

name: Marine Resources Law
desc: Legal regimes governing the protection and exploitation of ocean resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: International Human Rights
desc: The recognition and protection of human rights in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Indigenous Peoples in Comparative and International Law
desc: The legal situation of indigenous peoples in various states and in modern international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Law of Armed Conflict
desc: The legal basis for armed conflict or military operations; the rights and obligations of combatants and civilians in a region of armed conflict; war crimes.

name: International Law Problems
desc: Selected issues in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: International Environmental Law
desc: Customary international law and treaties relating to the environment; institutional structures. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in International Law and Transactions
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Conflict of Laws
desc: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year.

name: International Trade Law
desc: Rules and regulatory systems that govern the international movement of capital, goods and services.

name: International Business Transactions
desc: Legal problems in international financial and commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: International Commercial Disputes
desc: International commercial arbitration and other means for resolving legal disputes relating to international commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Cultural Property and Art Law
desc: National and international aspects of the law relating to the art trade and the protection and regulation of cultural property and cultural heritage.

name: Topics in Cultural Heritage and Art Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Maritime Law
desc: Canadian maritime law and admiralty practice.

name: Cultural Law
desc: Relationship of law to cultural activities and phenomena.  International, national, and indigenous laws as they apply to various forms of tangible and intangible cultural expression.

name: Introduction to Asian Legal Systems
desc: Introduction to the comparative study of legal systems of East and South-East Asia, including those of China and Japan.

name: Chinese Law: Implications for Canada-China Relations
desc: Overview of the laws and legal system in the People's Republic of China with some introduction to Taiwan law. Legal interpretation of implications for Canada-China relations.

name: Trade and Investment in The People's Republic of China
desc: The legal regime in The People's Republic of China governing trade and foreign investment. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Japanese Law
desc: Constitutional foundation and protection of human rights under Japanese law.

name: Human Rights in Asia
desc: Legal issues relating to civil, political, social and cultural rights in particular areas in Asia. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Comparative Law
desc: Basic theory of comparative law and the differences between the civil law tradition and the common law tradition.

name: European Union Law
desc: The legal system of the European Union as created by the treaties establishing the Union and by the Union's institutions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Comparative Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Public Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Innovations in Governance and Regulatory Design
desc: Emerging interdisciplinary scholarship on regulation, governance, and institutional design.  Examination of research and experience around both formal and legal regulatory strategies, and other informal, decentred, or non-state-based methods of ordering individual and organizational behaviour.

name: Federalism
desc: An examination of the principles of Canadian federalism.

name: Comparative Constitutional Law
desc: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada.

name: Topics in Constitutional Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Issues of Equality and Social Justice
desc: Selected topics related to the Charter right to equality and other rights related to social justice. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Human Rights
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law
desc: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 200 or LAW 352.

name: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
desc: Rights of Aboriginal people stemming from their aboriginal status and from treaties. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: First Nations Self-Government
desc: Issues relating to First Nations' assumption of self-government powers. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: First Nations and the Administration of Justice
desc: The justice system and its operation in relation to First Nations people. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: First Nations and Economic Development
desc: Legal issues affecting land use and economic activity involving First Nations' resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in First Nations Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Family Law
desc: The law relating to family relationships, including the law of marriage, divorce, maintenance, custody, matrimonial property, and related matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 240 or LAW 359. [3-0]

name: Children and the Law
desc: The civil and criminal law affecting juveniles; custody, guardianship and adoption.

name: Topics in Family Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Racism and Law
desc: Legal issues relating to race and racism, including related issues of gender, culture or identity. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Race and Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Women, Law and Family
desc: Feminist and other critical perspectives on the relationship between unequal gender relations and laws embodying a concept of "family". Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Reproduction and Law
desc: Legal issues relating to human reproduction. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Sexuality and Law
desc: Legal issues relating to sexual activity, orientation and identification. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Social Justice
desc: Not offered every year; consult the Faculty.

name: Topics in Law and Social Relations
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Administrative Law
desc: The system of legal control exercised through non-judicial agencies and the relationship of the courts to the administrative process. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 210, LAW 372, or LAW 509.

name: Topics in Administrative Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Municipal Law
desc: The municipality as a legal entity; its creation, operation and powers; by-laws and their validity; contractual liability; judicial review; business regulation; expropriation and land use control.

name: Land Use Planning
desc: The legal and administrative aspects of the regulation of land use and development, especially at the local level. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Municipal and Planning Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Immigration Law
desc: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts.

name: Refugee Law
desc: International and Canadian refugee law; the Refugee Convention and its implementation in Canada; the practice of refugee law in Canadian courts and tribunals. Course content does not duplicate Law 377.

name: Externship
desc: Students work for an approved organization, supervised by a Faculty-approved mentor and a faculty member. Consult the Faculty for full eligibility criteria.
prer: LAW  476 and either (a) one of LAW  359, LAW  400 or (b) one of LAW  469, LAW  387, LAW  392, LAW  459. Or other studies that provide adequate preparation for the program.

name: Externship Reflection
desc: Structured reflective exercises on the LAW 379 Externship experience.

name: Disabilities and Law
desc: Legal issues relating to people with disabilities. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Health Law
desc: Legal and policy issues relating to the health care system, including legal aspects of individual and public health decision-making.

name: Mental Health Law
desc: The law relating to commitment and treatment issues for persons with mental disabilities.

name: Social Welfare Law
desc: Aspects of the law structuring the provision of welfare and other social services in Canada. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Sustainable Development Law
desc: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities.

name: Environmental Law
desc: A foundation course dealing with the regulatory and policy framework for the protection of the environment in Canada, such as pollution control and biodiversity conservation.

name: Environmental Law in Practice
desc: Jurisdiction, remedies and administrative schemes as they apply in practice to selected environmental law problems. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Selected Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
desc: Case studies of leading problems in environmental law and regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Environmental Law Workshop
desc: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Environmental Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Natural Resources Law
desc: A foundation course dealing with legal problems common to the management of natural resources such as fisheries, mines and minerals, petroleum, forests, and water resources.

name: Green Rights and Warrior Lawyers
desc: Explore the human right to a healthy environment and the rights of nature through the stories of environmental lawyers and defenders worldwide who struggle for environmental justice through law. No pre- or co-requisites.

name: Mining Law
desc: Acquisition of mineral interests; development, financing and organization of mining companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Forest Law
desc: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

name: Fisheries Law
desc: Legal regimes for the exploitation and regulation of fisheries. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Oil and Gas Law
desc: Legal regimes for the disposition of interests in petroleum; government regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Natural Resources
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Advanced Criminal Law
desc: Selected topics in advanced substantive criminal law and related issues.

name: Advanced Criminal Procedure
desc: Selected topics relating to procedural law and practice in criminal matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 260 or LAW 400.

name: Penal Policy
desc: Selected legal policy issues relating to punishment for crime. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: The Law of Sexual Offences
desc: Criminal law relating to sexual offences, including non-consent, evidentiary and procedural rules, and sentencing.  History of sexual offence laws and law reform movements.

name: Principles of Sentencing
desc: This course is designed to teach students the law and policy involved in sentencing persons convicted of crimes. Students will develop an in-depth understanding of statutory and case law rules regarding sentencing and will be required to apply those rules to actual sentencing scenarios.

name: Topics in Criminal Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Criminal Justice
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Taxation
desc: A survey of the law and practice of income and capital gains taxes. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 220, LAW 407, or LAW 506. [3-0]

name: Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders
desc: Survey of statutory provisions and judicial decisions governing the taxation of corporations and shareholders. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562.

name: Taxation of Partnerships
desc: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563.

name: International Taxation
desc: The tax aspects of international transactions. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565.

name: Tax Policy
desc: The policies underlying the creation and implementation of tax laws. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 411 or LAW 566.

name: Taxation of Trusts and Estates
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564.

name: Tax Administration and Dispute Resolution
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567.

name: Taxation of Corporate Reorganizations
desc: Survey of statutory provisions and judicial decisions governing the taxation of corporate reorganizations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 414 or LAW 550.

name: Labour Law
desc: Union-management relations; the collective bargaining process; the collective agreement, arbitration and conciliation procedure. The relationship between the union and its membership. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 415 or LAW 416. [2-0] or [3-0]

name: Labour Law and Policy
desc: The role of the law in the operation of the labour market. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Resolution of Labour Disputes
desc: Labour arbitration and collective agreement negotiation and interpretation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Individual Employment Law
desc: Legal aspects of employment relationships other that those arising by collective bargaining. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Labour Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Intellectual Property
desc: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence.

name: Topics in Intellectual Property
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Communications Law
desc: Selected legal issues relating to the communications industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Cyberspace Law
desc: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace.

name: Topics in Law and Technology
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: International Justice and Human Rights Clinic Practicum
desc: The Clinic Practicum is a collaborative effort where clinicians work in teams of two to four on cases and projects that respond to human rights violations and/or global injustice.

name: International Justice and Human Rights Clinical Seminar
desc: The seminar explores foundational texts and treaties in international human rights, international humanitarian and international criminal law necessary to undertake the IJHR Clinic case and project work in the Fall and Spring Practicum.

name: Advanced Legal Research
desc: Research using electronic databases, information systems, and non-legal databases relevant to the resolution of legal issues.

name: Topics in Private Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Medical Negligence Law
desc: Legal issues relating to tort claims in negligence and related causes of action against health care providers, with a primary focus on physicians and hospital authorities.

name: Topics in Tort Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Restitution
desc: Unjust enrichment as the basis of civil liability. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Commercial Transactions
desc: The law of sale of goods, bills of exchange, promissory notes, and cheques. [3-0]

name: Secured Transactions
desc: The law governing the creation, perfection and enforcement of security interests in personal property.

name: Construction Law
desc: Legal issues relating to the construction process. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Insurance Law
desc: The general legal principles of life, automobile, fire and other types of insurance; the regulation of the insurance industry.

name: Condominium Law
desc: Legal issues over the lifecycle of condominium/strata property from creation and development, through operating life, to termination.

name: Creditors' Remedies
desc: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy.

name: Insolvency Law
desc: The law relating to insolvency, receivership and bankruptcy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Corporate Solicitors'  Workshop
desc: Introduces students to the work of a corporate solicitor, including experience in planning, drafting and negotiating commercial transactions. Pass/Fail.

name: Topics in Commercial Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Sports Law
desc: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Media and Entertainment Law
desc: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Sports, Media, Entertainment or Communications Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Trusts
desc: History and nature of trusts; express, resulting, implied and constructive trusts; charitable and purpose trusts; administration of trusts; breach of trust. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 250 or LAW 451.

name: Succession
desc: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates.

name: Equitable Remedies
desc: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing.

name: Topics in Trusts and Estates
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Real Estate Transactions
desc: The law relating to the sale and purchase of land, real estate agency, and mortgages.

name: Real Estate Development
desc: A study of the legal aspects of the development of real estate projects such as shopping centres, sports centres and condominiums. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Real Property
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Business Organizations
desc: A conceptual overview of business organizations in Canada, including partnerships and corporations, and the rights and duties of shareholders and directors. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 230, LAW 459, or LAW 508.

name: Advanced Corporate Law
desc: Selected topics such as the nature of shares, equity financing, corporate structure and reorganization, and shareholder squeezeouts.

name: Corporate Transactions
desc: Legal aspects of selected transactions relating to public corporations and corporate governance. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Close Corporations
desc: The corporation, taxation, accounting, insurance and estate planning aspects of the close corporation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Securities Regulation
desc: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability.

name: Competition Policy
desc: The law and policy relating to the regulation of competition in Canada and other jurisdictions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 414 or LAW 464.

name: Introduction to Corporate Finance
desc: Interdisciplinary elements of corporate finance and law, in both theory and practice.

name: Business Law Capstone
desc: Integration of theoretical and practical elements of business law. For students opting for the Business Law Concentration.
prer: All of LAW  407, LAW  459, LAW  463. And 6 credits of other courses from the Concentration.

name: Topics in Corporate Law
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Ethics and Professionalism
desc: The ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules of professional conduct and cases, and the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system including their role in securing access to justice.

name: Civil Procedure
desc: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 270 or LAW 469. [2-0] or [3-0]

name: Innocence Project
desc: Clinical program giving hands-on experience in reviewing claims of innocence post-conviction. Not offered every year; consult Faculty.
crer: One of LAW  280, LAW  476 and LAW  471.

name: Preventing Wrongful Convictions
desc: Substantive legal principles and rules of evidence that can cause or help to prevent wrongful convictions or other miscarriages of justice. Roles of the participants in the criminal justice system. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

name: Advanced Trial Advocacy
desc: Skills-training in all aspects of civil and criminal trial advocacy.
prer: One of LAW  270, LAW  469. LAW 280 or LAW 476 is also recommended.

name: Appellate Advocacy
desc: Issues relating to advocacy before appellate courts; techniques of appellate advocacy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Trial Advocacy
desc: Techniques of advocacy in civil and criminal cases including interviewing, pre-trial preparation, tactical analysis, development of facts, direct and cross examination and various ethical considerations.

name: Competitive Trial Advocacy Credit
desc: Trial advocacy. Restricted to students participating in one or more faculty approved trial advocacy competitions. Students enrolled in this course must also be enrolled in LAW 474.

name: Evidence
desc: The admissibility and use of evidence in litigation. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 280, LAW 476, or LAW 507.

name: Negotiation and Dispute Resolution
desc: Negotiation and bargaining; formulation of general principles governing the negotiation process; negotiation in legal practice; alternative means of dispute resolution.

name: Foundations of Dispute Resolution
desc: Theoretical premises underlying the dispute-resolving process; arbitration, other non-judicial means of resolving legal disputes, and their relationship to litigation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Mediation
desc: Mediation of legal disputes; negotiation theory and practice as they relate to mediation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Litigation, Dispute Resolution and the Administration of Justice
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Topics in Procedure and Evidence
desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

name: Competitive Moots and Advocacy Credit A
desc: Appellate and related forms of advocacy. Restricted to students representing the Faculty for the first time in an approved advocacy competition.

name: Client Counselling Competition Credit
desc: Interviewing, counselling and negotiating. Restricted to students representing the Faculty in an approved client counselling competition.

name: Law Review Credit
desc: Editing and business operations by senior editors or the business manager for UBC Law Review, Canadian Journal of Family Law or any other equivalent legal journal based in the Allard School of Law. One time credit only; cannot be repeated.

name: Clinical Term
desc: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. Under supervision, students will act for clients in a range of legal matters and can expect to appear before courts and tribunals. Students will also work with community-based organisations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 490 or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.

name: Clinical Term: Paper
desc: The graded component of LAW 488.

name: Clinical Criminal Law
desc: Dealing with criminal files under the supervision of experienced lawyers. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.
prer: One of LAW  260, LAW  400 and one of LAW  280, LAW  476.

name: Law Students Legal Advice Program Credit
desc: Restricted to a limited number of upper year students who (a) in their first or second year have participated in the provision of legal services to the public through the Law Students Legal Advice Program, and (b) continue that participation in their second or third year. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491.

name: Directed Research
desc: Enrolment restricted.

name: Directed Research
desc: Enrolment restricted.

name: Directed Research
desc: Enrolment restricted.

name: Directed Research
desc: Enrolment restricted.

name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
desc: Critical analysis of recent scientific literature that combines disciplines that students are integrating in their Integrated Sciences Curriculum.

name: The Size of Things
desc: Scaling as a general approach to laws governing the geometry, kinematics and dynamics of systems. Dimensional analysis, isometry and allometry applied to topics from Biology, Physics, Earth Science and Economics. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Symmetry
desc: Recognizing symmetry; point groups in 2D and 3D; plane groups in 2D; space groups in 3D; the role of symmetry in the natural and human world. [3-0-0]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Research Development Project
desc: Retreat to develop skills in writing scientific research proposals.  Emphasis on formulating and testing hypotheses to explain observations.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to retreat.
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Science of Measurement and Instrumentation
desc: Interactive course integrating diverse aspects of science: semi-quantitative overview of physical principles underlying modern measurement technology; philosophy of measurement; accuracy and limits to measurement, and resultant scientific, sociological and economic consequences. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Topics in Integrated Sciences
desc: Interactive examination of a theme common to all areas of science. Themes will change from year to year. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [3-0-0]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

name: Theory and Practice of Games in Economics and Evolution
desc: Exploration of human and animal interactions: integrating evolutionary and economic perspectives to investigate individual and social behaviour.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344. [3-0-0]

name: Integrative Bioinformatics
desc: Storage and processing of information in biological systems. Computational methods for recovering and interpreting stored genetic information. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Darwinian Medicine
desc: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
desc: Application of systems science encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems approaches to study regional sustainability. [3-0-0]
prer: Third-year or higher standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Field Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
desc: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate a selected region of the world.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to field course.
prer: ISCI 360 or permission of the Integrated Sciences Director.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Normally taken in Winter Session of third year or Summer Session after third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students in the ISP Co-op program.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Models in Science
desc: Meaning, nature, use, strengths and limitations of models as investigative tools in all scientific disciplines. Detailed investigation of selected model systems from different scientific disciplines. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Ethical Issues in Science
desc: Theoretical and practical consideration of ethics in the practice, reporting, public impact and accountability of science. [3-0-0]

name: Directed Studies
desc: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Comparative Field Research Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
desc: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate, analyze and research two unique regions of the world. Course location may vary; course location must be different than ISCI 361; fee payable prior to field course. [3-0-0]

name: Student Directed Seminars
desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. [3-0-0]
prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months.  Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Co-Operative Work Placement IV
desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Topics in Scandinavian Studies (in English)
desc: Selected issues and topics in Scandinavian cultural studies.

name: Major Works of Scandinavian Literature (in English)
desc: Selected Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, and Icelandic texts ranging from Old Norse sagas to contemporary literary works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in Scandinavia.

name: Contemporary Scandinavian Fiction (in English)
desc: Study of texts, topics, or genres against the background of current Scandinavian literary, social, and political developments.

name: Vikings and Norse Mythology (in English)
desc: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

name: Scandinavian Crime Fiction (in English)
desc: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

name: Scandinavian Cinema (in English)
desc: An introduction to the cinemas of the Scandinavian region.

name: Scandinavian Drama and Film in Translation
desc: Traces the explosive development of a provincial theatre into one of the seminal forces of twentieth-century drama and film. Emphasis on Ibsen, Strindberg, and Bergman.

name: The Northern European Epic in Translation
desc: Major prose works of the Scandinavian literatures with emphasis on the stylistic qualities of the Old Icelandic sagas and their transformation in the novels of modern Icelandic, Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian writers. Possible authors: Laxness, Blixen, Hamsun, Lindgren.

name: The Literatures of the Baltic in English Translation
desc: An examination through literature of the historical, cultural, and ethnic elements that have made the Baltic area the crossroads of northeastern Europe. The emphasis is on literature from the Germanic  and Finno-Ugric languages. Authors to be studied include Strindberg, Tikkanen, Transtromer, Kaplinski, Grass, Bobrowski, Lenz.

name: Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English)
