desc: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.

name: The World of the Sagas (in English)
desc: Scandinavian contributions to medieval and early modern world literature, culture and history.

name: Beginners' Spanish I
desc: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Communicate with basic vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Beginners' Spanish II
desc: Continuation of foundational elements of the language. Communicate using essential vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to past, present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Elementary Spanish I
desc: Expansion of fundamentals. Enhanced ability to exchange information, discuss the past and future, and express wishes, hopes and feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A1-A2 objectives.

name: Elementary Spanish II
desc: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of more elaborate structures in a variety of tenses and modes. Communicate to explore Hispanic culture and to hypothesize about present and past situations. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.

name: Conversational Spanish I
desc: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

name: Conversational Spanish II
desc: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
desc: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses.
prer: SPAN 202 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
desc: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses.
prer: SPAN 202 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Revolution! (in English)
desc: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings.

name: Intermediate Spanish I
desc: Complex grammatical structures in context to enhance proficiency. Explores relevant cultural topics through reading, writing, and discussion. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.

name: Intermediate Spanish II
desc: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire.  Enhances proficiency through reading, writing, and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.

name: Conversational Spanish for Advanced Speakers
desc: Expands the comprehension and communicative skills of upper-level students and heritage speakers through  topics drawn from Hispanic culture and current events.
prer: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. Or placement test for heritage speakers.

name: Spanish for Business
desc: Language of commerce, finance, marketing, and economics. Competence in business practices of the Hispanic world.
prer: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
desc: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world.
prer: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature (in English)
desc: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation.

name: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
desc: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures.
prer: SPAN 202 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Dependency and Revolution in Latin American History and Culture
desc: Continuities and changes in the Americas from before Columbus to the present. Includes the first modern global empire and its ambivalent legacies.
prer: SPAN 202 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
desc: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
desc: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
desc: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
desc: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Upper Intermediate Spanish I
desc: Strengthening fluency and accuracy in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on mediation, interpretation, and metalinguistic competencies through translation and comparative stylistics. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
prer: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Upper Intermediate Spanish II
desc: Continued strengthening of fluency, accuracy, and spontaneity in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on contextualized grammar and vocabulary; critical reading and discussion of texts. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
prer: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: History of the Spanish Language
desc: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology.
prer: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: From World to Screen: Topics in Hispanic Cinema
desc: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Cinema. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Celebrating Diversity: Topics in Peninsular and Latin-American Culture
desc: Selected topics relating to the diversity of cultural production in Peninsular and Latin American Culture.  Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
desc: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: From Text to Stage: Topics in Hispanic Theatre
desc: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Theatre. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Multicultural Beginnings: Topics in Medieval Literature and Culture
desc: Selected areas of study relating to literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula to the 15th century. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Hispanic Linguistics
desc: Spanish as a linguistic system. Includes the structure of Spanish words and sentences, dialectal varieties in both Spain and Latin America, and linguistic theory.
prer: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Ascent and Decline: Topics in Golden-Age Peninsular Literature and Culture
desc: Selected areas of study relating to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Modernization and Autonomy: Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture since the 18th Century
desc: Selected areas of study relating to the literature and culture of modern Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Discourse and Dialect: Topics in Spanish Language
desc: Selected areas of study relating to Spanish linguistics or its relation to other languages spoken in the Hispanic world. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Imperial Eyes and Foundational Fictions: Topics in Spanish-American Colonial and Nineteenth-Century Culture
desc: Selected areas of study relating to colonial and/or nineteenth-century Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Peoples and Nations: Topics in Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Spanish-American Culture
desc: Selected areas of study relating to modern and/or contemporary Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Research Intensive Seminar in Hispanic Literature and Culture
desc: Theories and methodologies of the discipline. Consult the Department for this year's offering.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Directed Reading
desc: Focus on a topic agreed on by both Faculty Supervisor and student. Restricted to students with 4th year standing and permission from both the Department Head and Faculty Supervisor.
prer: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture I
desc: Listening to and speaking ASL.  Emphasizes core grammar and vocabulary, contextual use, connection between language and Deaf culture. For students new to ASL.

name: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture II
desc: Skills in using ASL in a range of social contexts. Training in grammar and vocabulary that builds fluency, and in using the language appropriately for meaningful interactions with members of the Deaf community. For students with basic ASL conversational ability.

name: Introduction to Archaeology
desc: Survey of world archaeology, from the emergence of humankind to the beginning of state societies.

name: Bones: The Origins of Humanity
desc: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

name: Archaeological Methods
desc: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

name: Great Archaeological Discoveries
desc: An examination of some momentous discoveries in archaeology that have shaped our knowledge of the ancient world and the history of humanity.

name: Forensic Anthropology
desc: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

name: Ancient North America
desc: Introductory survey of North American archaeology comparing the ancient cultures from all major regions of Canada and the US.

name: Ancient Latin America
desc: The archaeology of ancient Mexico, Central and South America, highlighting recent discoveries about the emergence and growth of civilizations such as the Aztecs, Maya, Zapotec, Inca, Chimor and their ancestors.

name: Taming the Wild: Animals, Alcohol and Agriculture
desc: How, when and why humans became dependent on cultivated foods and domestic animals and the methods used to document plant and animal domestication.

name: Archaeological Interpretation
desc: Current theoretical developments explored through the practice of archaeology. Examples drawn from a range of times and places focusing on emerging technologies, food production, colonial encounters and culture contact, materiality and symbolic systems, social inequality and complexity, and human-environmental interactions.

name: Summer Field Training in Archaeology
desc: Intensive training in excavation techniques and interpretation, including mapping procedures, recording, preliminary analysis, and reporting. Students will participate in an excavation for the Summer Session and will use this excavation as a basis for lectures, discussions and reports. Additional Field Trip Fees are charged for this course.

name: The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
desc: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

name: Archaeology of Hunter-Gatherer-Forager-Societies
desc: Early hunter-gatherer-forager societies, spanning the period from the emergence of the first tool-using hominins to the origins of agriculture.

name: The Emergence of Complex Societies in Eurasia and Africa
desc: Archaeological evidence and theories for the origins and spread of settled village life, food production systems, and complex social and political organization: Early Neolithic period through to the appearance of the old world civilizations.

name: Archaeological Foundations of East and Southeast Asia
desc: Survey of the archaeology of East and Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the beginnings of the economic, social, political, and artistic traditions and systems of the great civilizations, and the conditions in which they arose. Theories of cultural development emphasizing Neolithic and state-level societies will be discussed.

name: Archaeological Foundations of Mesoamerica
desc: The archaeology of Mexico and Central America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization. Seminar format discussing recent research and current discoveries.

name: Archaeological Foundations of South America
desc: The archaeology of South America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization, and a primary focus on the Andean region.  Seminar format with lectures discussing recent research and current discoveries.

name: Paleoanthropology
desc: Origin and development of the hominins; the hominin fossil record, and theories relating to hominin evolution.

name: Primatology
desc: A comprehensive survey of primates, with emphasis on evolution, ecology, social organization,  social behaviour, and field studies.

name: Molecular Archaeology
desc: Molecular techniques in archaeology and their application to anthropological and archaeological research.

name: Archaeological and Anthropological Mapping
desc: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

name: Analytical Techniques in Archaeology
desc: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

name: Archaeology of a Special Area
desc: Analysis of the archaeology of a specific areal, methodological, and theoretical topic, including a summary of the literature and examination of specific sites and analytical issues. The area covered will vary according to the instructor's expertise.

name: Prehistory of a Special Area in the New World
desc: Analysis of the prehistory of a selected New World area, including a summary of the literature and discussion of relevant problems. The course will provide background for students in North, Central, and South American area studies. Typical offerings include the prehistory of Mesoamerica, the Southwest, North America and the Mayan areas.

name: The Archaeology of Death
desc: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology.

name: First Nations Archaeology of British Columbia
desc: An advanced study of the prehistoric archaeology of coastal and interior Native Peoples. A critical analysis of the archaeological evidence and interpretations of prehistoric cultural developments from the earliest migrations up to historical contact.

name: Practising Archaeology and the Management of Cultural Resources
desc: Survey of the use of archaeology in the public context and interest, particularly the identification, evaluation, conservation, and management of archaeological resources.  Laws and policies, principles, methods, and ethical concerns guiding current practices, public involvement, relationships with indigenous communities, and contemporary issues in cultural resources management.

name: Paleodiet
desc: The archaeological evidence for the change of human diets over time and the methods used to reconstruct past diets.

name: Archaeological Survey Methods
desc: Analytical and practical skills in locating archaeological sites and data leading to spatial patterns and historical interpretation.

name: Introductory Topics in Food and Resource Economics
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food and resource economics. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Managerial Economics
desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301, ECON 304, COMM 295.
prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102 and MATH 105.

name: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
desc: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally. [3-0-1]

name: Introduction to Global Food Markets
desc: An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies. [3-0-1]

name: Empirical Methods for Food and Resource Economics
desc: Introduction to empirical methods with applications for problems in food and resource economics; standard linear regression and methods to address data deficiencies; interpretation of regression results for forecasting and policy analysis.

name: International Agricultural Development
desc: Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment.

name: Land and Resource Economics
desc: Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity. [3-0]

name: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
desc: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management. [2-1-0]
prer: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

name: Government and Business
desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making.

name: Market Research and Analysis in Agri-Food Industries
desc: Macro and micro aspects of agri-food market and industry analysis, market strategy, consumer behaviour, secondary market research, quantitative and qualitative market research. [3-0-0]

name: The Economics of International Trade and the Environment
desc: Market failure and gains from trade in the presence of natural resource externalities; the multilateral trading system and the environment; case studies in trade-related environmental impacts. [3-0]
prer: One of ECON 301, FRE  295, COMM 295 or 6 credits of upper-level FRE or ECON.

name: Economics of Food Consumption
desc: Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics.

name: Causal Inference in the Economics of Natural Resource Conservation
desc: Estimating causal relationships in natural resource economics; applied data analysis; econometrics; counterfactual thinking, and applications to the economics of: natural resource conservation, species loss and extraction, protected areas, international trade of wildlife products, and endangered species legislation.
prer: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, BIOL 300, ECON 326, COMM 291, FRST 231 and one of ECON 101, ECON 310.

name: Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics
Directed Studies in Food and Resource Economics
Undergraduate Thesis
desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis.
prer: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

name: Introduction to Conservation
desc: Seminars on current natural resources conservation and forest sciences topics. [3-0-0]

name: Observing the Earth from Space
desc: Exploration of innovative Earth observation and other geospatial technologies and how they allow us to better understand the changing Earth. [3-0-0]

name: Foundations of Conservation
desc: Conceptual foundations of conservation; means of conserving nature and natural resources. [3-0-0]

name: Visualizing Climate Change
desc: Introduction to climate change through the lens of local landscapes and future scenarios, using visual media to communicate the underlying science & psychology, and engage communities in local climate change solutions.

name: Issues in Genomics and the Environment
desc: Introductory genomics in the context of genetics and epigenetics; current and topical issues, including genetic determinism, environmental DNA, revival of extinct species, and applications of genomics to improve our life and environment including adaptation to climate change. [3-0-0]

name: Ecology in a Changing Climate
desc: Impact of climate change on ecological systems. Builds framework for understanding past and future changes following fundamental organizing units of ecology - individuals, populations, species, communities, and ecosystems.

name: Elements of Biodiversity
desc: The units of biodiversity, from genes to ecosystems, how they are structured in space, and their importance to human well-being and ecosystem health. [3-0-0]
prer: One of APBI 260, BIOL 230, FRST 201, GEOB 207.

name: Conservation Science and Sustainability
desc: Fundamental concepts in conservation science. Different philosophies, perspectives, and disciplines used in setting priorities for managing biodiversity at all scales. [3-2-0]

name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems for Forestry and Conservation
desc: Introduction to principles, practice and context of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applied to forest management and natural resource conservation issues. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry. [2-2-0]

name: Aboriginal Forestry
desc: Issues the may be encountered in professional natural resources work with or for Aboriginal communities and organization, including contemporary issues of Aboriginal rights and title, traditional uses, and self-government. [3-0-0]

name: Belowground Ecosystems
desc: Current concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; to understand the roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. [3-0-0]
prer: Fourth year standing in the Faculty of Forestry or a Bachelor of Science Program awarded by any Faculty. Permission is required for registration.

name: Land, Trees, and Property Institutions
desc: Exploration of the forces that gave rise to the global variety of systems of property for trees and forestlands; evolution in the governance of property. [3-0-0]

name: Sustainable Energy: Policy and Governance
desc: Energy as a global policy problem; current energy challenges; energy systems and energy analysis; the politics and policy of energy alternatives. [3-0-0]
prer: Third- or fouth-year standing; 100-level MATH course.

name: Conservation Decision-Making and Policy
desc: An introduction to policy and decision making for conserving biodiversity in an uncertain world using a combination of ecological data and decision science. [3-1-0]

name: Directed Studies in Natural Resources Conservation
desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies of specific problems in natural resources conservation.

name: Integrated Field School
desc: Field methods, research and analysis, community oriented projects, and the interactions between biological and social aspects of conservation research. Students may not take any other courses in conjunction with CONS 451. Restricted to B.Sc.N. students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Major.

name: Global Perspectives Capstone
desc: Examination of global resources and sustainability via scenario evaluation, modelling, and prescription.
prer: One of CONS 340, GEOB 270 and fourth year standing in the Global Perspectives Major.

name: International Conservation and Forest Ecosystem Management Field School
desc: International, experiential learning in conservation and forest ecosystem management. A 300-level ecology course such as CONS 330 is strongly recommended as a prerequisite. Fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration is required.
prer: One of FRST 231, BIOL 300 and all of FRST 210, FRST 211. Or 6 credits of ecology based courses (e.g. BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 260, APBI 360). Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required.

name: Conservation Planning in Practice
desc: Theory, tools and practical skills needed to conduct conservation planning at the community level.  Addresses issues of developing and implementing plans in the context of sustainability goals, political realities and diverse public opinion. [2-2-0]

name: Fish Conservation and Management
desc: Principles of fish biology, population and community ecology necessary to understand conservation and management; overview of current issues, tactics and institutions involved with fisheries conservation and management. [2-3-0]

name: Contemporary Forestry and Conservation in China (UBC Global Seminar Series)
desc: This is a one-month UBC Global Seminar program in China allows students to learn forestry and conservation in Asia through lectures and field trips to nature reserves, plantations, wood industry firms and national parks in China.

name: Recreation and Tourism Planning
desc: Principles and methods for planning urban and rural recreation and related tourism resources including analyzing recreation resources, applying policies and standards, developing park/recreation area management plans, and understanding benefits to human and community wellbeing and biodiversity. [3-0-0]

name: Human Wildlife Conflict
desc: Evaluation of the impacts of human wildlife conflicts on wildlife populations; application of innovative methods to reduce human wildlife conflicts. [2-0-1]
prer: Third-year standing or higher. BIOL 230 or FRST 395 and APBI 315 or APBI 416 recommended.

name: Thesis or Special Project
desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the supervision of a staff member.

name: First Nations and Canada: (Re)writing History
desc: A survey of the history of Indigenous peoples in relation to the Canadian colonial state contrasting the Indigenous historical experience with conventional accounts of Canadian history.
crer: All of HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

name: Law and Governance: Indigenous and European Traditions
desc: Background on sources of Aboriginal and Canadian law; detail on section 35 of the Constitution Act; a review of relevant Canadian case law; insight on the importance of international law; and literature on governance.
crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

name: Perspectives on Reconciliation
desc: Notions of reconciliation and restitution that have emerged in Canada across space and time; key principles, discourses, legal and Constitutional mechanisms, actions and actors.
crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

name: Reconciliation and Resource Management
desc: Relationships and reconciliation processes between First Nations and other governments in the context of land and sea governance.
crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 314.

name: Reconciliation and Communities
desc: In-depth exploration of the communities of Haida Gwaii through community-based experiences and community service learning.
crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313.

name: Special Topics on Ecology and Society
desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by instructors teaching with the Haida Gwaii Institute. The course is expected to be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate for upper level students.

name: Case Studies in Haida Gwaii
desc: Integration of concepts of history, politics, First Nations, rural development, and forest ecology in natural resources management in Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

name: History and Politics of Resource Management
desc: Historical examination of resource management in Canada and conflicts arising therefrom, with emphasis on forests.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 352, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

name: First Nations Governance and Natural Resource Management
desc: The political, economic, and legal environment of Aboriginal-Canadian relations and its influence on resource use and management; review of historic relationships, emerging case law, and new reconciliation frameworks. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

name: Rainforest Ecology and Management
desc: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 354.

name: Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
desc: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 353.

name: Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
desc: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

name: Biophysical Dynamics of the Marine-Terrestrial Interface
desc: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems; how the physical characteristics of this interface affect inputs; which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

name: Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
desc: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357.
crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

name: Systems Thinking for Resource Management
desc: Introduction to systems thinking and resilience to understand dynamics of social change and innovation; use of case studies to demonstrate applications of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 359.

name: Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
desc: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.

name: Ocean People, Culture and Tradition
desc: The relationship between the culture of the Haida people and their marine environment; and traditional and modern approaches to management of marine resources.

name: Fisheries Co-Management of the North Pacific Coast
desc: Concepts of fisheries co-management with a focus on the North Pacific Coast; examples of other comanagement structures regionally and internationally.

name: Marine Protected Areas and Marine Spatial Planning
desc: Key concepts in MSP and key elements inherent in MPA and MPA network design, governance, implementation, management, compliance and monitoring.
crer: All of HGSE 360, HGSE 361, HGSE 363, HGSE 364.

name: Applications in Marine Conservation
desc: Exposure to field settings and research techniques in local marine environments.
crer: All of HGSE 360, HGSE 361, HGSE 362, HGSE 364.

name: Haida Gwaii Marine Conservation Seminar
desc: Key marine conservation issues, pairing broad topics with examples on Haida Gwaii to bring theory into practice.
crer: All of HGSE 360, HGSE 361, HGSE 362, HGSE 363.

name: Introduction to Resilience Theory in Community
desc: Theory of social-ecological resilience as  applied to cross-cultural community settings, using case studies from communities on Haida Gwaii and other exceptional cases of community resilience.

name: Re-Storying History: Indigenous Perspective
desc: Exploration of the diversity of Indigenous peoples of British Columbia and Canada and their unique histories, beginning with origin stories and oral histories and moving on to the histories and relationships that Indigenous groups have with the federal, provincial and territorial governments.
crer: All of HGSE 370, HGSE 372, HGSE 373, HGSE 374.

name: Language and Cultural Continuity
desc: An exploration of language as a means of looking at culture, and cultural continuity. Using Xaad Kilthe Haida language as a framing device, students will explore the integral connections between language, culture, history, land, health and resilience.

name: Community Planning and Development for Resilience
desc: An examination of the challenges and opportunities of developing and diversifying resilient resource dependent cross-cultural, rural communities using Haida Gwaii's comprehensive community planning as a case study.
crer: All of HGSE 370, HGSE 371, HGSE 372, HGSE 374.

name: Community Resilience Seminar
desc: The application of theory, concepts, stories, and histories of community resilience through focused readings, group discussions and engagement with local speakers to provide the opportunity to engage deeply and work at the theory-practice interface.
crer: All of HGSE 370, HGSE 371, HGSE 372, HGSE 373.

name: Systems Thinking and Social-Ecological Change
desc: Theories of systems change, including complex systems thinking, resilience/transformation, transition management and other social science-based change theories.
crer: All of HGSE 381, HGSE 382, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.

name: Ecological Economics
desc: Underlying philosophy and principles of ecological economics, including the cascading effects of change, unintended consequences of change, and why it might be difficult to separate our ecological goals from our political realities.
crer: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.

name: Political and Legal Aspects of Systems Change
desc: An examination of the emergence of Aboriginal Law in Canada, with a focus on the development of Aboriginal law as an innovation in shaping new contexts for Federal-, Provincial- and Corporate-Indigenous relations and its implications for systems transformation.
crer: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 381, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.

name: Social Innovation and Entrepreneurship
desc: An examination of the relationships between culture, ingenuity, creativity, entrepreneurship and innovation required to understand and foster systems change through Indigenous and cross-cultural examples.
crer: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 381, HGSE 381, HGSE 384.

name: Case Studies in Social-Ecological Change
desc: An exploration of complex issues of social-ecological change in the current social-economic-political context of reconciliation initiatives and Indigenous governance, highlighting the Haida worldview and Haida ways of knowing and being with western understandings of social-ecological systems.
crer: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 381, HGSE 382, HGSE 383.

name: Temples, Tombs, and Tyrants: The Archaeology of the Middle East, Greece, and Rome
desc: The rise of civilizations, cultural interconnections, and power dynamics in the ancient Middle East (including Egypt), Greece, and Rome (10,000 BCE - 300 CE). Archaeological methods and interpretation, and analysis of ancient artifacts in UBC collections.

name: The Archaeology of Life and Death in the Roman Empire
desc: The lives of non-elite individuals and groups living under the Roman Empire, seen through material evidence and its interpretation. Identity, urbanism, economy, agriculture, diet, religion, "Romanization," and burial.

name: Byzantium: Arts of an Empire
desc: Art, architecture, and material culture of the Byzantine Empire situated in the eastern Mediterranean (c. 300-1453); focus on social and cultural contexts of artistic production, including interactions with neighboring cultures.

name: Art and the Christian Transformation of the Roman Empire
desc: Visual culture and the rise of Christianity; social, political and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks.

name: Practicum in Classical or Near Eastern Archaeology
desc: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks; it may be repeated once.

name: Theories of Myth
desc: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended.

name: The Archaeology of Ancient Cyprus
desc: An overview of the archaeology of ancient Cyprus from the island's initial colonization in the 10th millennium BCE through the period of its rule as part of the Roman Empire (4th century CE).

name: Introduction to Theatre
desc: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

name: Introduction to Technical Production
desc: Foundation study of production technologies for the performing arts.

name: Graphics for Theatre and Film Design
Drama: Forms and Ideas I
desc: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential.

name: Drama: Forms and Ideas II
desc: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

name: Performance Study I
desc: Study of the actor's process.

name: Play-Interpretation and Production-Analysis
desc: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

name: Technical Production
desc: The construction and execution of scenery, costumes, properties, lighting, and sound for the stage.

name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Beginning Voice and Movement I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

name: Beginning Voice and Movement II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Production I
desc: Assigned projects in theatre production.

name: Styles of Decor and Dress
desc: Artistic, decorative, cultural, and social contexts of selected theatrical genres and periods.

name: Scenery Design I
desc: Principles and practice of scenery design for the performing arts.

name: Costume Design I
desc: Principles and practice of costume design for the performing arts.

name: Lighting Design I
desc: The optical, distribution, and control systems used in stage lighting design.

name: Sound Design
desc: Audio design and production for theatre and other performance forms.

name: Theory of Drama Performance
desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

name: Studies in Drama
desc: Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Introduction to Directing
prer: One of THTR 130, THTR 230 and THTR 299.

name: History of Theatre I
desc: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century.

name: Performance Study II
desc: Study of performance styles.

name: Creating Theatre I
desc: Study and practice of processes and forms used to create ensemble performance.

name: Studies in Asian Theatre
desc: Open to all students in third year and above.

name: Scenery Production I
desc: Scenery construction, rigging, and systems.

name: Scene Painting I
desc: Media, techniques, and textural treatments used in scene painting.

name: Stage Management
desc: Principles and procedures of stage management: organizations, systems, and operations.

name: Costume Construction
desc: Advanced assembly and specialized construction methods for producing costume for stage and screen.

name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Rehearsal and Performance
desc: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

name: Production II
desc: Assigned projects in theatre design and production.
crer: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, THTR 350, THTR 352, THTR 354, THTR 356.

name: Scenery Design II
desc: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio.

name: Costume Design II
desc: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design.

name: Lighting Design II
desc: Complex design and advanced technologies in stage lighting and scenography.

name: Advanced Study in Design and Scenography
desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consent of Department required.

name: Dramaturgy
desc: Advanced problems in dramaturgy, both in a historical and a contemporary context.

name: Directing Lab
prer: THTR 317. Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course.

name: History of Theatre II
desc: Key movements in world theatre history from the nineteenth century to the present.

name: History of Theatre from 1900 to the present
desc: The development of Western Theatre from 1900 to the present

name: Theory of Drama and Performance
desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on theatrical theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

name: Creating Theatre
desc: Ensemble creation culminating in the presentation of a theatrical work. Permission of the instructor is required.

name: Topics in Theatre
desc: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
prer: 6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.

name: Women in Theatre and Film
desc: A course dealing with women's involvement in and contribution to various aspects of Theatre and/or Film Topics will change from year to year.

name: Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice
Scenery Production II
desc: Technical direction; complex techniques and problems in scenery production.

name: Scene Painting II
desc: Study of selected scene painting styles.

name: Production and Theatre Management
desc: Production and theatre management with emphasis on budgeting, publicity, scheduling, press relations, special events, legal issues, season selection, resumes and interpersonal skills.

name: Costume Construction II
desc: Pattern development and cutting for costume for stage and screen using flat pattern and draping.

name: Interdisciplinary Projects
desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. (Acting) students.
prer: All of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Advanced Speech and Movement I
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

name: Advanced Speech and Movement II
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

name: Advanced Rehearsal and Performance
desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

name: Production III
desc: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
crer: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

name: Physical Therapy Foundations
desc: Builds on prerequisite concepts in anatomy, physiology, and physics taken at undergraduate and high school level to apply basic theories and principles of anatomy, human physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics, and physics to essential rehabilitation concepts.

name: BFA Studio Practice
desc: Introduction to a broad range of contemporary studio practice. Intended for first year Bachelor of Fine Arts VISA students.

name: Foundation Studio: Digital Media
desc: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

name: Foundation Studio: Approaches to Media
desc: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

name: Foundation Studio: Ideas as Practice I
desc: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

name: Digital Arts
desc: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture, with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media.
prer: A cumulative average of at least 72% in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.

name: Drawing
desc: Development of skills in drawing including life drawing. Introduction to the development of personal style and concepts.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Painting
desc: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Photography
desc: Introduction to photography techniques and image-making. Emphasis on camera techniques and film and darkroom production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Digital Photography
desc: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production.  Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183; or BMS student and VISA 110.

name: Print Media
desc: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Sculpture
desc: Contemporary sculpture practice and theory. Various sculpture materials and technologies including machinery use.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Special Studies
desc: Introduction to various aspects of contemporary studio practice. Not offered every year.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in two of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

name: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II
desc: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students.
prer: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

name: Intermediate Digital Arts I
desc: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects.

name: Intermediate Digital Arts II
desc: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects.

name: Intermediate Drawing I
desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development.

name: Intermediate Drawing II
desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

name: Intermediate Painting I
desc: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced  to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice.

name: Intermediate Painting II
desc: Further investigation of painting in the context of contemporary art.  Emphasis on self directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

name: Intermediate Photography I
desc: An investigation of approaches to photography and its meaning in the context of contemporary art. The term theme will be determined by the instructor. B & W, colour and digital production.

name: Intermediate Photography II
desc: An investigation of contemporary photography production and approaches to the constructed image with emphasis on medium and large format camera use and studio lighting techniques.

name: Intermediate Print Media I: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
desc: Intaglio and relief print applications (i.e., etching, wood and/or lino cut, and collagraph) in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing; discussion of contemporary and historical visual print culture.
prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.

name: Intermediate Print Media II: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
desc: Screen printing and other print applications in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing, explored within the context of contemporary art.
prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

name: Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
desc: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed.
prer: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

name: Intermediate Sculpture I
desc: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture.
prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

name: Intermediate Sculpture II
desc: Development of personal concerns in three-dimensional work. Emphasis on the integration of diverse materials and techniques.
prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

name: Special Studies I
desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

name: Special Studies II
desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

name: Artists in Society
desc: Exploring artistic practice through community-engaged partnerships and critical study.
prer: Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students majoring in Visual Arts or Art History.

name: Studio Theory
desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

name: Studio Seminar
desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

name: Performance Art
desc: Seminar-based studio focusing on performance and actions in the field of contemporary art.
prer: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.

name: Advanced Open Studio
desc: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
prer: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 352, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 375, VISA 390.

name: Advanced Digital Arts I
desc: Development of contemporary art works utilizing digital technologies including 3-dimensional applications, spatial, interactive and time-based installations. Focus on student-generated projects, either individual or group.
prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

name: Advanced Digital Arts II: Video
desc: Contemporary practices in video media examined through individual projects and directed study.
prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

name: Advanced Drawing and Painting I
desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.

name: Advanced Drawing and Painting II
desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.

name: Advanced Photography I
desc: Photography practice in the context of contemporary art. Interdisciplinary connections to other media will be encouraged.

name: Advanced Photography II
desc: The production of self-directed projects investigating photography as art. Focus on integrative approaches including conventional, digital and multi-media.

name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture I
desc: Studies in contemporary trends in studio practice and theory. Emphasis on advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture II
desc: Further studies in advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

name: Interdisciplinary Projects
desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

name: Advanced Special Studies I
desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

name: Advanced Special Studies II
desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

name: Exhibition Theory and Practice
desc: Exhibition course focusing on current curatorial practices and theories with an emphasis on contemporary visual art with the aim of preparing students to engage in the active organization of a large exhibition. Restricted to 4th year Majors in either VISA or ARTH, or permission of the instructor.

name: Performance Actions and Approaches
desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

name: Advanced Seminar I
desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

name: Advanced Seminar II
desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio I
desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Not offered every year.
prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio II
desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required.
prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

name: Business and Management Values
desc: Balancing organizational, personal, and community interests in a global economy. In addition to standard management textbooks and readings, the class will draw from the work of poets, fiction writers, essayists, and social critics.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Critical Evaluation of Information, Evidence, and Arguments
desc: Strategies to critically evaluate information relevant to Human Resource Managers. This course will examine common errors in logic, decision biases, and cause and effect relationships.
prer: All of COMM 291, COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Strategic Staffing
desc: Processes of workforce recruitment, selection, retention, and renewal. Includes human resources planning, development of an effective staffing strategy and employer brand, job analysis and descriptions, cost-benefit analysis of various recruiting methods, analysis and evaluation of selection methods.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Training, Development, and Performance Management
desc: Employee training, development and performance management in a variety of employment settings. Application of various training methods to performance enhancement, performance appraisal, feedback, and empirical evaluation of training investments.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Strategic Compensation
desc: Employee compensation, including pay systems, benefits systems, and rewards and recognition programs. Examination of the motivational underpinnings of compensation administration and the application of compensation principles to the achievement of employer strategic objectives.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Introduction to Organizational Consulting
desc: Frameworks from the social sciences useful for understanding organizational processes and how to apply these frameworks to particular organizational consulting challenges.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Labour Relations
desc: Integrated coverage of union-management relations including labour law, collective bargaining, and collective agreement administration.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Industrial Relations in an Era of Globalization
desc: Comprehensive examination of the Canadian industrial relations system, and its legal foundations, in the context of a global economy.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Organizational Analysis
desc: An analysis of organizational structures and intraorganizational processes; effects of organizational factors on individual behaviour.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Organizational Change
desc: The tactics and strategies for implementing constructive modifications in organizations.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Leadership
desc: Explores the characteristics of effective leadership and examines how to be a better leader.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Managing Diversity
desc: Explores the business and legal cases for diversity in the workplace. Examines how to effectively manage a diverse work force.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Power and Politics
desc: Examines the sources and consequences of power in the context of different corporate and national cultures.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Managing the Family Business
desc: Managing and working in a family business presents unique challenges: family issues can conflict with business issues. This course examines governance structures and tools to manage the interface between the family and the business.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: International Human Resource Management
desc: Application of human resource management practices to multinational enterprises. Comparative analysis of national human resource management systems.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Advanced Organizational Consulting
desc: Methods and techniques to diagnose and solve a broad range of organizational problems from the perspective of an organizational consultant.
prer: All of COMM 292, COHR 307 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Organizational Design
desc: Techniques and approaches for evaluating and adjusting the structures of organization.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Creativity and Innovation
desc: Techniques and approaches to managing creativity and innovation in organizations.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Knowledge Management
desc: Techniques and approaches to managing knowledge and learning in organizations.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Managing and Building Teams
desc: Techniques and approaches for building effective teams, handling decision-making in teams, creating reward structures, and developing appropriate leadership models.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Advanced Topics in Organizational Behaviour
desc: Understanding, critiquing, and analyzing behaviour and social processes in organizations. This course focuses on provocative and current topics that could not be covered in depth in the introductory course.
prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Employment Law
desc: Introduction to legislation and application of legal principles that govern the employment relationship.
prer: All of COMM 292, COMM 393 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

name: Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources
Data: Description, Display, and Inference
desc: Use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 126 or COMM 126.

name: Financial Accounting
desc: Construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 293.

name: Managerial Accounting
desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 294 or COMM 294.

name: Introduction to Finance
desc: Basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 298.

name: Market Research
desc: The process of marketing research including problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
prer: Either (a) all of ECON 315, ECON 316 or (b) ECON 308.

name: Corporate Finance
desc: Corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice; and financial policies, tools, and valuation.
prer: Either (a) all of ECON 315, ECON 316 or (b) ECON 308.

name: Investment Theory
desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 371 or COMM 371.
prer: Either (a) ECON 308 or (b) all of ECON 315, ECON 316.

name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 456, COEC 377, or COMM 377.

name: Entrepreneurial Finance
desc: Financial issues encountered by those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors.

name: Environment, Society, and Government
desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy, with an emphasis on their interactions with the environmental and indigenous communities. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

name: Database Technology
desc: Theory and technology of database management from an applications perspective; database design; database administration. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 437, COMM 437, or CPSC 304.

name: The Economics & Policy of the Environment, Energy, and Natural Resources
desc: Economic analysis of environmental problems, energy systems, and natural resources. Policy options to help resolve these issues. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 475,  COMM 487, or ECON 371.
prer: ECON 315 and one of ECON 316, ECON 308.

name: Strategic Management
desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of single- and multi-business unit private sector enterprises, analyzed using the case method. Integrates methodologies from economic and organizational theory to form the foundations for strategic analyses.

name: New Enterprise Development
desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.

name: International Business Management
desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 498 or COMM 498.

name: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
desc: Frameworks from linguistics, psychology, and speech and hearing sciences as applied to communication disorders, clinical populations and practices. [3-0]

name: Neuroanatomy for Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology
prer: As indicated on the website at www.audiospeech.ubc.ca or by permission of the instructor.

name: Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences
desc: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences. [3-0-0]
prer: Second year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Faculty of Science.

name: Introduction to Sustainability
desc: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives. [3-0-0]

name: Basics of Oral Microbiology
desc: Basic principles in the study of microorganisms and their relation to human health for dental hygiene students.

name: Oral Health Sciences I
desc: An introduction to normal, healthy facial, oral, and dental structures; oral health records, and charting terminology and symbols.

name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice I
desc: An introduction to the Dental Hygiene profession, practice roles and the process of care model.

name: Oral Health Sciences II
desc: An introduction to desease-related concepts during the study of dental materials, general pathology, plaque biofilm, nutrition, radiology, periodontology, and oral pathology.

name: Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice II
desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice in clinical and community-based settings.

name: Oral Health Sciences III
desc: An introduction to concepts and principles of pharmacology and local anesthesia, and further study of oral medicine, oral pathology, and radiology.

name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice III
desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice with emphasis on diverse clients with oral health care needs.

name: Applied Pharmacology
desc: Applied pharmacology concepts and principles for the dental health professional.

name: Policy Analysis and Change
desc: Critical reviews of oral health care delivery, oral disease processes and dental hygiene. [3-0-0]

name: Oral Epidemiology
desc: Basic epidemiological and statistical concepts and tests relevant to evidence-based oral health practices.

name: Dental Hygiene Practice I
desc: Dental hygiene concepts, processes, and skills for individuals and communities. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

name: Dental Hygiene Practice II
desc: Advanced dental hygiene concepts, processes and skills in community health, educational or institutional settings.

name: Oral Microbiology and Immunology
desc: Microbiology and immunological concepts relevant for dental hygiene practice.

name: Guided Study in Dental Hygiene
desc: Conduct an in-depth investigation of a health promotion issue.
prer: All of DHYG 400, DHYG 401, DHYG 461. And Faculty approval.

name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice IV
desc: Critical analysis of dental hygiene theory and practice related to diverse clients with complex oral health care needs.

name: Oral Health Care Trends & Topics
desc: Critical analysis of health care trends and oral health care delivery with emphasis on underserved diverse populations.

name: Assessment and Treatment Planning for Advanced Periodontal Diseases
desc: Available in online distance education format only.

name: Oral Medicine and Pathology
desc: Pathobiology of oral diseases. Available in online distance education format only.

name: Literature Review II
desc: A continuation of DHYG 461. [2-0-0]

name: Introduction to Philosophy
desc: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.

name: Introduction to Philosophy
desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 101.

name: Introduction to Philosophy II
desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 102.

name: Introduction to Critical Thinking
desc: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

name: Introduction to Scientific Reasoning
desc: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

name: Greek Philosophy I: Socrates and Plato
desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato.  Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

name: Greek Philosophy II: Aristotle and After
desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

name: Symbolic Logic
desc: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests.

name: Introduction to Ethics
desc: Theories of obligation and value; moral reasoning; normative ethics, descriptive ethics and meta-ethics. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

name: Contemporary Moral Issues
desc: Moral issues such as life and death decisions, paternalism, markets, animal welfare, technology, and global justice.

name: Introduction to Epistemology
desc: Topics in epistemology such as skepticism, truth, justification, a priori and a posteriori knowledge. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

name: Minds and Machines
desc: Philosophical and theoretical issues that pertain to how mental phenomena fit into the material world. Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 250 or PHIL 150.

name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
desc: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

name: The Philosophy of Plato
desc: A study of Plato's dialogues and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

name: The Philosophy of Aristotle
desc: A study of Aristotle's writings and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

name: Medieval Philosophy
desc: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the 14th century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham.

name: Philosophy in the 17th Century
desc: Survey of 17th-century philosophy from Bacon to Leibniz, including the writings of Hobbes, Descartes, and Spinoza. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

name: Philosophy in the 18th Century
desc: Survey of 18th-century philosophy from Locke to Kant, including the writings of Berkeley, Rousseau, and Hume. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

name: Philosophy After 1800
desc: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.

name: Logic: Metatheory and Computability
desc: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability.

name: Induction, Decision and Game Theory
desc: Formal methods relevant to probabilistic and inductive reasoning. Decision theory, game theory, axiomatic probability theory and its interpretations, belief dynamics, simulation and modelling.
prer: One of PHIL 125, PHIL 220 or instructor permission.

name: Modal Logic
desc: Logic of the modal operators "It is necessary that" and "It is possible that." Possible-world semantics and a method of derivation for this logic.

name: Non-Classical Logics
desc: One or more of conditional logic, deontic logic, epistemic logic, many-valued logic, systems of belief dynamics.

name: Philosophy of Logic
desc: Fundamental concepts and methods of logic; the logistic method, syntax and semantics; the conditional; entailment; consequence; modal logic; problems concerning extensionality and intentionality. Frege's distinction between sense and reference; Russell's theory of definite descriptions; Tarski's definition of truth.

name: Philosophy of Language I
desc: Philosophical discussion of language, meaning, and communication. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 326 or PHIL 425.
prer: At least one of LING 201/PHIL 220, plus 6 additional credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

name: Social and Political Philosophy
desc: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

name: Business and Professional Ethics
desc: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, "whistle blowing" and self-regulation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 331 or PHIL 434.

name: Environmental Ethics
desc: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 332 or PHIL 435.

name: Bio-Medical Ethics
desc: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333 or PHIL 433.

name: Sex, Gender and Philosophy
