desc: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

name: Power and Oppression
desc: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.

name: Ethics for the Sciences
desc: Philosophical exploration of ethical issues in the non-medical sciences, including topics such as intellectual integrity, responsible conduct of research, protection of human subjects, ethics of animal experimentation, and the social responsibilities of scientists. Credit will be granted for only one of ISCI 433 or PHIL 337.

name: Philosophy of Law
desc: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.
prer: Restricted to second- or higher-year standing.

name: Philosophy of Art
desc: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.

name: Introduction to Metaphysics
desc: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

name: Philosophy of Religion
desc: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 347 or PHIL 349.

name: Introduction to Continental Philosophy
desc: Major themes and figures in the Continental philosophy tradition; possible topics include 19th century precursors, 20th century philosophers, and comparisons between analytic and continental philosophy.

name: Philosophical Perspectives on Cognitive Systems Research
desc: Philosophical exploration of questions and theories arising from research into the mind, as conducted in psychology, linguistics, and computer science.
prer: 3 credits selected from any of PHIL 211, 212, 220, 230, 235, 240, 250, 260, or COGS 200

name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
desc: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith
desc: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
desc: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
desc: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

name: Philosophy of Science
desc: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 369 or PHIL 460.

name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

name: Philosophy and Literature
desc: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems.  Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

name: Existentialism
desc: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

name: Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

name: Honours Tutorial
desc: For students in third-year Honours.

name: Morals, Politics and the Individual
desc: Introduction to major themes in moral and political philosophy. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 400, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

name: Knowledge, Explanation, and the Nature of Things
desc: Introduction to major themes in epistemology and metaphysics. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 401, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
desc: Advanced study of the Presocratics, or of a philosopher such as Plato, or of a school such as the Sceptics or Stoics. Topics vary from year to year.

name: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
desc: Advanced study of a medieval philosopher such as Aquinas, or school.

name: Topics in the History of Modern Philosophy
desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher or school such as Descartes, Hume, Empiricism, Rationalism, or the British utilitarians.

name: The Philosophy of Immanuel Kant
desc: Study of Kant's critical philosophy.

name: Topics in 19th-Century Philosophy
desc: Study of a major 19th-century philosopher such as Hegel, Mill or Nietzsche, or school, such as German Idealism.
prer: One of PHIL 314, PHIL 315, PHIL 316, PHIL 340.

name: Topics in Twentieth-Century Philosophy
desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

name: Philosophy of History
desc: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history.

name: Topics in Symbolic Logic
desc: Formal semantics, proof theory, incompleteness and decidability, axiomatic set theory, independence results. Consult the Department as to which topics are offered in a given year.

name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of language.
prer: PHIL 326. And 6 credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

name: Philosophy of Mathematics
desc: Logicism, formalism and constructivism, implications of metatheorems such as those of Gödel and Church, mathematical truth, mathematics and mental construction, mathematics and the physical world.
prer: Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.

name: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
desc: Central concepts and problems in political life and thought including obligation, citizenship, representation, justice; equality; civil rights and liberty; disobedience.
prer: 9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.

name: Topics in Ethical Theory
desc: Classic or contemporary works in ethical theory.
prer: 9 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above; PHIL 230 is recommended.

name: Topics in Epistemology
desc: Analysis of the concept of knowledge; problems of justifying ordinary and basic empirical beliefs.

name: Philosophy of Perception
desc: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
prer: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.

name: Topics in Continental Philosophy
desc: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 448 or PHIL 449.

name: Topics in Metaphysics
desc: Topics including ontology, universals and particulars, substance, determinism and indeterminism, identity over time, and theories of truth.
prer: 9 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. PHIL 340 is recommended.

name: Philosophy of Mind
desc: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation.
prer: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.

name: Philosophy of Action
desc: Explanation of human actions; the conditions of responsibility; freedom of the will; the domains of rational and moral appraisal; the category of action and the individuation of actions.

name: Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science
desc: Philosophical topics in the cognitive sciences, such as empiricism vs. nativism, consciousness, mental representation, cognitive architecture, language & thought, and situated cognition.
prer: PHIL 441 (Philosophy of Perception), or PHIL 451 (Philosophy of Mind), or 6 credits of Philosophy at the 200-level or above (excluding PHIL 220 and PHIL 320).

name: Philosophy of Social Science
desc: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social sciences: the problem of objectivity, the use of models and evidence, causation and causal reasoning, formal methods, the status of social kinds and norms, scientific explanation, laws.
prer: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.

name: Space and Time
desc: Such topics as: Are space and time continuous? Is motion always relative to another body? Does time flow? Is time irreversible?
prer: PHIL 340 or 12 credits of mathematics or science.

name: Philosophy of Biology
desc: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology.
prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.

name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
desc: Topics such as probability and induction; foundations of measurement; theory construction.

name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
desc: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

name: Directed Reading
desc: Same as PHIL 486-9.

name: Honours Tutorial
desc: For students in fourth-year Honours.

name: Seminar for Majors in Philosophy
desc: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

name: Endodontics
desc: Application of the basic principles of endodontics. [0-1.5-0; 1-1.5-0]

name: Introduction to Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Oral Radiology
desc: Radiographic techniques and radiological interpretation with emphasis on extraoral techniques. [0.5-1.5]

name: Oral Medicine and Oral Diagnosis
desc: Oral diagnosis, including orofacial pain and temporomandibular disorders. [1-3-0; 1-3-0]

name: Oral Medicine, Oral Diagnosis and Therapeutics
desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-2-2]

name: Advanced Oral Radiology and Oral Radiography
Directed Research in Oral Biology
desc: An elective laboratory project taken with the permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head.

name: Advanced Periodontics
desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-3-0]

name: Beginners' French I
desc: Basic vocabulary, the rudiments of grammar and familiarization with cultures of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR.

name: Beginners' French II
desc: A continuation of FREN 101. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR.

name: Keeping Up Your French
desc: Task-based entry-level course for non-specialists. Credits from this course may not count towards a Major or Minor in French, nor as prerequisite to subsequent core courses in French.
prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

name: Elementary French I
desc: Continued improvement in listening, speaking, reading and writing. This course is aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 11, FREN 102 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Elementary French II
desc: A continuation of FREN 201. This course aligned with level A2 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 111, FREN 201 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Oral French Practice
desc: Opportunities for students already well-grounded in grammar to improve their oral skills. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN 215 or FREN 224 and FREN 225.

name: Introduction to Early French Literature and to Textual Analysis
desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the Middle Ages to the 17th century, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose. To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Introduction to Modern Literature written in French and to Textual Analysis
desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the 18th century to the present, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose.  To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

name: French Language and Style I
desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
prer: FREN 123. Or assignment based on placement test.

name: French Language and Style II
desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
prer: FREN 222. Or assignment based on placement test.

name: Introduction to Quebecois Literature Literature and Culture (in English)
desc: An introduction to the historical, political and cultural contexts that influenced the development of literature and culture in Quebec.

name: Intermediate French I
desc: Refinement of reading, writing and speaking skills through the study of contemporary literature and other authentic documents of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112, FREN 202 or assignment bsed on placement test.

name: Intermediate French II
desc: A continuation of FREN 301. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 122, FREN 301 or assignment based on placement.

name: Introduction to Literature in French
desc: Critical reading of foundational literary texts in French from genres of prose fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and theatre.
prer: One of FREN 123, FREN 302 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Critical Writing
desc: Practical tools for university-level writing in French. Apply stylistic devices and rhetorical structures to form questions and arguments, analyse literary and cultural objects, and produce a variety of essay genres.

name: Selected Works of African and Caribbean Literature
desc: Representative works from different genres, viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

name: Selected Works of European French Literature
desc: Representative works viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

name: Introduction to Quebec Literature
desc: Survey of representative literary texts from Quebec viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.
prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 311 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

name: Arts, Cultures and Society from the Middle Ages to the Revolution
desc: Exploration of early French culture and literature from the Middle Ages to the close of the Early Modern period and the French Revolution; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa.
prer: FREN 311 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

name: French Civilization I
desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from their origins to the Third Republic (1875).
prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223. Or permission of the instructor.

name: French Civilization II
desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from the Third Republic to the present, completed by a thematic study of contemporary French culture.
prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

name: French-Canadian Civilization
desc: A thematic approach to selected topics in French-Canadian culture and civilization.
prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

name: The Francophone World in Images
desc: A socio-cultural study of francophone communities of Canada, the Caribbean, Europe, and North and Sub-Saharan Africa as seen through their films and other visual forms.

name: Arts, Cultures and Society from Romanticism to the Present Day
desc: Exploration of modern and contemporary French culture and literature from the early 19th century to the present day; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa.
prer: FREN 311 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401.

name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French I
desc: Training in formal oral presentation in French. Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours Program in French.
prer: One of FREN 215, FREN 225. 68% or better in FREN 215 is recommended.

name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French II
desc: Further training in formal oral presentation in French.  Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward the Honours Program in French.

name: French at Work
desc: Communicative French for students preparing for a career in the francophone world. This course is aligned with the B1 objectives of the CEFR.

name: French Grammar
desc: Principles of grammar theory and contextualized French grammatical concepts. Emphasis on terminology and analysis of grammatical issues. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
prer: One of FREN 123, FREN 302 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Advanced French Grammar
desc: Advanced grammar theory and critical analysis of difficult French grammatical structures. Emphasis on autonomous examination of complex grammatical issues.

name: Advanced Composition
desc: Development of essay writing skills in French.

name: Translation
desc: Principles, practical strategies and methods of translation from French to English and English to French. Overview of the main challenges involved in intercultural communication.
prer: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Introduction to French Linguistics
desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French.
prer: Either (a) FREN 223 or (b) all of FREN 352, FREN 401.

name: Introduction to French Literary Theory and Methodology
desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French literary criticism, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced study of literature in French.

name: Foundations of French Cultural Identity (in English)
desc: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that cut across French history, politics, and social structures. Not available for credit toward a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.

name: Upper-Intermediate French I
desc: Communicative proficiency at an autonomous level: vocabulary enrichment, pronunciation practice, grammatical analysis and development of efficient reading and writing techniques. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 123, FREN 302 or French Immersion 12, or assignment based on placement test.

name: Upper-Intermediate French II
desc: A continuation of FREN 401. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR.
prer: One of FREN 224, FREN 401 or assignment based on placement test.

name: Medieval French Literature
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of French-language literature of the Middle Ages (11th-15th centuries) in their historical context
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Renaissance: Studies in 16th-century French Literature
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of sixteenth-century French literature in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Ancients and Moderns: Studies in 17th-century French Literature
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of seventeenth-century French literature in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Enlightenment and Revolution: Studies in 18th-century French Literature
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of eighteenth-century French literature in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Tradition and Modernity: Studies in 19th-century French Literature
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of nineteenth-century French literature in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: The Modern and Contemporary French Novel
desc: Major historical, social and artistic movements reflected in representative novels published in France from the 19th Century to the present.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: French Digital Culture
desc: Contemporary issues and debates on how media and digital technologies have impacted French culture and society. Examines how text, language, and writing are used in digital media.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Contemporary French Literature and Culture
desc: Aesthetic and ideological trends of twentieth- and twenty-first century French literature in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Popular Fiction
desc: Popular genres in modern French fiction, including science fiction, crime, romance, fantasy and historical fiction. Aesthetic characteristics, historical context and cultural relevance.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: African and Caribbean Francophone Literatures
desc: Representative and contemporary writings from African and Caribbean francophone cultures.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Women's Writing
desc: Representative women's writings from the Middle Ages to the present; contemporary women's writings in the Francophone world.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Selected Topics in French Literature and Culture
desc: Study of a literary or cultural topic that extends beyond one chronological period and/or place proper. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Studies in Theatre
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: Studies in Prose Fiction
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: Studies in French Autobiography
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: French Cinema
desc: Study of major past and contemporary French film productions.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Francophone Cinema
desc: Study of major past and contemporary film productions from around the Francophone world.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Studies in Non-fiction Prose
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: Quebec Literature and Culture
desc: Study of representative aspects of Quebec literature and culture through the study of literary texts, films, and artistic productions in their historical context.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Francophonie: History and Current Debates
desc: Historical origins, cultural and linguistic paradoxes of Francophonie.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Francophone Literatures and Cultures of North America
desc: Forms of French language cultural expression in North America in their historical context. Discussion of issues around minority linguistic and cultural rights.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Cultures of the Francophone World
desc: Forms of cultural expression of the Francophone world studied in their context. Regions may include the Americas, Africa, East Asia, Europe, Indian Ocean, Middle East, and/or the Pacific.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Postcolonial Studies
desc: Interdisciplinary approaches to Postcolonial Studies through francophone literature and theory.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Old French
desc: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts.
prer: One of FREN 223, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: French Phonetics
desc: Theory and practice of the sound system of the French language. Anatomy of speech production, sound discrimination, phonetic description and transcription.
prer: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Creative Writing in French
desc: Theory, techniques and practice of creative writing in French in a variety of genres.
prer: FREN 321 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Advanced Translation
desc: Extensive practice in French-English and English-French translation of a wide range of texts and discourses, such as literary, legal, medical, administrative, commercial materials. Analysis of linguistic and cultural problems posed by translation of specialized material.

name: History of the French Language
desc: Overview of the development of the French language from its Latin roots to its modern forms. Examination of the internal and external factors which brought about changes in its phonology, morphology, syntax and lexis.
prer: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Studies in Modern French Linguistics
desc: Current topics in French linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

name: Morphology and Syntax of the French Language
desc: Analytical principles pertaining to the study of words and word-stems (morphology), and phrases and sentences (syntax) in written and spoken French.
crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

name: Syntactic Description of the French Language
desc: The syntactic markings of French (word order, agreement, pronominalisation, etc) and their underlying semantic systems.
crer: FREN 353 and 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

name: Lexicology and Semantics of the French Language
desc: Study of the vocabulary of modern French, focusing on basic principles in lexical semantics, lexicology, phraseology, lexicography, terminology and new technologies, neology.
crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

name: Canadian French: A Descriptive Approach
desc: The phonetics, phonology, lexicon, and syntax of spoken and written Canadian French.
crer: FREN 351 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

name: French Language and Societies
desc: Study of language in its social context, covering aspects of sociolinguistics within and across the French-speaking communities of the world.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Contemporary Varieties of French
desc: Study of the different varieties (or dialects) of contemporary French and issues related to French-speaking communities around the world.
prer: FREN 353 and one of FREN 353, FREN 225.

name: French Theory
desc: Core ideas of French theorists. Influence of French theory on the social sciences and humanities, focusing on Marxism, feminism, structuralism, deconstruction, postmodernism and postcolonialism.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Studies in Literature and the Arts
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: Studies in Literature and Philosophy
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: Studies in Literature and History
prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

name: History of the Book
desc: A historical approach to the social transformations of the book trade in France.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Early Encounters: Travel Literature and Colonial Writing in French
desc: Narratives of travel and exploration in French before 1800 and their relationship to colonization, knowledge production and representations of the self and others.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225.

name: Research Seminar in French Literature and Culture
desc: Research on critical topics related to French literature and culture. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prer: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402.

name: Research Seminar in French Language and Linguistics
desc: Research on critical topics related to French language and linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

name: Directed Reading
desc: Focus on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required.

name: Beginning Japanese IA
desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 11 and/or JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 100 or JAPN 160.

name: Beginning Japanese IB
desc: Continuation of JAPN 100 (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 101 or JAPN 160.

name: Intensive Beginning Japanese I
desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions. Offered in Term 1. Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 160 or JAPN 150 or both JAPN 100, JAPN 101.

name: Beginning Japanese II A
desc: Continuation of JAPN 101 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 200 or JAPN 102 or JAPN 260.

name: Beginning Japanese II B
desc: Continuation of JAPN 200 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 201 or JAPN 103 or JAPN 260.

name: Basic Japanese Grammar
desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing and reading Intended for students with a background in spoken Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 204 or JAPN 104.

name: Intensive Beginning Japanese II
desc: Continuation of JAPN 160. Offered in Term 2. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 260 or JAPN 151 or both JAPN 102, JAPN 103 or both JAPN 200, JAPN 201.

name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Japanese
desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 261 or JAPN 161.

name: Intermediate Japanese I A
desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 320 or JAPN 210 or JAPN 360.
prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

name: Intermediate Japanese I B
desc: Continuation of JAPN 320. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 321 or JAPN 211 or JAPN 360.

name: Intermediate Japanese II A
desc: It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.
prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

name: Intermediate Japanese II B
desc: A continuation of JAPN 322. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 and JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.

name: Reading Course in Japanese for Honours Students
Intensive Intermediate Japanese I
desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 360 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321.
prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese II
desc: Continuation of JAPN 360. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 361 or JAPN 251 or both JAPN 212, JAPN 213 or both JAPN 322, JAPN 323.
prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I
desc: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 400 or JAPN 300.
prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing II
desc: Continuation of JAPN 301. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 401 or JAPN 301.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition I
desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on appropriate language use in formal situations. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 402 or JAPN 302.
prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition II
desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on the development of formal presentation skills. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 403 or JAPN 303.

name: Classical Japanese I
desc: The grammar, orthography, and literary style of pre-modern Japanese (bungo).  It is strongly recommended that students have 12 credits of JAPN, or equivalent, prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 422 or JAPN 311.

name: Classical Japanese II
desc: A continuation of JAPN 422.  Focus on reading pre-modern primary sources and producing English translations. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 423 or JAPN 312.

name: Japanese for Professional Life I
desc: Technical Japanese as it is used in business, commerce, industry, etc. Emphasis on specialized current vocabulary and on the development of communicative competence relevant for workplaces in these fields. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 424 or JAPN 314.
prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

name: Japanese for Professional Life II
desc: Continuation of JAPN 424. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 425 or JAPN 315.

name: Advanced Oral Communication I
desc: Oral communication skills appropriate for studying and working in a Japanese-speaking environment either formal or informal. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 450 or JAPN 410.
prer: One of JAPN 300, JAPN 400 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

name: Advanced Oral Communication II
desc: A continuation of JAPN 450. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 451 or JAPN 411.

name: Readings in Modern Japanese Essays
desc: Advanced reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to taking JAPN 452. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 452 or JAPN 406.

name: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
desc: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of literary texts in modern Japanese. Advanced conversation, translation into English and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for advanced research in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 453 or JAPN 408.

name: Newspaper Japanese I
desc: Developing fluency in reading contemporary Japanese newspapers; concentration on current and emerging vocabulary, evolving grammatical features, and style of presentation. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 456 or JAPN 416.
prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

name: Newspaper Japanese II
desc: A continuation of JAPN 456. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 457 or JAPN 417.

name: Topics in Japanese Language, Culture, and Society
desc: Advanced Japanese language course combined with analysis of various media in literary, journalistic, and popular genres drawn from history, sociology, cultural studies, etc. Practice in the use of standard reference tools prepares students for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to JAPN 459. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 459 or JAPN 419.
prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and permission from instructor.

name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese I
desc: Analysis of the grammatical structure of modern Japanese. Contrastive analysis of Japanese and English as well as error analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 460 or JAPN 420.
prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 303, JAPN 403.

name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese II
desc: A continuation of JAPN 460. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 461 or JAPN 421.

name: Researching Modern Japanese Religions
desc: Research tools and approaches to the interdisciplinary study of modern Japanese religions (nineteenth century to the present) including state-of-the-field works in English, and locating primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 462 or JAPN 452.
prer: 6 credits of 200- or 300-level courses in Asian religions; 3 credit writing-intensive course in Asian Studies; ability to read modern Japanese or 18 credits of Japanese language courses and permission of instructor.

name: Japanese Media and Translation
desc: Emphasizing the development of translingual and transcultural literacies in Japanese popular media with a primary focus on film.
prer: One of JAPN 450, JAPN 452, JAPN 453, JAPN 456 or placement with native or near-native Japanese proficiency.

name: Supervised Study in the Japanese Language
desc: Primarily for graduate students. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 470 or JAPN 440.

name: Tutorial in Japanese for Honours Students
desc: This course will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 472 or JAPN 442.

name: Indigenous Studies
desc: For students in the Indigenous Teacher Education Program (NITEP) only.

name: Indigenous Education Seminar and Classroom Observation I
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Reviewing the Principles of Teaching
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Language and the Curriculum
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching History and Government I
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Geography I
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Secondary English
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Mathematics I
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching General Sciences
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Practicum I
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.  Pass/Fail.

name: Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference
Indigenous Education Seminar and Classroom Observation II
desc: Pass/Fail

name: Communication Skills in Teaching
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Chemistry
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching History and Government II
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Geography II
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Global Education
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Mathematics II
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Physics
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Biology
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Practicum II
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: English and Reading: Secondary
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: School-based Orientation Practicum
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Communication Skills in Teaching
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Field Experience and Seminar
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: School-based Orientation Practicum: Elementary
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: School-based Orientation Practicum: Middle Years
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Teaching First Nations Languages in Elementary Schools
prer: One of LLED 489, LING 200, LING 400. LLED 486 and LING 433 are recommended as pre- or corequisites.

name: Indigenous Education Seminar and Classroom Observation III
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Teaching and Learning in Digital Environments: Critical Perspectives
Regional Field Studies in Education: Study, Travel, and Community Experience
desc: Not offered on a regular basis.
prer: 12 credits of coursework approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education) as being appropriate to the particular study.

name: Field Experience and Seminar
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Instructional Design
desc: Principles of instructional design and their application to the development, analysis, and evaluation of instructional plans for selected settings, instructional formats, and age groupings of learners. Credit will be granted for only one of EPSE 401 or EDUC 401. [3-0]

name: School-based Extended Practicum: Elementary
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum

name: School-based Extended Practicum: Middle Years
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.

name: Governance, Finance, and School Organization in its Social Context
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: School-based Extended Practicum: Secondary
prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.

name: Community-based Field Experience
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Clinical Supervision of Teaching
desc: Recent research on teaching effectiveness. Enrolment limited to persons with teaching or supervisory experience.

name: Aboriginal Education in Canada
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Critical Issues in Indigenous Education
desc: Post-practicum students will explore how a school program may need to be modified in order to integrate more fully First Nations history, content, and world views.

name: Supervised Research Investigation
desc: Available only to outstanding students approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

name: Inquiry Seminar I
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Inquiry Seminar II
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Inquiry Seminar III
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Special Studies in Education
desc: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

name: Critical Analysis of Teaching: Planning for Context Appropriate Instruction
Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.

name: Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers
desc: Pass/Fail.
prer: Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.

name: Introductory Modern Standard Arabic I
desc: Basic listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Modern Standard Arabic at the Beginning Elementary level.

name: Introductory Modern Standard Arabic II
desc: Continued development of basic listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Modern Standard Arabic. Introduction to various aspects of Arab and Islamic culture.

name: Greening the City
desc: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2]

name: Introduction to Urban Forest Design
desc: Basic concepts of landscape design as it relates to urban forestry.

name: Urban Forests and Well-Being
desc: Basic relationships between urban residents' mental and physical well-being and their urban forest environment. [2-0-2]

name: Urban Forest Inventory and Assessment
desc: Overview of urban forest resources: structure and composition, extent, and ecosystem services and benefits provided; introduces methods and tools for urban forest inventory, monitoring, and assessment, and how they are integrated into the planning and management of urban forests.

name: Arboriculture Principles and Practice
desc: Principles and practices of individual urban tree management with emphasis on underlying biological and ecological concepts, plant-environment interactions above and below ground and implications for establishment, evaluation, and conservation of individual trees in a variety of urban situations. [3-1-0]
prer: Pre-req or co-req:  UFOR 316 and Third-year standing.

name: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
desc: Identification and suitability of woody plants used in the urban environment, with a focus on biological characteristics for plant identification, criteria for species selection, and other considerations for urban woody plant cultivation.

name: Environmental Justice and Urban Green Equity
desc: Theory, concepts and applications of urban green equity and urban environmental justice with particular focus on implications for urban forest policy, planning, management, and design. [3-0-1]

name: Urban Forestry Field School
desc: Development of field skills, professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, and policy. Offered at Malcolm Knapp Research Forest over a 7-day period in April.
prer: UFOR 200. And third year standing in the B.U.F. program.

name: Integrated Urban Forestry Capstone Studio
desc: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of urban greenspace management and planning through within a collaborative holistic group project linked to a real-world urban forestry situation.
prer: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program.

name: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law
desc: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning. [3-1-0]

name: Ecological Restoration
desc: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
prer: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230. And third year standing

name: Ecology of Urban Green Infrastructure
desc: The nature and dynamics of urban ecosystems with emphasis on urban forests and greenspaces. The role of green infrastructure in urban sustainability with particular focus on the ecological impact of urban forest management, design, and policy decisions. Credit may be granted for only one of UFOR 420 or UFOR 520. [3-0-1]

name: Directed Studies in Urban Forestry
desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies on a specific topic/problems in Urban Forestry and related greenspace planning, management, or governance.

name: Biodiversity in Urban Areas
desc: Urban centres can be designed and managed to contribute to biodiversity conservation commitments. Topics include designing human-dominated landscapes to promote biodiversity, the tools required, assessing outcomes, and the benefits and negatives of nature in the city.
prer: One of FRST 200, BIOL 230 or permission of the instructor.

name: Introduction to Data Science
desc: Use of data science tools to summarize, visualize, and analyze data. Sensible workflows and clear interpretations are emphasized. [3-0-1]

name: Reproducible and trustworthy workflows for data science
desc: Data science methods to automate the running and testing of code and analytic reports, manage data analysis software dependencies, package and deploy software for data analysis, and collaborate with others using version control. [3-0-1]

name: Visualization for Data Science
desc: Analysis, design, and implementation of static and interactive visual representations; visualization literacy; data communication; exploratory Data Analysis; application of theoretical principles to visualization development. [3-1.5-0]
prer: STAT 201 and one of CPSC 203, CPSC 210, CPEN 221.

name: Organization of Adult Basic Education Programs
desc: Rationale, structures, and functions of basic education completion. [3-0-0]

name: Adult Correctional Education
desc: Planning prison education; methods and techniques as they are affected by historical, philosophical, structural, and organizational contexts of penal institutions. [3-0-0]

name: Teaching Adults
desc: Planning, conducting and evaluating instruction for adults.  Consideration is given to different beliefs and ways of thinking about teaching. [3-0-0]

name: Institutions of Adult Education
desc: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education.  Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined. [3-0-0]

name: Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
desc: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes. [3-0-0]

name: The Community Practice of Adult Education
desc: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups. [2-3-0]

name: Diploma Seminar and Internship in Adult Education
An Overview of Adult Education
desc: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

name: Nepali Language in a Community Context
desc: Beginner to conversational level Nepali combined with experiential learning and cultural activities at local Nepali community sites. Interactive practice with everyday phrases, grammar structure, and vocabulary with Nepali community members.

name: The Middle East: Critical Questions and Debates
desc: Critical questions and debates in Middle East Studies that shape scholarly and public perception of the region.

name: City-Making: A Global Perspective
desc: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.
prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

name: City Visuals
desc: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city.
prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

name: Indigeneity and the City
desc: Place-based exploration of the multiple, complex and contested ways urban Indigeneity is constituted in Canada today, with opportunities for field trips and hands-on learning.
prer: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

name: The Just City in a Divided World
desc: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes.
prer: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

name: Smart Cities: Concepts, Methods and Design
desc: Rapid transformation of cities by information technology and socio-economic innovation; growth in citizen-generated data and the internet of things; emerging theory, methods, and frameworks for understanding "Smart Cities".
prer: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

name: Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
desc: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.

name: Immunogenetics
desc: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar. [3-0-1]
prer: MICB 302 and one of BIOL 334, BIOL 335. A standing of "B" or better is recommended.

name: Developmental Origin of Human Disorders
desc: Genetic and epigenetic determinants of development from conception to birth. Topics include development of the neural tube, face, heart, endoderm, blastocyst, embryonic stem cells, gastrulation, genomic imprinting, placental complications, chromosomal abnormalities and prenatal diagnosis. Discussions based on published research articles. [3-0-1]
prer: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234 and one of BIOL 331, BIOL 335. A standing of 'B' or higher recommended.

name: Human Genomics and Medical Genetics
desc: Sequence and structure of the human genome. Human genetic evolution. Identification of genes affecting normal and pathological variation.  Molecular mechanisms of genetic diseases and disorders. Medical applications of human genetics. [3-0-0]
prer: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. A standing of 'B' or higher is recommended, however, higher grades take priority in the registration process.

name: Genetics and Cell Biology of Cancer
desc: Molecular mechanisms of oncogenes and tumor suppressors in cancer biology, methods of and insights from studying cancer genomes, and current topics in cancer research. [3-0-0]
prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 302, BIOC 303.

name: Directed Studies
desc: A supervised individual program of study of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of faculty and the student. Permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head is required.

name: Education in the Adolescent Years
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Adolescents with Special Learning Needs
desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

name: Teaching Highly Able Learners
desc: Identification and appraisal of developmental and educational needs of highly able learners. [3-0]

name: Education during the Adolescent Years
desc: Developmental characteristics of persons from pre-school age through adulthood. Physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional growth of both normal and exceptional children in grades 8-12. The teacher's role in assisting such students to deal with major developmental issues and problems.  Pass/Fail.

name: Applying Developmental Theories in the Classroom
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Development, Learning and Culture in the Classroom
desc: This course is designed to provide teacher candidates with a broad overview of how children develop, learn and grow in diverse societies, in order to build safe, supportive, caring and respectful relationships and environments. Pass/Fail.

name: Assessment and Learning in the Classroom
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Introduction to the Study of Exceptional Children
desc: An examination of all groups of exceptional children in terms of definition, incidence, characteristics, diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite to most other courses in Special Education. Can be taken concurrently with several other introductory courses in Special Education. [3-0]

name: Educational Application of Developmental Theories
desc: Theories of human development; physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional developmental characteristics from infancy to adolescence; implications for educational practice with students of different age and developmental status during the elementary school years.  Pass/Fail.

name: Learning Disabilities
desc: Identification, assessment and needs of children with learning disabilities. [3-0-0]

name: Development and Exceptionality in the Regular Classroom
desc: The teacher's role in dealing with major developmental and special educational issues and problems within the regular classroom program, including working with supportive services, parents, and communities. Designated sections will focus on early childhood, middle childhood or adolescence. Pass/Fail.

name: Classroom Inclusion of Students who are Blind and Visually Impaired
desc: Inclusion issues of students with visual impairments in general education classrooms; information about visual impairment, classroom adaptations and accommodations, and application of Universal Design. Appropriate for education majors and classroom teachers. [3-0]

name: Field Experiences with Individual Atypical Children
desc: Supervised experience working with several atypical children in a community setting. Diagnosing needs, planning programs and integrating instruction and materials on an individual basis. [1-9]
prer: Permission of the department is required.

name: Programming in Special Education: Developing Perspective
desc: An examination of the range of educational methodologies and teaching procedures and a discussion of their implications for the establishment of programs useful in working with exceptional children. The course comprises a practical examination and a detailed comparison of the major special educational methodologies. [3-1]

name: Family-Centred Practice for Children with Special Needs
Special Topics
desc: A study of innovative practices, ideas, and theories in special education. The specific topics may change yearly to reflect changing priorities and interests in special education, and the specific interest and competencies of visiting and regular faculty. [3-0]
prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Permission of the instructor is required.

name: Education and Culture in the Deaf Community
desc: Designed for students intending to work with deaf persons.

name: Education of Students with Developmental Disabilities in Inclusive Settings
Principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis
desc: Credit will be given for only one of EPSE 404 or 405. [3-0-0]
prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Or permission of instructor.

name: Typical and Atypical Development in Infants and Children
Educational Programming for Highly Able Learners
desc: Planning elementary and secondary level programs for highly able learners. [3-0]

name: Assistive Technologies in Special Education
desc: The use of microcomputers, adaptive technology, and software across age levels and areas of exceptionality in special education and health care settings. [2-1]

name: Augmentative and Alternative Communication for Individuals with Severe Speech and/or Physical Impairments
Technology for the Visually Impaired
desc: Preparation of teachers to work with a variety of technological devices designed for students who are blind or visually impaired, e.g., computers, electronic reading devices, and closed circuit television. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children. [2-2]

name: Assessment of Learning Difficulties
desc: Theories of learning and instruction; principles and practices of diagnosis and assessment as these relate to students with relevant special needs.

name: Assessment of Classroom Learning
desc: Pass/Fail.

name: Provisions in the Education of the Visually Handicapped
desc: Provisions, procedures and methodology in the teaching of specific curriculum for the blind and visually impaired. Life skills and adjustment to blindness. This course is restricted to students in a program of Education of Visually Impaired Children. [3-0]

name: Classroom Inclusion of Students Who are d/Deaf or Hard of Hearing
desc: An introductory course focused on supporting the academic and social inclusion of students who are d/Deaf or hard of hearing in the general education setting.

name: Programming for Children with Specific Learning Disabilities
desc: Methods and programs for learning disabilities are reviewed. Practical experience in the development and execution of a remedial program is required. [3-0]

name: Assessment and Positive Behavioural Support in School and Community Settings
Survey of Behaviour Disorders in Children and Adolescents
Interventions for Children and Adolescents with Behaviour Disorders
Introduction to Orientation and Mobility for the Blind
desc: Understanding the process of teaching independent travel to blind students, including orientation and mobility skills in school. Restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children or those who hold the Diploma or the equivalent. [2-2]

name: Educational Diagnosis and Remedial Instruction
desc: Interpretation of informal and standardized test scores in educational diagnosis; estimates of actual and optimum levels of individual achievement; individual differences as factors affecting performance; methods of encouraging the optimum achievement of individuals; methods and practice materials for remedial teaching.

name: Human Development in Education
desc: Investigates selected concepts of developmental theory in terms of their influence upon teaching and learning. The course will explore development in a wide range of domains including: social, physical, emotional and cognitive development.

name: Introduction to Research in Education
desc: The nature of scientific study and essentials of survey, experimental and other empirical research designs. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work.
prer: EPSE 482. May also be taken as a corequisite.

name: Introduction to Statistics for Research in Education
desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work involving quantitative methodology. [3-0]
prer: Proficiency in modern high school algebra. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 before registering.

name: Reading and Interpreting Research in Education
desc: Introductory research methods course for students who wish to be critical readers rather than producers of educational research.  Develops skills for locating, understanding, interpreting and critiquing educational empirical research.  May not be used as a prerequisite to EPSE 592 or EPSE 596. [3-0]
prer: Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 before registering.

name: Nonparametric and Related Statistics
desc: Distribution-free statistical techniques for analysis of ranked data, and analysis of discrete observations. [3-0]

name: 1st Year CAP Seminar
desc: CAP seminar focused on writing and reading, including both literature and introduction to academic scholarship. Topics vary each year. Credits count toward both the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement and the Literature Requirement. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

name: Writing for Research in the Social Sciences and the Humanities
desc: Analysis of and practice in academic writing and reading in the social sciences and the humanities. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

name: International Perspectives on Writing in the Social Sciences and Humanities
desc: Analysis of and practice in writing and reading for research in the social sciences and humanities; national and international aspects of scholarship and of writing cultures. Fulfills the first component of the Arts' Writing and Research Requirement.  Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Cultural Studies
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the cultures of Canada and Japan, and the interrelations between them. Specific topics vary from year to year but will include themes such as constructing the past; nationalism; self-perceptions; cross-cultural perceptions; multiculturalism in Canada and Japan; images in architecture, film and literature; mythologies.

name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Political, Economic and Geographical Perspectives
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to political, economic and geographical interactions between Japan and Canada, the links between these countries and other Pacific Rim nations, and the historical origins of these connections. Specific topics will vary from year to year, but will include themes such as economic integration in the Pacific region; the role of resource economies such as Canada's; security relations in the Pacific; the role of Japanese investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

name: Topics in Interdisciplinary Arts Studies
desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Arts studies.  For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

name: Global Citizenship, Part 1: Introduction
desc: Themes of global citizenship, sustainability, and civil society, and barriers and bridges to global thinking.

name: Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference
Knowledge Dissemination: Communicating Research to Public Audiences
desc: Research, theory, and practice in the communication of expert knowledge to non-specialist audiences; popular media and dissemination. Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation workshops. Final work term report required. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.
prer: 6 credits first-year English or Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report required.

name: Community-Based Research and Knowledge Creation
desc: Principles and practice of conducting research in community partnership. Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts
desc: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

name: Special Topics in Arts Studies
desc: Selected topics offered by a distinguished visitor to the campus. For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

name: Living Language: Science and Society
desc: Multidisciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prer: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

name: Co-operative Work Placement V
desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

name: No Knowledge is Neutral
desc: Capstone seminar in the research, theory and practice of knowledge production, mobilization, and contextualization, including issues of authority, expertise, and positionality.
prer: Restricted to students in the Sciences Po-UBC Dual Degree.

name: Introduction to Engineering I
desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: roles and responsibilities of the engineer, the engineering disciplines, sustainability, an introduction to the engineering design process, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, prototyping, engineering graphics, technical communication, and engineering ethics.

name: Introduction to Engineering II
desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: the engineering design process, sustainability, prototype testing, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, team functioning, engineering graphics, and technical communication.

name: Introduction to Engineering Co-op
desc: An introduction to Engineering Co-op including: completion of preemployment workshops, career skills toolkits, networking opportunities, interview training, individual coaching sessions, and job search skills. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term I
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Introduction to Engineering
desc: Non-credit course designed to introduce students to Engineering. Information on the Faculty, the profession and the particular skills and type of work done by practising engineers in different disciplines. [1-0-0]

name: Engineering Case Studies
desc: Application of scientific principles and technical knowledge to practical problems. Introduction to the engineering design process and to engineering graphics.

name: Computer-Aided Engineering Graphics
desc: Orthographic projection, technical sketching, development of the ability to visualize in three dimensions. Standards and conventions of engineering drawing, graphical presentation of engineering data. Micro-computer based graphics aids. Engineering geometry and the solution of space problems.

name: Introduction to Computation in Engineering Design
desc: Analysis and simulation, laboratory data acquisition and processing, measurement interfaces, engineering tools, computer systems organization, programming languages. Credit will only be given for one of: APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.

name: Engineering Analysis I
desc: Functions, limits, differentiation, applications of derivatives, integration, applications of definite integrals.

name: Engineering Analysis II
desc: Integrals and transcendental functions, techniques of integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates, infinite sequences and series, vectors and the geometry of space, and partial derivatives.

name: Engineering Communication
desc: Purpose, audience, content, format, and tone are studied, as are team-based report writings and presentations. Community Service Learning projects are integrated into existing assignments. An LPI level 5 is required for registration in this course.

name: Electricity, Magnetism, and Waves
desc: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, electric potential, conductors, capacitance, electric currents, resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields and forces, sources of magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves, light propagation, geometrical optics.

name: Linear Algebra for Engineers
desc: Systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, engineering application of linear algebra, matrix operations, special matrices, determinants, vector space, orthogonality, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, linear transformation. [3-0-0]

name: Statics
desc: Force vectors, Cartesian coordinate system, free body diagram, dot and cross products, forces equilibrium of particles, force and moment equilibrium of rigid bodies, analysis of trusses, frames and machines, friction, wedges, pulleys, and belts. Applications of linear algebra in statics.

name: Matter and Energy I
desc: Thermometry, states of matter and phase change, ideal and real gases, 1st law of thermodynamics, 2nd law of thermodynamics, liquids, solutions.

name: Matter and Energy II
desc: Atomic structures and bonding, solid crystals, chemical equilibrium, reactions in gas phase and in aqueous solutions, acid-base and redox reactions, kinetics of chemical reactions, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.

name: Technical Communication
desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 201, CHBE 201, CIVL 203, CPEN 281, ELEC 281, IGEN 201, MANU 201, MECH 226, MTRL 201, or APSC 201.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics I
desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics II
desc: Continuation of written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Technology and Society I
desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic, and environmental aspects of society. The specific subject matter varies from year to year. Examples of subjects considered include, resources, energy, nuclear power, technology, the effects of technology on the family, education, agriculture, international policy and others. [3-0-0]

name: Technology and Society II
desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic and environmental aspects of society. The subject matter varies from year to year and differs from APSC 261. It may be taken as a continuation of APSC 261 or taken independently. Examples of subjects considered include pollution, work place health hazards, social impact of computers, problem solving, green revolution, technology and the third world, engineering ethics and others.

name: Technology and Development
desc: Environmental, economic, political, and social aspects of appropriate technologies in the developing world. Appropriate technology and infrastructure, trade and finance, transportation, energy, water access, communication, health, and gender.

name: Engineering Materials
desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

name: Engineering Materials Laboratory
desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
desc: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
