desc: Theoretical analysis of economies that use money; the emergence of money; the roles of money in the economy; models of money demand; the optimal quantity of money seignorage and inflation; monetary policy and macroeconomic stability; monetary policy in an open economy.
prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 315 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309.

name: Economics of Taxation
desc: The economic analysis of taxation. Equity and efficiency; optimal taxation theory; partial and general equilibrium analysis of incidence; analysis of taxes such as the personal and corporate income taxes, sales and excise taxes, payroll taxes and property tax.

name: Economics of Public Expenditures
desc: The role of government in the economy; efficiency and economic justice. Theory of public goods; applications to topics such as education, medical care and social services. Pricing and investment rules for public enterprises.

name: International Trade
desc: International trade theory and policy in general equilibrium; relative costs, factor proportions, imperfect competition and the pattern of trade; efficiency and distribution. Credit granted for only one of ECON355 and ECON455.

name: International Macroeconomics and Finance
desc: Balance of payments; market for foreign exchange; mechanism for adjusting the balance of payments; internal vs. external stability; current problems and issues. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 456, COEC 377, or COMM 377.

name: Seminar in International Economic Relations
desc: Selected topics focusing upon various issues arising in international economic relations. Open only to fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: Economics of Labour Markets
desc: The theory of labour supply and demand for individuals, households, and firms. Policy implications for Canadian taxation and benefit programs. Employee selection, hiring and promotion. Credit may not be obtained for both ECON 360 and 460.
prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 315 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309.

name: Economics of Trade Unions
desc: The microeconomic and macroeconomic effects of unions on wages, prices and employment. Industrial disputes and their resolution. Credit may not be obtained for both ECON 361 and 461.
prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 315 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309.

name: Market Structure
desc: Market structure and social welfare, theory of price discrimination, equilibrium in oligopolistic markets, entry and exit decisions, product differentiation and spatial models, theories of hierarchical organization, agency problem in the modern corporation, vertical integration and control, market structure and technical progress.

name: The Economics of Government Regulation of Business
desc: Normative and positive theories of government regulation of business. Topics include natural monopoly, socially optimal monopoly pricing, regulation of multi-firm industries, competition policy. Selected empirical studies.

name: Economics of Intellectual Property: Patents, Drugs, and Rock 'n Roll
desc: Economic research into patents and copyrights, and policies regulating them. Analysis of the impact of stronger intellectual property rights on innovative activity, with applications to culture, the music industry, pharmaceuticals, consumer electronics, and the Internet.

name: Economics of Nonrenewable Resources
desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of nonrenewable natural resources. Emphasis is placed on the economics of alternative energy sources. Other topics include mineral economics, criteria for the optimal use of resources, and measurement of resources.

name: Economics of Renewable Resources
desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of renewable resources. Special attention is given to criteria for the optimal use of depleting resources such as forests and water. Other topics include public policy with regard to environmental quality, conservation, and outdoor recreation.

name: Transportation
desc: Economic characteristics of the provision of transportation services, both passenger and freight; the market structure of the industry and the economic impact of the varying degrees of public regulation and promotion within the industry; the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy.
prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 315.

name: The Economic Consequences of Religion
desc: Analysis of the economic aspects of religious behaviour, the structure of religious organizations, the effects of competition in the religious marketplace, the economic benefits of religion, and some of the ill-effects of religion (such as religious strife and terrorism).

name: Political Economy
desc: State and politics in economics. How states emerge, how dictators stay in power. Why groups engage in costly conflict, how countries turn into democracies and what its benefits are.
prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 315 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309 and one of ECON 325, ECON 327 and one of ECON 326, ECON 328.

name: Comparative Economic Systems
desc: Economic analysis of non-market/non-price systems of resource allocation. Economic analysis of central planning, co-ordination problems in hierarchical organizations, and the role of quantity restrictions, quotas, standards, etc. in regulating economic behaviour. The Soviet system of economic planning is used throughout as an example of the issues discussed. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 387 or ECON 487.

name: Seminar in Applied Economics
desc: Selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of Economics. Each section will focus on a different field. Restricted to Economics Majors, and Combined Majors in Economics their final academic session.
prer: All of ECON 325, ECON 326 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305. For additional possible prerequisites see individual course descriptions on the School's  website.

name: Advanced Empirical Methods for International Economics
desc: Econometric methodologies necessary to conduct applied research, including time series analysis and panel data methods; review of empirical work in international economics.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

name: Seminar in Applied International Economics
desc: Focus on a particular aspect of applied international economics. Independent empirical research project required.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: Reports and group discussions of selected topics for fourth-year Honours students.

name: Honours Essay
desc: Essay on some theoretical, applied, or institutional problem. Open only to fourth-year Honours students.

name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu I
desc: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.

name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu II
desc: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102.

name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu
desc: Spoken and written Hindi and Urdu. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200.

name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I
desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201.

name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II
desc: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202.

name: Introduction to the Devanagari Script
desc: The writing system of Hindi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as HINU 200.

name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu
desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301/302 or HINU 300.

name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300.

name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
desc: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300.

name: Introduction to the Perso-Arabic (Urdu) Script
desc: The writing system of Urdu for those with some background in the spoken language.

name: Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature
desc: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials.

name: Hindi Film
desc: Regional, religious, and historical dialects of Hindi and Urdu as repesented in films.

name: Basic Cantonese I
desc: Elementary level (part I) course in Cantonese for non-heritage learners with no prior exposure to or background in Cantonese. Focus on training for basic listening and conversational skills in Cantonese. Heritage speakers of Mandarin are NOT eligible.
prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 233, CHIN 108, CHIN 234. Or placement approval.

name: Basic Cantonese II
desc: Elementary level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 301. Focus on training for basic listening, conversational, and reading skills.

name: Basic Cantonese for Mandarin Speakers
desc: Basic oral and presentation skills in Cantonese. This is an accelerated course that covers content and topics similar to CNTO 301 and CNTO 303, but is structured specifically for heritage speakers of Mandarin.
prer: One of CHIN 243, CHIN 244. Or placement approval.

name: Intermediate Cantonese I
desc: Intermediate lower level (part I) Cantonese for non-heritage learners.
prer: One of CNTO 303, CNTO 311. Or placement approval.

name: Intermediate Cantonese II
desc: Intermediate lower level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 401.

name: Advanced Cantonese through Popular Culture
desc: Popular culture in Hong Kong from media such as television, cinema, popular music, literature, social media, etc., through advanced authentic Cantonese listening and reading materials.  Open to non-heritage and heritage speakers of Mandarin and/or Cantonese.
prer: CNTO 401. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework is strongly recommended.

name: Beginner's Polish
desc: Introduction to contemporary Polish. Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

name: Intermediate Polish
desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition.

name: Introduction to Twentieth-Century Polish Literature
desc: Readings and discussion of selected works of representative writers.

name: Polish Literature and Film in Translation
desc: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

name: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English)
desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film.

name: Human Anatomy
desc: Structure of the neural, muscular, and skeletal systems of the human body. Special emphasis on movement analysis and the physiological effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477. [3-2]

name: Health and Exercise Management
desc: Role of physical activity in the maintenance of a healthy life. Application of basic physical fitness and exercise methods, exercise techniques and fitness appraisal. [2-2]

name: Systems Physiology I
desc: Structure and function of the skeletal system, muscular system, integumentary system, neuro-hormonal control, and endocrinology. Emphasis will be to develop an understanding of the integrative nature of the systems discussed. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477. [3-2]

name: Systems Physiology II
desc: Structure and function of the cardiovascular system, respiratory system, urinary system, digestive system, and immune system.  Emphasis will be to develop an understanding of the integrative nature of the systems discussed. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [3-2]

name: Lifespan Motor Development
desc: A lifespan approach to motor development that examines underlying factors affecting physical growth, physical activity behaviour, and human motor performance, while highlighting contemporary issues and trends in society.

name: Performance Analysis of Selected Individual Sports and Activities
desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 148 and 248 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

name: Sport and Exercise Psychology
desc: Psychological theories and research related to sport and exercise behaviour. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477

name: Leisure and Sport in Society
desc: Introduction to the political, economic and social basis of leisure and sport; concepts, theories and problems.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Research Methods in Kinesiology
desc: Critical evaluation of research studies and methods with emphasis on the physical activity context. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477. [3-0]

name: Introduction to Statistics in Kinesiology
desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics, and distribution-free statistical techniques. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [3-0-0]

name: Human Motor Behaviour I
desc: Processes underlying human movement and learning motor skills and factors influencing acquisition, performance, and movement control.

name: Biomechanics I
desc: Application of elementary principles of physics and math to a quantitative analysis of movement.  Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement.

name: Nutrition, Physical Activity, and Health
desc: Study of nutrition and its application to physical activity and health.  Macro- and micronutrient classification and recommended daily intakes, their digestion, functions in the body and their role in supporting physical activity and health will be discussed.
prer: All of KIN  131, KIN  132 and second-year standing; similar courses to KIN 131 and KIN 132 can be considered.

name: Exercise Physiology I
desc: Acute and chronic effects of exercise on body systems; basic concepts of cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity.

name: Performance Analysis of Selected Team Sports and Activities
desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 148 and 248 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

name: Health Policy and Society
desc: Health policy and the social context in relation to active health.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Human Athletic Performance
desc: An exploration of human movement and related issues pertaining to sports and athletic performance for non-Kinesiology students. Not for credit in the B.Kin. Program. [3-0]

name: Human Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy
desc: The musculoskeletal structures and neural innervations involved in the control of human movement. Attention will be given to the practical application of human anatomy as it pertains to clinical, athletic, or everyday situations.
prer: Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK and BKIN programs.

name: Sensorimotor Control of Human Movement
desc: Processes and mechanisms involved in the sensory, perceptual, and cognitive contributions to human movements. [3-0]

name: Neuromuscular Integration of Human Movement
desc: The neurophysiological and functional neuroanatomical processes involved in the sensory and motor control of movement, posture and balance in the human. Peripheral and central sensorimotor structures, and neurological diseases that affect human movement and balance control will be discussed. [3-0]

name: Biomechanical Properties of Tissues
desc: Mechanics of muscular contraction and how the mechanical properties of the muscle, ligaments, tendons, and bone work synergistically. [3-0]

name: Exercise Testing and Prescription
desc: Conditioning methods, exercise techniques and appraisal methods for fitness in physical activity and sport. [2-2]

name: Chronic Health Issues and Physical Activity
desc: Issues related to physical activity and public health. Focus on community interventions.  Creation of activity plans that promote physical, mental, and/or social well-being in persons dealing with chronic health issues. [3-0]

name: Introduction to Athletic Training
desc: Recognition, prevention, and first aid treatment of common sports injuries. Laboratory sessions emphasize principles and techniques of basic protective taping and strapping. [2-2]

name: Advanced Applications of Exercise Physiology
desc: Explore how the cardiovascular and respiratory systems are regulated and integrated during exercise. [2-0-2]

name: Instructional Strategies for Including Persons with Disabilities in Physical Activity
desc: Examining curricular and instructional adaptations for accommodating participants with disabilities in inclusive physical activity environments. [2-0-2]

name: Creating Effective, Developmentally Appropriate, Physical Activity Learning Environments
desc: The pedagogical skills and knowledge required to design, and implement, developmentally appropriate physical activities learning environments in a variety of settings. [2-2]

name: Leisure Services for Persons with a Disability
desc: Policy issues relating to leisure opportunities for persons with disabilities. [3-0]

name: Foundations of Coaching
desc: Methods of athletic conditioning, planning the program, psychology of training and coaching, athletic evaluation. [3-0]

name: Movement Experiences for Young Children
desc: The design and implementation of movement experiences for children in early childhood years. [3-0]

name: Sport, Peace, and Conflict
desc: Relationships that sport and leisure have with peace, conflict, and social inequality in Canada and internationally. [3-0]

name: Leisure, Sport and Popular Culture
desc: Selected aspects of leisure and sport examined in relation to modern social structures and cultures. [3-0-0]

name: The Modern Olympics: Power, Politics, and Performance
desc: Examination of the Modern Olympic Games as an event with important political, economic, environmental, and cultural ramifications. [3-0]

name: Indigenous Sport and Physical Culture in Settler Canada
desc: Historical and contemporary issues in Canada that shape Indigenous sport and physical activity, health programs, and policies. [3-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Neuroanatomy of Human Movement
desc: Neuroanatomy of human motion in healthy and clinical populations. [3-0]

name: Laboratory Investigations in Neuromechanical Kinesiology
desc: Integration and application of laboratory principles and techniques for experimental investigations of topics in neuromechanical kinesiology, including biomechanics, motor behaviour, and neurophysiology. [1-2]
prer: Restricted to students registered in the BKIN program, third-year standing.

name: Prevention of Sports Injuries
desc: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries to the musculoskeletal system and sense organs. [3-0]

name: Medical Aspects of Sport and Exercise
desc: Training and safety strategies for the management and prevention of disorders of internal organs and central nervous system. Topics include environmental and nutritional factors in conditioning and pre-event preparation. [3-0]

name: Sport Nutrition
desc: Sport nutrition guidelines, physiological mechanisms of fuel use in the body, nutritional strategies to support weight change, hydration, and ergogenic aids the needs of special athlete populations. [3-0]
prer: All of KIN  131, KIN  132, KIN  232 and third-year standing.  Similar courses to KIN 131, KIN 132, and KIN 232 can be considered.

name: Pulmonary Physiology of Exercise
desc: Operation of the lungs, chest wall, and ventilatory control mechanisms during dynamic whole-body exercise. [3-0]

name: Skeletal Muscle Physiology: From Generation to Regeneration
desc: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of muscle adaptability to physical activity: muscle development, signaling cascades of hypertrophy and atrophy, and satellite cell contribution to muscle regeneration/repair; etiology of intramuscular fatigue. [3-0-1]

name: Planning Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
desc: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies. [3-0]

name: Exploring Alternative Methods for Teaching Games and Sports
desc: Examination of innovative, developmentally appropriate, conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction. [2-2]

name: Psychobiology of Physical Activity
desc: Exploration of the role that physical activity and exercise play in modifying the neurobiological, autonomic, endocrine, and inflammatory responses to stress. [3-0]

name: Aging, Health, and Society
desc: Examination of current issues in the sociology of aging and health.

name: Health Promotion and Physical Activity
desc: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. [3-0]

name: Interculturalism, Health and Physical Activity
desc: Examination of multiculturalism and interculturalism in the delivery of community-based physical activities for diverse populations; connections between physical activity and health in different cultural contexts.  Community service learning and participation in culturally unfamiliar physical activities are core elements.

name: Meaning and Values in Sport
desc: An analysis of the experience of sports activities. [3-0]

name: Sport Marketing and Communication
desc: A seminar on the application of social science theories and methods to sport marketing and communication. [3-0]

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Field Experience
desc: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

name: Experiential Pedagogical Opportunities in Physical Activity and Sport
desc: Supervised professional practice in community and school-based settings.
prer: KIN  342. Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BKIN program.

name: Advanced Seminar in Neuromechanics
desc: Topics consider how neurological, cognitive, sensory, mechanical and muscular systems interact to control human motion and its response to the physical environment. [3-0]
prer: Two of KIN  310, KIN  311, KIN  313, KIN  316, KIN  411, KIN  419. Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Systems Biology, Exercise and Health
desc: Topics examine the roles of physical activity and fitness on physiological systems and underlying cellular and metabolic mechanisms. [3-0]
prer: Two of KIN  320, KIN  321, KIN  322, KIN  335, KIN  420, KIN  424, KIN  432, KIN  435, KIN  438. Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Indigenous Sport, Physical Activity and Health
desc: Topics explore the relationship between Indigenous physical cultures, physical activity, health and wellbeing. [3-0]
prer: Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Leadership Education for Physical Activity
desc: Topics consider health-related fitness, physical competence, cognitive understanding, and positive attitudes about physical activity. [3-0]
prer: Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology of Movement
desc: Topics examines the application of psychology to understanding and supporting healthy sport, physical activity, and health behaviors. [3-0]
prer: Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Sociocultural Studies
desc: Topics explore the social, cultural and global context of sport, exercise, physical activity, health, and the body. [3-0]
prer: Two of KIN  360, KIN  363, KIN  364, KIN  368, KIN  460, KIN  464, KIN  465, KIN  466, KIN  467. Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in Interdisciplinary Research in Kinesiology
desc: Topics will be approached from multiple perspectives in a course designed to explore the interdisciplinarity of the field of kinesiology. [3-0]
prer: Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.

name: Directed Studies in Kinesiology
desc: Opportunity for students to conduct an independent study in a subject area of interest to them, under the direction of a KIN faculty member.
prer: Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.

name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Kinesiology
desc: Opportunity for independent study that includes original data collection, under the direction of a KIN faculty member.
prer: Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.

name: Projects in Kinesiology
desc: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of kinesiology.
prer: Fourth-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.)

name: Introduction to Writing in Academic and Professional Registers
desc: Examination of sociolinguistic knowledge and skills that are central to the production of academic and professional texts.

name: Critical Reading and Writing in Academic and Professional Registers
Language Field Experience
desc: Guided individual and group projects related to concurrent studies. Field-based assignments related to language study.

name: Introduction to Analyzing Meanings of Images in Texts
desc: Systematic analysis of visual and verbal modalities in academic and professional registers through a "grammar" designed for this purpose.

name: Field Research in Social Processes of Inclusion and Exclusion: Discourse Perspectives
desc: Roles that social discourses of inclusion and exclusion play in intercultural integration.

name: Introduction to Language Communities and Variation in Language Practices
desc: Sociolinguistic analysis of language variation according to age, ethnicity, class, race, and gender, and how these variations function in both reflecting and constructing specific identities and memberships in society.

name: Introduction to Intercultural Communication and Socialization in Multicultural Contexts
desc: The processes by which individuals become competent members of society through the use of language.

name: Introduction to Translating in a Globalized Society
desc: Basic tenets of translation as a methodology for increasing students' sociocultural understanding, intercultural communication, pragmatics, and written English.

name: Language Maintenance and the Integration of Immigrants in Canada: An Introduction
desc: The concept of societal and individual bilingualism/multilingualism in a variety of settings, including Canada in particular.

name: Introduction to Public and Private Language Practices in a Globalized Society
desc: Exploration of the interrelationships between language structure, usage and social context and the interpretive differences that may result from their interaction.

name: Introduction to the Nature of World Englishes
desc: Exploration of the emergence of new English varieties, as well as a critical examination of main reasons linked to the rise of English worldwide and its proposed role as a neutral global language.

name: Introduction to Language Across the Curriculum
desc: Understanding text structure within, and language diversity among, subject areas. Analysis of oral and written language from various curriculum areas in which English is the medium of instruction; implications for learning and instruction. [1.5-3-0]

Language Across the Curriculum in Multilingual Classrooms: Secondary

desc: Pass/Fail.

desc: Pass/Fail.

desc: Credit may be obtained for only one of LLED 310, 391, 300.

Living Language: Science and Society
desc: Multi-disciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prer: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Using Canadian Children's Literature in the French Education Classroom
desc: Taught in French. Credit will be given for one of LLED 440, LLED 420.

desc: Taught in French.

desc: Drama-based activities relevant to a wide range of classroom contexts; involves reading about, practicing, and discussing various creative drama approaches and strategies developed by contemporary scholars and practitioners. Pass/Fail.

Trends and Issues in Teaching Children's Literature
Teaching Folklore in the Elementary Classroom
Transcultural Children's Literature
desc: Ways in which children's literature is informed by diverse, complex influences including culture(s) and language(s), and related problems, issues and controversies.

Teaching Adolescents Literature

name: Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Intermediate and Middle Years
prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

name: Disciplinary Literacies: Intermediate Through Secondary
desc: How teachers can support students to develop disciplinary literacies that will enable them to understand, analyze, interpret and critique ideas, genres, and language in discipline-specific texts in and beyond the intermediate and secondary school contexts.

prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

name: Supporting Language and Literacy for First Nations Learners (K-12)
Identifying and Supporting Learners with Literacy Difficulties
desc: Individualized assessment, diagnosis, and instructional planning for students with literacy difficulties. Intensive practicum is included in the 6-credit version of this course.
prer: An introductory- level reading or language arts course; successful completion of an extended practicum or one year of teaching experience.

name: Trends and Issues in Literacy Instruction
prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

name: Inquiry-Based Pedagogy in School Library Programs
desc: Principles and practices of teachers and teacher-librarians designing and teaching curriculum using inquiry-based pedagogy. LLED 469 is a core course for the Teacher Librarian Diploma.

name: Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language
The Education of Immigrant Students
desc: An examination of the cultural backgrounds of major ethnic groups. Instructional techniques for meeting the needs of immigrant students in the regular classroom with respect to culture and language.

name: Advanced Studies in Language and Literacy Education
desc: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and 429.

name: Digital Media in English Language Arts Education
Special Topics in English Education
prer: An introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.

name: Supervised Study in Modern Languages Education
Sociocultural Determinants of Health
desc: Methods for analyzing population health data and medical research reporting.

name: Basic Geomatics for Natural Resources
desc: Techniques of measuring and surveying as they are applied in assessing and managing natural resources. [2-2-0]

name: Forest Access and Transportation
desc: Introduction to the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability. [2-3-0]

name: Introduction to Forest Operations
desc: Basic geomatics, surveying and forest operations. [2-4-0]

name: Harvesting Systems and Forest Access
desc: The mechanics and productivity of a broad range of forest harvesting systems combined with topics on forest access. [3-0-1]

name: Analytical Methods in Forest Hydrology
desc: Analytical methods in forest hydrology and their applications in the planning of forest operations with a focus on the hydrologic and hydraulic design procedures for stream crossings. [3-2]

name: Economics, Contracts, and Finances in Forest Operations
desc: A capstone project-based course with applications of engineering economics, contract preparation, and financial planning in the context of Forest Operations. [2-2]

name: Operational Planning and Management
desc: A comprehensive overview of operational planning, financial and contractual management. Includes an experiential learning opportunity that focuses on critical thinking and teamwork. These skills combined with the theoretical course content are applied in a practical application with an external stakeholder. [2-2-0]

name: Operative Dentistry
desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-4.5-0]

name: Orthodontics
desc: Differential diagnosis, treatment planning, biomechanical principles and clinical treatment. [1-2-0]

name: Prosthodontics I
desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

name: Advanced Operative Dentistry
desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-3-0]

name: Practice Management
desc: Ethics, jurisprudence, practice management, intra- and interprofessional relationships. [2-0-0]

name: Prosthodontics II
desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

name: Supervised Study in Southeast Asian Languages
Introduction to Sociology
desc: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Interaction and Culture
desc: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

name: Inequality and Social Change
desc: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

name: Sociology of Family
desc: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

name: Ethnic Relations
desc: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

name: Global Population Dynamics
desc: Core processes that influence world population patterns and trends.

name: Canadian Social Structure
desc: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

name: Research Methods
desc: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
desc: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

name: Sociology of Personal Life
desc: A sociological examination of everyday life exploring the social in the personal.

name: Shopping, Society, and Sustainability
desc: Major theories of consumer society, evaluating impacts of shopping on human and non-human environments and popular solutions to these impacts.

name: Introduction to Social Interaction
desc: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

name: Crime and Society
desc: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies. The scope and nature of the crime problem, the growth of criminology as a science and profession, and relationships between components of state criminal justice systems.

name: Technology, Work and Society
desc: The social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work and the labour force.

name: Sociology of Creativity
desc: The application of sociological concepts to the examination of creative processes.

name: Data and Society
desc: Impacts of changing information and communication technologies on societies and social interactions.

name: Citizenship and Identity
desc: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

name: Global Pandemics
desc: Global pandemics in relation to social inequality, social interaction and social institutions.

name: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
desc: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

name: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
desc: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

name: Sociology of Migration
desc: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time.

name: Canadian Society
desc: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

name: Gender Relations
desc: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

name: Sociology of Masculinity
desc: How masculinity differs across social contexts and time periods.

name: Diversity in Family Forms
desc: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociology of the Life Course
desc: Individuals and families through the life course.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Social Statistics I
desc: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.

name: Consumers and Consumption
desc: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

name: Sociology of Aging
desc: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Organization of Work
desc: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

name: Community Studies
desc: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

name: Sociology and Natural Resources
desc: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

name: Social Inequality
desc: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies.

name: Built Environments
desc: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

name: Sociology of Sexualities
desc: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372.

name: Classical Traditions in Theory
desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370.

name: Contemporary Directions in Theory
desc: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370.

name: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
desc: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102; and SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Experimental and Mixed Methods
desc: Experimental methods in sociology integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches. Emphasis is on research design to inform policy and decision making.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
desc: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
desc: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociology of Health and Illness
desc: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care.  Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 384 and SOCI 484.

name: Drugs and Society
desc: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives.

name: Selected Topics in Canadian Society
desc: Selected areas of study relating to Canadian society such as BC Studies; French Canada's demographic problems; rural communities; social welfare and community programs in Canada. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

name: Feminist Theory
desc: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

name: Theories of Family and Kinship
desc: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Selected Topics in Sociological Theory
desc: An in-depth examination of selected sociological theories. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

name: Social Statistics II
desc: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

name: Sociology of the Environment
desc: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment.

name: Sociology of Food
desc: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

name: Urban Sociology
desc: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

name: Global Citizenship
desc: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.

name: Directed Studies
desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. And permission of the Department.

name: International Service Learning
desc: International field placement normally for eight to ten weeks; pre-departure seminars (eight to twelve seminars or equivalent) with student presentation seminars upon return from the field.

name: Economic Sociology
desc: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

name: Society, Economy and Family
desc: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Families and Work
desc: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Honours Tutorial
desc: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program.

name: Political Sociology
desc: The social and economic bases of political power. May include studies of the state and interstate relations, ideology and control, alienation and anomie, political movements and social revolutions, political violence and terrorism, and the political economy of world conflict.

name: Social Movements
desc: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies.

name: Sociology of the Arts
desc: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured.

name: Sociology of Education
desc: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy.

name: Queer Theory and Politics
desc: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.

name: Sociology of Crime and Justice
desc: Critical examination of specific forms of crime and delinquency in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Issues selected for study will be further scrutinized within the cultural framework of ethics, morality, and social justice.

name: Sociology of Mental Illness
desc: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population.

name: Social Determinants of Health
desc: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

name: Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
desc: Approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces. Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches.
prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. Or permission of the instructor(s)

name: Contemporary Chinese Society
desc: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations.

name: Advanced Studies in Sociology
desc: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

name: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
desc: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition.  Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to  Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students. [2-2]

name: A Behavioural Approach to Planting Design
desc: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales. [2-2]

name: Creativity and Design Applied
desc: An exploration of creativity and design and their application to a number of design disciplines. Web based. [3-0-0]

name: Landscape Technologies I: Site Engineering
desc: Terrain design, drainage, and stormwater management. Open only to B. End. students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 431 or LARC 531.

name: SITE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING II
desc: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Open only to B.En.D. students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 440, LARC 540 or DES 231.

name: Green Network Planning
desc: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas.

name: Foundations of Medical Practice I
desc: Integrating foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Organized on the basis of clinical presentations. Pass/fail.

name: Foundations of Medical Practice II
desc: Increasingly complex clinical presentations through integration of foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/fail.

name: Foundations of Scholarship and Flexible Enhanced Learning I
desc: Various medically-related learning experiences and scholarly activities. Emphasizes social accountability, introduces scholarly methods, and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/fail.

name: Foundations of Medical Practice III
desc: Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/Fail.

name: Transition into Clinical Education
desc: Prepares students to transition from classroom-based to clinical learning environments. Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Prepares students for clinical practice in Year 3 Clerkship. Pass/Fail.

name: Flexible Enhanced Learning II
desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

name: Clerkship
desc: Core experiences across the breadth of medicine through clinical and academic learning opportunities in ambulatory, hospital-based, and rural/remote settings. Interactions with patients under supervision. Pass/Fail.

name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: Senior Elective encompasses 6 months of Year 4 of the MD undergraduate program. Students will choose from available electives between 2 and 4 weeks in duration and participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with those electives. Pass/fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Senior Elective
desc: A senior clinical or academic elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and/or academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

name: Transition into Postgraduate Education and Practice
desc: Enables students to effectively transition from medical school to residency and medical practice. Complex clinical presentations that integrate foundational sciences and practice themes. Prepares students for practice as residents and physicians. Pass/Fail.

name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

name: Clinical Skills IV
desc: Final examination for third year encompassing all clinical subjects.

name: Clinical Electives
desc: Summer clinical experience for UBC medical graduates who did not attain a residency position.
prer: Students must have a UBC MD degree and have fully completed applications to residency positions for the first iteration of the postgraduate match in their Year 4 (submission of a Rank Order List to the Canadian Residency Matching Service, CaRMS).

name: Preparation for University Writing and the LPI
Content and Language Enrichment Tutorials
desc: Sustained language support for linked content courses in International Program. Students develop strategies for self-directed learning.

name: UBC Vantage College Projects
desc: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

name: Multi-disciplinary Research Project
desc: Research project that culminates in student-led conference and research presentation. [1-0-1]

name: Sustainability and Engineering Design
desc: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-2; 1-0-2]

name: Multi-disciplinary Engineering Design Project
desc: Design project that culminates in student-led project fair. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [2-0-3]

name: Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
desc: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system. [2-3-0]

name: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
desc: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements. [1-0-0]

name: Principles of Microeconomics with Applications to Land and Food Systems
desc: Microeconomic principles focused on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in Land One Option. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, LFS 101, ECON 101, or ECON 310

name: Land One: First-year Integrative Seminar
desc: Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both Indigenous and Western perspectives.  Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in the Land One option.

name: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
desc: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status.

name: Land, Food and Community I: Introduction to Food Systems and Sustainability
desc: Managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum.

name: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
desc: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems. [3-0-1]
prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: Aquaculture Field Studies
desc: An orientation to the aquaculture system in BC. Participating students are assessed a fee.

name: International Field Studies
desc: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

name: International Field Studies in Policy Analysis for Agriculture and Natural Resources
desc: Field studies carried out abroad under the direction of the instructor. Students will be guided to apply selected tools for analysis of agricultural and natural resource policy in developing countries with input from local policymakers. Participating students are assessed a fee.
prer: Third year standing and permission of instructor. 9 credits of upper level ECON, FRE or COMM courses are strongly recommended.

name: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

name: Land, Food, and Community II: Principles and Practice of Community Food Security
desc: Project-based application of the principles and processes of community food security. Emphasis on developing skills required to address economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.
prer: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

name: Audio Storytelling
desc: Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio and podcasting technology.

name: Living Language: Science and Society
desc: Multidisciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prer: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Land, Food, and Community III: Leadership in Campus Food System Sustainability
desc: Design, analysis, recommendation or implementation of solutions in response to a food sustainability issue faced by community partners. Emphasis is on professional communication, leadership development, project management and decision-making skills.

name: Topics in Land and Food Systems
desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues related to land and food systems.

name: Career Development Practicum
desc: Practical application of degree program learning appropriate to students' career goals. Enrolment subject to competition and availability of practicum placements.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

name: Integrated Technical Communication
desc: Written and oral communication in chemical and biological engineering: business correspondence, laboratory reports, technical description, and poster presentations. Restricted to students in second year of the Chemical and Biological Engineering programs.
prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Founding Principles in Chemical and Biological Engineering I
desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering profession and the physical sciences that form the founding principles of the discipline.

name: Founding Principles in Chemical and Biological Engineering II
desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering profession with emphasis on the biological sciences that form the founding principles of the discipline.

name: Computational Methods
desc: Mathematical formulation of chemical and biological engineering problems; standard techniques of numerical analysis and their application to chemical, environmental and biotechnological systems; program development; use of commercial numerical analysis software.

name: Material and Energy Balances
desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering; units; stoichiometry; phase equilibria; material balances; energy balances.

name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Process and Technology
desc: Processes used in chemical and biological industries, which emphasize underlying physical, chemical, and biological principles.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics I
desc: Energy and the first law; second law of thermodynamics; entropy; availability (energy) analysis; thermodynamic properties of fluids, application to power generation, refrigeration, and liquefaction, as well as biological, environmental, and electrochemical systems.

name: Transport Phenomena I
desc: Fluid Mechanics. Momentum-transfer in fluids in laminar and turbulent flow; microscopic and macroscopic material; momentum and energy balances; rheology; dimensional analysis; flow in conduits; pumps; fluid metering.

name: Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry Laboratory
desc: Experiments chosen to illustrate and use material presented in 200-level CHBE and CHEM courses.
crer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHEM 250, CHEM 251, CHEM 260.

name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory Practice
desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering laboratory practice with topics in physical, inorganic and organic chemistry.
crer: All of CHBE 220, CHBE 241, CHEM 250, CHEM 260.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
desc: Laboratory experiment in 2nd year Chemical and Biological Engineering

name: Introduction to Unit Operations
desc: Foundational concepts and design equations for basic unit operations such as: comminution, screening, filtration, centrifugal separations, evaporation and crystallization.

name: Unit Operations II
desc: Stage-wise mass transfer operations; extraction and absorption; single and stage-wise binary and multi-component distillation; principles and equipment design for continuous contact mass transfer operations including absorption, binary distillation and others such as extraction, drying, and humidification.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics II
desc: Volumetric and thermodynamic properties of fluids; equations of state; heat effects; ideal and non-ideal mixtures; fugacities and activity coefficients; vapor-liquid and liquid-liquid phase equilibrium; solubility of gases and solids in liquids; chemical reaction equilibrium; equilibrium partitioning of pollutants.

name: Mass Transfer Bridge Module
desc: Mass transfer; molecular diffusion; convective transfer; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; mass transfer coefficients; interphase mass transfer.

name: Transport Phenomena II
desc: Heat and mass transfer; conduction and molecular diffusion; convective transfer; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; heat exchanger design; mass transfer coefficients; interphase mass transfer.

name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

name: Process Dynamics and Control
desc: Introduction to modelling of chemical processes; transient response analysis; design of feedback control systems; stability analysis; frequency response analysis; process control applications; instrumentation; advanced control techniques; distributed control systems.

name: Process Engineering Laboratory
desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 200 and 300-level CHBE courses. Field trips may be required.
prer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHBE 264.

name: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in environmental engineering as used by  engineers.

name: Biological Engineering  Laboratory
desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in biotechnology as used by engineers. Field trips may be required.
prer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 264, CHBE 221.

name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 300-level Chemical Engineering program courses. Field trips may be required.
prer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHBE 264.

name: Fundamentals of Sustainable Engineering
desc: Introduction to sustainable practice for Chemical and Biological Engineers.  Pollution prevention, cleaner production, green chemistry and engineering, and sustainable design; environmental impact assessment including life-cycle assessment, total cost analysis and environmental systems analysis; applications in chemical and biological process industries.

name: Water Pollution Control
desc: Legal, environmental and physicochemical aspects of industrial water pollution and its abatement will be surveyed; techniques for design of wastewater treatment processes currently used in industry; case studies from chemical and process industries will be considered in detail.
prer: One of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280, MTRL 263.

name: Computer Flowsheeting and Unit Operation Design
desc: Theory and practice of computer flowsheeting in chemical plant design; hands-on use of modern process simulators, prediction of thermodynamic properties of fluids; behaviour of single and multiphase systems. Design of unit operations.

name: Bioprocess Engineering I
desc: Biological process engineering in the fields of biotechnology and biomedical engineering; enzymatic and cellular kinetics; cell culture, process development and product recovery; bioreactor design and operation. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 381, CHBE 560.
prer: One of CHBE 221, BMEG 245 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105. Third or fourth year standing.

name: Mechanical Pulping and Papermaking
desc: Process and unit operations in mechanical pulping and papermaking, emphasizing principles and practice of refining, screening, cleaning, papermaking and properties of paper products, key economic and environmental issues.

name: Biomass Fractionation Technology
desc: Process and unit operations in the conversion of wood chips to pulp and green bio-products. Biorefinery concepts and emerging technologies for the production of biomaterials, biochemicals and bioenergy. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 402, GBPR 501.

name: Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
desc: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Restricted to students in the Joint Degree in Biotechnology. [1-4-0]

name: Engineering Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
desc: Classical thermodynamic relations from a molecular perspective. Pressure-volume-temperature relations; chemical equilibria by Gibbs' method; vapor-liquid equilibria; thermodynamic calculations based on macroscopic and statistical methods; nonequilibrium processes; molecular simulations. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 451, CHBE 551.
prer: One of CHBE 346, MTRL 350. Or equivalent.

name: Environmental Process Design Project
desc: 8-month project-based course, concepts from chemical, biological, and environmental science engineering with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations to solve problems related to the protection of the environment. [2-0-8]
prer: All of BIOL 112, CHBE 241, CHBE 254, CHBE 344, CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 373.

name: Biological Process and Product Design
desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical and biological engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major biological processes.
prer: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 345, CHBE 356, CHBE 376, CHBE 381.

name: Chemical Process and Product Design
desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major chemical processes.
prer: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 345, CHBE 356, CHBE 376.

name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

name: Heterogenous Catalysis and Advanced Reactor Design
desc: Definition of heterogeneous catalysis; properties of catalysts; kinetics of catalytic reactions; ideal heterogeneous reactors; non-isothermal reactor design; mass and heat transfer effects in heterogeneous reactors; examples of industrial reactors.

name: Process Synthesis
desc: Strategy for the conceptual design of industrial chemical and biological processes; rules of thumb for chemical engineers, simulation to assist process synthesis, reactor-separator network synthesis, introduction to product design and molecular structure design, efficiency and sustainability in the chemical industry.
prer: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 346, CHBE 376, CHBE 344.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Economics
desc: Estimation of capital and operating costs; interest calculations; taxes; economic comparison of alternatives; economic optimization.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
desc: Experiments in unit operations relating to process, environmental and biological engineering. Experiments are designed to provide experience in instrumentation and control. Field trips may be required.
prer: All of CHBE 345, CHBE 355, CHBE 356, CHBE 362 and one of CHBE 365, CHBE 366.

name: Rehabilitation and Design of Aquatic Habitat
desc: Modelling the effects of the environment and nutrient availability on growth and waste production; designing closed and open environments for aquatic organisms; developing prescriptions for habitat rehabilitation.
prer: CHBE 221 or equivalent and third-year standing required.

name: Transport in Biological Systems
desc: Mass transport and fluid flow, including physiological tissues and tissue constructs. Mass transport deficiencies that lead to the development of pathological tissue and drug delivery to these tissues. Biological engineering for the design of tissue constructs and artificial organs. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 470, CHBE 570, BMEG 371.

name: Chemical Process Engineering
desc: Selection and design of major equipment used in chemical process plants, including heat exchangers, separators, reactors.
prer: All of CHBE 345, CHBE 352, CHBE 355, CHBE 376.

name: Process Control Engineering
desc: Frequency response analysis; advanced control techniques; multivariable control systems; mathematical tools for computer control systems; design of computer control systems; engineering design of industrial control applications; plant wide control concepts; distributed control systems concepts.

name: Modelling and Optimization in Chemical Engineering
desc: Mathematical modelling of chemical plants and processes; computer simulation; introduction to numerical optimization techniques.

name: Fuel Cell and Electrochemical Engineering
desc: Stoichiometry, thermodynamics and kinetics of electrode reactions; conductivity and mass transport in electrolytes; material, energy and voltage balances; design of  electrosynthesis, electrorecovery of metals, and energy generation of batteries and fuel cells. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 477, CHBE 577.

name: Polymer Science and Processing
desc: Introduction to polymer chemistry, polymer properties, polymer processing and technological applications
prer: One of CHEM 260, CHBE 251 or equivalent

name: Chemical Engineering Aspects of Occupational Health and Safety
desc: Relationship between current engineering practice and worker health and safety. Engineering analysis of industrial health and safety problems.

name: Hazardous Waste Processing Technology
desc: Characterization, treatment and final disposal of hazardous waste with emphasis upon chemical engineering principles. Topics to include relevant legislation, in-plant minimization, treatment options and clean-up of contaminated sites. Case studies to be used for illustration.
prer: Third year Chemical and Biological Engineering.

name: Bioprocess Engineering II
desc: Bioprocess flowsheeting; production-scale fermenter design; product recovery and purification; bioseparations; chromatography; viral inactivation and removal; process validation.

name: Petroleum Refining Process Modelling and Simulation
desc: Petroleum feed stocks testing methods, pseudocomponents, and property methods. Design and simulation of separation and reaction systems. Steady state and dynamic simulation.

name: Energy Engineering
desc: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy.  Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources.  Environmental considerations of energy use. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 483, CHBE 583.

name: Green Engineering Principles and Applications for Process Industries
desc: Pollution prevention, cleaner production, green chemistry and engineering, industrial ecology, eco-industrial parks, and sustainable development; environmental impact assessment including life-cycle assessment, total cost analysis and environmental systems analysis; reduce/recycling/reuse of wastes and by-products.

name: Air Pollution Prevention and Control
desc: Impacts of air pollutants on health, visibility, smog formation, ozone depletion and global warming; air quality and emission standards; atmospheric dispersion of air pollutants; prevention and control technologies for particulates, SOx, NOx, VOCs, and CO2. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 485, CHBE 575.

name: Waste Management for Resource Recovery
desc: Physico-chemical, thermal, and biological methods for purification of solid waste and wastewater, and conversion to bioproducts/industrial products, energy and clean water.

name: Interfacial Phenomena
desc: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 357, CHBE 487, CHBE 587.

name: Carbon Capture, Conversion and Sequestration Technologies
desc: Examination of carbon capture technologies, and CO2 conversion and sequestration options.
